I took it for a spin with Clara 0.9 and everything seems to be working well.#2015-10-3113:17ryanbrushFor anyone else who is curious, clara-tools is an experimental UI to visualize rule logic and sessions. (It's what I used in the Strangeloop 2014 talk.) It's not as battle hardened as clara-rules itself but has drawn some interest.#2015-10-3123:31devn@ryanbrush: you rule. thanks!#2015-10-3123:32devn@ryanbrush: i guess I'm a little surprised there hasn't been more interest in it. Is the situation you have at Cerner one in which clinical staff help to write rules, or evaluate the results of the engine?#2015-10-3123:34devni've always thought that the explanation piece of a rules engine was one of the biggest driving factors behind choosing to use one on a project, so I guess I'm surprised there aren't fancier explanations or more interest in graphing#2015-11-0116:49ryanbrush@devn Our internal code has its own facilities for doing explanation that are specific to the domain, and unfortunately not something I can get into publicly. I do think clara-tools has a bright future, it just hasn't quite made it to being a big priority yet.#2015-11-0120:22devn@ryanbrush: Yeah, no surprise to me that there's some special sauce for domain-specific explanation. We're already there ourselves.#2015-11-0120:24devnI guess I'm wondering aloud a little bit about whether or not it's the concern of Clara to provide hooks into extending/providing the built-in explanation facilities.#2015-11-0120:26devnOr if it's more along the lines of: "clara gives you plenty of data to build your own explanations. use it."#2015-11-0120:27devnI think there's a delicate balance there, but I don't have a strong opinion at the moment.#2015-11-0123:30devnHeya @ryanbrush -- Is there a reason why there isn't a group-by-esque built-in accumulator?#2015-11-0123:52ryanbrush@devn No reason besides the fact that we just hadn't needed it yet. I think it makes sense and would be happy to include it if someone wants to take a stab at it.#2015-11-0123:54devn@ryanbrush: cool, was seeing max/sum/all/min/average and such, which made me wonder if group-by would somehow be problematic for automatic retraction#2015-11-0200:02ryanbrushRetraction presents some edge cases that aren't trivial but it's solvable in group-by similar to how we do it in other accumulators. Notice the all accumulator takes care to only remove what is retracted, for instance. Group-by is more complicated but I think a suitable approach would work.#2015-11-0200:03devnGotcha. Thanks.#2015-11-0200:04devn@ryanbrush: as long as I've got you here: something that's been on my mind that I think I remember reading something on the ML about is: How much can I rely on storing rules in a database, what about sessions? We've been toying with the idea of exposing some level of rule authorship at some point in the future, but either way, we are going to have differing sets of rules, some of which will be generated based on configuration data.#2015-11-0200:11devnOther random things on my mind: 1.) I've been reading about Jess and Drools, and they have a collect or collectBy IIRC. Since map can be written in terms of reduce, is it reasonable to say that Clara has collect by way of its accumulate? Is all basically collect? 2.) Do you have any suggested reading? I am occasionally flop-sweating a bit over whether or not I should reach for an accumulator, for instance. This is my first time working with a rules engine, and so I am still sort of in the hunting and pecking phase. Not entirely confident.#2015-11-0200:15ryanbrushI don't see any problem with storing rules or externally or generating them, and mixing those rules with hand-written rules. mk-session supports multiple inputs that can pull rules in from multiple heterogenous sources. Note that to load new rules you need to create a new session...you can't add or update rules to a session that has already been created.#2015-11-0200:16ryanbrushAs for collect and collectBy, it's been a while since I've used Drools but I believe they are basically just the all accumulator (or some other special accumulator case).#2015-11-0200:18ryanbrushAs for recommended reading, most of what I've found lately subscribes to the approach of rules-for-business-users rather than directed at engineers, so there's not much out there. I think designing rules just follows the best practices for designing code: take the simplest, most clear, and least surprising approach possible...and iterate to improve it.#2015-11-0200:18devn@ryanbrush: yeah, we're pulling from multiple sources right now. I guess the big question was: as of right now, do you foresee any future compatibility issues with storing the value of a defrule. Like, if 1.0 changed to having :lhs {:different [] :stuff []}#2015-11-0200:20ryanbrushNo, I think the schema for the defrule and defquery value is pretty much locked down.#2015-11-0200:21ryanbrushAny changes there would be non-breaking (like we might add properties for activation groups or things like that). But that basic structure of a rule is pretty fundamental to the system, so I don't see it changing.#2015-11-0200:21devn@ryanbrush: good common sense advice. i would hope we're meeting our obligation to keep things clean, but in some cases I question whether I'm taking the "easy" route over the "simple" route, simply because I don't know what I don't know.#2015-11-0200:21ryanbrush@devn Haha, I feel that way every day I wrote code!#2015-11-0200:22devnheh, yeah, kind of a universal problem simple_smile#2015-11-0200:22devnbtw @ryanbrush -- i dropped you a PM#2015-11-0200:23ryanbrush@devn By the way, what do you think about changing the URL for this group to http://www.clara-rules.org/ ? It's a bit cleaner and more accessible front door to Clara than the GitHub page.#2015-11-0200:23devnOf course!#2015-11-0200:23devnThis is really your channel. simple_smile#2015-11-1321:04noprompt@ryanbrush: this appears to be invalid is there a way to express this?:#2015-11-1321:04noprompt
[?it <- accumulator
   [:or
    [X1 (= ?v x)]
    [X2 (= ?v x)]
    [X3 (= ?v x)]]]
#2015-11-1321:07nopromptthe error we receive 
{:type java.lang.IllegalArgumentException
   :message "Only one argument can be passed to a condition."
   :at [clara.rules.dsl$construct_condition invoke "dsl.clj" 53]}
#2015-11-1321:08nopromptmaybe it's worth a PR but i think it'd be helpful to use ex-info here providing the offending form. we had to do a bit of binary chop to find the problem.#2015-11-1321:15ryanbrush@noprompt: Yeah, that error message is pretty bad; we need to share something better there. As for the problem itself, accumulators can only accumulate over simple fact-based expressions rather than everything in a complex expression. So rather than having the [:or ] "inside" the accumulator, you'd need to accumulate over each of X1, X2, and X3 independently.#2015-11-1321:20ryanbrushThere might be other ways to break down the problem depending on what you're trying to accomplish. For instance, if X1, X2, and X3 are children of a super type, you can match on the super type. Clara just uses Clojure's type system by default, which also works with Java's type hierarchy and obeys clojure.core/derive if you want to use that to logically derive new types.#2015-11-1321:25noprompthere's what we came up with:#2015-11-1321:25noprompt
[?it <-
 [:or
  [?x1 <- accumulator :from
   [X1 (= ?v x)]]

  [?x2 <- accumulator :from
   [X2 (= ?v x)]]

  [?x3 <- accumulator :from
   [X3 (= ?v x)]]]]
#2015-11-1321:26noprompt@ryanbrush: you mentioned derive can you explain how that would work? afaik it only works with namespaced keywords.#2015-11-1321:30ryanbrushSure. Some users are just using Clojure maps as their fact types and tagging type metadata to them in the form of namespaced keywords, where derive will work.#2015-11-1321:31ryanbrushI think the child in derive can also be an arbitrary record type...it's the parent that needs to be a namespaced keyword. This might be an abuse of the intent of derive, though.#2015-11-1321:32ryanbrushAs for the model you came up with: I'm actually not sure that will work...or at least I don't have a test covering binding to the result of an :or expression and that isn't something we've done in production.#2015-11-1321:33nopromptright. we're using records and unfortunately that does not work with derive (e.g. (derive Square Shape)).#2015-11-1321:33ryanbrushAnother approach would be to break up the accumulators into separate rules, each of which insert some "GroupOfX" type that can be joined to in another rule that combines them all.#2015-11-1321:34nopromptoh i see what you're saying wrt derive.#2015-11-1321:34nopromptre: your uncertainty. well we'll kick the tires for you and let you know if it does work. üòÑ#2015-11-1321:38ryanbrushI know the above approach will work.#2015-11-1321:38nopromptokay, we'll do that if this turns up dry.#2015-11-1321:41ryanbrushI'm almost certain that you won't be able to bind the result of an ":or", so I think the post above is your best bet. The Rete algorithm splits up the or's into separate rule invocations, and there aren't well-defined semantics for binding the result of other boolean operators in general. But merging the results of separate accumulators will work and is something we do frequently.#2015-11-1321:43ryanbrushBy the way, please do report bad or misleading error messages, here or on the github project. I think this is a weak point in Clara right now, especially for new users, so we want to make that better.#2015-11-1322:35noprompt@ryanbrush: re: error messages, we're investing in clara so hopefully you can expect more than just an experience report. simple_smile#2015-11-1322:36nopromptwe focus a lot on producing good error messages at work and use ex-info to not only provide a description but, where possible, provide a prescription to solve the problem.#2015-11-1322:50ryanbrushSounds great! And I definitely agree with the idea of good, prescriptive error messages. This can be challenging when dealing with the kind of deep macros, like what Clara does when building the Rete network, but is an important step forward.#2015-11-1322:53ryanbrushBy the way, I'm planning on moving Clara to its own GitHub project organization and add at least one more committer soon, a colleague who has made some nice pull requests. It shouldn't be too disruptive, but I'll be sure to share here when that happens.#2015-11-1417:05ryanbrushI had some fun playing with Instaparse and Clara recently, so I blogged about it: http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/#2015-11-1519:17devnWhat do y'all think about meeting up on Monday night after dinner?#2015-11-1519:17devn@ryanbrush: very cool#2015-11-1611:40thomas@ryanbrush: read your blog post. really good. thank you.#2015-11-1614:18ryanbrush@thomas Thanks! It was a lot of fun to write. I appreciate the kind words!#2015-11-2413:33raggehello#2015-11-2413:34ragge@ryanbrush: are there any guidelines/limits for the number of facts?#2015-11-2414:40ryanbrush@ragge Not really, besides the limits of the JVM. We frequently have 100,000+ facts in our sessions, and I've tested into the millions (although for a limited scenario). Most of the work is done in Clojure group-by and reducer functions, which scale well.#2015-11-2414:43ryanbrush@ragge The only thing to keep in mind is doing a non-equality cartesian join over lots of facts. Rule constraints that join on equals use hash-based joins, which scale well. This constraint applies pretty commonly to rule engines.#2015-11-2416:21ragge@ryanbrush: thanks for your reply, will definitely give it a go for our use case (which is currently around 50k facts)#2015-11-2416:52ryanbrush@ragge Sounds good. Clara's performance should at least be competitive with other JVM-based rule engines and is working well with a large number of facts for us. If you do run into a workload that isn't doing well, please let me know.#2015-11-2417:23Al Bakeris there a performance measurement of Clara?#2015-11-2417:24Al Bakeror guidelines, like how much memory you should budget for number of facts/rules?#2015-11-2421:15ryanbrush@albaker I use Criterium (https://github.com/hugoduncan/criterium) against a function that loads and exercises our Clara rulesets to measure performance. I did post the program I wrote some time ago to benchmark Clara itself at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-benchmark, but generally its easier just to write your own test function and use Criterium to measure.#2015-11-2421:18ryanbrush@albaker Some considerations for a memory budget: each condition on a rule will compile into its own function, and identical conditions between rules are reused, reducing the overall size. The facts are mostly just stored in Clojure sequences, or maps grouped by fact type. In general, the memory footprint will be dominated by the size of the facts you have.#2015-11-2421:20ryanbrushI think the best way to think of it as you're just writing Clojure functions and creating Clojure structures. Clara will wire things together, but the footprint is generally a function of the size of your data.#2015-11-2423:28Al BakerCool, thanks! #2015-11-2516:11ryanbrushFYI, I just pushed Clara 0.9.1 to Clojars. It's a fix release for a specific scenario, but worth the upgrade. https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/dWLm9veo-dA#2015-11-3017:55devn@ryanbrush: Is it possible to use [:or [?foo <- my/accumulator [X (= a 1)]] [?bar <- my/accumulator [Y (= b 2)]]]#2015-11-3018:04devn@ryanbrush: here's a sketch of what we imagine: 
(defrule thing-a
  [?foo <- [:or
            [my/accumulator [Foo (= a 1)]]
            [:not [Foo (= a 1)]]]]
  =>
  (when-not (nil? ?foo)
    (insert! (map->Bar ?foo))))
#2015-11-3018:04devnWe want Foo to be optional, but when it exists, we'd like to accumulate over matching Foo facts.#2015-11-3018:06ryanbrushThe best way to solve this problem is to have my/accumulator provide a default value. That way if there are no Foo records, the default value will be returned from the accumulator and propagate down.#2015-11-3018:07ryanbrushFor instance, the provided sum accumulator will return a sum of zero if there are no items to sum.#2015-11-3018:07devnFunnily enough, we talked about that a bit.#2015-11-3018:09ryanbrushAs a side note, you can't quite think of [:or]'s in rules quite like you'd think of or expressions in Clojure. [:or ..] doesn't "return" a value that can be bound to. (In fact, in the Rete algorithm [:or] actually causes two separate rules to be generated for each branch.)#2015-11-3018:11devn@ryanbrush: thanks!#2015-11-3018:15ryanbrush@devn By the way, when fiddling with this I noticed Clara isn't reporting an error if a user attempts to bind a variable in an unsupported location. This is a bug, so I logged it here https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/144#2015-11-3019:29devn@ryanbrush: that is good to know, indeed#2015-11-3019:30devn@ryanbrush: trying to be respectful of your time here, but another question: with accumulators, can I make a function which produces an accumulator and use that in the LHS?#2015-11-3019:32devnlike 
[Bar (= ?x x)]
[?foo <- (make-accumulator ?x) :from [Foo (= ?y y]]
#2015-11-3019:32devnthis basically comes down to wanting to tweak the initial value to the accumulator#2015-11-3019:37ryanbrush@devn Definitely! The accumulators in clara.rules.accumulators are all just functions that return accumulators and should be a good reference. They use constants for the initial value but you can easily pass it as a param.#2015-11-3019:37devnasking because all of the examples i've seen are def'd and only took the field to compare on#2015-11-3019:38devncool, guess I could have tried it, but didn't know calling a function in place of a def'd accumulator had any edges i needed to be aware of#2015-11-3019:38ryanbrushAny function that returns an accumulator will work. The provided ones just happen to use fields.#2015-11-3019:47devn@ryanbrush: a couple other small bits - Any reason that things like min/max couldn't optionally take a function to coerce the value of a field to be comparable? For instance, dates. - Using reduce-to-accum seems to imply :supports-retract given that min, max etc. call comparison-based, which in turn calls reduce-to-accum with an initial value of nil. Is that true? I remember reading the pull request a couple of times, but are there any good rules of thumb to use when building accumulators to know that you've supported retraction? Now that I write that out, my other question is: When retract is mentioned, is it talking about automatic retraction, explicit retraction, or both?#2015-11-3019:55ryanbrushAs long as your accumulator has a retract-fn, it supports retraction. reduce-to-accum is a convenience function that makes it easier to turn general reduce functions into accumulators by (by default) creating a retract-fn that removes the retracted item from the accumulator and re-runs the reduce. In some cases you can create more efficient retract-fn implementations. See, for instance, sum...to retract a value from a sum you can just subtract the value, which is of course more efficient than re-running the entire sum with the value removed.#2015-11-3019:55ryanbrushThis applies to both automatic and explicit retraction.#2015-11-3019:57ryanbrushReally the retract-fn is just to "undo" the presence of an item in the accumulated value, like subtraction undoes the value in a sum. the reduce-to-accum just offers a "brute force" way to do this for all reduce functions by re-running them. In some very performance-sensitive cases where you don't care about retraction you can skip supporting it, but I wouldn't do so unless you have a special need.#2015-11-3019:59ryanbrushFWIW, Clara accumulators work pretty much exactly like the same concept in Jess and Drools. You just write the functions in Clojure. üòâ#2015-11-3020:00ryanbrush(Also, I need to drop offline for a bit but will be back on later today.)#2015-11-3020:09devn@ryanbrush: that's a lovely explanation, thank you!#2015-11-3020:09devn@logbot#2015-11-3020:10devn(mentioned the @logbot so there's actually a log of some of this stuff, it scans every 2 hours, so it should join shortly.)#2015-12-0104:41ryanbrushWorking on some updates that should make clara-tools more useful. (I think at least @devn will be interested in this.) Details here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/w1GDmxLE_Vo#2015-12-0117:18devn@ryanbrush: That's awesome!#2015-12-0117:23devn@ryanbrush: It would be neat to be able to "step" through a session. I'm not really sure how doable that would be, or if it'd be crazy for large sets of facts, but since you mentioned Bret Victor -- I imagined the Braid example. Being able to step through time and "see" rules fire would be cool.#2015-12-0117:26devnI'm imagining something like the current show-session tool, but with some sort of temporally inspectable aspect to it.#2015-12-0117:27devnWhether that's a slider, or a split pane that shows what matches and when.#2015-12-0117:27devnAnyway, looking forward to giving it a look later today or tomorrow. Thanks for all of the awesome work!#2015-12-0118:36ryanbrush@devn Interesting idea. Should be doable by plugging into listeners for state changes. Might be something to experiment with.#2015-12-0202:06devn@ryanbrush: trying to check out clara-tools 0.1.2-SNAPSHOT from lein checkouts, but:

   Could not locate org/httpkit/server__init.class or
   org/httpkit/server.clj on classpath.

I'll be able to take a look and merge tomorrow.#2015-12-0202:38devn@ryanbrush: :thumbsup:#2015-12-1000:02devn@ryanbrush: potentially stupid question -- but what's the best way to try out changes to clara-tools on the dev branch in my project?#2015-12-1000:03devni was trying to use lein checkouts, but it is yelling at me for not having cljsbuild/compiler__init.class or cljsbuild/compiler.clj on the classpath#2015-12-1000:10ryanbrush@devn I just run lein install in the clara-tools 0.2-Dev branch and point my consuming project at the snapshot version.#2015-12-1000:13devn@ryanbrush: well, that worked. thanks. i think that's what i wound up doing last time i had it working.#2015-12-1000:13devnthis is looking really great!#2015-12-1000:14devnlooks like you're tinkering with the logic graph at the moment, or im calling it wrong, not sure which simple_smile#2015-12-1000:15ryanbrush@devn cool! It's still really rough, and the logic graph definitely needs work. I'm going to start using it against some real data soon so it should improve.#2015-12-1000:15devnim getting a bunch of "No reader function for tag object" from readTagged(LispReader.java)#2015-12-1000:16ryanbrush@devn I am also a terrible web developer who is learning Reagent as I go. ;)#2015-12-1000:16ryanbrushHmm, haven't sent that one.#2015-12-1000:16ryanbrushFeel free to log issues if you have something reproducible#2015-12-1000:18devn@ryanbrush: looks like i'm getting it for queries that return nothing and when clicking on facts that aren't actually within the session?#2015-12-1000:19devnjust some first blush debugging, not sure if that's the case, just guessing#2015-12-1000:21devnI'm probably not calling it the way you'd expect... I just call (watch/browse!) after all rules have fired#2015-12-1000:22devn
(-> (watch/mk-watched-session "FOO" rules :cache false)
    (insert-all facts)
    (fire-rules))

(watch/browse!)
#2015-12-1010:42thomasHi, just a quick question... are rules written in Clara Clojure functions? just a thought that crossed my mind.#2015-12-1101:44ryanbrush@thomas Sort of. To elaborate a bit: The rules are forms, and the rule constraints and actions are just Clojure expressions. All of these get compiled down into Clojure functions in the end, which are executed as part of a Rete-style rule network. I have no idea if that's what you're looking for or not. üòâ#2015-12-1101:46ryanbrush@devn Not sure why that use wouldn't work. Facts that aren't in the session should be seen in the UI. I almost certainly have a bug in there somewhere. clara-tools will harden over the next few weeks but the current draft is very much use at your own risk (although bug reports and patches are of course welcome.)#2015-12-1101:47ryanbrushBy the way: Clara 0.9.2 is out: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/kuy-XPUKzLU. It fixes an ugly edge case of truth maintenance and hopefully does a better job reporting errors in a number of scenarios.#2015-12-1108:48thomas@ryanbrush: reason for me asking is that I was wondering if Clara could be combined with Onyx and make it some sort of Rule/Event processing engine.#2015-12-1115:06ryanbrush@thomas I don't know much about Onyx, but I'm sure you could invoke Clara rules and queries from with in a function running within Onyx. The rule engine working memory would be local to that node, which in many cases is fine.#2015-12-1115:08ryanbrush@thomas Ultimately I'd like to have an implementation of Clara's working memory that is distributed across a processing cluster, so you could just write rules to deal with input and emit outcomes. This is significantly more challenging. I had an experimental extension of Clara where the memory was distributed across a Storm cluster, but this effort was dropped due to other needs. The big challenge is fault tolerance of a distributed working memory. If a node becomes unavailable, how do we recover its part of the Rete network? I've been toying with some solutions to this by mapping Clara's working memory onto existing fault tolerant processing patterns but this is little more than an idea right now.#2015-12-1115:08thomas@ryanbrush: ok thank you, this is something I would like to look into at some stage#2015-12-1115:09thomasie. read one day#2015-12-1115:12ryanbrush@thomas Yes, me too!#2015-12-1115:13ryanbrush@thomas Poking around Onyx a bit I think you could use Clara as a stateful aggregator of previously grouped data pretty easily, using Onyx's state management/windowing capabilities. So you could have a stream of data, inserting updates into a Clara working memory, and computing results like that. Could be useful to solve a number of problems.#2015-12-1115:14thomasI was wondering if something like that could be done... would be very cool.#2015-12-1115:18ryanbrush@thomas Yeah, I haven't used Onyx but it seems doable from what I can see.#2015-12-1402:05devn@ryanbrush: so, i suspect this might be considered out of scope for clara, but all the same: any thoughts on rule persistence/versioning? for instance, i might receive rules over the wire.#2015-12-1402:05devnif this is the case, I may need to for instance, make a function registry so functions within the LHS or RHS are resolvable when I read them in#2015-12-1402:07devnis this something you or anyone else following along has dealt with? what'd you choose as a method of versioning and mapping rule logic?#2015-12-1415:14ryanbrush@devn We just keep rules in source control and it let it handle versioning. I'd imagine a variety of content management systems would be up to the task. As for a function registry, I just use fully-qualified function names from a library, and just have rules depend on a specific library version to use those functions. So not so much as a "function registry" as just using a versioned dependency JAR and qualified function names.#2015-12-1415:15ryanbrush@devn Of course, a more sophisticated solution could be built, but I've found just using source control and dependency management sufficient for our needs. And, as you know, Clara rules are just data structures that could be stored wherever convenient.#2015-12-1420:37xandrewsany recommended reading on the subject of rules systems design?#2015-12-1422:43devn@xandrews: I'm going old school in my reading list#2015-12-1422:44devnI picked up Expert Systems - Design and Development by John Durkin#2015-12-1422:44devnRule-based programming with OPS5, Programming Expert Systems in OPS5#2015-12-1422:45devnAs someone who's still quite the newb, I've been learning from the simpler systems of the past like CLIPS and OPS5#2015-12-1422:48devnThere's another much more official looking book that I have not picked up#2015-12-1422:51devnAlso: http://reports-archive.adm.cs.cmu.edu/anon/1995/CMU-CS-95-113.pdf#2015-12-1422:51devnand https://www.amazon.com/Expert-Systems-Principles-Programming-Edition/dp/0534384471#2015-12-1500:44devn@ryanbrush: Is there any way to reference elements of the rule itself, within the rule?#2015-12-1500:45devn@ryanbrush: for instance, it would be cool if I could bind $?name $?docstring or $?lhs#2015-12-1500:46devnSo I could push forward some additional metadata about the rule which inserted a fact, for instance#2015-12-1501:11ryanbrush@devn It's not in the public API, but the clara.rules.engine/rule-context dynamic var is populated when a rule is firing. So you could do something like (get-in clara.rules.engine/rule-context [:node :production]) , which would have :name and :doc properties.#2015-12-1501:11devn@ryanbrush: ah perfect#2015-12-1501:12ryanbrush@devn It would be simple to add a (current-rule) function that just returns that to the public namespace as well. I can see how it would be useful.#2015-12-1501:12devnDo defrules and queries allow meta on them when defining them?#2015-12-1501:13devnlike (defrule ^{:cool true} "foo" ... => ...)#2015-12-1501:13devnerr forgot the name there#2015-12-1501:13devnbut you catch my drift#2015-12-1501:15ryanbrushIt doesn't use meta (but that would be add-able). This might be a good case for rule properties. You could do (defrule my-rule {:cool true} "doc here" ... => ...) This is how rule salience is set but you can put arbitrary properties there.#2015-12-1501:15ryanbrushSee the salience example for the structure: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/#2015-12-1501:15devnah, just discovered that while reading the source#2015-12-1501:15devnplease excuse my laziness#2015-12-1501:15ryanbrushNo worries.#2015-12-1501:16devnI ran into a situation with salience and accumulators. I don't have a simple repro as it was a month ago or so now#2015-12-1501:18devnit was a custom accumulator, so probably a good chance it was my fault#2015-12-1501:18devnbut i was curious if you were generally aware of any problem that might exist when accumulating and using salience#2015-12-1501:19ryanbrush@devn I'm not aware of any issues with salience and accumulators, although we've used both pretty extensively. If you are able to reproduce something we'd definitely want to track it down.#2015-12-2504:03devnIs it possible to do something like this in Clara? Cheese( $chedddar : name == "cheddar" ) I find myself doing a lot of: 
[Foo (= ?x x) (= x "bar")]
Am I missing something, or is there a way to do both binding and equality in one go?#2015-12-2504:05devnIn general, I think a blurb about this would be a good documentation addition. [Foo (= 2 ?bar bar)] is different from [Foo (= ?bar bar 2)]#2015-12-2504:05devnAnd, the wiki documentation still references == in some places.#2015-12-2504:06devn./cc @ryanbrush -- also, happy holidays simple_smile#2016-12-2919:10ryanbrush@devn Not a way to do that directly today, but it seems like a worthwhile change. Feel free to log something and I'll take a closer look when I get back from holiday travels.#2016-12-3022:53devn@ryanbrush: question for you -- we have rules which are generated dynamically, and we were noticing that our runs with caching turned on were missing the cache. Turns out it was due to ordering.#2016-12-3022:54devnWhat do you think about using sets to check for cache hits?#2016-12-3023:01devnHonestly, this might be an instance of "not clara's responsibility" -- I think we're going to wind up managing our own cache using an LRU or TTL cache#2016-12-3023:02devnjust curious what you thought -- took a bit of tinkering to figure it out#2016-12-3023:02devnand I guess I don't see why it couldn't be a set#2016-12-3023:02devnor coerced into one#2016-12-3023:02devnthe generated source rules, i mean#2016-12-3023:05ryanbrush@devn I'm open to the idea of using a set to improve cache hits. Come to think of it, if the code that generates rules produces a set (rather than a list) that is passed to mk-session, then that might actually trigger a cache hit by itself. We should be able to think of mk-session as a memoized function. If passing a set of rules into mk-session doesn't hit the cache then we could probably change that.#2016-12-3023:06devnyes, making it a set makes it a cache hit#2016-12-3023:06ryanbrush@devn However, managing your own cache might be a better idea, anyway, since putting all rules into a set (or doing a deep comparison in a sequence) could get expensive for a lot of rules. You could probably do something more efficient in user code if you know that things changed or didn't.#2016-12-3023:08devni guess my thinking was that it was a little subtle why at first. i opened up yourkit to figure out what was slow, found myself in mk-session, beta and alpha creation, yadda yadda, noticed a lot of DynamicClassLoader business, saw a bunch of eval's which i believe are the generate LHS and RHS fns#2016-12-3023:09devnfinally noticed we were just getting cache misses, diff'd the generated rules, noticed the order issue, yadda yadda#2016-12-3023:10devni couldn't really think of a good reason why clara couldn't just make the decision to take whatever collection is passed to mk-session and make it a set, or if someone really wanted duplicates, (sort-by hash [...]) or something#2016-12-3023:12ryanbrushYeah, that's fair. Just want to understand any performance implications there might be but I think we can do that.#2016-12-3023:13devnfor really large numbers of rules, for instance?#2016-12-3023:19devn@ryanbrush: One More Thing‚Ñ¢ -- Do you have any thoughts on analyzing/visualizing the time-complexity of build-network provided a set of rules?#2016-12-3023:21devnGeneral question is: How much does the design of the rules being added to a session effect the performance of build-network? For instance, a really shallow logic graph vs one with a lot of depth.#2016-12-3023:24devnWondering aloud if there's any potentially actionable information about the complexity of the network that would be useful to someone building an expert system.#2016-12-3023:24devn"your logic graph is really shallow, which means build-network is going to be slower"#2016-12-3023:29ryanbrush@devn good question, but probably not one that I can answer on my mobile right now. ;) I'll post something more thoughtful when I get the chance.#2016-12-3023:31devn@ryanbrush: ha, no worries! @enn and I were working together today and I popped open Slack and realized I asked you a question about Clara at 10PM on Christmas Eve. You owe me nothing, and I'm very grateful for all of your help.#2016-01-1101:23datajohnnyhello#2016-01-1101:23datajohnnyhow can I make this just return the string to the caller? https://gist.github.com/datajohnny/a927c54a56f00035676e#2016-01-1112:53jthomson@datajohnny: my understanding is that the RHS of a clara rule should be side-effecting. Sometimes, the side effect will be updating the Clara session itself, via insert! and retract!. A common pattern for what you are trying to do would be to insert! a new fact on the RHS of your rule, then query the session for those facts after fire-rules.#2016-01-1112:54jthomsonyou could follow one of the examples in the clara-examples project#2016-01-1112:54jthomsonhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/shopping.clj#2016-01-1315:02datajohnnyhello, I been fiddling around and im stuck at this right now: https://gist.github.com/datajohnny/3b82660ba27fd80f448c#2016-01-1315:14ragge(insert! (->Person)))#2016-01-1315:14raggeyou're calling the positional constructor for Person#2016-01-1315:14raggeit requires two arguments, name and age#2016-01-1315:14raggeyou're only giving one#2016-01-1315:14raggehttps://gist.github.com/datajohnny/3b82660ba27fd80f448c#file-gistfile1-txt-L29#2016-01-1315:14raggeCaused by: clojure.lang.ArityException: Wrong number of args (0) passed to: core/eval6101/->Person--6116#2016-01-1315:15datajohnny@ragge: what I want is to add that record when the rule is true#2016-01-1315:16datajohnnyI thought I was accomplishing that in that manner#2016-01-1315:16datajohnnydo I need to pass the params in?#2016-01-1315:17datajohnnyanother thing is that for some reason age the (>= 21 age) is not working if I set the age on the session to 21#2016-01-1316:00ryanbrush@datajohnny That test rule matches a person when the age is >= 21, so it is only true if such a person has already been inserted. The right-hand side of the rule is just a Clojure s-expression that can insert additional facts derived from what matched. So typically you would insert the person (as that example does), match on age >=21, and insert a new fact if that's the case (like a PersonIsAdult fact).#2016-01-1316:01ryanbrush@datajohnny: If you want to get an idea of general usage patterns, I'd check out the examples at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-examples/tree/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples#2016-01-1316:04datajohnny@ryanbrush: thanks#2016-01-1316:06ryanbrush@datajohnny: You bet!#2016-01-1316:49datajohnny@ryanbrush: can the rules work with just maps instead of records, I am trying to build kinda like the same thing you had in your latest blog post but instead of grammar I am getting a json payload#2016-01-1316:56ryanbrush@datajohnny: It can use records. You'll need to provide a function that returns a "type" for map you use, which will match the type of the rule. See the fact-type-fn at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/#fact-expressions. There's also a unit test that shows some usage of it at https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1977. The test generates rules in place but you can see a provided fact-type-fn that just reads a field from a record in action.#2016-01-2119:15pguillebertHello#2016-01-2119:16pguillebertI‚Äôm new to clara-rules and trying to model a rule with a ‚Äúmust not‚Äù condition#2016-01-2119:16pguillebertlike ‚Äúdo not trigger if there is this object present"#2016-01-2119:16pguillebertis it doable ?#2016-01-2121:17devn@pguillebert: sure, totally doable.#2016-01-2121:24devn@pguillebert: 
(defrecord Foo [a])
(defrecord Bar [b])
(defrecord Baz [b])

(defrule foo
  [:not [Foo]]
  [Bar (= ?b b 3)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Baz ?b)))

(defquery q:baz []
  [?baz <- Baz])

(-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
    (insert-all [;; (->Foo 1)
                  (->Bar 3)])
    (fire-rules)
    (query q:baz))

;; => ({:?baz #crede.rules.examples.Baz{:b 3}})
#2016-01-2121:25devnWith the same setup, but including a Foo: 
(-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
    (insert-all [(->Foo 1)
                 (->Bar 3)])
    (fire-rules)
    (query q:baz))

;; => ()
#2016-01-2121:27devnThere is also [:exists [Foo]], but I am not sure I understand the nuance there, though:#2016-01-2121:27pguillebertok, with :not#2016-01-2121:28devn
(defrule foo
  [:exists [Foo]]
  [Bar (= ?b b 3)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Baz ?b)))

(defquery q:baz []
  [?baz <- Baz])

(-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
    (insert-all [(->Foo 1)
                 (->Bar 3)])
    (fire-rules)
    (query q:baz))

;; => ({:?baz #crede.rules.examples.Baz{:b 3}})
#2016-01-2121:28pguillebertI just have to trust the magic#2016-01-2121:28devn@pguillebert: it's definitely taken me some getting used to#2016-01-2121:29devnit's happened more than once now where we wrote some rules, had some initial facts, and then a week or two later realize: "oh, this could be simplified a whole lot"#2016-01-2121:29devnor "hmm, this record type is too general, we should fan out to multiple types of records in this rule"#2016-01-2121:40pguillebertok thanks#2016-01-2121:40devn@pguillebert: it really helps to keep an up-to-date graph of the logic, how rules are connected#2016-01-2121:41pguillebertthis is really a different way of expressing what I want#2016-01-2121:41pguillebertyeah ok#2016-01-2121:42devn@ryanbrush: do you have any thoughts on the following: 
(defn group
  "Return a generic grouping accumulator. It behaves like
  clojure.core/group-by with the exception of specifying the grouping
  step.

  Parameters:

  value-fn - unary function which returns the grouping key.
  grouping-fn - binary function which recieves the current key
    value the current reduce value and returns a new key value.
  combine-fn - function for clara.rules/accumulator :combine-fn.
  convert-return-fn - function for clara.rules/accumulator :convert-return-fn."
  [{:keys [value-fn grouping-fn combine-fn convert-return-fn]
    :or {value-fn identity
         combine-fn merge
         convert-return-fn identity}}]
  {:pre [(ifn? grouping-fn)]}
  (clara.acc/accum
   {:initial-value {}
    :reduce-fn
    (fn [m x]
      (let [v (value-fn x)]
        (update m v grouping-fn x)))
    :combine-fn combine-fn
    :retract-fn #(throw (RuntimeException. "group retract-fn triggered"))
    :convert-return-fn convert-return-fn}))

(defn group-by
  "Return an accumulator which behaves like clojure.core/group-by."
  [f]
  (group
   {:value-fn f
    :grouping-fn (fnil conj [])
    :combine-fn (fn [a b]
                  (merge-with (comp vec into) a b))}))
#2016-01-2121:42devnWhat should retract-fn be here? /me puzzles#2016-01-2121:44devnperhaps I should be using reduce-to-accum here instead#2016-01-2122:00devn
(defn group-by
  [f]
  (clara.acc/reduce-to-accum
   (fn [m x]
     (let [v (f x)]
       (update m v (fnil conj []) x)))
   {}
   identity
   (fn [a b]
     (merge-with (comp vec into) a b))))
#2016-01-2122:06ryanbrush@devn retract-fn should "undo" the effect of adding an element to the accumulated result. In this case, I think it's the opposite of a group-by step for a single value...which presumably would be finding that value in its underlying group and removing it. Probably not trivial to implement but seems doable.#2016-01-2122:07devn@ryanbrush: the behavior of group-by with reduce-to-accum seems to be doing what i'm looking for by default. am i crazy?#2016-01-2122:09devn
(defrule foo
  [?foo <- (my-group-by :a)
   :from [Foo]]
  [Bar (= ?b b 3)]
  [:test (do (println ?foo)
             ?foo)]
  =>
  (println ?foo)
  (insert! (->Baz ?foo)))

(defquery q:baz []
  [?Qux <- Baz])

(let [f (->Foo 3)]
  (-> (mk-session [foo q:baz])
      (insert-all [(->Foo 1)
                   (->Foo 1)
                   (->Foo 2)
                   f
                   (->Bar 3)])
      (retract f)
      (fire-rules)
      (query q:baz)))
#2016-01-2122:09devnprints: 
{1 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1} #myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1}], 2 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 2}], 3 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 3}]}
{1 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1} #myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1}], 2 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 2}]}
{1 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1} #myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 1}], 2 [#myproject.rules.examples.Foo{:a 2}]}
#2016-01-2122:10ryanbrush@devn, no that makes sense. It's probably not the most efficient implementation if you have lots of retracts since it will redo the entire computation. The retract optimization could do something more efficient by removing a single value rather than re-reducing.#2016-01-2122:10devnahhh, i see what you're getting at#2016-01-2122:10devnthe number of retracts here will be really small, so no worries#2016-01-2122:11ryanbrushYeah, I wouldn't worry about it unless you have lots of retracts and data, and you can always optimize it later without changing visible behavior.#2016-01-2122:11ryanbrushCool use of accumulator, by the way.#2016-01-2122:12devnI think we talked about this awhile back, but any interest in pulling something like this into clara's accumulators?#2016-01-2122:12devnI suppose you'd be looking for the more efficient impl that undoes a single step#2016-01-2122:13ryanbrushI'd bring that one in if you want to put together a pull req and a simple test. #2016-01-2122:13devnand honestly, I'm not sure if I'll spend the time there... really, this group-by is just a tad more complicated#2016-01-2122:13devnit's nice to group-by over a set of facts, and then call a function on the resulting set to bind to ?x#2016-01-2122:13devnlike you might group by date, and then find the minimum date#2016-01-2122:13devnand bind that#2016-01-2122:15ryanbrushInteresting. It's not a flow we've used directly but makes sense to me. I might actually think about doing so in our own rules.#2016-01-2122:17devn@ryanbrush: either way i'll send a PR your way with a simple test and we can talk more there#2016-01-2122:17devnthanks!#2016-01-2122:18ryanbrush@devn Sounds good!#2016-01-2122:27pguillebertmmmh. apparently this is not working :#2016-01-2122:27pguillebert [:not [:test (and (= ?ndate ?sdate) (= ?ndes ?sdes))]]#2016-01-2122:28pguillebertcan I negate tests on variables ?#2016-01-2122:40pguillebertsame test applied in a when in the RHS does what I want (prevent rule firing based on :test)#2016-01-2122:40pguillebertI mean, a when-not#2016-01-2122:40pguillebertis this a limitation or am I missing something ?#2016-01-2123:02devn@ryanbrush: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/pull/164/files#2016-01-2123:03devn@pguillebert: does it work if you just (not (and ...)) in a [:test ...] without the wrapping [:not ...]?#2016-01-2123:09pguillebertI just killed my emacs simple_smile#2016-01-2123:09pguillebertI didn‚Äôt try, will test tomorrow#2016-01-2123:31devn@pguillebert: my guess is you had an infinite loop#2016-01-2123:31devn@pguillebert: feel free to gist code in here if you'd like another set of eyes#2016-01-2220:07ryanbrush@pguillebert: Ugh, I think you came across a bug here. facts#2016-01-2304:13devnso we might have some basic idea of what IsClean means, but we'll enrich that fact with :cleanliness-threshold :low based on the information from the external configuration DB#2016-01-2304:15devnnot sure if that's what you're looking for or not...#2016-01-2304:16devnobviously we've punted on guaranteeing we aren't affected by upstream schema changes for the moment#2016-01-2304:22devni'd like to talk about the configuration problem in general. we're going to need to have versioned rules per customer, likely with some kind of function registry, which may be as stupid as associating a set of versioned rules with a pointer to a git SHA where a particular file at that SHA is the mapping of our application's private functions, to the "public" functions that rules authors indirectly tap into when building rules#2016-01-2304:24devnim also curious about persisting durable sessions. that would be interesting for auditing, capturing configuration at a There are a couple more improvements I wanted to include, but they can be delayed if necessary. 0.10 in its current form is a big enough step forward that it makes sense to get out there.#2016-02-0117:47pguillebertok great#2016-02-0515:03ryanbrushAaaand Clara 0.10.0 is up on Clojars! A couple small features, a number of bug fixes, and significantly improved performance for some workloads. Release notes here: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0100#2016-02-1820:41devnHeya @ryanbrush -- dumb question for you#2016-02-1820:42devnSay I create a session, and insert 3 (->Temperature 100 "ABC") facts, and then retract (->Temperature 100 "ABC") once on that session#2016-02-1820:43devnShould there be 0 (->Temperature 100 "ABC") facts?#2016-02-1820:59wparkerAre these top-level insert calls i.e. (clara.rules/insert session fact) or logical insertions and retractions? @devn#2016-02-1820:59devntop-level#2016-02-1821:00wparkerA quick trial suggests that top-level retracts one at a time#2016-02-1821:00wparkerLogical retractions of equal facts from the same production currently have a truth maintenance bug; see https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/171#2016-02-1821:00devn
session (-> (mk-session [grouping-query
                                 grouping-convert-query])
                    (insert-all [(->Temperature 30 "MCI")
                                 (->Temperature 10 "MCI")
                                 (->Temperature 80 "MCI")
                                 (->Temperature 80 "MCI")]))

        retracted-session (-> session
                              (retract (->Temperature 80 "MCI")
                                       (->Temperature 80 "MCI")))
#2016-02-1821:01devn@wparker: oof, good catch.#2016-02-1821:01devn@wparker: I guess my question is, after running the same trial myself is: should it?#2016-02-1821:02wparkerI‚Äôd expect that to have temperatures of 30 and 10#2016-02-1821:02wparkerDoes it not?#2016-02-1821:02devnIt does.#2016-02-1821:02wparkerSo you insert 2 temperatures of 80 and then retract 2 of them; I‚Äôd expect there to be none left#2016-02-1821:03devnI guess I halfway expected that, for instance, some deeper identity of a fact beyond just its equality with a corresponding fact in the session would have some bearing.#2016-02-1821:03devnSo if I bound (->Temperature 80 "MCI") to high-temp, and then used high-temp twice in the insert-all#2016-02-1821:04devnWhen I do a (retract session high-termp), it would actually retract both facts#2016-02-1821:05devnI was surprised, but I guess after thinking about it, it doesn't really matter which of the facts is retracted.#2016-02-1821:05wparkerOh, I think I see#2016-02-1821:06wparkerYeah, at least for now I think the memory just uses equality and retracts one each time#2016-02-1821:06wparkerThe key bit of code is the remove-first-of-each calls in the memory#2016-02-1821:06wparkerhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/memory.cljc#2016-02-1821:06devnI was thinking that you know, under the covers, an instance of (-> Foo 1) would have an object ID or something taken into account underneath#2016-02-1821:06devnbut it makes sense that it doesn't#2016-02-1821:07wparkerYes, it just uses Clojure equality#2016-02-1821:07devnSo, @wparker here's one more question for you simple_smile#2016-02-1821:08devnhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/pull/164/files#diff-d16f31f970a20e4115932869c9aa825dR310#2016-02-1821:08devnIs this actually a good test of truth maintenance in action for a grouping accumulator?#2016-02-1821:08devnOr is it merely testing that top-level retract does what it's supposed to?#2016-02-1821:12devn@wparker: reading through the issue you filed, and thinking "boy, generative tests in this case would make a lot of sense."#2016-02-1821:20wparkerI‚Äôm not super familiar with how accumulators work in the engine, but one thing to keep in mind there is that reduce-to-accum creates a retraction function#2016-02-1821:20wparkerhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/accumulators.cljc#L91#2016-02-1821:24wparkerRegarding generative tests: that could be helpful, but I haven‚Äôt come up with any good ideas on how to make them (I haven‚Äôt thought about it that deeply though).#2016-02-1822:34ryanbrush@wparker @devn A good suite of generative tests would be great, and may have found a number of issues in logical edge cases. This would require generating rules with different criteria and ensuring consistency to really do well, and how to do so doesn't seem obvious. But I like the thought if anyone wants to play with it.#2016-02-1822:36ryanbrushAs for retraction, Clara used Clojure equality semantics by design. This seems like the least surprising behavior to treat facts as values....just like the number 1 is 1 no matter what its "identity". Seems like the Clojure way to me, and is analogous to removing an item from a map or set.#2016-03-0417:05ennI‚Äôm running into some behavior that I don‚Äôt understand. I have a fact type of which I only ever expect 1 or 0 instances. If the session has 0 instances, I‚Äôd like to make a rule which inserts an instance with some reasonable default values. Right now I have this rule: 
(defrule default-event-date
  "If there is no EventDate, create one far in the future."
  [:not [EventDate]]
  =>
  (clara.rules/insert!
   (r/map->EventDate {:date (time.coerce/to-date-time "30000")})))
This correctly does not fire if I start the session with an EventDate fact. If I don‚Äôt, however, run-rules never returns. It seems to just keep firing. I would expect it to fire once.#2016-03-0417:07ennAh, just found the mailing list thread about this. I guess that the fact gets retracted when the LHS stops being true, which causes it to get re-inserted, which causes the LHS to stop being true, which causes it to get retracted, etc. ad infinitum#2016-03-0417:17ennThe suggestion is to use insert-unconditional!, but that seems to never fire, even when there are no facts#2016-03-0417:23ryanbrush@enn Hmm, insert-unconditional! should fire in example above if no EventDate facts are in the working memory when fire-rules is called. It might be worth restarting the REPL in case fact types got reloaded (and rules are looking at a different type). If things are still failing and can be narrowed down to a reproducible test I can take a look.#2016-03-0417:24enn@ryanbrush I was mistaken‚Äîit does fire, it just doesn‚Äôt show up in explain-activations. Is that expected?#2016-03-0417:32ryanbrush@enn So explain-activations uses the truth maintenance facility to figure out what is supporting the fact, which wouldn't be used in an unconditional insert. I think one could argue the fact that unconditional inserts aren't seen here is a bug, but there are tradeoffs there. Another use case for unconditional insert is for performance-critical edge cases where users don't want to pay the accounting cost of tracking truth and activation explanation...which we couldn't offer if we tracked truth maintenance/explain-activations for unconditional inserts.#2016-03-0417:34ryanbrush@enn In short, I'd be open to adding unconditional activations to explain-activations, but I'd want to consider the tradeoffs and make sure our performance-critical use cases (some inserting more then 100,000 facts) have a path forward as well.#2016-03-0417:36ryanbrush@enn As for the original problem of an infinite looping rule, this comes up enough that I think we need a better way to expose and explain it to the user. I've seen other engines limit the number of recursive activations to a few thousand and throw an exception with context to explain where the failure is coming from. Tempted to add that to Clara as well.#2016-03-0417:42enn@ryanbrush: thanks for the explanation. That makes sense. I was just using explain-activations as a debugging tool, so now that I know it has that limitation, it‚Äôs not a problem that it‚Äôs not showing up.#2016-03-0417:48ryanbrush@enn Fair enough. I mostly want to extinguish any sort of surprising behavior, even if it is for debugging purposes. I'll think about it some more but won't make any immediate changes here.#2016-03-0821:07devnHowdy @ryanbrush -- 2 selfish questions for you: 1) Any guess on when 0.11 might make it out into the wild? 2) Any chance of the new work you began on clara-tools continuing?#2016-03-0904:41ryanbrushHey @devn, there is one more fix I wanted to get into 0.11, but I can see it dropping next week. As for clara-tools, I'm not sure when I'll get back to it. We found a simpler way to solve some of the internal problems I had been enhancing clara-tools for and other demands are taking most of my time. I'd be happy to collaborate with anyone interested in moving it forward and hope to work more on it starting in mid April, but can't promise much more than that.#2016-03-1418:31kahunamoore@ryanbrush: @devn I‚Äôve started building an IDE-like environment (called Clarity) for clara and have been studying clara-tools. However, I‚Äôm looking to take a different approach. Two requirements I would like to meet are integration with Cursive/Intelli-J and as a plugin for other editors#2016-03-1418:33kahunamooreopps‚Ä¶ hit return before I was done editing. I started it as a plugin for lighttable but abandoned that when the project team abandoned LT. I might revisit it at some point but right now I‚Äôm working on the Cursive approach first. I‚Äôm not sure using an HTTP server will be the approach I settle on. I‚Äôm trying to leverage the existing JDI infrastructure. The HTTP server was clearly the right call given the requirements (I‚Äôm guessing a problem at work and needing visibility‚Ä¶) I‚Äôm hoping to write as little code as possible but still integrate with what people are already doing (e.g. IntelliJ debugger, repl). I want to create some visualizations for the debugger, some utilities for the repl, etc. The logic -> graph and session -> graph functions are very helpful.#2016-03-1814:49ryanbrushClara 0.11.0 is up on Clojars. It's a smaller release than 0.10, but has a couple bug fixes that are worth picking up if nothing else. Release notes here: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0110#2016-03-2120:53devnWe may have been experiencing one of those bugs and calling our behavior good#2016-03-2120:53devnI suppose it's also possible there's a regression, but we're looking into it now. Will let you know what we find#2016-03-2120:54devn@ryanbrush: ^#2016-03-2120:55devnWe do not use insert unconditional or salience #2016-03-2120:56devnWe are using the deprecated accumulator function though.#2016-03-2122:15devnLooks like #171 is what broke us.#2016-03-2122:15devnWe have a couple instances of the RHS using both a retract!, and an insert!#2016-03-2122:47ryanbrush@devn Traveling right now so can't look in depth, but using retract with truth maintenance can create difficult to reason about situations in any rule engine. If there is some test case that does not behave as one would expect I'll take a look at it.#2016-03-2123:03devnafter thinking about it for a little bit, i see why this is broken.#2016-03-2123:03devnclara is doing it's job correctly.#2016-03-2200:21devnI guess I'm still interested in understanding exactly what's going on here#2016-03-2214:54mikeroddevn: did you have an example of what broke somewhere?#2016-03-2214:55mikerodis it the same as https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/F-8vcsZC2i4 ?#2016-03-2217:02devn@mikerod: yes#2016-03-2217:03devnThat's the situation, which I guess makes good sense to me.#2016-03-2217:03devnWe don't need to retract here. I pushed back against the use of it, but it worked, until we bumped to 0.11.0 of course simple_smile#2016-03-2220:21mikeroddevn: yeah, in that particular scenario the previous behavior was questionable#2016-03-2220:21mikerodThe RHS is retracting the facts that are supporting the truth of the rule in general#2016-03-2220:22mikerodThis goes against the concept of logical truth maintenance of inserted facts. Retracts will often lead you into bad situations when it comes to truth maintenance. In this particular scenario, the rule shouldn't insert anything because anything it inserts loses its logical support immediately, due to the retract of all the recommendations.#2016-03-2220:23mikerodLooks like Will put more details on the Google groups though.#2016-03-2220:24mikerodIn our use-cases, we avoid retracts pretty much completely. We like to rely on the logical truth maintenance of inserts to do any "retracts" for us. It does involve adding new fact types occasionally, which Clara's default is via :type metadata or the Java class hierarchy (on Java side) or JS hierarchy (on JS side)#2016-03-2314:01ryanbrushHey all, still out of town but I think @mikerod's answer here and @wparker's answer in the forum are on target. I kind of regret adding retract! at all since it's such an easy way to shoot oneself in the foot. (This isn't the first time it has caused confusion.) I'm tempted to deprecate it, or move it into a specialized package to make it clear. I don't think there is a great way to "fix" retract! when interacting with truth maintenance, since it's semantics conflict with what the engine does. Looking back on it, it feels like it's the equivalent of a GOTO statement for expert systems.#2016-03-2315:41devn:thumbsup:#2016-03-2319:54mikerodso it is "retract! considered harmful"#2016-03-2319:55mikerodmaybe just a part of Clara docs that gives that big warning#2016-04-0819:58devn@mikerod I am behind on the ML discussion, but I think there was some discussion of removing it altogether. Frankly, I'm really happy to hear that.#2016-04-0821:58mikerod@devn perhaps. I think there may be valid usages, but they need to be constrained and perhaps we could see about reporting errors on the cases that have vague or ambiguous semantics#2016-04-1414:56saicheongI have just started learning clara. In clara-examples, the facts that are inserted into working memory are typically record type.#2016-04-1414:57saicheongI wonder if 'primitive' data can also be inserted - like Strings or Keywords.#2016-04-1415:00saicheongHow do we write the condition expression to match a keyword or a string?#2016-04-1416:04devn@saicheong: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/wiki/Guide#fact-types#2016-04-1418:35ryanbrush@saicheong: By default you can any type known to Clojure's type function, which includes the Java class hierarchy (including Strings, or clojure.lang.Keyword, but that's not something I've done.) If you need something more sophisticated, the link @devn posted is a good reference.#2016-04-1423:24saicheongSay I have a rule that inserts a keyword :exceed-cap. Now I need to this keyword to match other rules. Will this expression in a rule match the keyword?: [clojure.lang.Keyword (= :exceed-cap)]#2016-04-1500:38devn@saicheong: I haven't done what you're describing. You could try it but something tells me that won't work.#2016-04-1500:39devnI am heading out otherwise I'd help you out.#2016-04-1502:51wparker@saicheong: I believe the problem with the constraint you have there is that you‚Äôre calling = with one argument, which always returns false. The symbol ‚Äúthis‚Äù in rule constraints is bound to the fact under consideration; I believe you need to test that ‚Äúthis‚Äù is equal to :exceed-cap. Example gist: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/9cafbe73b2c3b99153fd3fcfc8daa4c3#2016-04-1503:00wparkerOne thing to keep in mind (without knowing anything about your use-case of course) is that one of the major optimizations of Clara (and the Rete algorithm it is based on more generally) is only testing facts against conditions that their type allows them to match. That is, if you inserted something that isn‚Äôt a Keyword into the example in the gist above, that equality check wouldn‚Äôt ever be tried. Checking equality against a keyword should be very, very fast though, just something to be aware of more generally. Of course, if your use case is small enough even thinking about that could be premature optimization.#2016-04-1503:00saicheong@devn: Thanks. I'll try it out when I get some time. #2016-04-1503:06saicheong@wparker: thanks for the tip on using 'this' in the expression. I'll try that out too. #2016-04-2515:43ryanbrushclara-rules 0.11.1 is up on Clojars. It's a fix release with some nice performance optimizations from @mikerod. Details in the change log: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0111#2016-04-2717:33devnHuzzah#2016-04-2719:59mikeroddevn: Is that a delayed celebration of the 0.11.1 release?#2016-04-2719:59mikerodüòõ#2016-04-2719:59devn@mikerod: yes simple_smile#2016-04-2719:59mikerodYeah, try it out. Report if you notice anything - good or bad.#2016-04-2720:00mikerodIn our case, it actually had a few fairly subtle changes that did help our performance#2016-04-2720:00devnwill do, we're picking up development on the rules engine side of things in a week or so#2016-04-2720:00devnbut i can at least bump the version and run tests#2016-04-2720:00devnand see how things shake out#2016-04-2720:00mikerodCool#2016-04-2720:00devnthanks for all of your work#2016-04-2720:01mikerodNo big deal. We are getting a lot of good use out of Clara so far and it is fun to work on.#2016-04-2720:02mikerodThanks for your feedback and contributions to it too!#2016-06-0616:38devnHello friends#2016-06-0616:40devnQuestion for you... Provided: 
(defrecord DatedFact [date whatever])
(defrecord LatestFact [date whatever])

(def latest
  "Accumulator for finding the maximum value of a :date field."
  (clara.acc/max (comp time.coerce/to-long :date)
                 :returns-fact true))

(clara/defrule simple-latest-rule
  [?result <- latest :from [DatedFact (= ?date date)]]
  =>
  (clara.rules/insert! (map->LatestFact ?result)))

(clara/defquery query-latest [] [?latest <- LatestFact])
#2016-06-0616:40devnThis will insert! for all DatedFacts.#2016-06-0616:42devnWithout the constraint on (= ?date date), it will fire only once.#2016-06-0616:43devnI understand why this is so, but I guess I'm interested to know what you think about how you'd prevent this sort of thing from happening by rule authors.#2016-06-0617:05devnOn second thought, I could use a good plain english explanation of why this is the case.#2016-06-0717:17ryanbrushHey @devn, a good rule of thumb is that Clara will have one activation for each unique combination of bound variables. So when you remove the ?date binding in that accumulator, it just grabs the latest for all records and fires once. If you add a binding in an accumulator, it accumulates separately for each binding (?date in this case) and fires once per unique binding.#2016-06-0717:20devnThanks for that explanation. I was thinking about the binding on ?date being a sort of bucketing/grouping operation, so for each bucket of unique ?date values, capture the greatest date.#2016-06-0717:22devnusing ?date there doesn't make much sense from a practical standpoint, since the accumulator pulls :date anyhow#2016-06-0717:22ryanbrushYeah, that's he idea.#2016-06-0717:23devn@ryanbrush: a loaded question: any thoughts on multiple sessions vs a single, shared session?#2016-06-0717:23ryanbrushIf you need richer semantics, you can always access any fields in the resulting accumulated value in the RHS, or even use a custom accumulator. But that depends on the use case#2016-06-0717:23devnmy question is sort of intentionally vague#2016-06-0717:24devnthe big question is: are there common triggers in your mind for when to split out a new session using the results of queries on another session?#2016-06-0717:25ryanbrushAs for a single vs multiple sessions, just depends on what's easier to work with. We tend to use multiple sessions since there is very little overlap between them so it makes sense to keep separate. But YMMV.#2016-06-0717:26ryanbrushBut big sessions should perform pretty well, so whatever is simpler seems like a good starting point. We have sessions with 100k records and thousands of rules easily.#2016-06-0717:27devnthinking out loud: i guess it's like namespacing or anything else, it's just that there is a pretty pipeline-ish feel to what we've built, and with the number of facts that are inserted for specific rule firings, it seems like there might be some valuable in splitting things out a bit more to make inspection easier#2016-06-0717:27devnthen again, from the standpoint of providing explanations, there's some overhead associated with passing those facts through to another session#2016-06-0717:28devnsince, for the purposes of a UI for instance, you need to capture the explanations from different sessions and cobble them together#2016-06-0717:28devnnot hard, really#2016-06-0717:28devnjust easier to have the single session#2016-06-0717:29ryanbrushYeah. The old loose coupling/high cohesion design trade offs never really go away.#2016-06-0717:29devnSpeaking of UIs... üòâ#2016-06-0717:30devnIIRC I think you said the tools.ui work is on hold/not gonna happen#2016-06-0717:31ryanbrushYeah, not much is going on in that space now. It hasn't been a big need for us, so other demands have moved up. Happy to work with others that might be interested though.#2016-06-0717:32ryanbrush(Oops....Need to drop offline for a bit here, but will be back on later in the day.)#2016-06-0717:34devnIt hasn't been a big need for us either, but generally speaking, onboarding people who haven't worked with a rules engine could be easier. I've been thinking about whether it's a UI that I want, or if it's just better editor tooling to bring "focus" to specific rules, or parts of rules.#2016-06-0717:42devnclara provides an opportunity to deliver good explanations. so, i wonder about a sort of meta-explain that could provide a more readable version of why a rule fired. I imagine in the above case seeing something like: For each DatedFact (of which there were 10), retrieve the latest fact for each unique ?foo value grouping. There were 3 unique ?foo values (`"A", "B", "C"`). As a result, 3 LatestFact facts were inserted into the session. Since you've requested I focus my attention on the date field of LatestFact in my summaries, these are the date values on LatestFact which were inserted: 2016-05-10, ...#2016-06-0717:47devnI would of course settle for: "Me take DatedFact, put unique ?foo in many bucket, put LatestFact with date of 2016-05-10." üôÇ#2016-06-0717:49devnBTW, @mikerod && @ryanbrush -- Excited to see the work and thought going into session durability. Thank you.#2016-06-0718:10mikeroddevn: I'd echo sort of what Ryan said that smaller sessions can work alright. If you have heavy-weight logic in rules though, it is good to share that if it applies to many other sessions. One idea would be to just derive facts for the common logic in one session, and then insert those facts into another new session later. That isn't too expensive if the hard-work is in the rules that make those derived facts.#2016-06-0718:11mikeroddevn: And yes, the durability stuff will be coming along hopefully in a timely manner. I'm working on a prototype for it still currently and will keep design thoughts and discussions posted on the https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/issues/198 issue#2016-06-0718:12mikerodIf you have any input there on how you'd want it to work, I'd be interested to hear that too. I have a use-case in mind, but it is good to know if there are any differing needs. I had a really rough demo of some thoughts @ https://github.com/mrrodriguez/clara-durability-demo but that would not be the expected way everyone would need to interface. I was just toying with an idea of being able to use an extension point like clojure.core/print-dup to give hooks for serialization.#2016-06-0718:13mikerodIn our case, our working memory of the rules session will actually have different types of objects in them, like Java Serializable, Avro, Clojure records#2016-06-0718:13mikerodSo I am messing around with ideas on how to efficiently provide capabilities to serialize this data when the serialization formats of groups of the data points actually, likely needs to vary..#2016-06-0823:21devn@mikerod: interesting to hear that you can even do that (have serializable, avro, clojure recs floating around in the session)#2016-06-0823:31devn@mikerod: what does that look like in practice? Like, where do you use avro in a session?#2016-06-1100:38wparker@devn: There isn‚Äôt any barrier to having non-Clojure types in a session. For fields, Clara will just fall back to using JavaBean properties if it can. https://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/blob/0.11.1/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L165 You might get into trouble using things like Java primitives or maybe a falsey value, but I‚Äôd expect normal Java objects to work. As far as why, I work with @mikerod so I can speak to that; the short answer without saying too much is that while our group#2016-06-1100:39wparkergroup‚Äôs code is mostly in Clojure, we‚Äôre part of a larger Java system, and our external interaction points involve Avro records.#2016-06-1100:44wparkerOh, btw even though random Java objects are fine mutating them Java-style underneath the rules engine after inserting them isn‚Äôt, at least if you want predictable results üôÇ#2016-06-1100:59devn@wparker: ah, so the avro records you deal with are beans?#2016-06-1102:38wparker@devn correct. Not that facts have to be beans, it is just convenient for field access. You can always just use whatever functions/interop you want on the fact instead.#2016-06-1102:38devn@wparker: i feel pretty daft asking, but again, im curious what an example of this looks like in clara's DSL#2016-06-1102:39devnAre you talking about :fact-type-fn?#2016-06-1102:39devnEither way, I'm curious to see (even a hackish, half-working) sample of this#2016-06-1102:40devnWe're talking about Avro a bit lately#2016-06-1102:41devni've been musing about rules existing at other layers of our platform, which may select an existing avro schema, or produce a new one, for instance#2016-06-1102:44devn@wparker: also, regarding #157 -- i honestly don't recall when we made that change, only that we observed cache misses due to ordering concerns#2016-06-1102:44wparkerIt would just look like anything else, say#2016-06-1102:46wparker(defrule rule-using-bean [?fact <- AvroFact (meets-some-condition? field-on-AvroFact)] => whatever-RHS-you-want)#2016-06-1102:46wparkerI suppose you could do interesting things with the fact-type-fn and Avro schemas, but that wasn‚Äôt what I was referring to#2016-06-1102:47wparkerSay a fact-type-fn that used an Avro schema to determine the type.#2016-06-1102:47wparkerBut a generated Avro class can just be used like any other class#2016-06-1102:48devnhuh, i assumed there must be magic to make that work, but i must confess that my journey in programming has omitted serious java work, so while i understand chunks of the clojure compiler and such, i am often missing context w/r/t things like java beans#2016-06-1102:49devn@wparker: thanks much for the explanation#2016-06-1102:49wparkerWell, I haven‚Äôt personally created those Avro models, so I can‚Äôt exclude magic completely üôÇ#2016-06-1102:49wparkerBut once you have classes, they are just that#2016-06-1102:50wparkerYou‚Äôre welcome#2016-06-1102:51devn@wparker: also regarding 199 and your question about clojure equality, I don't think we've ever done anything with activation groups#2016-06-1102:52wparkerWell, it wouldn‚Äôt have to be activation groups in particular, I was just choosing that as an example of one of the options to mk-session#2016-06-1102:53devnDate: Wed Dec 30 16:46:15 2015 -0600#2016-06-1102:53wparkerCaching is on rules + options, which makes sense since the options impact the session semantics#2016-06-1102:54devnso, #157 was Jan 12#2016-06-1102:54devnüòÑ#2016-06-1102:54devnerr, but closed Feb 4#2016-06-1102:54devnbut, yeah, makes sense.#2016-06-1102:56devnNow I'm curious to see if removing that call to (set) changes behavior#2016-06-1102:57wparkerDo you mean trying with it removed on your code on the case that had a cache miss?#2016-06-1102:57devnyes#2016-06-1121:05devn@mikerod: http://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-1733#2016-06-1121:06devnWas just walking through open clojure issues and wanted to drop it here since I saw you wrapping with #=#2016-06-1302:19mikeroddevn: thanks for the heads up. Yeah, my original demo is likely to not be all that close to what I end up going with. However, it is good to know where the hiccups are right now with the default impl's of print-dup and I forgot about this existing issue there.#2016-06-1302:20devn@mikerod: it actually prompted me to do a general jira survey for "dup" issues. I was unable to figure out how to get JIRA to search for #= despite several attempts at various quoting and escaping schemes#2016-06-1302:21devnactually, i wound up doing a walk over most of JIRA yesterday. I don't know that it was "enjoyable", but focusing on the critical and high priority issues and reading them through was worth the time I think#2016-06-1302:38mikeroddevn: I think that is often a good idea'#2016-06-1302:38mikerodI try to keep up with it somewhat, but it'd be good to get a refresher over the bigger existing issues#2016-06-1302:38mikerodI agree that searching for print-dup stuff is certainly a non-trivial one üôÇ#2016-06-1302:38devnit moves slow enough that if you give it a good look post-release, you'll know what's up for awhile#2016-06-1302:39mikerodI've done a reasonable amount with print-dup before, but it is a lesser documented area and as you've shown here, there are caveats#2016-06-1302:39mikerodyeah, I'd think so#2016-06-1302:39devnheh, speaking of print-dup: I wrote a thing awhile back that took all of the sexps from the #C03S1KBA2 IRC channel going back to 2009#2016-06-1302:40devnand ran them in a sandbox, capturing output (if any), and value#2016-06-1302:41devnI used print-dup to serialize the entire collection of results out to a file at some point, and i remember finding some tricky bits, but i don't remember details anymore#2016-06-1302:42devndespite the "first rule of hash equals club is don't talk about hash equals", i remember it being quite solid back in 1.2, 1.3#2016-06-1302:43devnthere were at least 30k random examples serialized to a file, and read successfully, including Swing and all sorts of other nonsense#2016-06-1302:44devnthough it's one of those things that Rich and Co. have basically said: use at your own risk, i have a hard time imagining it going away#2016-06-1302:46devnAnyway, as long as I mentioned that project: http://getclojure.org/#2016-06-1302:47devnIt's nothing to write home about, and since it was all sandboxed, there are plenty of things which didn't pass the sniff test and were subsequently not run in the sandbox, but there's some interesting stuff in there, usually further into a search. A search for comp has results for the first few pages that are like (comp comp comp comp) for example, which is not very interesting.#2016-06-1302:50mikeroddevn: sounds interesting#2016-06-1302:50mikerodI'll ahve to look at that#2016-06-1302:50devnit's not really, i assure you üôÇ#2016-06-1302:51mikerodyeah, print-dup is weird. It seems to be, in some ways, a recommended approach to serialization of Clojure structures, but it is still not really fully "official"#2016-06-1302:51devni had dreams of building a sort of hoogle for clojure. codeq + clojure.tools.analyze + query over sexps, something like that#2016-06-1302:51mikerodit is primitive though. to use it successfully, you have to implement your own back references etc.#2016-06-1302:51mikerodif you have a lot of pointers to the same objects in memory or something like that.#2016-06-1302:51devn@mikerod: do you work with ryan, out of curiosity?#2016-06-1302:52mikerodthis website is interesting GetClojure#2016-06-1302:52mikerodI think I remember looking at this a long while back perhaps?#2016-06-1302:52mikerodmaybe you posted it somewhere before and I was curious#2016-06-1302:52devnyeah, it's my first clojure project from the olden days#2016-06-1302:52mikerodah I see#2016-06-1302:53mikerodYeah I work at the same company as Ryan. Also Will on here#2016-06-1302:53mikerodw parker#2016-06-1302:53devni'd like to understand clara internals better, but i think i need to start smaller and implement a dumb version of rete before I'll be of much use#2016-06-1302:54devn(mostly for the purposes of contributing)#2016-06-1302:54mikeroddevn: yeah, I actually find the codebase to be approachable, but it is good to have some background#2016-06-1302:54mikerodclara.rules.engine is almost something you could look at stand-alone to reason about the way the Rete network propagates data around#2016-06-1302:54mikerodclara.rules.compiler is more compilation complexity#2016-06-1302:55mikerodbuilds the rete graph etc, but I think you can sort of gloss over that and just look at clara.rules.engine to get a good feel for how data moves around#2016-06-1302:55devnis it crazy to think about building some instrumented visualization of the graph construction?#2016-06-1302:55mikerodwriting a toy version of your own could be a good learning experience though I'd imagine#2016-06-1302:55mikerodI think that could be a cool and useful thing#2016-06-1302:55devnsort of a stepping debugger or something#2016-06-1302:56mikerodI know that Ryan played some with some visualizations here and there#2016-06-1302:56mikerodhowever, nothing too serious yet. just demo's or trials of things I think#2016-06-1302:56mikerodhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools#2016-06-1302:57mikerodand also, it may not visualize the graph like you are saying. Visualization has different sort of levels you may be interested in.#2016-06-1302:57devnyes, exactly#2016-06-1302:57devnthere are layers to the explanation/visualization#2016-06-1302:57mikerodThere is an older paper referred to in the Clara wiki too#2016-06-1302:57mikerodhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-rules/wiki/Introduction#the-rules-engine#2016-06-1302:57devnsome of them useful at a domain level so people using our stuff can understand why a decision was rendered#2016-06-1302:58mikerodhttp://reports-archive.adm.cs.cmu.edu/anon/1995/CMU-CS-95-113.pdf this paper#2016-06-1302:58devnand then there's the "i'm a programmer, show me the hairier view, with data"#2016-06-1302:58mikerodI found it to have a really good overview of Rete. It is certainly dated and lacking many of the optimizations and extensions to Rete present in Clara, but it is a good base.#2016-06-1302:58devnand then there's the "i know kung fu, show me the internals"#2016-06-1302:58mikerodYes. Some interesting stuff!#2016-06-1303:00mikerodyeah, clips has good material#2016-06-1303:00devni mean, it's cool to see something lispy#2016-06-1303:00mikerodand OPS5.
