It scans the whole namespace and finds all rules/queries in vars of that namespace.#2017-02-0115:20mikerod(mk-session [one-rule another-rule some-query] 'some.ns.with.rules)#2017-02-0115:23mikerod@mike1452 Will mentioned that records allow you to refer to record fields directly in the rule. For non-records, you can use destructuring though. Just so you kmow 
(defrule my-rule [:my-type-thing [{:keys [x y]}] (= x ‚Äúhello‚Äù)] 
<etc>)
#2017-02-0115:23mikerodThere should probably be documented examples of that sort of destructuring.#2017-02-0115:27mike_ananevthanks#2017-02-0222:00apbleonard@wparker @mikerod Thanks so much - that's exactly the examples I was looking for. Assembling rules dynamically will help us handle our mostly similar (but slightly different) rule-sets for different products. Btw destructuring maps also good to know, as records are not often used in our Clojure codebase.#2017-02-0222:02mikerodIt‚Äôs probably good to be aware that if you can order rules in a meaningful order of precedence, Clara will attempt to use that as a heuristic during conflict resolution (picking which rule to fire first, when multiple are eligible).#2017-02-0222:03mikerodSo if you have rules or sets of rules that naturally depend on other rules/sets of rules, you want to put the dependents after the dependencies. This may not matter to you and may not be worth worrying about until you have a concrete performance concern.#2017-02-0222:06apbleonardWe have relatively low numbers of rules (no more than 100s depending on how granular we make them), but enough for Clara to really help sort out the complexity. üôÇ #2017-02-0222:06mikerodIf I had rules like: 
(defrule a [(acc/all) :from [A]] => (insert! (->B)))
(defrule b [(acc/all) :from [B]] => (insert! (->C)))
(defrule c [(acc/all) :from [C]] => (insert! (->D)))
All three rules would be ‚Äúeligible‚Äù to be fired immediately, since the acc/all accumulator is always considered ‚Äútrue‚Äù. It will just fire with an empty collection if it has no matches, yet. If I mk-session like 
(mk-session [c b a])
This would cause Clara to choose to fire the rules in the opposite order that you would want. The Truth Maintenance System will be sure that your rules logically are correct after firing the rules, however, it will waste cycles firing rules too soon and having to retract and re-fire them later as their dependencies in their LHS change. So you want mk-session like 
(mk-session [a b c])
#2017-02-0222:07mikerod@apbleonard Yeah, it likely isn‚Äôt something to concern yourself with now. I‚Äôm just brining it to your attention since when you start to consider generating rules, etc, it may be something to consider later on if performance becomes and sort of concern.#2017-02-0921:36gamecubateHello. Clojurescript doesn‚Äôt seem to be supported at this time. Bummer. Was just what I needed for a project at work.#2017-02-0922:37wparker@gamecubate ClojureScript is definitely intended to be supported, although it isn‚Äôt used as much as the Clojure version as far as I can tell and not at all at Cerner.#2017-02-0922:37wparkerThose don‚Äôt look like fatal warnings to me, did you run into further problems?#2017-02-1003:50gamecubate@wparker I didn‚Äôt want to spend too much time digging into this. So, I‚Äôve switched over to core.logic but I have to say progress is glacial (this said less than 2 hours after the switch). Clara‚Äôs eloquent DSL I miss already.#2017-02-1015:20wparkerTo elaborate a bit, those are basically linter warnings that seem related to the rebinding, in a particular namespace, of core Clojure library definitions to new values. You can look at the source in both cases for whatever version of ClojureScript and Plumatic Schema you‚Äôre using to see those redefinitions happening. Whether that is good style in any particular case is a matter of opinion, but I don‚Äôt think the linter warnings are actually errors. Obviously your choice to use Clara in any project or not, but nothing I see here makes me think there is a bug with Clara‚Äôs ClojureScript support. That said, Clara‚Äôs ClojureScript certainly isn‚Äôt as hardened as the JVM version and bug reports are welcome.#2017-02-1015:21wparkerAgainst master: https://github.com/plumatic/schema/blob/master/src/cljx/schema/core.cljx#L402 and https://github.com/clojure/clojurescript/blob/master/src/main/cljs/clojure/reflect.cljs#L33#2017-02-1016:04gamecubate@wparker End of day when I wrote this. I wasn‚Äôt thinking. Of course they were warnings! I gave up there and then instead of doing what I normally do (which is to ignore warnings) and proceed. Will resume Clara tests. Thanks for the nudge. üôÇ#2017-02-1016:49gamecubateMacros‚Ä¶ Checking Clara docs, I see mk-session is a macro indeed. I need to probably add a 
(:require-macros [???])
directive. Will try...#2017-02-1016:51ryanbrush@gamecubate I'd check out the ClojureScript examples, like the one at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojurescript/clara/examples/shopping.cljs.#2017-02-1016:52ryanbrushNote that mk-session doesn't exist and isn't support in ClojureScript, since it dynamically compiles rules. You'll need to use defsession (which compiles them upfront), as seen in that example. In fact, starting with that example, running it, and experimenting with changes to it is probably a pretty good way to get started with the ClojureScript flow.#2017-02-1016:53gamecubate@ryanbrush Thanks. Going through the example now.#2017-02-1016:55ryanbrush@gamecubate Sure thing! If you find problems, please log bugs or let us know. Just to warn you, we've used only the Clojure version in production and therefore haven't deeply optimized the CLJS flow so you might run into more issues there. But bug reports, and especially help tuning or optimizing the CLJS flow against real workloads, would be welcome.#2017-02-1016:55ryanbrush@gamecubate I think we're also behind on the version of ClojureScript we've tested against, so validating against newer versions is welcome as well.#2017-02-1016:56gamecubate@ryanbrush üëç#2017-02-1017:00gamecubate@ryanbrush Would you recommend I run my code against 0.13.0-RC4 (as per README.md) or, per your example, 0.13.0-RC7?#2017-02-1017:01ryanbrush@gamecubate Probably doesn't matter for your needs, but the readme is just out of date. 0.13.0-RC7 will be good. (We're overdue in just releasing 0.13.0 itself, so expect that in a release soon.)#2017-02-1017:01gamecubategot it#2017-02-1017:05gamecubateWow. This is one great example.#2017-02-1017:06gamecubateJust need to replace dommy with (my chosen) Reagent code.#2017-02-1017:12ryanbrushYeah, we probably should update the example to use a more modern approach. üôÇ#2017-02-1017:18gamecubateIt works nicely, though.#2017-02-1017:18gamecubate
fire-rules
successful. Am plugging in reactive (test) UI right now.#2017-02-1017:19gamecubateMy first instinct (as with all Reagent app data) would be to wrap the session in a (reagent) atom, but defsession being a macro and all, not sure this is even feasible, nor desirable, nor useful.#2017-02-1018:13gamecubateDone. Works nicely. Will now try and compile with advanced-optimizations.#2017-02-1018:16gamecubateWorks!#2017-02-1018:17gamecubateClara it is, then. üôÇ#2017-02-1018:56ryanbrush@gamecubate Glad it works! Note that defsession will create the initial, empty session as a static var, but that can be referenced and manipulated like any other Clojure data structure. I haven't thought a ton of good design patterns with Reagent...but just thinking of the session as any other complex, immutable structure is probably a good start.#2017-02-1018:57ryanbrush@gamecubate if you do come up with good patterns for using this with Reagent and are interested in sharing examples of doing so, we could look at including them in the examples project (possibly replacing the dommy example that exists today).#2017-02-1019:03gamecubateSo far still exploring. What I have done thus far is for my event handlers (someone enters data in a field and clicks on add button -> triggers handler) to insert new session data: 
(-> my-session (insert (->Customer ‚ÄúAlex‚Äù)) (fire-rules))
. Now am trying to figure out what to do for my reagent components to show the changes. Normally, without Clara, the event handler would simply update the atom that my components are watching. But now, with Clara, inserted data is held in the session and I need to find a way for my components to track that instead.#2017-02-1019:13gamecubateNow, with rules, the handler changes to:#2017-02-1019:14gamecubateMy customer-list component should change as well, and that‚Äôs where I am not sure how to proceed to get session data I need.#2017-02-1019:21ryanbrushNot a Reagent expert, but I think it should be possible to keep a Clara session in a Reagent atom, and swap it out every time you update facts or fire rules.#2017-02-1019:21gamecubateHow do I access records of a certain type, say ClientRepresentative?#2017-02-1019:22gamecubate
(def session-db (reagent/atom my-session))
#2017-02-1019:22gamecubateNot sure.#2017-02-1019:22ryanbrushAll access goes through queries. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/queries/#2017-02-1019:26gamecubateHow does one write a query that retrieves all records of a certain type? Something like 
(defquery get-clients ‚Äú‚Äù [] [???])
#2017-02-1019:27gamecubatewith that type defined as 
(defrecord Client [name])
.#2017-02-1019:29gamecubateI might need an example for using accumulators/all. That looks like the one I need.#2017-02-1019:35gamecubateOh I see. might be 
[?client <- Client]
#2017-02-1020:49gamecubateGot it. Just need to set a rule that updates the (reagent atom) db whenever a new session insert takes place.#2017-02-1021:14gamecubateSo, this works. I am not sure however that this should be added to examples because it only serves to demonstrate that using Clara and Reagent together requires (in my solution at least) an extra level of indirection (view -> event handler -> clara insert -> reagent atom db update -> view ‚Ä¶). The business logic that Clara offers a DSL for is too simple in this case. I‚Äôll try and think of something more convoluted before submitting said example.#2017-02-1021:51ryanbrushCool, glad it's working. No rush in adding something to the examples...it's just nice to see a pattern that works with Reagent.#2017-02-1021:53ryanbrushOne thing to note: the session itself is immutable, so you'll probably want to keep it in atom itself and swap out when you make changes. The rules you have above will work because they are just appending state, but you're actually resetting back to an old session state every time.#2017-02-1022:03ryanbrushThere are probably other interesting variations on this. For instance, we could have reactions that fire on a swap of an atom containing the session, and those reactions would query the session and update other state. This could be a little closer to the purely "reactive" ideals of Reagent, rather than having rules that actively update state.#2017-02-1022:08gamecubateI see. Changes needed then; will think about it to see where and how. Thanks! Gotta go pick up kid @ daycare (immutable task for me :). Cheers.#2017-02-1218:42mike_ananevHi! Can Clara detect a rule collisions? If rule C contradicts to rule A ?#2017-02-1220:59apbleonardFairly new to Clara but ... it probably depends slightly what you mean. If you have a rules like "if A then B = 1" and "if A then B = 2", then when you query the session for values of B (assuming A is true) you'll find two values in the lazy sequence returned by the query function.#2017-02-1221:01apbleonardIf you have rules like "if A then B" and "if B then retract A" ... well, I haven't got that far yet!#2017-02-1222:17mike_ananev@apbleonard yeah, first variant with two answers is correct, i think. second variant is not, cause "if A then B" will insert fact B, but if retract A then B will be retracted automatically. my question about contradiction was about case if some big organization issues new policy about smth, i want to check that rules in new policy are not contradict to older policies. so i want to find collisions before new policy is issued.#2017-02-1321:22mikerod@mike1452 @apbleonard the 2nd variant could actually cause an infinite loop since Clara‚Äôs insert! will do some automatic truth-maintenance which can hang indefinitely if you have a ‚Äúlogical loop"#2017-02-1321:24mikerodHowever, the 1st variant sounds to be more of what you were asking. You have to deal with duplicated inserts yourself. You could have rules all insert some fact like B there, then have some ‚Äúfinal‚Äù/‚Äùoutcome" rule(s) or query(s) that use an accumulator that you can make decide which facts are the most relevant or correct when you get into a situation of ‚Äúcontradictions"#2017-02-1321:27mikerodHowever, I think you were also wanting the engine to tell you about these rules so you could remove them perhaps? That would be something you‚Äôd probably have to workout yourself. Sounds domain-specific.#2017-02-1321:27mikerodIt isn‚Äôt really clear what a ‚Äúcontradicting‚Äù rule means from the rules engine‚Äôs perspective. With the exception of logical contradictions, but those also aren‚Äôt even clear in the engine right now since the RHS can insert basically anthing#2017-02-1321:28mikerodand the LHS can test constraints that aren‚Äôt simple to statically analyze.#2017-02-1416:30wparker@mike1452 @apbleonard If you use manual retractions in the RHS you become responsible for ensuring that the rule execution order works out so that you get your desired results. It is basically the same idea as with logical vs unconditional insertions discussed at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ This can be done with salience and/or strategic structuring of your rules, but in my experience adds significant complication and room for error#2017-02-1416:31wparkerMy suggestion would be to use accumulators or negation conditions as Mike alluded to above. If you have a priority order of different logical states it wouldn‚Äôt be too hard to get the state with the highest priority in an accumulator and use that state in a rule RHS. Alternatively, you can write rules like#2017-02-1416:34wparker(defrule negation-rule-1 [?a <- A (some-predicate-here)] [:not [B (other-predicate-here)]] => (insert something))#2017-02-1416:37wparkermanual RHS retractions can be useful for getting things out of memory or for performance, in general wouldn‚Äôt be my first resort though#2017-02-1416:47mike_ananev@wparker thanks for suggestions! btw, what is most biggest rules database you've ever seen in production memory that Clara worked with? 10,100, 500?#2017-02-1416:47wparkerdo you mean the number of rules?#2017-02-1416:47mike_ananevyeah#2017-02-1416:55wparkerI think we have some rulesets with at least 10K rules now, can‚Äôt say exactly off the top of my head since we autogenerate a lot of rules with some internal framework code#2017-02-1416:58wparkerthere‚Äôs a reason we‚Äôve spent a lot of effort optimizing performance üòõ#2017-02-1418:04mike_ananevwow, cool!#2017-02-1419:19apbleonard@mike1452 FWIW I have exactly the same challenges. We handle complex government policies introduced atop of older policies, and half the battle is understanding pathways through the logic, and the total space of inputs and the variety of resulting outputs. I'd love to implement the rules trivially enough to give fast feedback to policy makers on what their new policy just did to the complexity of the problem. I feel like clojure's core.logic should be able to help with this...? If that makes sense, anyone know of people using core.logic with Clara?#2017-02-1420:49ryanbrush@apbleonard I'm a fan of core.logic, but am unaware of anyone using it tightly with Clara. I think core.logic works great for problems that can be described as a set of constraints, and core.logic will search that constraint space for a solution. Clara is more centered around encoding business rules or domain expertise. It's not always obvious which tool is best for a given job, so I always think it's a good idea to experiment with both in your problem space before choosing a direction.#2017-02-1421:10wparkerClara-rules 0.13.0 is released. - The replacement of the previous durability API with a more robust and performant one. This is discussed at issue 198. Note that this is experimental and is subject to further change; that said we're successfully using it in production at Cerner. - Improvements in error reporting in rule and query conditions, discussed at issue 255. Thanks to Carlos Phillips for this one. - Various performance improvements and bug fixes discussed on the changelog.#2017-02-1421:11wparkerI meant to say ‚Äúhighlights include‚Äù before my bullets.. I fail at Slack formatting üòõ#2017-02-1421:11wparkerAnyway, basically a cross-post from https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/Q2p7l-Vmcr0#2017-02-1621:52jarrodctaylorCould anyone be so kind as to help me understand how variable definition works? This is the most concise example I have to illustrate my confusion. 
(require '[clara.rules :as rule])

(rule/defrule wat
  [1 (= ?a "a")]
  [1 (= ?b "b")
   (nil? (println ?a))    ;; => "a"
   (nil? (println ?b))    ;; => "b"
   (nil? (println ?a ?b)) ;; => "a nil"
   ] => nil)

(-> (rule/mk-session [wat] :fact-type-fn (constantly 1))
    (rule/insert 1)
    (rule/fire-rules))
#2017-02-1621:53jarrodctaylorWhy does ?b disappear when printed together with ?a?#2017-02-1622:41wparkerI wouldn‚Äôt expect that to happen, but I can see the behavior you describe when I drop your example in a REPL#2017-02-1622:44wparkerIt is a weird case in that you‚Äôd normally expect the bindings to come off the actual fact in some way, but it still seems like incorrect behavior at first glance, probably merits a GitHub issue#2017-02-1622:45wparker@jarrodctaylor#2017-02-1622:52jarrodctaylorI was experiencing the behavior with a more traditional rule in my application. This above was as too the point of an example to demonstrate it as possible. I will open a issue on GitHub. #2017-02-1622:52zyloxi know ive had issues when i try to refer to a binding in the same condition (might be the wrong term) where it was bound.#2017-02-1622:53zyloxbut if i used the raw field version it worked fine#2017-02-1623:10wparkerI suspect that the reason adding ?a causes ?b to be different is that if you have ?a in the constraint it will become a join with the previous fact, and if it is absent it is a condition on a single fact#2017-02-1623:10wparkerThose are different paths in the compiler so one could have a bug the other doesn't#2017-02-1623:11wparkerDoing a quick test like#2017-02-1623:11wparker
` (rule/defrule wat
  [1 (= ?a "a")]
  [1 (= ?b "b")
   (and (nil? (println ?a))
         (nil? (println ?b))) 
   ] => nil)
`#2017-02-1623:11wparkermakes b be nil as well#2017-02-1623:12wparkerwith ?a and ?b in the same constraint#2017-02-1623:12wparker@zylox : a ‚Äúcondition‚Äù contains constraints, that is you can have a condition like [FactType constraint1 constraint2]#2017-02-2603:21mikerodhttps://leanpub.com/readevalprintlove004/read I don't recall if this was shared in this channel yet. It is an interesting read on rules engines by Fogus. I particularly like the simplified implementation of a (naive and simplistic) rules system. The "fruit fly" system. Hah. It does shed some light on some ideas at a high level. There is a little mention of Clara in the end "credits" too. So there is that. üòú #2017-03-0210:57newresI have a question about using guards on rules in Clara. I am aiming to create rules that can never insert a fact that already exist. The guard statement works fine if I am manually inserting the fact that the guard stops, but if the rule itself is creating this statement the guard does not stop the rule from triggering again and I get an infinite loop.#2017-03-0216:05zyloxya thats a tricky one ive dealt with too. i'm not sure what the solution is either.#2017-03-0216:19newreswith a naive implementation of rules where each rule is checked separately I can see this not being an issue as after each insertion the guard would be checked and with the new fact that guard would be passed. Could this be a bug in the implementation, where somehow not the full condition of the rule is checked for it to fire again?#2017-03-0216:34zyloxmaybe i didnt understand what you meant by gaurds, but if a rule inserts something that that same rule looks at, its pretty much always going to cause another firing#2017-03-0216:34zyloxis my understanding#2017-03-0217:16newresI think i figured out the roof of the problem#2017-03-0217:16newresI compeltely glanced over the fact that clara does truth maintenance#2017-03-0217:18newresthis means if the result of the rule puts in the guard of the rule the fact loses support gets retracted and the rule fires again#2017-03-0217:18wparkerSounds correct, looking through https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/truth_maintenance.clj and http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ might be helpful üôÇ#2017-03-0217:18zyloxtruestory#2017-03-0217:19newresI feel very dense about this#2017-03-0217:20wparkerYou can use unconditional insertions that won‚Äôt use truth maintenance if necessary. In our use cases we strongly prefer truth maintenance and find that it makes the code simpler to reason about, but obviously use-cases differ#2017-03-0217:20newresi was staring at this like a whole evening thinking what the problem could be, whoops.#2017-03-0217:20wparkerIt is a common point of confusion üôÇ#2017-03-0217:21newresIt kind of solves pretty much every problem I had with clara though, so that is a relief#2017-03-0217:22zyloxso you are saying you were stuck in an infinite loop about the infinite loop and the truth about truth maintenence resolved it#2017-03-0217:24newresyeah basically using a guard with truth maintenance, where the result of the rule (or another) triggers the guard can start an infinite loop#2017-03-0217:24newresespecially in the case where it is just a single rule that triggers the guard#2017-03-0217:25zylox(i was just making a light hearted joke about how your proccess of realizing how it was working was similar to a rules network) though your understanding sounds correct to me#2017-03-0217:25newresah LOL#2017-03-0217:25newreswell like I said I feel dense today#2017-03-0219:52nrayapatihttp://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html#2017-03-0219:54nrayapatiOverview of the talk @mikerod gave at the Clojure/conj 2016 conference.#2017-03-0220:31mikerodOh yes. Still cleaning up that site some. Going to change the theme since it sucks on mobile. However the content is there. #2017-03-0220:33zyloxnope this is permanent now#2017-03-0220:33zyloxweve seen everything#2017-03-0221:41ryanbrush@mikerod Okay, I'll resist the urge to tweet about it until you have the finishing touches in place. üòÑ#2017-03-0221:42mikerodHaha. Thanks. I'll fix it within a day or so. Out of town so I'm a bit slow. #2017-03-0320:00mikerod@ryanbrush FYI I changed the visual theme to something that is reasonable on mobile and desktop. So I'd consider the Clara blog good to go at this point. #2017-03-0320:17ryanbrush@mikerod Looks great, and nice post!#2017-03-0320:40mikerodThanks!#2017-03-2216:54wparkerVersion 0.14.0 of clara-rules is released. I posted at https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/UscQQgDtN-Y with a description of the changes relative to 0.13.0 (the previous version).#2017-04-1222:50souenzzoHi. How to make an "or" in "match" part of rule. Example: 
;; There is 2 types: groups and items
;; Example:
;; :group [1 false 2]
;; :group [1 false 3]
;; :item [2 true]
;; :item [3 false]
;; :group [4 true 5]
;; :item [5 false]
;; Group '1' contains items '2' and '3'
;; Group '4' contains item '5'
;; My `select` query shoud find [[4][1]]
;; because they are groups and they are selected
;; or contains a selected item
(defrule selected-groups
         ;; Or this
         [:group [[id selected _]] (= ?id group) (= selected true)]

         ;; Or this
         [:group [[id _ item-id]] (= ?id id) (= item-id ?item-id)]
         [:item [[item-id selected]] (= ?item-id item-id) (= selected true)]
         =>
         (insert! ^{:type :select} [?id]))
(sorry for big example) (yes, I know how to do it with 2 rules.) (I dont care with duplicate entries)#2017-04-1322:29wparker@souenzzo Would something like [:or [:group ‚Ä¶] [:and {:group ..] [:item]] meet your needs? There are some docs at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/booleans#2017-04-2001:28devn@wparker thanks for session->fact-graph#2017-04-2001:28devni'm pretty excited about that change#2017-04-2014:19zyloxsame#2017-04-2015:19alex-dixonHaven't made time to try it yet üòï#2017-04-2015:39mac@devn I musty be missing something, which commit contains 
session->fact-graph
?#2017-04-2016:22wparker@mac it isn‚Äôt in master yet. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/283#2017-04-2016:23mac@wparker Ah, got it. Thanks.#2017-04-2016:26wparkerglad to hear it could be useful for others as well. I‚Äôd be interested to hear about experiences with it or any tools, visualizations, etc. anyone comes up with and wants to share#2017-04-2016:28wparkerfor the use-case I had in mind I‚Äôll probably be looking at ways to show particular parts of the graph since the session is so large that showing the entire graph would be an information overload#2017-04-2119:55devn@wparker we built something hackish to build graphviz, and for the entire session the graph was way too big to be useful#2017-04-2119:56devnthen there was an attempt at using cytoscape.js to make it traversable#2017-04-2119:56devnso you could see a few nodes away from YOU ARE HERE#2017-04-2119:57devnwhat i found myself wanting was a way to define views over the graph, like, i may not care about all the edges and nodes between Node A and Node B, so I'd like to define a view that shows me Node A -> Node B without all of the intermediate steps#2017-04-2120:00devnI imagine having something like: (def views {:everything [FactA FactB ...], :simple [FactA FactC FactF]})#2017-04-2120:01devn:simple automatically collapses nodes and edges along the path of A->C->F#2017-04-2120:02devn@wparker another thing that I think would be nice would be to generate a static graph#2017-04-2120:03devnof all the facts in the project, regardless of whether they are ever used#2017-04-2120:04devnbut maybe your PR achieves this?#2017-04-2120:05devnwhat we built relied on the data returned from inspect, which IIRC required us to fire-rules#2017-04-2120:06devnim interested in building the graph of all the relationships, not just the relationships that survive after running the rules#2017-04-2120:07wparkerThe graph would include all logical insertions regardless of whether they were used for anything, but unconditional/external insertions wouldn‚Äôt be if they weren‚Äôt used for anything#2017-04-2120:08wparkerSince Clara allows them to be garbage-collected if they aren‚Äôt used#2017-04-2120:10wparkerMy general line of thinking here was to build a graph, and then#2017-04-2120:10wparkerprovide functions to retrieve particular subsets of the graph, potentially modify it, etc.#2017-04-2120:11wparkerand then look at how to display those views. Basically have a data-oriented approach to the problem that different views could layer on top of#2017-04-2120:11zyloxyou can always reduce the data in a graph, thats the wonder of them#2017-04-2120:12wparkerIn particular, in our case we‚Äôd probably want to combine fact graphs with some other indicators that our specific to our internal frameworks#2017-04-2120:12wparkerso I‚Äôm looking for composability#2017-04-2120:13wparkerI‚Äôm not clear on what :simple would be - do you mean that if you had A -> B -> C you‚Äôd have a direct edge of A -> C?#2017-04-2120:15wparkerAlso, @devn I‚Äôd be curious about why cytoscape.js versus any other graph visualization options you tried or considered - the visualization layer isn‚Äôt something I know much about yet#2017-04-2121:06devn@wparker I did not directly participate in the decision to use cytoscape, but as I recall it was chosen partly for performance, and partly because it made the traversal of subgraphs relatively easy.#2017-04-2121:06devn@wparker RE: direct edge on A->C, yes, that was what I was thinking#2017-04-2121:07devnor perhaps you have A->[summary collection of intermediate nodes]->C#2017-04-2121:08devnbasically anything to make it easy to skip the display of 382910 nodes and edges that don't actually tell you much that you care to know about getting from A to C#2017-04-2121:09devni think it's often the case that the fact that you got to C suggests everything you'd need to understand about B#2017-04-2121:14devnfor instance, there is a big fan out and fan in between A and C, like A->[B1, B2, B3, B4, B5, BN]->C If C is a specific fact like: MoreThanThreeBs, then who really cares what those Bs were? all I really care about is that by virtue of A, I have the possibility of many Bs, and all I care to know is if I get to state C from A#2017-04-2121:21devnWe have a lot of scenarios where we need to look at hundreds of thousands of facts on our way to a state, but in the end all we really care about is that given a Lab, we determine whether it is normal or abnormal according to a massive set of facts, and then produce an AbnormalLabResult or NormalLabResult. Labl->AbnormalLab/NormalLab is how I'd prefer to view it in a UI rather than render the 500k+ nodes and corresponding edges in between#2017-04-2121:24devnbeing able to express something like: "Provided #{A}, render direct edges to #{C, D} through nodes of type #{B}" would be nice#2017-04-2121:27devnStop me if what I'm saying doesn't make any sense#2017-04-2121:29devnI suppose I imagine that for any collection of rules and facts, there are layers to the view. For instance, I don't care about seeing the source of a rule by default, that's another layer. Similarly, I don't care which specific constraints in that rule were met, unless I do.#2017-04-2121:30wparkerI can see where that would be useful for some rules patterns, yes. I‚Äôm thinking that it probably wouldn‚Äôt be too hard to transform the graph down to that level though?#2017-04-2121:30devn@wparker no, sure, that's doable#2017-04-2121:30devnI'm just listing stuff that I don't think would be totally out of bounds for clara.tools.*#2017-04-2121:31wparkerAh, I see#2017-04-2121:31wparkerBy the way, I think having transformation functions in the fact-graph namespace could be useful, I just haven‚Äôt gotten to that point yet#2017-04-2121:32devnI totally understand for instance, that if you have the raw data, you can do whatever you please, but it would be really nice to not leave that as an exercise for the reader, and instead have a couple of basic built-in tools for specifying what you want to look at#2017-04-2121:32wparkeror other namespace as appropriate as you say ‚Äúclara.tools.*‚Äù#2017-04-2121:33devnLike, a function which dumps graphviz, even if there is no dependency within clara to actually render it, seems like it might be useful#2017-04-2121:34devnand then adding on to that: Dumps graphviz where you specify the starting node (the type of fact), and how many hops should be rendered#2017-04-2121:35devnor: Dumps graphviz, and lets you set the color for nodes based on their fact type#2017-04-2121:35devnetc.#2017-04-2121:35wparkerFor that, I‚Äôm thinking you‚Äôd do something like (-> original-graph remove-intermediate-steps render-to-graphviz)#2017-04-2121:36devnsure, yeah#2017-04-2121:38devnIt would be interesting to generate some anonymized graphs for all of our projects just to get a sense for what transformation functions would be generally useful#2017-04-2121:40devnI know there are Reasons‚Ñ¢ to not include the transformation kitchen sink or unnecessary deps, but I feel like a simple toolkit for rules engine graph generation would be super helpful to have, maybe even as part of core#2017-04-2121:41devnas opposed to an external lib#2017-04-2121:52wparkerYeah, there is often a tradeoff of not tying things together too much versus not providing enough functionality especially if you get into needing other libraries as dependencies. Adding generic data transforms doesn‚Äôt seem like it adds too much burden though since it is very easily ignorable if you don‚Äôt need them#2017-04-2121:55wparkerI‚Äôm guessing the types of transforms needed will depend heavily on the domain. For example, in our case, I think a lot of it would revolve around taking a given fact and showing everything either upstream or downstream from that fact, and potentially ‚Äúbacktracking‚Äù a bit from some joins on that path, but not the rest of the rules session#2017-04-2121:57wparkerIf you have a fact A that flows through rules B->C->D->E->F and you don‚Äôt get the expected F it would be nice to be able to easily see where it ‚Äústopped‚Äù#2017-04-2121:57wparkeror in the case of accumulation how it interacted with other facts in that chain#2017-04-2122:03wparkerThe first step is to make the full data set available for manipulation though#2017-04-2122:03wparkerYou could get most of it from inspect already but not when you go through accumulators#2017-04-2122:03wparkerwhich we use a lot of#2017-04-2808:36puzzlerHow does the performance of Clara queries compare to something like Datascript?#2017-05-0115:33ennCan anyone suggest how I might instrument my rules to figure out which one is throwing an NPE? The NPE is during > during an accumulator‚Äôs reduction which makes me assume it‚Äôs the max accumulator, which I use in only a handful of rules. I‚Äôd like to narrow down which specifically is throwing the exception, but I‚Äôm not sure how I‚Äôd go about putting logging in the LHS of a rule. (The RHS is too late as the accumulators are used only in LHSs.)#2017-05-0116:13zyloxdo you have an example stack trace?#2017-05-0116:17ennyes:#2017-05-0116:19enn@zylox http://paste.lisp.org/display/345606#2017-05-0116:47zyloxya i got nothing unfortunately. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.clj might be of some help#2017-05-0117:28wparker@enn unfortunately errors during accumulation aren‚Äôt handled as well as errors in non-accumulator conditions; https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/265 is logged to improve that (non-accumulator conditions were improved in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/255 )#2017-05-0117:29wparkerIn the meantime your best option is probably to wrap the accumulator in question in a way that indicates what rules you‚Äôre in when it throw an exception#2017-05-0117:30wparkerClara accumulators are just maps containing functions, and the accumulator can be modified by adding a new value onto one of the keys#2017-05-0117:31wparkerYour stacktrace tells me you‚Äôre throwing in the reduce-fn#2017-05-0117:33wparkerSo you could do something like (defn ->wrapped-reduce-fn [original-reduce-fn rule-name] (fn [& args] (try (apply original-reduce-fn args) (catch Exception e (throw (ex-info (str ‚ÄúThrew exception in accumulation in ‚Äù rule-name) {} e))))#2017-05-0117:34wparkerand (defrule [?result-binding <- (update (acc/min :field) :reduce-fn ->wrapped-reduce-fn rule-name) ‚Ä¶#2017-05-0117:35wparkeractually to work with the update you‚Äôd need to reverse the args order of ->wrapped-reduce-fn, but that is the basic idea#2017-05-0117:37wparkerThe problem with tracing is that when you throw an exception and exit the rules firing loop you‚Äôll lose the transient listener that has the info you want#2017-05-0117:37wparkerWhen a RHS exception is thrown we call to-persistent on the listeners but that won‚Äôt happen in an exception during accumulation https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1787#2017-05-0117:38wparkerYou could write your own listener that had global side effects or some such to get around that if you wanted though#2017-05-0117:41wparkerThere are some docs on what the different accum function fields do at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/, you can also look at the structures created at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/accumulators.cljc#2017-05-0117:50ennThank you, the wrapping idea makes sense#2017-05-0117:52ennthough a little clunky as we are not specifying the reduce-fn directly (it‚Äôs created via acc/max and comparison-based)#2017-05-0118:03wparkerYeah, it is clunky, but hopefully if you have just a handful of rules and a particular exception it won‚Äôt be too bad. Obviously not as nice as having built-in error handling i.e. issue 265 but hopefully solves your immediate need#2017-05-1819:42wparkerClara-rules 0.15.0 is released and available on Clojars. Highlights include a variety of improvements to session inspection, including functionality to create a graph data structure of facts to facts they caused to be logically inserted, and a fix to a memory leak that caused the memory to retain references to bindings from retracted facts in some cases.#2017-05-1819:43zyloxüéä#2017-05-1819:46wparkerThe changelog has further details on the changes: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#2017-05-1819:58ryanbrushAwesome, Will!#2017-05-2304:04devn@wparker thank you for all of your work.#2017-05-2304:05devnYou've made my job easier.#2017-05-2410:32nkabrichcan anyone recommend a good tool/library to visualize the output of clara.tools.fact-graph/session->fact-graph?#2017-05-2412:47skurorhizome?#2017-05-2412:48skurohttps://github.com/ztellman/rhizome#2017-05-2609:18puzzlerCan someone point me to documentation about how to construct clara rules dynamically?#2017-05-2611:02nkabrichAFAIK defrule just generates a data structure so you can either build that by hand dynamically or check out clara.rules.dsl/parse-rule#2017-05-2614:13wparker@puzzler There are a number of examples of dynamic rule creation in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj You can also just build the rule data structures yourself if that is more convenient for your use-case; see the schema at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/schema.clj#L62#2017-05-2614:16wparkerYou‚Äôll need to fully qualify reference in your LHS (left-hand side) code if you use that approach, although in the RHS code it will evaluated in the ns you give if you give one as noted in the comment on the schema; that would be good to do in the LHS too, it just hasn‚Äôt been implemented yet#2017-05-2614:40ryanbrushThere is also an example of generating rules from an external DSL on this blog post. Towards the bottom you'll see the Clojure data structure that defines the rules themselves. http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/#2017-05-2614:41ryanbrushBut often just writing defrule for your rules, then looking at the data structure it creates can give you a good idea of what you need, as @nkabrich suggests.#2017-05-2718:55newresoh wow I was just about to ask about dynamic rule creation#2017-05-2718:57newresThe issue I have would be that the list of conditions in the lhs (and some part of the rhs) would be based on the elements of a list that is bound with a condition#2017-05-2718:58newresThe problem is I can not seem to express it right with defrule nor the underlying code datastructure#2017-05-2719:03newresI might be stepping too much over what the rete network does so it might be slow, but if nothing else there should be a way to look into the underying knowledge base for a set of checks the very least based on which I could bind a variable on the right hand side#2017-05-2719:04newresbut this seems like internal stuff to clara the very least#2017-05-2719:29newreswas thinking maybe having a test expression that uses a functon and perhaps some internal way of peering into the current knowledge base, based on which it would return variables#2017-05-2719:43ryanbrush@newres I'm not sure I entirely follow your use case, but it seems possible in principle with some of the rule generation patterns described above. However, I'm not sure I'd suggest that approach if you can avoid it. It might be better to, for example, put the needed data in some structure on the left-hand side, and bind the entire structure to a variable...and then de-structure that variable on the right-hand side to get the nested structure out.#2017-05-2719:52newres@ryanbrush The problem I would have in binding everything and move it to the right hand side is that in the current implementation I need to use the conclusion in the guard.#2017-05-2719:56newres@ryanbrush is there a way on the lhs to reach into the current knowledge base with an expression, without resorting to unification and bindings? Basically with regular programming with some datastructure as a knowledge base the problem is pretty easily solvable, I would not mind skipping any optimizations clara provides just in a few cases.#2017-05-2720:00newres@ryanbrush to describe the problem I have a bit better, suppose I have bound a list to the variable ?L. Based on this list I need to check x number of conditions where x is the length of that list and the conditions vary based the the list elements.#2017-05-2720:07ryanbrushThe left hand side can only see the fact it is analyzing, and previously bound variables. Unfortunately there isn't a way to dynamically peek into the memory more than that...and there isn't a way to really make that visible that will be stable, either, since the order of evaluation of each rule constraint isn't defined, and we use a mutable structure underneath that can change at any time.#2017-05-2720:08ryanbrushGenerating rules ahead of creating the session can be done, but it's not clear whether that helps much. The visibility of the LHS to the fact its evaluating and previous, explicitly bound variables in earlier constraints on the LHS is a pretty firmly build in.#2017-05-2720:09ryanbrushBut you can still bind a list or other structure in one LHS constraint, and then analyze it in a subsequent LHS constraint, if that helps.#2017-05-2720:09ryanbrush...which includes test guards#2017-05-2720:14newresThe problem there is I do not know how I would express the fact that for all elements in that list I need a new slightly different constrained. For example suppose I have in the list 3 variables ?p1, ?p2, ?p3 I would need 3 conditions that check like [T (= ?a s) (= ?p1 p) (= b o)] [T (= ?b s) (= ?p2 p) (= c o)] [T (= ?c s) (= ?p3 p) (= d o)]#2017-05-2720:16newresI can probably generate or write up such rules for the length of x manually if writing it for arbitary lengths is not possible#2017-05-2720:17ryanbrushAnother simpler option (which may or may not work for your needs) is to use an accumulator to match a list of all items of type T, and then analyze that list in your guard.#2017-05-2720:18ryanbrushThe accumulator might not bind anything but the result, so it just passes a list down, and you can call an arbitrarily sophisticated function in the guard to sort it out. Some documentation here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/#2017-05-2720:22newresso I could get all the values of T where the middle variable is a member of the list (In my implementation nearly everything is T, so I need to narrow some things down), than have test as a guard that pretty much checks what the conditions would do in a normal case#2017-05-2720:22ryanbrushYeah, that should work.#2017-05-2720:23ryanbrushIt's probably not the most idiomatic way to structure rules, but we've done things like this as well.#2017-05-2720:24ryanbrushIf you really want to get fancy you can write your own accumulator...but just grabbing everything (or just using simple filters if that works) can get you there.#2017-05-2720:26newresis there a simple way to say that i want [T (= ?b s) (= ?pl p) (= c o)] where ?pl is a member of a list l#2017-05-2720:26ryanbrushYeah, you can pass ?pl to any function on the LHS after it is declared, including checks for inclusion in a list.#2017-05-2720:27newresaha yes that would work, not sure about the efficiency but right now getting it working would be a good step#2017-05-2720:28newresThanks for the help! i am probably pushing clara in some really weird and unexpected ways but the docs really help#2017-05-2720:29ryanbrushCool. Glad I could help and good luck with your system!#2017-05-2720:29newresand the board and the slack, thanks !#2017-05-2914:44nkabrichWhy is this rule creating an infinite loop? I'm trying to insert a "default fact" if no other rule has yet inserted that fact. Or is there a better pattern for this? 
(defrule infinite-loop
  [:not [SomeFact]]
  =>
  (rules/insert! (map->SomeFact {:a 1})))
Also if I add {:salience -1} to this rule, it seems to hang in the LHS? I'm not exactly sure but in any case when I set the salience a (println "looping") in the RHS fails to print and thread hangs.#2017-05-2914:48souenzzonot sure but, i think you can: first accumulate some fact, if it's equal zero, then insert the default.#2017-05-2915:20alex-dixon@ryanbrush Would it be ok to add a Clara channel here? https://discord.gg/v9QMy9D#2017-05-2915:23nkabrich@souenzzo hmm thanks, but I'm still running into an infinite loop using an accumulator and :test to insert a default#2017-05-2915:31alex-dixon@nkabrich Are you using (acc/count)?#2017-05-2915:33alex-dixon
[?nfacts <- (acc/count) :from SomeFact]
[:test (= 0 ?nfacts)]
#2017-05-2915:33alex-dixon?#2017-05-2915:34nkabrich@alex-dixon nope, ill give that a whirl#2017-05-2915:36ryanbrushIf an insert on the RHS causes the LHS to become false, the insert is retracted since it is no longer supported...causing the LHS to become true again and an infinite loop occurs.#2017-05-2915:37ryanbrushThe key is for the RHS insert to not match the LHS. Like check in the LHS for not a default value that the RHS could insert, so it doesn't retract the RHS inserted fact.#2017-05-2915:38ryanbrushYou can also use insert-unconditional to avoid this truth maintenance loop outright, but that can cause other headaches that depend on the order of facts inserted.#2017-05-2915:38nkabrichahh, makes total sense thanks for the explanation.#2017-05-2915:39ryanbrushSure thing. It's probably the biggest pitfall of rules engines like this....but can be overcome with some care#2017-05-2915:41ryanbrush@alex-dixon I'm not familiar with that service. Let me take a look at it later today#2017-05-2915:45alex-dixon@ryanbrush Thanks. There‚Äôs some discussion within the community to converting from Slack to it. Seems like we‚Äôre in a trial period right now. I know from the JS community that Slack‚Äôs message limit is a problem and Discord is generally looked to as the solution (they keep unlimited message history) https://github.com/reactjs/redux for example is a popular JS library that has moved to Discord#2017-05-3015:02ryanbrushAs for the Discord conversation, if the bulk of the Clojure community goes over there then we should go along. That said, I feel like I already have too many collaboration tools I use...so I'll probably only be active on the forums where most of Clojure is. I have no objections if users want to create a Clara channel there...I just won't promise to frequent all of these.#2017-06-0813:35jfntnI‚Äôm not familiar with clara but I‚Äôve been wondering if it could be used to model a HFSM/Statechart by defining a hierarchy of rules?#2017-06-0813:42jfntnI.e. in any given state, only a subset of the engines rules are loaded, and generally you‚Äôd want children states to activate their parent‚Äôs rules#2017-06-0813:44jfntnThe OOP like mechanics can easily be achieved with a custom hierarchy in clojure, but I‚Äôm wondering if scoping rules to their respective state in clara would involve instantiating different rulesets, or dynamically mutating a global rules registry#2017-06-0913:35fabraoWell @jfntn , I used to classify I kind of link status to avoid chains of ifs, but my experience is that it was more complex than I thougth, so I changed to datascript to be more clear and simple#2017-06-0913:36fabraohere is an example what I did 
(defn limite [chave]
  (read-string (chave (:referencia (:config sistema)))))

(defrecord IcmpLocalizacao [nome-link localidade jitter latencia perda])
(defrecord Problema [mensagem nome-link localidade])

(defrule ligacao-fragmentada
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :fragmentada ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule telefonia-degradada
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> jitter (limite :jitter)) (> latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :degradada ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule perda-qualidade
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (> jitter (limite :jitter)) (<= latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :qualidade ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule atraso-telefonia
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (<= jitter (limite :jitter)) (> latencia (limite :latencia)) (<= perda (limite :perda))]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :atraso ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defrule sem-comunicacao
         [?local <- IcmpLocalizacao (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade) (= jitter -1) (= latencia -1) (= perda -1)]
         =>
         (insert! (->Problema :comunicacao_locais ?nome-link ?localidade)))

(defquery problemas-comunicacao []
          [Problema (= ?mensagem mensagem) (= ?nome-link nome-link) (= ?localidade localidade)])

(defn gerar-fatos [fatos]
  (let [regras (atom #{})]
    (doseq [fato fatos]
    (let [link (first (first fato))
          valor (second (first fato))
          localidade (:localidade valor)
          icmp (:icmp valor)
          jitter (:jitter icmp)
          perda (:perda icmp)
          latencia (:latencia icmp)]
    (swap! regras conj (->IcmpLocalizacao link localidade jitter latencia perda))))
    @regras))

(defn compilar-regras [fatos]
  (into #{}
        (-> (mk-session 'correlacao.item.regraslink)
            (insert-all (gerar-fatos fatos))
            (fire-rules)
            (query problemas-comunicacao))))
#2017-06-0913:38fabraoin datascript 
(defn- classificar-elemento [conn tipo op-jitter op-perda op-latencia jitter perda latencia]
  (let [resultado (d/q '[:find ?localidade ?link
                         :in $ ?op-jitter ?op-perda ?op-latencia ?ref-jitter ?ref-perda ?ref-latencia
                         :where 
                         [?e :link ?link]
                         [?e :localidade ?localidade]
                         [?e :jitter ?jitter]
                         [?e :perda ?perda]
                         [?e :latencia ?latencia]
                         [(?op-jitter ?jitter ?ref-jitter)]
                         [(?op-perda ?perda ?ref-perda)]
                         [(?op-latencia ?latencia ?ref-latencia)]
                         ]
                       conn op-jitter op-perda op-latencia jitter perda latencia)]
    (if (= #{} resultado)
      []
      (resultado->set resultado tipo)
      )))
#2017-06-0913:39fabrao(classificar-elemento @conn :fragmentada nevermind > nevermind jitter perda latencia)#2017-06-0913:43fabraoI see that datascript was more flexible, but you can use any other ways to define rules for your job, like in https://github.com/threatgrid/naga or even clojure.logic#2017-06-0917:59mikerod@jfntn I guess I don‚Äôt fully grasp your problem statement#2017-06-0918:00mikerodHowever, Clara has certainly been used in a way that creates logical ‚Äúgroups‚Äù and/or ‚Äúhierarchies‚Äù of rules#2017-06-0918:00mikerodYou can have intermediary facts inserted that act as ‚Äúblockers‚Äù for some rules, or have some rules not be able to be satisfied until certain facts are present#2017-06-0918:01mikerodHowever, this isn‚Äôt done by ‚Äúturning off‚Äù rules or by excluding rules from the rulebase/session created, instead it is done purely through logical relationships the rules express#2017-06-0918:02mikerodAlso, the ‚Äútype‚Äù dispatch function used by Clara rules LHS conditions is pluggable. So you could do things with ad hoc hierarchies of Clojure#2017-06-0918:02mikerodhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2017-06-0918:03mikerodhas some details on the custom ‚Äúfact type‚Äù fn (and similarly the associated ‚Äúancestors‚Äù fn#2017-06-0918:03mikerodI may be speaking way too vague to help answer your question though#2017-06-0918:03jfntnOk interesting, I guess I was wondering if it was valid to consider an approach where the app dynamically loads/unoads a different session depending on some external state machine#2017-06-0918:04mikerodI think @fabrao may have had some interesting points above too. There is a chance that forward-chaining rules aren‚Äôt the best approach to certain sorts of problems#2017-06-0918:05mikerodI would say it is not a good situation to have when your rules end up being of the form: A -> B; B -> C; C -> D; D -> E - when that chain starts to get really long and only one linear flow of logic#2017-06-0918:06mikerod@jfntn well consider one of the compelling strengths of a Rete-based forward chaining rules impl like Clara - it stores a bunch of state to avoid re-calculation of join and non-joining constraints done in previous states of the system#2017-06-0918:06mikerodif you flip from session to session, they will not share any of this state with one another. there is a chance that that is suitable for your needs. I‚Äôm just calling it out.#2017-06-0918:08mikerodAlso, the time to create a session is typically non-trivial if you have a fair number of rules involved. So often the pattern is to keep the sessions in memory. There will be limitations to how many rule sessions you can store in memory at a time. The size of them is mostly dependent on the number or rules and conditions involved#2017-06-0918:08fabraohttps://github.com/hraberg/mimir#2017-06-0918:09jfntnSo I guess I was assuming you could somehow keep the facts but change the rules, not sure if that makes sense in practice#2017-06-0918:09jfntnhttp://blog.cognitect.com/blog/2017/5/22/restate-your-ui-using-state-machines-to-simplify-user-interface-development#2017-06-0918:10mikerod@jfntn you could query the facts produced from a fire-rules execution of a session#2017-06-0918:10jfntnThis article includes this definition for an fsm:#2017-06-0918:10mikerodand you could insert those facts into any other sessoin that uses them#2017-06-0918:10jfntn
(def fsm {'Start          {:init             'Ready}
          'Ready          {:missing-password 'Password-Error
                           :missing-email    'Email-Error
                           :submit           'Submitting}
          'Password-Error {:change-password  'Ready}
          'Email-Error    {:change-email     'Ready}
          'Submitting     {:receive-success  'Success}})
#2017-06-0918:10mikerodI believe I just read this a few days ago#2017-06-0918:10mikerodI hadn‚Äôt really thought much about it though.#2017-06-0918:11jfntnI was imagining something like rules as transitions instead of keywords, and a sort of recursive definition where the Symbols on the right-hand side could be whole FSMs#2017-06-0918:11mikerodHave you found that it is difficult to express the FSM sort of logic just using 1 session?#2017-06-0918:13jfntnWouldn‚Äôt you have to encode the transitions across many rules though? Maybe I just want something that will define a valid session from recursing over this tree#2017-06-0918:14mikerodIt isn‚Äôt immediately clear to me how it would look#2017-06-0918:15mikerodPerhaps this article is enough to go off to make a toy example in Clara with 1 session#2017-06-0918:15mikerodBut it may not be sophisticated enough to show anything useful - I don‚Äôt know#2017-06-0918:16mikerodI‚Äôm just trying to find the simplest solution the the problem and I‚Äôd hope there would be a nice mapping of the idea to a single session. Just to avoid the details of bouncing around between them#2017-06-0918:16mikerodYou could certainly have a map of ‚Äúsession name key‚Äù -> session#2017-06-0918:16mikerodand have RHS‚Äôs produce a fact that says what is the ‚Äúnext session‚Äù to evaluate#2017-06-0918:17mikerodOr to flip that and just have the RHS produce a fact that your outer FSM uses to transition to the next step - I think that is what you said above#2017-06-0918:18fabraoit seems like workflow engine#2017-06-0918:20mikerodFunny#2017-06-0918:20mikerodJBoss had jBPM I think#2017-06-0918:20mikerodwhich basically (I believe) is a FSM sort of system that triggers Drools rules at certain stages#2017-06-0918:20mikerod(among other things)#2017-06-0918:21mikerodSo I guess the idea came up there as well. I‚Äôm still just curious about whether or not a single session can‚Äôt express an FSM in the sense of the web app article though#2017-06-0918:32jfntnSeems like it should be possible, but the article is only trying to represent a single FSM, and to extend that definition to a Statechart you have to imagine that each state on the right is not final but can have recursive fsm definitions.#2017-06-0918:32jfntnYou‚Äôd be able to chart the whole app with something along those lines:#2017-06-0918:32jfntn
(def app-statechart
  {'Visitor
   {:login
    {'LoginForm
     {'Start          {:init 'Ready}
      'Ready          {:missing-password 'Password-Error
                       :missing-email    'Email-Error
                       :submit           'Submitting}
      'Password-Error {:change-password 'Ready}
      'Email-Error    {:change-email 'Ready}
      'Submitting     {:receive-success 'Success}}}
    :signup {... }}
   'User  {...}
   'Admin {...}})
#2017-06-0918:40jfntnThe key distinction is that for a given node in the tree, valid transitions at that state are the union of its and its parents‚Äô transitions (or rules in our case), so rules that are not in this set are illegal#2017-06-0918:51mikerodinteresting#2017-06-0919:16fabraoDont you think clara is too complex for that?#2017-06-0919:19fabraotake a look here https://github.com/vvvvalvalval/datalog-rules#2017-06-0919:20fabraoyou can define many ruleset and apply it in your context, so you can dynamic it for your needs#2017-06-0920:19mikerodThere is no engine there, but I‚Äôm assuming you put it on top of something like datascript#2017-06-0920:19mikerodand I think you end up in a backwards-chaining situation there#2017-06-0920:20mikerodwhich may be find and fit the need. I think it just comes down to what you want out of it.#2017-06-0920:20mikerodalso, you have to consider any performance concerns you may have, clj/cljs support (I think datalog-rules would be fine in either), etc#2017-06-0922:07jfntnNo I think conceptually we do want forward chaining and all the caching goodness from clara, just trying to wrap my head around what type of application-level integration we could have#2017-06-1000:17mikegai@jfntn modeling a statechart should be no problem within a single session -- you just need to gate each rule controlling exit/enter with a "gating condition" that matches the current state.#2017-06-1000:18mikegaiThe state chart syntax you supplied could be operated over and expanded to a set of rules, each of which begins with matching the state from which those entry/exits apply#2017-06-1000:48mikegaiMaybe something like this (in tuple / #precept syntax instead of default Clara): 
(def-tuple-rule ready-exit-missing-password
  [[:app :state :login]]
  [[:login :state :ready]]
  [[_ :missing-email]]
  =>
  (insert-unconditional! [[:login :state :password-error]]))
#2017-06-1000:49mikegaia macro would expand the concise statechart syntax to rules like that.#2017-06-1000:50mikegaiand then of course you could define/derive :missing-email elsewhere#2017-06-1000:50mikegai@jfntn do I have what you're thinking right?#2017-06-2610:19mishagreetings! Is using clara for sessions as small as single UI form ‚Äì an overkill in context of mobile applications (e.g. React Native apps, where performance is more expensive than on desktop websites or backend)?#2017-06-2614:37mikerod@misha It could be. Even if not for performance, it may just be too complex of a tool for the job. What sort of reasons were you thinking that it may be helpful for a single form?#2017-06-2614:37mikerodI guess I wouldn‚Äôt think a form would have enough complex control flow#2017-06-2614:50mishaby form I mean registration/billing/etc. form (just to clarify)#2017-06-2614:51mishaforms can get pretty complex, with all the fetching, autosuggesting, autocompleting, validation, etc.#2017-06-2614:55mishabut what I am really after, is a way to manage lots of state, it can be as complex, as entire application state: think many dependent and independent widgets on the same screen, or even many screens, but with routing implemented with rules too, instead of having it as a standalone thing with its own tools and approaches.#2017-06-2615:23mikerod@misha yeah, that sounds interesting. I don‚Äôt know on the performance concerns. I‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôve heard of someone using Clara on mobile applications to have anything to go off of.#2017-06-2615:24mikerodAlso, precept seems to be using Clara in a somewhat similar way as you describe. However, I‚Äôm not sure it is handling routing.#2017-06-2615:24mikerodhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept#2017-06-2615:25mikerodThe space/time complexity of Clara is going to be reliant on the number of rules, complexity of the join conditions within the rules, and the size of facts in working memory.#2017-06-2615:25mikerodSo you can get a pretty large range of performance characteristics depending on your use-case#2017-06-2615:26mikerodThe tendency of the rules network is to favor time over space. e.g. intermediate match state is saved to avoid recomputing values later. So a space vs time tradeoff.#2017-06-2615:26mikerodIf your working memory state isn‚Äôt prohibitively large though, the space may still be reasonable#2017-06-2615:26mishaI am yet to read into precept, but guys do not hesitate to call it framework, so I am being "careful" there :)#2017-06-2615:29mishaas far as mobile apps performance concerns go, I am worried about cpu speed at the moment, since I was forced to move datascript to a separate RN thread because of pull calls speed on a somewhat large db.#2017-06-2615:31mishaBut I am looking at rule based systems‚Ñ¢ from an application state management pov, which might be only few hundred kvs at most, I think#2017-06-2617:08zyloxEDIT: i need to read better#2017-06-2621:31mikerod@misha well if cpu is your worry than at least Clara favors that over space usage#2017-06-2621:32mikerodIt‚Äôd be cool if you could try it out and report back with how it performs in this mobile case#2017-06-2621:32mikerodNothing stands out to me as being too prohibitive#2017-06-2621:55misha@mikerod first, I need to start thinking in terms of rules, but as soon as will have something to show ‚Äì I'll let you know.#2017-06-2622:00mikerodsounds fun!#2017-06-2622:01mishaopieop#2017-06-2717:11devnhowdy folks -- so, i have a base session which contains a bunch of configuration facts and what-not#2017-06-2717:12devnwhen the application receives a payload, we push those facts into the session and fire rules#2017-06-2717:13devnbut, if we have 10 concurrent requests üò¨#2017-06-2717:13devnwe had been doing these serially via a queue, but design is a-changin' a bit#2017-06-2901:17cflemingHi everyone - I develop Cursive, and I‚Äôve been chatting to @zylox about the possibility of adding support for the Clara macros to Cursive.#2017-06-2901:17cflemingSince Cursive indexes source, it needs some support to understand macro forms - I‚Äôm planning to open an API for that, but that‚Äôs way off since it‚Äôs a large project.#2017-06-2901:18cflemingOne thing I‚Äôm interested in is being able to add support using grammars migrated from specs for macros, since I expect there will be more of them in the future.#2017-06-2901:19cflemingHas anyone investigated or thought about creating specs for the Clara macro forms? That would be a big help in adding support for them to Cursive.#2017-06-2901:19cflemingAs well as selfishly meaning that I can actually try to migrate some macro specs to Cursive - I haven‚Äôt seen any in the wild yet.#2017-06-2901:20cflemingSince the macro forms also seem quite complex, it seems like having specs for them would also be generally useful to developers using Clara.#2017-06-2902:11ryanbrush@cfleming Hey, cool idea. I haven't really used specs for macros yet, but I think it would be straightforward to do so for Clara's macros. The structure is pretty well defined (the defrule and defquery macros already have a schema defining their return values) and has been stable for some time.#2017-06-2902:12cfleming@ryanbrush Nice. So is there actually a grammar for the macros themselves anywhere? I see some railroad docs, but they seem incomplete.#2017-06-2902:12cflemingThe schema I guess is for the returned data, right? Not the actual macros?#2017-06-2902:13ryanbrushWe had written quite a bit of error handling code for malformed defrule macros to make it easier to debug, but we don't have a formal grammer besides the (incomplete) EBNF we used for the railroad docs.)#2017-06-2902:13ryanbrushRight, the schema is for the returned data.#2017-06-2902:13ryanbrushI agree this could be helpful for rule authors.#2017-06-2902:14cflemingAre there examples of Clara rules in any OSS projects? I don‚Äôt work with it myself so I‚Äôm not sure how a lot of the tricky cases (destructuring etc) work.#2017-06-2902:16ryanbrushSort of. The precent project (https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept) uses Clara, but is more of a wrapper so isn't the most common usage.#2017-06-2902:17ryanbrushThe best place for examples is probably the clara-examples project itself: https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/tree/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples#2017-06-2902:18cflemingThanks, I‚Äôll take a look at those.#2017-06-2909:45flipmokidHi, I'd like to use Clara in my app which uses Component. I'm currently scratching my head on how I can create a rule that when matched writes to a channel supplied by Component when the application starts. Would anyone be able to give me guidance on how I might do it?#2017-06-2916:00flipmokidOkay silly me, I'm adding the required components as facts and I can pull them out as needed in the rule for use in the right hand side.#2017-06-2916:09zyloxi thought as much but i didnt know enough about Component to say anything haha#2017-06-2921:40devn@cfleming FWIW, I have a cursive license, we have 100s of hand-written rules, and would be happy to be a guinea pig#2017-06-2921:42devni could also share sanitized rules#2017-06-3010:10flipmokidHopefully a quick one, I'm using clara with :fact-type-fn (fn [[e a _]] a). I'm inserting a bunch of facts e.g. 
(rules/insert-all session [[1 :event/eventTypeId 1]
                                          [1 :state/timeElapsed 19]
                                          [2 :event/eventTypeId 1]
                                          [2 :state/timeElapsed 23]])
to match with an example rule of 
(def football-over-20-mins-rule
  (clara-dsl/parse-rule
   [[:event/eventTypeId [[e a v]] (= 1 v) (= ?e e)]
    [:state/timeElapsed [[e a v]] (> v 20) (= ?time v) (= ?e e)]]
   (println "Event " ?e " has gone over 20 mins with " ?time)))
At some point I want to retract all facts for a given 'e', as the event might have finished and I want to keep my facts lean. What is the best way of collecting all facts for matching 'e' so that I can retract them all?#2017-06-3012:42ryanbrush@flipmokid Your best bet is probably to write a query (via defquery) to get all facts for a given e, and then use retract to remove them. There isn't a retract-all (yet), but since it's a multi-arity function you can call it arbitrarily like (apply retract session [my-facts])#2017-06-3012:46flipmokidSorry, it's probably my bad understanding of rules but for my [e a v] fact type how would I get all e's out. As far as I understand the first part of a rule is the type (which is a) and so I'm not sure how I would specify how to pull all entities of a particular number. I'm currently inserting a fact [e :event/retract true] and then trying to find these [:event/retract [[e a v]] (= v true) (= ?e e)] but not sure how to get all matching facts that have the same e#2017-06-3012:58flipmokidI guess I just need someone to help me understand how to write a rule/query that can pull the e's (it's having to write the type at the start that is throwing me). I'm not sure if I can check for the :event/retract fact and then have an accumulator to get all e's for it#2017-06-3013:08ryanbrushI think I see the sticking point here. You'll probably want to match a query on a special "parent" type of all (you can use clojure.core/derive to declare a parent type, which Clara will honor if it's done before the session is created.) Then the query can have a predicate to match on whatever subset you want.#2017-06-3013:09ryanbrush...or I suppose you could just have your fact match on java.lang.Object (assuming your running the Clojure rather than the ClojureScript version) and have your predicate check that.#2017-06-3013:31flipmokidI'm not sure derive will be of much help. For a fact [e a v] e will always be a number (the id of the sporting event) which is not known in advance, a will be the attribute and v can be anything e.g. [1 :state/timeElapsed 19] So do you think if I wanted to stick with my tuple-shaped facts it would be difficult to extract all es of the same value if my fact-type-fn is (fn [[e a v]] a)? Out of interest do you know how Precept handles retractions of its tupled shaped facts?#2017-06-3013:36ryanbrushIf you know the values of a ahead of time then it derive could work, but might be painful to derive all of that. But a defquery approach might work like:#2017-06-3013:37ryanbrush`(defquery [:e-to-remove] [Object [my-tuple] (= ?e-to-remove (first my-tuple))])#2017-06-3013:37ryanbrushHaven't actually tried that, but it's an idea to try with. I'm not familiar with how Precept handles this sort of thing.#2017-06-3013:38flipmokidThat looks interesting, let me give it a go#2017-06-3013:41ryanbrushSounds good. There are some steps I left out...you'll want to return the full tuples from the query, for instance, so they can be retracted.#2017-06-3013:58flipmokidActually, I'm not sure the Object part will match as I'm not using the type function (please let me know if I'm being stupid though, I often am!) (defquery [:e-to-remove] [Object [my-tuple] (= ?e-to-remove (first my-tuple))])#2017-06-3014:10ryanbrushAh, of course. You'll need a custom ancestors function to complement the custom type function. There is an example here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2017-06-3014:10ryanbrushSo your custom ancestor could just return :all-facts if you wanted to match everything. üòâ#2017-06-3014:11ryanbrush(:all-facts is just an arbitrary keyword here that could be returned by the ancestors function.)#2017-06-3014:48flipmokidAh okay. I'll try that. Thanks for your help so far, I really appreciate it#2017-06-3015:22flipmokidBrilliant that worked! 
(def retractions-rule
  (clara-dsl/parse-rule
   [[:event/retract [[e a v]] (= v true) (= e ?e)]
    [?elems <- (acc/all) :from [::all [[e _ _]] (= e ?e)]]]
   (println "RETRACTION MATCHED " ?elems)))
Many thanks for your help#2017-06-3015:33ryanbrushNice!#2017-07-0213:06ryanbrushJust released clara-rules 0.15.1! Details in the change log: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0151#2017-07-0613:37souenzzoCan I write a rule that check if there is some other rule that match facts of type x#2017-07-0613:37souenzzo?#2017-07-0614:01zyloxunless you fed rules into the session as facts, not that i know of#2017-07-0614:01zyloxif you had the rules stored somewhere your right hand side could execute some sort of static introspection i guess#2017-07-0800:53dragoncubeWithing REPL are newly defined rules are picking up? I create session with mk-session and :cache false#2017-07-0801:28ryanbrushmk-session should pick up new rules in the REPL. It will only look in the current namespace, though, unless you are explicitly passing namespaces.#2017-07-0806:34dragoncube@ryanbrush so I need to call mk-session again? if so, is there any way to transfer facts from one session to another? or maybe fire-rules would be enough?#2017-07-0814:55ryanbrushYou'll need to pass in your facts into the new session again. Clara won't do this automatically, but I usually reload the facts or keep them in a list.#2017-07-0821:03dragoncubeI see, so I need to write small wrapper for insert-fact, retract-fact which would store facts in separate collection. Then use this collection then I need to re-init session.#2017-07-0821:27ryanbrushYes, that would do it.#2017-07-0821:44dragoncubeThanks!#2017-07-1317:22fmjreyHi, new to clara here, and having difficulties with query parameters, is there an example of query with parameters that I could look at somewhere?#2017-07-1317:32nickowsyhey @fmjrey, have you taken a look at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples?#2017-07-1317:32fmjreyyes I did, unless I missed it I have only seen query without params#2017-07-1317:35nickowsyahh, that could be. A very simple example 
(defquery get-promotions
  "Query to find promotions for the purchase."
  [:?type]
  [?promotion <- Promotion (= ?type type)])
#2017-07-1317:35nickowsy
(query session get-promotions :?type :lunch)
#2017-07-1317:35nickowsythat example is from the docs. Are you trying to do something more complicated?#2017-07-1317:36fmjreyyeah I saw that example, and now looking at this: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/cbecbdf916625a46ee93e7c84ed411aab3f1dbc1/src/test/clojure/clara/test_java.clj#L51#2017-07-1317:37fmjreythis is a java based example, which looks like it uses strings as map keys, will try that now#2017-07-1319:07fmjreyI think I found the issue, I use query variables in some nested part of the expression, as the long error message says.#2017-07-1319:09fmjreyBasically this does not work: 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?type :?name :?data]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor [?type ?name ?data])])
#2017-07-1319:09fmjreyBut this does: 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?d]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor ?d)])
#2017-07-1319:10fmjreyThanks @nickowsy for trying üôÇ#2017-07-1319:13nickowsyüëç#2017-07-1321:53wparker@fmjrey the params have to be in the query conditions 
(defquery get-feature
  [:?type :?name :?data]
  [?feature <- Feature (= descriptor [?type ?name ?data])])
is trying to use bindings in the Feature condition without creating them#2017-07-1321:53wparkerthe use in the params doesn‚Äôt create them, that is for indexing into the query results later#2017-07-1321:55wparkerBasically the query params won‚Äôt make an otherwise-invalid query valid, they just control how you‚Äôll view the data later when using the query results#2017-07-1321:57wparkerSo in the ‚Äúpromotion type‚Äù example in the doc, you‚Äôll provide a type to query for, and you‚Äôll only get results back of that type; without the param you‚Äôd get back other types as well#2017-07-1321:57wparkerThis is the key line of code: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1960#2017-07-1323:40dadairIs there a way to react to retractions? I'm using facts to generate tree manipulation functions (i.e., if FactA, AddChildToSomeTree), and want to be able to remove that tree node if the Fact is retracted#2017-07-1400:50dadairSorry I should add that these are automatic retractions of derived/sourced facts#2017-07-1414:54wparker@dadair it sounds like you‚Äôre describing truth maintenance so perhaps that will meet your needs http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/#2017-07-1719:31wparkerclara-rules 0.15.2 is released and on Clojars. This was a fix release for a bug in the distinct accumulator.#2017-07-2016:10mishagreetings! What can I read on combining event sourcing with rule engines? Or about any rules<-> (finite) state machines transitions.#2017-07-2422:55wparker@misha you might try the Google Groups mailing list as well, I know some people have considered using Clara for event processing before. Regarding finite state machines, keep in mind that Clara supports arbitrary code, notably in the RHS (consequences) of rules, so the ability to introspect is limited if your application doesn‚Äôt add further restrictions.#2017-07-2508:16misha@wparker thanks, will check it out. to have a real life value, FSMs need to support arbitrary code (i/o) execution as part (or as a consequence) of the state's transitions as well, so that comes down to a design decisions in both cases. In the exercise app I am (re)writing now - html5 video/audio tags are basically i/o, as far as the rest of the buttons in UI are concerned, despite those tags being their own FSMs.#2017-07-2621:27wparker@U051HUZLD I was thinking of mainly what types the rules could insert; given an arbitrary set of rules one can‚Äôt infer which other rules a given rule could trigger. It is possible to add metadata of some kind specifying this or to parse it if you restrict the RHS code you write to something you can reliably parse. This seemed possibly relevant if you were trying to translate rules to a FSM, specifically w.r.t. the allowed state transitions.#2017-07-2516:08iku000888Is it possible to use protocol methods in the left hand side of rules?#2017-07-2516:09iku000888I have a vague feeling it would violate clara's design but cannot articulate why üôÇ#2017-07-2516:12ryanbrushYes, the LHS supports arbitrary Clojure expressions, including protocol methods.#2017-07-2516:20iku000888Would you be kind to give an example?#2017-07-2516:21iku000888Having trouble wrapping my head around how to refer to the instance showing up in the LHS#2017-07-2516:22iku000888
(defprotocol IFoo
  (test-foo [this]))

(defrule is-foo
  [IFoo (test-foo ?not sure how to express?)]
  =>...)
#2017-07-2516:23iku000888@ryanbrush Thanks for the help in advance üôÇ#2017-07-2516:24ryanbrush@iku000888 Ahh, I thought you meant calling protocol-based methods on the LHS. The type the rules matches needs to be an actual type, either a Java type or a Clojure type via deftype.#2017-07-2516:25ryanbrush(The one exception is customized "types" discussed here, but this probably isn't applicable to your discussion: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/)#2017-07-2516:26ryanbrushOne correction: I meant clojure.core/derive rather than deftype above.#2017-07-2516:26iku000888I think I understand#2017-07-2516:27iku000888Just thought at first glance I could reify a bunch of stuff and passing it through rules would be a usecase#2017-07-2516:28iku000888Thanks for clarifying! Much appreciate your time.#2017-07-2516:28iku000888üôá#2017-07-2516:33iku000888
(defprotocol IFoo
  (test-foo [this]))

(deftype Foo []
  IFoo
  (test-foo [this] true))

(defrule is-foo
  [Foo (test-foo ?not sure how to express?)]
  => (println "is a foo"))
#2017-07-2516:33iku000888Wait, so if it is an actual type I can invoke protocol methods?#2017-07-2621:39wparkerHeads up about something potentially tricky: If you‚Äôre on the JVM when you create a protocol, behind the scenes Clojure creates a corresponding Java interface of the same name. An interface is a type that you can write rules against, but it might not do what you expect.
