Only types that Clojure knows satisfy the protocol at the time of their creation will implement the interface. For example:#2017-07-2621:40wparker
` user=> (defprotocol MyProtocol (proto-method [_]))
MyProtocol
user=> (defrecord MyRecord1 [] MyProtocol (proto-method [_] "Hello World"))
user.MyRecord1
user=> (defrecord MyRecord2 [])
user.MyRecord2
user=> (extend-type MyRecord2 MyProtocol (proto-method [_] "Hi World"))
nil
user=> (proto-method (->MyRecord1))
"Hello World"
user=> (proto-method (->MyRecord2))
"Hi World"
user=> (instance? user.MyProtocol (->MyRecord1))
true
user=> (instance? user.MyProtocol (->MyRecord2))
false
`#2017-07-2621:42wparkerIn another ns you could potentially import the interface rather than the protocol depending on how you set up your ns header i.e. import vs require on it#2017-07-2621:43wparker@iku000888#2017-07-2702:07iku000888@wparker thanks! Did not know about that.#2017-07-2516:33iku000888@ryanbrush#2017-07-2516:35ryanbrushYes, if Foo is a type, you should be able to invoke the test-foo protocol method on it like you show.#2017-07-2516:35iku000888(defrule is-foo [Foo (test-foo this)] => (println "is a foo"))#2017-07-2516:36iku000888Works!#2017-07-2516:37iku000888Thanks again and sorry for the noob noise üôá#2017-07-2516:37ryanbrushSure thing! I'm glad it works for you.#2017-07-2516:38ryanbrushJust be aware you might have to reload your rules if you redefine the types in a REPL, since the type will change when you do that. üòâ#2017-07-2516:38iku000888üëç#2017-07-2517:07iku000888@ryanbrush blogged about my first glance of clara-rules (for people in Japan) and thanked you there. Hope that is okay.#2017-07-2517:07iku000888http://qiita.com/iku000888/items/72525cd34cd3c0b44b31#2017-07-2518:14ryanbrush@iku000888 Nice! Thanks for blogging about our little project. üòâ#2017-07-2616:51iku000888The first impression motivated me to learn more abt clara-rules and thus another blogpost with a personally cooked up example http://qiita.com/iku000888/items/17ad5f7fa2f0da069997#_reference-37f1c943ec03175da6b6#2017-07-2721:07iku000888Man one can write so many blogs out of clara-rules! (This one shows it can be used for cross entity join logic) http://qiita.com/iku000888/items/7bb53bd3af51ea2e9e68#2017-07-2721:09iku000888I am about to start this project with a gigantic hari-bally specification and feel like clara-rules is a great match. Going to explore more!#2017-07-2818:50nickowsyhi, I'm new to clara and I'm having a bit of trouble understanding clara's durability. I'm serialize the data, storing the rule base separately. When I restore everything, insert new facts, and fire-rules...my rules are not running again. Rules fire great if I use the original session. i.e. not the one that was restored. I have been looking at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_durability.clj and my broken test is at https://github.com/nfox2004/clara-durability/blob/master/test/clara_durability_help/core_test.clj. Any suggestions would be awesome! thanks#2017-07-2819:38wparker@nickowsy from a quick glance over your test I see your original session has a custom :fact-type-fn. You‚Äôll need to supply the same :fact-type-fn that the original function had when deserializing the rulebase. See the 2-argument version of deserialize-rulebase: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/durability.clj#L653#2017-07-2819:38wparkerSo something like (deserialize-rulebase session-serializer {:fact-type-fn your-fact-type-function})#2017-07-2819:41wparkerThe reason it is that way is that arbitrary Clojure function objects aren‚Äôt serializable, so you have to either impose some kind of restriction on the functions used that gives you serializability or require the user to handle it; we went with the latter#2017-07-2820:11nickowsy@wparker thanks a ton! makes total sense üôÇ#2017-07-2823:01dadairNot sure if this question goes against the design of fact-based systems, but is there a way to "update" a fact? That is, say we insert ->Fact x, and then we insert ->Fact y, is it possible to only get a single Fact with updated value y in a query?#2017-07-2823:05dadairconcrete example: 
(-> (handle test-file test-action) (r/query fields-for :?formRef "/forms/aae-form"))
=>
({:?formRef "/forms/aae-form",
  :?fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
  :?field #{#justice.rules.forms.FormField{:formRef "/forms/aae-form",
                                           :fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
                                           :descriptor {:type "VALUE",
                                                        :valueType "STRING",
                                                        :value "foo",
                                                        :constraints {:minLength 1, :required true}}}
            #justice.rules.forms.FormField{:formRef "/forms/aae-form",
                                           :fieldRef "/forms/aae-form/data/order/reason",
                                           :descriptor {:type "VALUE",
                                                        :valueType "STRING",
                                                        :value "",
                                                        :constraints {:minLength 1, :required true}}}}})
I'd like the query to return all FormField's with unique :fieldRef; so in the above example if I update the :descriptor :value from "" to "foo", I only want the single fact returned#2017-07-2916:09zyloxGenerational data is kind of tricky. I think you could do what you want though (assuming im understanding) if, externally, you have some way to track "newest", having some sort of version field (whether this is datetime or incremented or whatever). Then, in the rules network, have an accumulator for the "newest" value of that field, and insert ->NewestFact and then depend on that instead. Logical retractions should take care of the rest. @dadair#2017-07-2916:11zyloxi just realized you probably meant internal insertions not external.#2017-07-2916:14zyloxif its internal (so inserting on the rhs), thats trickier because in my experience execution order dependent rules get you in trouble real quick, and without that i'm not sure how you would know what fact is "newer". If your goal is actually whatever fact has the most fields populated, you could still do a check on that in the accumulator, or probably better with rules with checks on the fields you care about.#2017-08-0500:24mrchanceHi! Is it possible to cause side effects when a fact gets retracted by the truth maintenance mechanism? I am building something that builds a network of core.async pipes and am thinking about establishing and severing connections based on Clara facts.#2017-08-0522:28mikerod@mrchance could you just make a :not style ‚Äúnegation rule‚Äù to logically handle the condition you are going for?#2017-08-0522:29mikerodWhatever you are wanting to monitor for being logically retracted via truth maintenance. It seems you should be able to make an explicit rule looking for that situation#2017-08-0522:35mikerodHowever, this side-effect of severing connections would certainly have to be resilient to any issues of being executed multiple times on the RHS. don‚Äôt rely on it only being ‚Äúcalled once‚Äù#2017-08-0600:34mrchance@mikerod hm, ok. Idempotency shouldn't be an issue, good hint though. Gonna try that, although I am not 100% clear on how you mean that. In my use case, there would be rules that produce a [Linked a b] fact which would call something like core.async/pipe on a and b, only it returns something that can be called or closed when the respective Linked fact goes away in order to sever the connection again. How would I address that using :not rules?#2017-08-0600:37mrchanceClara is awesome btw. ! Played with it a bit more in the meantime#2017-08-0600:42mikerod@mrchance an alternative that comes to mind is to hook into Clara‚Äôs listeners to try to watch for the particular retraction you are interested in. However, I‚Äôd probably say it is best if that isn‚Äôt necessary.#2017-08-0600:42mikerodI hate to suggest things like insert-unconditional! but I see an approach with that at least‚Ä¶#2017-08-0600:43mikerodI‚Äôd like to think of something better though#2017-08-0600:43mrchanceYeah, I saw the ns in the docs and thought about that#2017-08-0600:43mikeroddemo:#2017-08-0600:45mikerod
(defrule makes-chan
  [?a <- A]
  [?b <- B]
  =>
  (let [chan (somehow-make it)]
    ;; Not sure what you do with `chan` here
    (r/insert! (->LogicalThing ?a ?b))
    (r/insert-unconditional! (->OpenedChan chan))))

(defrule closes-chan
  [:not [LogicalThing]]
  [?oc <- OpenedChan (= ?chan chan)]
  =>
  (r/retract! ?oc)
  (close-the ?chan))
#2017-08-0600:46mikerodI think it just gets sort of dirty when you are managing your own unconditional facts and retracts - typically a pattern to avoid#2017-08-0600:47mikerodnot sure how prevalent this would be for you though in terms of managing it. also, not positive my solution is really a solution to the issue at all#2017-08-0600:47mrchanceOk, I can see what you're getting at, but I agree it looks suboptimal#2017-08-0600:47mikerodClara has a listener protocol you can attach onto#2017-08-0600:47mikerodand I believe you can find the relevant retract events there#2017-08-0600:47mikerodnot sure there have been docs posted up on that#2017-08-0600:48mrchanceNot many, from what I browsed yet üòâ#2017-08-0600:48mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/listener.cljc#2017-08-0600:49mikerodThe ITransientEventListener#2017-08-0600:50mikerodeven when looking at this though, I think it is perhaps opaque which retraction you‚Äôd want to listen to#2017-08-0600:50mrchanceHm, maybe. I'll give it a try#2017-08-0600:50mikerodI believe (retract-facts! [listener facts]) & (retract-facts-logical! [listener node token facts]) would have the info#2017-08-0600:51mikerodretract-facts! I believe is retracts from the RHS and retract-facts-logical! is retracts from truth maintenance#2017-08-0600:51mikerodother ‚Äúretract‚Äù things I believe are more internal node-to-node activity#2017-08-0600:51mrchanceAh, ok#2017-08-0600:52mrchanceThanks! I'll test it #2017-08-0600:53mikerod(mk-session rules :listeners [my-listener-impl])#2017-08-0600:53mrchanceI think there is some big potential here, like a completely reactive description of stateful systems, something that's always awful when it moves past what e.g. component can handle #2017-08-0600:53mrchanceThat's simple enough üòâ #2017-08-0600:54mikerodyeah, it isn‚Äôt actually documented on mk-session, not sure why. I don‚Äôt think those ns‚Äôs are really called ‚Äúexperimental‚Äù around this at this point#2017-08-0600:56mikerodthe only thing I‚Äôm concerned about is if you do not impl all the functions of the protocol#2017-08-0600:56mikerodI can‚Äôt remember if you have to ‚Äúpad‚Äù those with a no-op in some way#2017-08-0600:56mrchanceTypical case of documentation not growing as fast as its software#2017-08-0600:56mrchanceShouldn't be a problem, it's a one time thing so some boilerplate is no issue#2017-08-0600:57mikerodthere is the clara.rules.listener/default-listener though#2017-08-0600:57mikerodyou could just delegate everything else through that#2017-08-0600:57mikerodbut it‚Äôs just a no-op#2017-08-0600:57mikerodyeah, idk. I‚Äôve done stuff with this before too. I just can‚Äôt remember#2017-08-0600:57mrchanceOk, then actually delegating is probably more work ;)#2017-08-0600:57mikerodhah yes#2017-08-0600:58mikerodI could have swore there was a smoother way#2017-08-0600:58mrchanceI think this one is good enough, if it works#2017-08-0600:58mikerod> I think there is some big potential here, like a completely reactive description of stateful systems, something that‚Äôs always awful when it moves past what e.g. component can handle That is cool though#2017-08-0600:59mrchanceYeah#2017-08-0600:59mikerodwould be interesting to hear what success you have with that#2017-08-0600:59mrchanceSure, I'll let you know#2017-08-0601:00mikerodbtw, looks like precept uses Clara :listeners when I did a quick GitHub search#2017-08-0601:00mikerodhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/6d919a91f846c9e5ca2d53384efe4da7981f1914/src/cljc/precept/listeners.cljc#2017-08-0601:01mikerodI knew they were doing interesting things in using Clara for app state mgmt (may be saying that wrong)#2017-08-0601:01mrchanceRight, I stumbled across that too #2017-08-0601:01mikerodthey impl‚Äôed the protocols though and included the no-ops#2017-08-0601:02mrchanceProbably going to have a look into their code, I like the idea of precept as well#2017-08-0601:05mikerodyeah, I‚Äôve wanted to look at that codebase sometime soon#2017-08-0601:05mikerodseems like some interesting stuff#2017-08-0605:18wparkerSeveral people have had use cases that sounded like what they were looking for was the ability to get the changes in query results relative to an earlier state, and it sounds like that sort of functionality might be what you‚Äôre looking for as well @mrchance . That could be done with some wrappers in your code around the session along the lines of ‚ÄúQuery the session, store the results, insert/retract facts, fire the rules, then query again and diff the results‚Äù. It could be done as a Clara listener too by tracking on the listening calls in QueryNode: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.15.2/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L430#2017-08-0605:22wparkerIt is functionality that I think would be useful for Clara itself to provide at some point, a listener to do that would probably get into Clara‚Äôs internal impl details somewhat e.g. ‚Äúis this node a QueryNode?‚Äù logic. Wouldn‚Äôt matter if it was part of Clara and tested there though.#2017-08-0613:10mrchance@wparker True, that's another way to look at it. This might work too. Your answer also makes me wonder if Datascript would be the better choice for this usecase though, since there you get the transaction logs anyway#2017-08-0714:03wparkerI haven‚Äôt had occasion to use DataScript, but it also seems like something that could be useful for a use-case like what you describe @mrchance . I suspect much depends on what the simplest way to model the logic you have in mind is and what performance characteristics you‚Äôre looking for.#2017-08-0717:20mrchanceYes, it all depends on the details. From the FactUi readme it looks like they took a bit from both worlds as well#2017-08-0702:00mikerod https://github.com/arachne-framework/factui Looks like more fun with rules (and Clara)#2017-08-1310:20Oliver GeorgeI'm interested in how Clara (or rule engines more generally) would work in an environment where a relational database is used as the repository of all information.#2017-08-1310:20Oliver GeorgeI'm only learning about this stuff so I could be missing something obvious.#2017-08-1310:22Oliver GeorgePerhaps the key is not letting anyone directly write to the database which would bypassing the rule engine causing it to get out of sync with reality.#2017-08-1310:23Oliver GeorgeA simple "typical architecture" might answer my question.#2017-08-1319:51hagmonkCan anyone explain why the following case doesn't do what I expect?#2017-08-1319:52hagmonk
(let [matched    (dsl/parse-rule
                   [[:eav
                     (= ?attribute (:attribute this))
                     (= ?attribute_value (:attribute_value this))
                     (= ?id (:id this))]]
                   (insert! {:type ?attribute :id ?id :value ?attribute_value}))

      unscreened (dsl/parse-rule
                   [[:state
                     (= (:value this) 2)
                     (= ?id (:id this))]
                    [:milestone
                     (= (:value this) -1)
                     (= ?id (:id this))]]
                   (insert! {:type :unscreened :id ?id}))

      type-query (dsl/parse-query [] [[?unscreened <- :unscreened]])

      session    (mk-session [matched unscreened type-query] :fact-type-fn :type :cache false)]
  (time (-> session
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :state :attribute_value 2 :id 33695360})
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :milestone :attribute_value -1 :id 33695360})
            fire-rules
            (insert {:type :eav :attribute :milestone :attribute_value 123456 :id 33695360})
            fire-rules
            (query type-query))))
#2017-08-1319:52hagmonkI insert two facts which cause a third fact of type :unscreened to be inserted#2017-08-1319:53hagmonkI then fire the rules, and insert another fact which should negate the earlier fact#2017-08-1319:53hagmonkInstead, when I query the session for :unscreened, I see that fact still present#2017-08-1415:18curtis.shaffer@olivergeorge authorization on the database is something that can be done; certain databases (Oracle is the one that comes to mind) support triggers which you could use to detect changes#2017-08-1415:22curtis.shaffer@hagmonk as far as I can tell, all three of those facts will still be in the session; the 3rd fact insertion does not negate the 2nd fact insertion. the :id field makes me think that you want it to be an update, which is not what is done#2017-08-1415:38zylox@hagmonk What Curtis said. You could use an accumlator to grab the highest valued :milestone fact. or if you are looking for all non negative, you could add a :not constraint. Depends on what you are looking for.#2017-08-1417:50wparker@olivergeorge it might help if you can clarify your question. From Clara‚Äôs point of view, it doesn‚Äôt matter what the ultimate source of the data it processes is. Note though that if rules do things that depend on ordering you have to be careful since Clara can fire and then retract a rule; the contract when using truth maintenance is that the state of the rules engine works out before fire-rules returns. But if you, say, performed operations on a database in a rule RHS you‚Äôd have to be careful about controlling rule ordering with salience etc. Our workflows typically involve something retrieving data, providing the data to Clara, firing the rules, querying the resulting session, and then saving the query results - does that help?#2017-08-1504:38Oliver GeorgeYes thanks. That makes sense. #2017-08-1513:44souenzzoI can/I should run a query inside a rule? (query the "self")#2017-08-1515:03mikerod@souenzzo it isn‚Äôt clear to me what you are trying to do#2017-08-1515:03mikerodCurrently you can‚Äôt run a query directly from within a rule#2017-08-1515:03mikerodbut it‚Äôd probably be good to have some sort of example of what you are trying to accomplish or thinking about#2017-08-1515:06souenzzoI was trying to run a query on "right side" of a defrule. But I already find another solution.#2017-08-1720:07ennCan an accumulator accumulate across more than one fact type (joined on some field)? All of the examples show only a single fact type in the :from clause.#2017-08-1722:20wparker@enn Strictly speaking no, but with a custom ancestors fn you can create a new type that is the parent of multiple types for whatever fact types you‚Äôre working with#2017-08-1722:21wparkerSame goes for other condition types as well#2017-08-1722:21wparkere.g. if you have FactTypeA and FactTypeB, you can make FactTypeC a parent of both#2017-08-1722:22wparkerthen [?facts <- (acc/all) :from [FactTypeC (‚Ä¶)]] would accumulate on both FactTypeA and FactTypeC#2017-08-1722:22wparkersee http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ for more info#2017-08-1722:45ennInteresting.#2017-08-1722:45ennI hadn‚Äôt thought of that approach.#2017-08-1722:47wparkerEdit: ‚Äúwould accumulate on both FactTypeA and FactTypeB‚Äù#2017-08-1804:51iku000888Has anyone tried using clara-rules via a self hosted cljs compiler?#2017-08-1804:52iku000888I run into errors like this#2017-08-1804:52iku000888
cljs.user=> (require 'clara.rules)
            ‚¨Ü
WARNING: macroexpand already refers to: cljs.core/macroexpand being replaced by: clojure.reflect/macroexpand at line 33 clojure/reflect.cljs
                     ‚¨Ü

                     ‚¨Ü

                           ‚¨Ü

              ‚¨Ü

#2017-08-1804:53iku000888I was testing out calvin and have a pretty tiny repro, if there is interest.#2017-08-1805:11iku000888https://github.com/iku000888/tiny-samples/tree/master/node-and-cljs#2017-08-1815:28wparker@iku000888 supporting self-hosted ClojureScript in Clara isn‚Äôt something we‚Äôve looked at to my knowledge, and I would anticipate that changes would need to be made to support it. If anyone has gotten that to work it would be interesting to know though. From the looks of your errors Schema has some problems with self-hosted ClojureScript as well, so there might need to be changes there as well for self-hosted CLJS Clara to work. Feel free to log an issue to Clara and anyone who wants to look at what that would take is welcome to do so. It would be nice to have, it just hasn‚Äôt been a priority. I canof how Schema would approach any problems with self-hosted ClojureScript in their codebase,#2017-08-1815:29wparkerI can‚Äôt speak to how Schema would approach any problems with self-hosted ClojureScript in their codebase, and I don‚Äôt know if there have been any previous discussions on the subject, but in my observation they‚Äôve been pretty open to PRs, issues, etc. in the past#2017-08-1815:30iku000888@wparker thanks for the feedback!#2017-08-1815:31iku000888Will log an issue on the clara repo and schema (after checking they have an issue on self host)#2017-08-1815:32iku000888Would be super cool if self host support lands though, just saying üôÇ#2017-08-1815:42iku000888https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/337#2017-08-1815:42iku000888@wparker Is there is anything else I can provide?#2017-08-1815:49wparkerthat works thanks @iku000888#2017-08-1815:49iku000888Thanks again!#2017-08-1815:52wparkerThere would need to be some changes to Clara as well for this, not just Schema. A quick one that jumps out is that clara.rules.compiler is a clj file and has a java.beans.PropertyDescriptor import#2017-08-1815:52wparkerhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L1#2017-08-1815:52wparkerThat‚Äôs the compiler from rules/queries to an executable structure#2017-08-1820:52mikerod@enn I‚Äôll add on more possibility to this: > Can an accumulator accumulate across more than one fact type (joined on some field)? All of the examples show only a single fact type in the :from clause. You can also ‚Äúwrap‚Äù multiple types of facts in a common fact type and accumulate instead on that.#2017-08-1820:52mikerodwithout a need of actually creating a real ancestor, hierarchical change#2017-08-1820:55mikerod
(defrecord CommonWrap [wrapped])

(r/defrule wrap-fact-a
[?a <- FactA]
=>
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?a)))

(r/defrule wrap-fact-b
[?b <- FactB]
=>
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?b)))


(r/defrule accum-them
[?acc <- my-accumulator :from [CommonWrap]]
<etc>
=>
<rhs>)
#2017-08-1820:56mikerodthe accumulator could just access the original, field ‚Äúx‚Äù, like (-> w :wrapped :x)#2017-08-1820:56mikerodor you could make it have the same fields as the original even with 
(r/insert! (->CommonWrap ?a))
#2017-08-1820:58mikerod> There would need to be some changes to Clara as well for this, not just Schema. Yeah, I think clara.rules.compiler would probably require the most work on self-hosting#2017-08-1820:58mikerod(aside from schema breaking clara anyways)#2017-08-1820:59mikerodunless there is a way to just not use the schema on the self-host side#2017-08-1820:59mikerodI think technically, the schema are just used for testing and documentation purposes#2017-08-1820:59mikerodbut wouldn‚Äôt be too trivial I don‚Äôt think still#2017-08-1820:59mikerodAlso, the ‚Äúdurability‚Äù feature of Clara would likely have trouble#2017-08-1821:00mikerodbut may not be needed anyways and probably could just be skipped for that sort of build#2017-08-2120:37souenzzoHow to test [:test (is-it-possible? ?foo ?bar)]??#2017-08-2216:11wparkerI don‚Äôt understand your question - could you clarify?#2017-08-2218:43souenzzoI find out that (= ?foo ?bar) isn't a function. For now I'm using [?res <- (my-fn? ?foo ?bar)] [:test (= ?res true)]#2017-08-2219:51souenzzoI'm having trouble with: lein test - pass all my tests *on repl* - I can test multiple times and get ok, but when I reload the rules namespace, all rules behavior change (my test fail) How to debug?#2017-08-2313:38ryanbrush@souenzzo There are a couple pitfalls on the that can happen. One is that the rule session is being cached, so you're re-running previous rules. This can be turned off by passing :cache false to mk-session as described at http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.15.2/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-mk-session#2017-08-2313:39ryanbrushThe other pitfall that can happen is if you're reloading your fact types, the reloaded types may be a different class than what Clara was compiled against, so the facts won't match.#2017-08-2313:39ryanbrushThis can also be addressed by not caching the rules session as described above, or by placing the fact types in a namespace that isn't reloaded in your REPL.#2017-08-2313:40ryanbrushOf course, this only applies if you're using the Java or Clojure type system for your facts (which is the default) rather than using a custom fact type.#2017-08-2314:12souenzzoAlready tryied with :cache false, :cache true...#2017-08-2314:12souenzzoI will try to move defrecord to another ns#2017-08-2314:29souenzzoOh. I noticed that my problems started when I started importing records in different namespaces. (still moving to test if records in a "standalone" ns will solve)#2017-08-2314:46souenzzofixed. @ryanbrush clara docs should contains this info.#2017-08-2319:25mikerod@souenzzo Just to add to this conversation: This does sound like something that may be a good idea to point out in some sort of Clara docs, especially concerning development time. However, records getting redefined I think is often at odds with a dynamic repl reloading workflow. I don‚Äôt think Clara is the only place affected.#2017-08-2319:27mikerodNot to suggest to use this lib or not, just to point out I‚Äôve seen the same concern addressed before https://github.com/ztellman/potemkin/blob/0.4.4/src/potemkin/types.clj#L326#2017-08-2319:28mikerodAt one point Plumatic (formerly prismatic) Schema actually defaulted to using potemkins defrecord+ to avoid recreated classes with the same name, that have no impl change, in a new dynamic classloader during (probably repl) reloads#2017-08-2319:29mikerod(still exists in schema now, but as an ‚Äúoptional‚Äù dependency https://github.com/plumatic/schema/blob/schema-1.1.6/src/clj/schema/potemkin.clj)#2017-08-2319:30mikerodI‚Äôm just pointing this out because in the past I used this ‚Äúnon reloading‚Äù style of defrecord to avoid weird issues with a record class getting reloading, with references still around to the old version of the class#2017-08-2319:30mikerodyou can get away with moving record definitions into some namespace you are careful to not :reload though#2017-08-2319:31mikerodas long as you don‚Äôt want to do something like :reload-all#2017-08-2319:32souenzzoThere is a document about repl development https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Using-Clara-from-the-REPL just add a mention/reference/tip about "be warning on reload types/records across namespaces".#2017-08-2319:33mikerodnice#2017-08-2320:28dadairIs it possible to specify multiple namespaces for mk-session? I have rules organized across a couple namespaces (to guarantee zero collaboration between two distinct rule sets that use common facts), and want to share common queries in a shared namespace. I've tried both (mk-session 'ns.one 'ns.shared) and (mk-session ['ns.one 'ns.shared]) and get a query invalid or not in rule base error for the shared queries#2017-08-2321:24wparkerExample of such usage: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1144#2017-08-2320:32souenzzo(mk-session 'full-ns.name 'full-ns.name2) works for me#2017-08-2320:38dadairseams to be working now üòï shrug#2017-08-2320:38dadairmust have had some weird REPL state#2017-08-2507:54iku000888Not sure how I can express this, but is there a way to express a left-join type of a rule?#2017-08-2513:44mikerod@iku000888 I‚Äôm thinking you‚Äôd probably write 2 rules in that case#2017-08-2513:44mikerodor do some of the joining on the RHS - which I often hesitate to think is a good idea#2017-08-2513:45mikerod
(r/defrule joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))

(r/defrule nil-joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))
#2017-08-2513:45mikerodis that the ‚Äúleft join‚Äù sort of thing?#2017-08-2513:46mikerodA always produce a C, just sometimes there is no B to go with an A#2017-08-2513:46mikerodC can hold whatever info you wanted out of the join#2017-08-2800:26iku000888@mikerod Thanks! I was struggling because for this specific problem coming up it was not clear how to create facts that are [:not [B (= ?id id)]]#2017-08-2800:27iku000888(I would only have facts that are [B (= ?id id)])#2017-08-2800:28iku000888But over the weekend I thought of retracting A's that do have a matching B#2017-08-2800:28iku000888Seems it should do the job#2017-08-2800:28iku000888üôÇ#2017-08-2917:20dadairI have a shared entry point into a rule session where a namespace associated with specific rules/queries can be applied: 
(defn run-rules
  "Runs a rule session given a rule namespace, a root state tree node, and a performed action."
  [ns root action]
  (let [session (-> (r/mk-session 'justice.rules.shared ns)
                    (r/insert (->Tree (walk/prewalk tree/augment-if-node root))
                              (->Action action))
                    (r/fire-rules))]
  ...
However, I get a No namespace exception when I pass a namespace in eg. (run-rules 'justice.rules.x ..). I've "fixed" the issue by adding (require ns) inside run-rules, but is there a better way to accomplish this? I could for example just require the namespaces in the ns declaration, or I could have a whitelist of namespaces to require, but I'd like to keep adding new namespaces to be as simple as creating a new namespace and passing it in to the generic shared entrypoint.#2017-08-2919:21mikerod> Thanks! I was struggling because for this specific problem coming up it was not clear how to create facts that are [:not [B (= ?id id)]] @iku000888 sorry for long delay, just saw your response. I‚Äôm not sure what you mean to create a fact to match a negation (ie condition with a :not). The negation condition is used in conjuction with the [A (= ?id id)] in my example. This together forms a ‚Äújoin‚Äù sort of query for all A that do not have a matching B. So back to that example, repeating for clarity: 
(r/defrule joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))

(r/defrule nil-joins
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:not [B (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->C)))
The rule names may not be the best, but sticking with them: * The rule joins is for the typical ‚Äúinner join‚Äù matches - it matches A with Bs they go with * The rule nil-joins is for the ‚Äúouter left‚Äù part of the join - it keeps the A results that do not have any actual join with a B This may not be the specific issue you had, but that was my interpretation of your ‚Äúleft-join‚Äù type of rule question. Given that you have something with retraction working, I‚Äôm thinking this is a different problem you are wanting to solve.#2017-08-2919:22mikerod@dadair Clojure or ClojureScript?#2017-08-2919:25mikerodEither way though, r/mk-session doesn‚Äôt attempt to require namespace for you.#2017-08-2919:25mikerodI‚Äôm not positive that would be a great idea either. Best practice in clj would be to be sure to appropriately declare the namespace you want to have compiled - most preferably in the ns header :requires#2017-08-2919:26mikerodYou could get away with a dynamic require call in your run-rules though. I‚Äôve had use-cases doing that before to load rules from arbitrary namespaces#2017-08-2919:26mikerodI don‚Äôt think there is a ‚Äúbetter way to accomplish it‚Äù though in terms of what Clara currently offers.#2017-08-2919:26mikerodIt expects things to already be compiled#2017-08-2919:40dadair@mikerod thanks, this would be regular clojure. I've moved away from dynamic require, as it was adding unnecessary compilation overhead (in terms of performance). I'm still using a ns-whitelist var though rather than using the (ns .. (:require ..)) form as I've had some formatters remove the references as they are "unused".#2017-08-2919:41mikerodYeah, if you wait to do a require in the fn, it could be a pretty big slowdown depending on the size of it#2017-08-2919:42mikerodand perhaps could be better suited at ‚Äúcompilation time‚Äù with whatever else you have to start up the app#2017-08-2919:42mikerodNot to get too lost in the weeds, but Clara does have a few other alternatives instead of loading whole ns‚Äôs of rules#2017-08-2919:45mikerodFor example, you can provide collections of rules to r/mk-session 
(defrule r1 <etc>)
(defrule r2 <etc>)
(defrule r3 <etc>)

(def rule-group1 [r1 r2 r3])

(defrule r4 <etc>)
(defrule r5 <etc>)
(defquery q1 <etc>)

(def rule-group2 [r4 r5 q1])

(defrule r6 <etc>)


<....>

(r/mk-session rule-group1 rule-group2 [r6])
#2017-08-3018:24wparker@dadair Agreed with @mikerod ‚Äòs previous comments. I wanted to add that namespace compilation can have arbitrary effects in Clojure; one notable one is protocol extensions. That is, a linter removing namespace whose vars you aren‚Äôt directly using from your requires could be dangerous to things other than Clara. Also, note that require will short-circuits if the namespace already exists unless you specifically request reloading, so the performance question is really whether you pay the cost at initialization of your Clojure environment or the first time you build the relevant session.#2017-08-2919:46mikerodso you can pick in choose at different granularities is my point#2017-08-3017:38mmerHi I am a newbie who is looking to use clara to help understand large nested maps. Is there an easy way to turn a large nested map into a series of facts?#2017-08-3018:27wparker@U4C3ZU6KX Not quite sure what your use-case is, but it seems like you could just use the normal map manipulation functions in clojure.core to create a ‚Äúderived‚Äù sequence of facts to insert. Perhaps just a recursive function that concatenates the facts at each nested level of the map/level of recursion?#2017-08-3116:22dadairis it safe to call insert! from different threads? e.g., within a future? I have a way to not need this (e.g., gather data with the future and then insert! from the main thread), I'm more just curious.#2017-08-3117:42mikerod@dadair I think that is a sort of tough question#2017-08-3117:42mikerodIt seems dangerous to assume semantically#2017-08-3117:43mikerodI do think that implementation-wise, as long as every thread has fully completed their r/insert! prior to r/fire-rules it may work#2017-08-3117:43mikerodThat isn‚Äôt to say I think it is a supported use-case#2017-08-3117:43mikerodSo in general, during the ‚Äúfire rules loop‚Äù cycle of the rules engine, the memory is in a mutable state#2017-08-3117:44mikerodThis is done primarily for performance. The caller perceives the working memory to be a persistent, immutable data structure that is returned after each call to r/fire-rules on a given sesion#2017-08-3117:45mikerodHowever, r/insert! (and a few other similar ones) is called from rule RHS‚Äôs. That means it is sort of in that ‚Äúfire rules loop‚Äù part of the lifecycle#2017-08-3117:50dadairyeah that makes sense, I thought as much#2017-08-3121:07souenzzoaccumulators respect saliency?#2017-08-3123:00wparker@souenzzo salience controls when a rule RHS (right-hand side, or consequence in other terms) fires; whether an accumulator is in the rule doesn‚Äôt impact it either way. It won‚Äôt control the time you actually run the accumulator, though I‚Äôm not sure why you‚Äôd want to do that.#2017-09-0114:31mikerodWell, I know Drools (popular Java-based rules engine)(prior to v6) used to have a good amount of performance issues around accumulators.#2017-09-0114:31mikerodEspecially several in a rule#2017-09-0114:31mikerodso people used to wish that salience would ‚Äúdelay‚Äù their evaluation#2017-09-0114:32mikerodLater on, a lot of laziness was added to Drools, but even more importantly (in my opinion) ‚Äúbatched‚Äù propagations of facts and it mostly solved the common issues around performance that came up.#2017-09-0114:32mikerodClara has ‚Äúbatched‚Äù propagation of facts, which seems to typically work out well. The engine basically ‚Äúgathers‚Äù up collections of facts at a time that are matching conditions before propagating down the network. This results in typically less churn/rework as the data flows.#2017-09-0114:33mikerodJust pointing that out if the question of salience was more about performance than ordering semantics#2017-09-0118:01dadairI'm not sure if this is directly tied to clara, but I am noticing a severe processing time drop the first time I run a rules session with a specific namespace. So for example, (-> (r/mk-session 'some.ns) (r/insert ..) .. (r/fire-rules)) takes 1000ms the first time it is called, but 50ms the second time. Is there some way I can reduce that first performance hit?#2017-09-0118:02dadairI know I need to profile the app to be sure what's going on, just darn jprofiler is too expensive >.<#2017-09-0119:00mikerod@dadair well, you can use visualvm for free#2017-09-0119:00mikerodwhich I‚Äôve had enough luck with when profiling rules before#2017-09-0119:01mikerodOh, r/mk-session creates and then caches the rulebase (Rete graph)#2017-09-0119:01mikerodCan you (r/mk-session 'some.ns) sometime earlier - like ‚Äústartup‚Äù?#2017-09-0119:02mikerodYou‚Äôll still take the hit though. Just maybe you could move the hit out of the processing where it is more painful.#2017-09-0119:34dadairawesome thank you, that will solve my issues (and thanks for the nudge at visualvm, looks good too!)#2017-09-0119:39dadair@mikerod if I different collections of ns (i.e., (r/mk-session 'ns.a 'ns.b 'ns.c) vs (r/mk-session 'ns.d 'ns.e 'ns.f) can I pre-cache individual namespaces e.g. (r/mk-session 'ns.a)? Or would I have to pre-cache full collections (r/mk-session 'ns.a 'ns.b 'ns.c)? Basically, can I init each individually, if they are used in collections? Or will it only cache on the full collection.#2017-09-0120:05mikerod@dadair glad you can work with that. Building the rulebase graph can be a fairly expensive operation. It could perhaps be further optimized in Clara, but there are tricky aspects.#2017-09-0120:05mikerodFor one, there is some eval going on, which means it is running the clj compiler and I often see that time dominate for larger rulebase‚Äôs#2017-09-0120:06mikerod(terminology things: the ‚Äúrulebase‚Äù term just means the underlying ‚Äústatess‚Äù Rete-based graph that is wired together with working memory within the ‚Äúsession‚Äù)#2017-09-0120:06mikerodTo answer your next question, you have to build the r/mk-session with all rules/queries involved at once#2017-09-0120:06mikerodCan‚Äôt build piece-by-piece#2017-09-0121:56dadairok great thank you @mikerod#2017-09-0620:03mmerHi there - very simple question - what is the best way to insert a list of records? I am banging my head against a wall - hence the request for help#2017-09-0620:08enn@mmer see insert-all!#2017-09-0620:09mmerI tried that and when I look at the trace it is not inserting anything?#2017-09-0620:12wparker@mmer are you doing this insertion from outside the session or in a rule right-hand side (consequence)?#2017-09-0620:14mmerThe problem is that I have a function returning a lazySeq and that is preventing it from being loaded! Thanks -not a clara issue at all.#2017-09-0620:31wparkerüëç just for completeness - the ! variants are to be used in rules, the variants without ! are to be used outside the session#2017-09-0622:39mmerThanks - I got it working - highly nested maps caught me out along with laziness.#2017-09-0622:40mmerI do have another question - in the [:test] block what expressions can be used. For example is the following valid?#2017-09-0622:40mmerI seem to be getting a NullPointer error.#2017-09-0622:53mmerThe reason for the NullPointer was that I was passing nil into :test.#2017-09-0704:57dadairIs there any reason why a LHS such as [A (= ?x x)] [B (= ?y y)] where x and y definitely exist (non-nil), would not fire with the order [A ..] [B ..] but would fire with [B ..] [A ..]?#2017-09-0713:42mikerod@dadair I don‚Äôt see how it should be different. Do you have a more complete rule example?#2017-09-0713:42mikerodJust to be sure you don‚Äôt have any extra constructs in play?#2017-09-0714:53wparker@dadair @U0LK1552A I wouldn‚Äôt expect that kind of ordering to make a difference for non-accumulator rule conditions normally. If you are using manual retractions in rule RHS‚Äôs (right-hand-sides) you might be able to get yourself into some odd situations with undefined behavior that could be impacted. A more concrete reproducing example would be helpful to see if there‚Äôs a bug. For accumulators, it isn‚Äôt the easiest edge case to hit, but https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/218 is outstanding.#2017-09-0714:54wparkerAlso, regarding your example 
`[A (= ?x x)] [B (= ?y y)]
` I wouldn‚Äôt actually expect whether x or y is nil to impact whether the rule fires at least based on those conditions alone#2017-09-0714:56wparkerthose aren‚Äôt result bindings, having a field value of a fact be nil (but the fact itself being nil) is a reasonable possibility and Clara will handle that#2017-09-0715:03mikerodYep, that‚Äôs the reason was asking for more details to be sure there aren‚Äôt things like accumulators in play. Things get more complicated then.#2017-09-0716:20dadairThere seemed to be an issue with using a pre-cached rule session. I was looping through some known mk-session configurations and swapping them into an atom so I could avoid the first performance hit. Then later I'd pull the specific session out of the atom and would insert some facts and fire rules. For some reason this was causing really weird rule activation problems#2017-09-0716:21dadairSo for now I've inlined the mk-session and am taking the performance hit until I can figure out what was going on#2017-09-0714:03mmerCould someone please explain the rhs please - I have put a print and an insert! following on from each other on the rhs and the print always happens even if the rule fails?#2017-09-0714:12mikerod@mmer The most typical way to structure rules is in a way that they logically express their constraints, but do not necessarily have a guaranteed order the RHS may fire in. insert! inserts facts that are subject to the ‚Äútruth maintenance system‚Äù (aka the TMS) of the rules engine. If a rule fires at some point due to a, potentially transient, match of some facts, but later some of those facts are retracted, the engine will automatically retract the facts that relied on that match being present.#2017-09-0714:12mikerodWhen you do a side-effect like a print, there is no way to ‚Äúretract‚Äù the side effect#2017-09-0714:14mikerodThere are ways to structure rules that would prevent them from being able to ever fire their RHS ‚Äúearly‚Äù. This can be done with setting up the rule to not be able to fire due to some ‚Äúblocking‚Äù or ‚Äúguarding‚Äù criteria in the LHS that you know will not change it‚Äôs truthiness later. Also, you can sometimes do some tricks with :salience. However, in many cases, the best idea may be to just avoid the side-effects in the RHS and perhaps do them outside of the rules based on the facts that are found via queries after performing a fire-rules cycle.#2017-09-0714:15mikerodThere is some documentation on the TMS @ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/#2017-09-0714:25mmerThat helps. I thought I was going mad!#2017-09-0714:36mikerod@mmer yeah, it can be a tricky detail#2017-09-0714:38mmerThe docs say you can nest the boolean operators [:not, :or] etc. I have tried to do something like [:not [:or [] []] without much success. Is this just plain wrong on my part?#2017-09-0714:56mikerod@mmer things can get a little tricky with that#2017-09-0714:57mikerodSo it is good to note that :or is sort of ‚Äúsyntactic sugar‚Äù in rules#2017-09-0714:57mikerodIt can almost be thought of as just splitting the rule into 2 (or more depending on logic in use) rules#2017-09-0714:59mikerode.g. 
(r/defrule with-or
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [:or
   [B (= ?id id)]
   [C (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))
Is similar to just writing 
(r/defrule side-one
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))

(r/defrule side-two
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [C (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->D)))
#2017-09-0714:59mikerodThe point in that case is that there isn‚Äôt something like ‚Äúshort-circuiting‚Äù#2017-09-0715:00mikerodand the :or has certain variable visibility issues due to how that works out#2017-09-0715:00mikerodWhen it comes to :not + :or and/or nested :and, it may also be good to note that the engine will convert to DNF (disjunctive normal form)#2017-09-0715:00mikerodThere may be some variable visibility issues in that transition in certain complex cases#2017-09-0715:13mikerod@mmer but if you have an example that demonstrates an issue you are seeing, it‚Äôd be probably clearer to just look at that one and explain what is going on#2017-09-0715:14mmerI have eventually just split the rules in two so I do not need the not#2017-09-0715:21mikerodsometimes it is clearer to split things up from an comprehension perspective anyways#2017-09-0715:24mikerodProbably the most details on this subject can be found in the lengthy old issue comments @ https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/149#2017-09-0715:24mikerodas far as some of the transformations that happen#2017-09-0715:25mikerodOnly if you were interesting in details though. üòõ Probably not super easy to read through.#2017-09-0715:44mmerThanks#2017-09-0716:04mmerTo be more precise - when I load up the rules/queries into the session I get :#2017-09-0716:04mmerExceptionInfo Value does not match schema: {:constraints [(not ("s-expression" ?composition)) (not ("s-expression" a-clojure.lang.Symbol))]} schema.core/validator/fn--1296 (core.clj:155)#2017-09-0716:22wparker@mmer that looks like a syntax error in a rule/query#2017-09-0716:05mmerWhat sort of thing am I looking for in my rule etc?#2017-09-0716:58mikerodIt‚Äôs hard to decipher without the actual rule DSL that was written (probably could be improved in Clara to try to capture that better) There is probably some missing [ ] if not just having syntax out of order#2017-09-1214:11dadairI have a singleton fact that I insert for referencing that contains a large map (hundreds of KB), and is a part of the LHS of most of my rules, so that the RHS can use the map when inserting more rules. Are there any performance issues to consider here? Or ways to exploit the fact that it is a singleton and will never need to be compared between multiple instances? I know with persistent structures it isn't inefficient to have the large map in multiple places, but was wondering last night if perhaps there was a better way to reference it. The LHS query for it is dead simple: [Tree (= ?root root)] in all cases#2017-09-1216:49mikerod@dadair I don‚Äôt know of anything particularly harmful in the big fact like that#2017-09-1216:50mikerodIt‚Äôs probably best to make sure it has a ‚Äútype‚Äù that is distinct from anything else#2017-09-1216:50mikerodbeyond that, assuming it is immutable (as facts should be), a cached hashcode may become important#2017-09-1216:51mikerodClojure persistent maps cache hashcode#2017-09-1216:52mikerodYou could also consider wrapping the big map in a custom type that optimizes equality checking and hashing too if you had noticeable perf issues come up#2017-09-1216:54mikerodYou‚Äôre example does look like you have a type on it called Tree though, so I am not sure what implications that type has#2017-09-1216:56dadairTree is just a record wrapper around a map so it works with the default Fact type identification#2017-09-1216:58mikerodFor clarity: There are basically 2 situations that come to mind in this scenario: 1) How often is this big fact going to be compared to other different facts? 2) This big fact will be part of a token that is stored in memory. This token is sometimes used as a hash map sort of key. If this is hashed too often, the hash code may become a bottleneck. For (1) If the fact has a unique type that no other facts have, it should only ever be compared to maybe itself. The equals check should be fast tehre since most equals impl‚Äôs will short-circuit on the identical? (or Java == case) For (2) Clojure maps default to caching hash codes. Clojure records do not, prior to what looks like 1.9 (not yet fully released at least (see https://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-1224))#2017-09-1216:59mikerodSo if anything, if your Tree wrapper is made via defrecord, you may be able to see some time spent recalculating the hash code when if this fact ends up being involved in a lot of rules LHS ‚Äútokens‚Äù#2017-09-1216:59mikerodTokens contain a sequence of all the facts that matched for a particular successful invocation of the rule#2017-09-1217:00mikerodThen again, I may not get worked up about this situation unless you can see measurable issues with perf#2017-09-1217:02dadairThanks for the advice, I'm just trying to keep some performance considerations in my back pocket in case I need to improve performance. This Tree is somewhat like a database, so it will continue to grow over time. I'm already seeing processing times approach >= 100ms for the rule engine and I generally want things to be below ~50ms for some soft real-time constraints we have#2017-09-1217:04mikerodhmm#2017-09-1217:04mikerodI typically use VisualVM#2017-09-1217:04mikerodstart the ‚Äúsampling CPU‚Äù profiler#2017-09-1217:04dadairto clarify: the tree does not change within a rule session, only between rule sessions#2017-09-1217:04mikerodthen run whatever takes the tiem I‚Äôm interested in#2017-09-1217:05mikerodthen you take a ‚Äúsnapshot‚Äù, view the snapshot by drilling down through a fairly large callstack#2017-09-1217:05mikerodit has visuals to show how much time is being spent where in the callstacks#2017-09-1217:06mikerodFor this particular concern I had above, I‚Äôd just try to get to the ‚Äúbottom‚Äù of the larger time callstacks and see if I can find references to, in this example, the Tree object getting equiv or hash sort of calls on it#2017-09-1217:07dadairgreat I'll give that a try, thanks#2017-09-1217:10mikerodno problem. I‚Äôm always willing to take a look at a profiler snapshot, a portion of it, or just say ‚ÄúI see lots of time in Clara function X, any ideas?‚Äù too if you find those parts to be hard to sort through. I‚Äôm not sure how easy it may be to read profiler snapshots sometimes if not familiar with the codebase and/or the way clj compiles out java class names#2017-09-1300:06Oliver GeorgeI'm experimenting to see if I can rewrite my webapp form logic using Clara rules.#2017-09-1300:08Oliver GeorgeThe existing code does multiple passes: Field definitions and values used to generate cleaned field data and errors Field data and errors used by logic which might (1) show/hide fields, (2) disable/enable fields, (3) change field values, (4) manage relationships between fields... (lots of stuff). I borrowed the approach Django uses for form and field validation, they document it well here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.11/ref/forms/validation/#2017-09-1300:08Oliver GeorgeThe current approach has functions which take the form (field definitions, values...) and return a modified version#2017-09-1300:09Oliver GeorgeIteratively manipulating the data#2017-09-1300:09Oliver GeorgeI don't think Clara would work in this way#2017-09-1300:11Oliver GeorgeMy guess is I need each phase to have it's own facts so that each phase of the form processing can use previous phase's facts as inputs.#2017-09-1300:11Oliver GeorgeNot sure if I'm explaining that well#2017-09-1300:13Oliver GeorgeSpecific question: Am I correct that it's a bad idea to try and reproduce the "modify data" approach I'm currently using.#2017-09-1300:25dadair@olivergeorge correct, mutating data in Clara is discouraged (though not impossible). I am doing something similar actually with form field- and form-level validation. I don't do multi-pass internally in the rule engine, but rather the rule engine is called multiple times from (essentially) a reduce, which collects the final modifications to perform at the end#2017-09-1300:26dadairso the rule engine doesn't actually modify the forms, rather it returns what operations to perform in order to modify it#2017-09-1300:26dadairthen the reduce can take those, perform them, and send the modified form back to the rule engine, and it goes until it stabilizes#2017-09-1300:40Oliver GeorgeGotcha, thanks @dadair that makes sense#2017-09-1301:37Oliver George@dadair how do you check for stability? data comparison or does clara provide a "no new facts" test#2017-09-1301:39dadairstability from the rules side of things would be it returning from fire-rules, otherwise it wouldn keep going. "stability" in terms of your domain is different. For example, in that external reduce you would query the session for operations, if the query returns nothing, you could know that "the form is stable"#2017-09-1301:40dadairit all depends on how you set up your system#2017-09-1301:40Oliver GeorgeThanks again#2017-09-1301:41dadairI am in no way an expert on rule systems though, I'm just getting into it myself, that's just the approach I've taken so far#2017-09-1301:42Oliver GeorgeRight, interesting stuff. I imagine there's typical examples we can learn from in other similar rule systems.#2017-09-1303:21dadairAnyone have any advice re: calming Cursive x cannot be resolved warnings when using Clara?#2017-09-1303:22dadaireg ^#2017-09-1303:22dadairfor all the LHS bindings#2017-09-1303:23cfleming@dadair Unfortunately there isn‚Äôt a good solution for that yet. If the warnings bother you you can turn them off at Settings-&gt;Languages &amp; Frameworks-&gt;Clojure-&gt;Highlight unresolved symbols.#2017-09-1303:23cflemingThe drawback to that is that you also won‚Äôt get symbols that really are undefined highlighted.#2017-09-1303:24cflemingSadly until Cursive understands Clara better (which I am hoping to get to soon-ish) that‚Äôs the best option.#2017-09-1303:25dadairIs there a pluggable way for lib maintainers/etc to help with those endeavours?#2017-09-1303:26cflemingNot yet, but it‚Äôs planned.#2017-09-1303:26cflemingIf you were really keen, one thing that would help a lot would be to develop specs for the Clara macro forms.#2017-09-1303:27cflemingI‚Äôm hoping to be able to semi-automatically migrate those to Cursive, and I‚Äôm sure it would be a valuable contribution to Clara too.#2017-09-1303:28cflemingWe‚Äôve discussed doing that in this channel previously, but AFAIK no-one has taken up the torch.#2017-09-1303:28cfleming(me included)#2017-09-1303:32Oliver George@cfleming what format would you prefer specs in? Wondered if that's what you meant.#2017-09-1303:36Oliver GeorgeShouldn't be too bad given they've taken the time to document the syntax with railway tracks in the doco (is that the right term)#2017-09-1303:36cflemingRailroad diagrams, yeah#2017-09-1303:36cflemingThey‚Äôre not complete, but they should be a good start.#2017-09-1303:37cflemingI suspect there are lots of gnarly corners though, or at least that‚Äôs what I‚Äôm given to understand. But I think there‚Äôs a lot of code using Clara out there so hopefully if we can convince users to test it then we should get the edge cases out fairly quickly.#2017-09-1303:38Oliver GeorgeSounds good#2017-09-1303:39cflemingHaving specs would also help non-Cursive users check the grammars too.#2017-09-1303:41cflemingPrevious discussion: https://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/clara/2017-06-29.html#2017-09-1303:41cflemingOne question would be whether the Clara specs would be best developed in Clara itself or in a separate project.#2017-09-1303:42Oliver GeorgeYeah, I wondered that. Taking lead from clojure...#2017-09-1303:42Oliver GeorgeI have a meeting soon so signing off#2017-09-1303:42Oliver GeorgeIf anyone can tell me what I'm doing wrong with acc/all here I'd love to know: https://gist.github.com/olivergeorge/e37ff239783e1de8f97804bf472047a4#2017-09-1307:00Oliver GeorgeWorked it out. bidi required an earlier version of prismatic so I missed this fix https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/306#2017-09-1303:43cflemingOk, cool - I‚Äôd definitely like to pursue this.#2017-09-1303:43Oliver GeorgeI'll put up my hand to help on the spec front but not familar with clara so someone else would need to lead.#2017-09-1303:44cflemingOk. I can create a project to hold the WIP specs and have a go at it, hopefully later this week.#2017-09-1304:20dadairI'll help where I can if you post the repo#2017-09-1304:24cfleming@dadair Great, thanks.#2017-09-1317:18dadairWhat's the best way for debugging rules? Cursive breakpoints aren't reachable it seems (not surprising since the rules aren't "called", but rather exist within a session registry and are also macros). Currently I just add print statements and try to reason things out#2017-09-1317:30mikerod@dadair some of this may be helpful http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/inspection/#2017-09-1317:31mikerodSometimes I end up just mutating some testing atoms state from various points in rules though when I‚Äôm confused. The inspection may be a bit of a nicer approach.#2017-09-1317:32mikerodThere is clara.tools.inspect and clara.tools.trace that could both potentially be useful. The tests for these features in src/test may be helpful to see some usages.#2017-09-1317:37dadairgreat I'll take a look at that thanks#2017-09-1318:00mikerod@dadair Tests of the tracing like https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.15.2/src/test/common/clara/tools/test_tracing.cljc#L67 may be useful#2017-09-1318:00mikerodinspection is more human-readable I think#2017-09-1318:01mikerodbut the tracing sometimes has good data to work with, but can be a lot so have to pikc it apart some#2017-09-1319:42wparkerClara-rules 0.16.0 is released and on Clojars. Relative to 0.15.2 (the previous released version) this is a bugfix release for https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/303#2017-09-1320:00dadairIs there a benefit/drawback to doing: 
[A (false? x)]
instead of 
[A (= ?x x)]
[:test (false? ?x)]
#2017-09-1320:03wparkerFor constraints that can be determined to be true or false without any reference to other facts Clara will evaluate them upfront without trying to join them with anything and if they are false Clara won‚Äôt retain a reference to them#2017-09-1320:03wparkerSo for example, in the latter case, I‚Äôd expect Clara to retain a hard reference to every A inserted#2017-09-1320:04wparkerwhile in the former case, it wouldn‚Äôt retain a reference to an A without a value of false in field x#2017-09-1320:05wparkerIn cases where you do joins it can also be more efficient to have Clara do as much filtering as it can on each fact in isolation - apart from evaluating your join criteria, there is some (highly optimized) overhead to keeping track of joins#2017-09-1320:08dadairok great thanks#2017-09-1320:00dadairother than if you want to use ?x later in the RHS#2017-09-1321:19mikerod@dadair I‚Äôd tend to just suggest to not use :test unless you have a use-case that it can‚Äôt be avoided#2017-09-1321:19mikerodit just is more opaque to the engine and could mean you‚Äôre skipping out on optimizations#2017-09-1321:22dadairmakes sense, thanks!#2017-09-1321:33mikerodAs far as the actual effects of the example you give here, I don‚Äôt know there is a big difference. There is definitely a ‚Äúlittle‚Äù more overhead to adding the :test node, but I‚Äôm not sure you lose any particular optimizations in this particular case. I‚Äôd have to mess with it more to be sure though. However, still, I‚Äôd just go with my general rule here. üôÇ#2017-09-1321:35dadairabsolutely, thanks for the help!#2017-09-1322:48Oliver GeorgeI'm trying to encode some form logic which disables dependent fields (e.g. can't pick building if site isn't set, can't pick floor if building isn't set...)#2017-09-1322:48Oliver GeorgeMy rules don't terminate#2017-09-1322:49Oliver George
(ns spike-rules.core
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Operation [field-key field-state])

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?ops <- (acc/all :field-state) :from [Operation (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (println :update-fieldstate ?field-key)
  (insert! (->FieldState ?field-key (reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops))))

(defrule rule2
  "Insert field disable operation if a field depends on a field which is not set"
  [FieldState (= ?nil-field-key field-key) (= (nil? (:value field-state)))]
  [FieldState (= ?disable-field-key field-key) (contains? (:depends-on field-state) ?nil-field-key)]
  =>
  (println :disable-dependent ?disable-field-key)
  (insert! (->Operation ?disable-field-key {:disabled true})))

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil})
      (->Field :bl {:value nil :depends-on #{:site}})
      (->Field :fl {:value nil :depends-on #{:bl}}))
    (rules/fire-rules))
#2017-09-1322:50Oliver GeorgePerhaps rule1 is bad practice. I'm using it to combine the original field state with any operations which modify it. (in this case adding a :disable flag)#2017-09-1322:51Oliver George@dadair I was trying to avoid having to do the "merge field with ops" manually and refiring rules. That's the approach you were describing, correct?#2017-09-1322:58dadairWe actually do it slightly differently. In our case, the rule engine inserts the current state of the form, and the operation the user is trying to perform. Then there are rules that check if that operation is valid given the current state of the form. If it's valid, it returns a transformation of the input action that can actually be performed/persisted by an external state management service. If it's invalid, it transforms the input action to an action that will invalidate the field (or reject the action out-right), which is then again carried out by the external state management service#2017-09-1322:59defndainesMight add in a 
(println "?ops " ?ops)
as part of rule1.#2017-09-1323:11Oliver George@defndaines that shows that rule1 is firing repeatedly for the empty ops case. 
Loading src/spike_rules/round1.clj... 
:update-fieldstate :site []
:update-fieldstate :fl []
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:disable-dependent :fl
:disable-dependent :bl
:update-fieldstate :fl []
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:disable-dependent :bl
:disable-dependent :fl
:update-fieldstate :bl []
:update-fieldstate :fl []
Hmm, that makes me think it's not doing what I expect. It should have an operation for disabling that field.#2017-09-1323:12Oliver George@dadair thanks, as you say it's slightly different to what I'm focused on but sounds interesting... I'll get to that I expect.#2017-09-1323:19Oliver GeorgeLooks like I'm not best friends with acc/all yet#2017-09-1323:24defndainesMaybe check with some?#2017-09-1323:26Oliver George@defndaines I don't think that would work. I want field -> fieldstate even if ops is empty. That way rule2 has a full list of field-state facts to consider.#2017-09-1323:27Oliver GeorgeProblem is that acc/all doesn't seem to ever return the inserted Operations facts#2017-09-1323:29Oliver GeorgeThere's a feedback loop which seems a possible problem: * rule 1 inserts FieldState (before any Operations are inserted) * rule 2 fires because it sees a FieldState which should be disabled * rule 1 sees a new Operation and does truth maintenance to update the field's FieldState#2017-09-1323:30Oliver GeorgeOdd thing is that I don't ever see the Operation in Rule 1 via acc/all (the third step described)#2017-09-1323:30Oliver GeorgeI'm new to this, likely user error or bad assumptions on how things should work#2017-09-1323:43mikerod@olivergeorge acc/all returns an empty collection when no matches.#2017-09-1323:43mikerodI‚Äôm not sure that you‚Äôve already realized that, so pointing it out#2017-09-1323:44mikerod
(r/defrule foo
 [?xs <- (acc/all) :from [X]]
 [:test (seq ?xs)]
 =>
 (prn :foo))
Something like that would ensure that the rule wasn‚Äôt activated with no matches#2017-09-1323:45mikerodLooks like the acc/all docs could be a bit clearer on that#2017-09-1323:45mikerodBelieve it or not, it actually can be useful for it to match with the empty collection in other use-cases.#2017-09-1323:49Oliver George@mikerod Thanks Mike. The curious thing is that an inserted Operation is never returned from (all). I'll take a step back to understand truth maintenance better.#2017-09-1323:52Oliver GeorgeSimpler example 
(ns spike-rules.round1
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Operation [field-key field-state])

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?ops <- (acc/all) :from [Operation (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (println :rule1.ops ?ops)
  (println :rule1.insert! `(->FieldState ~?field-key ~(reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops)))
  (insert! (->FieldState ?field-key (reduce merge (:field-state ?field) ?ops))))

(defrule rule2
  "disable if read-only"
  [FieldState (= ?field-key field-key) (:read-only field-state)]
  =>
  (println :rule2.insert! `(->Operation ~?field-key {:disabled true}))
  (insert! (->Operation ?field-key {:disabled true})))

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil :read-only true}))
    (rules/fire-rules))
Returns 
Loading src/spike_rules/round1.clj... 
:rule1.ops []
:rule1.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->FieldState :site {:value nil, :read-only true})
:rule2.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->Operation :site {:disabled true})
:rule1.ops []
:rule1.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->FieldState :site {:value nil, :read-only true})
:rule2.insert! (spike-rules.round1/->Operation :site {:disabled true})
...
#2017-09-1323:52dadairYou could write a query to return all operations, if that query returns anything, then your memory does have operations inserted and it's your LHS of rule 1 that is incorrect #2017-09-1323:53Oliver GeorgeOkay, thanks will do.#2017-09-1323:55Oliver GeorgeActually, not sure how to do a query when it won't terminate.#2017-09-1323:55Oliver GeorgeI appreciate all the help#2017-09-1323:55Oliver GeorgeI'll take some time to learn more and try again.#2017-09-1400:02dadairoh right it isn't terminating#2017-09-1400:02dadairin that case I'd write a rule that should match on ANY Operation, and have a println on the RHS#2017-09-1400:02dadairthat way it should activate if an Operation is ever inserted#2017-09-1400:03mikerod@olivergeorge This is rough, but hopefully correct (thought about it quickly) So I think the loop goes like this (only including relevant fields): 1) insert Field{:field-key :site :read-only true} 2) activate rule1 3) fire rule1 - insert FieldState{:field-key :site :read-only true} 4) activate rule2 5) fire rule2 - insert Operation{:field-key :site} 6) retract previous rule1 results since (acc/all) changed 7) retract previous rule2 results since rule1 retracted the matching fact changed ;; due to (6) 8) retract previous rule1 results since (acc/all) changed ;; due to (7) - no actual retraction needed here, just updates the accumulator again (6) already retracted 9) (re-)activate rule1 ;; due to (8) 10) insert Field{:field-key :site :read-only true} ;; no Op1 anymore 11) repeat (4) and (5) 12) repeat (6) (7) ( 8 ) (9) 13) keep repeating (11) (12)#2017-09-1400:06Oliver GeorgeAh! right. That makes sense. Thank you.#2017-09-1400:06Oliver GeorgeI missed the op retraction.#2017-09-1400:06mikerodso you have to do something to avoid the cycle that starts there#2017-09-1400:06mikerodperhaps checking some field that would stop the ‚Äúfeedback loop‚Äù#2017-09-1400:06mikerodbut it‚Äôd be domain dependent I think to know the answer in that particular case#2017-09-1400:08Oliver GeorgeI wondered about having a fire-rules loop and doing (field+ops => field-state) aggregation between iterations.#2017-09-1400:09Oliver GeorgeI can see other possibilities.#2017-09-1400:09Oliver GeorgeThanks for putting me on track#2017-09-1400:10dadair@mikerod do you know of any solid references for designing forward inference rule systems? Or some common design patterns, etc?#2017-09-1400:39mikerod@dadair good question. I‚Äôm don‚Äôt really think I know a lot off the top of my head. Which is unfortunate#2017-09-1400:39mikerodI‚Äôll have to think about that one#2017-09-1401:52Oliver GeorgeIs there a simple way to extract all facts from a session?#2017-09-1401:53Oliver GeorgeMy best guess is query with an expression whose fact type is an ancestor of all records which seems to work just fine for records using [?ret <- Object].#2017-09-1402:38Oliver George@dadairI was going to suggest that perhaps the Doorenbos paper might be worth checking for references but it's 150 pages long.#2017-09-1404:12Oliver GeorgeOne technique which might have resolved my problem is using insert-unconditional! for Operations as that would ensure they aren't retracted (no feedback loop).#2017-09-1404:13Oliver GeorgeNot sure if using insert-unconditional! is considered a code smell / something to be avoided rather than common usage.#2017-09-1404:27Oliver George
(ns spike-rules.round1
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules :refer [insert! insert-unconditional! defrule defquery defsession]]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]))

(defrecord Field [field-key field-state])
(defrecord FieldState [field-key field-state])
(defrecord Disabled [field-key])

(defn exists
  ([]
   (acc/accum
     {:initial-value     false
      :reduce-fn         (constantly true)})))

(defrule rule1
  "Insert FieldState based on Field and Operations"
  [?field <- Field (= field-key ?field-key)]
  [?disabled <- (exists) :from [Disabled (= field-key ?field-key)]]
  =>
  (insert!
    (cond-> (->FieldState ?field-key (:field-state ?field))
      ?disabled (assoc :disabled true))))

(defrule rule2
  "disable if read-only"
  [FieldState (= ?field-key field-key) (:read-only field-state)]
  [:not [Disabled (= ?field-key field-key)]]
  =>
  (insert-unconditional! (->Disabled ?field-key)))

(defquery export-facts [] [?ret <- Object])

(defsession form-session [rule1 rule2 export-facts])

(-> form-session
    (rules/insert
      (->Field :site {:value nil :read-only true}))
    (rules/fire-rules)
    (rules/query export-facts))
#2017-09-1416:09mikerod> I was going to suggest that perhaps the Doorenbos paper might be worth checking for references but it‚Äôs 150 pages long. @olivergeorge I do think that this paper is a great explanation of Rete (skipping some of the out-dated about some of the ‚Äútestbed‚Äù system parts). I‚Äôm not sure it has a lot on ‚Äúhow to structure and design rules in practice‚Äù though.#2017-09-1416:11mikerodWhen looking for that sort of guidance I think I‚Äôve sort of just hunted around the internet searching for like ‚Äúrules engines best practices‚Äù#2017-09-1416:12mikerodI think Drools (popular Java/JVM based rules engine) had a fairly large amount of material with some general guidance on things. It‚Äôs still a search though. I wish I knew more direct sources though.#2017-09-1416:12mikerod@olivergeorge I‚Äôd be careful using insert-unconditional!#2017-09-1416:12mikerodYou start to get into an order dependent situation with your rules#2017-09-1416:13mikerodif an ‚Äúupstream‚Äù fact from a different rule is logically inserted and later retracted, but a downstream insert-unconditional! has already happened, it won‚Äôt be retracted and you‚Äôll get into an inconsistent state#2017-09-1416:13mikerodSo then you end up having to do things like add :salience to try to force the rule to fire later than another and this ends up just becoming increasingly brittle#2017-09-1416:14mikerodAlso, loses the ‚Äúdeclarative‚Äù sort of property that you get with rules all being under control of the truth maintenance system#2017-09-1416:59mmerOrganizing rules sets - My rule set has become reasonably large within a short time. I keep getting issues with Exceptions against the schema. These are really difficult to resolve. I wonder if this is because I am running in a repl rather than outside? However, I thought I would divide my project into 4 namespaces - rules (for those I know work) worker (for any functions that help with processing my data into the working memory) queries . This then leave me with an issue about what to do with the record definitions that need to be available in all of these and in the core where I am creating the session. I either get cyclical dependencies if I put the record defs in any of these files - so I move them out into another records namespace and each of the above and the core require and refer this namespace. However when I run the mk->session if fails to find the record defs. Any ideas?#2017-09-1418:32wparker‚ÄúHowever when I run the mk->session if fails to find the record defs. ‚Äù It sounds like the namespace defining the records wasn‚Äôt compiled then. In case you don‚Äôt know, Clojure won‚Äôt actually compile a namespace until something requires it. It can be weird in that if you have a fully qualified reference, it will resolve even if the namespace in question doesn‚Äôt require the namespace, but only if something required the namespace already. I personally think of Clojure‚Äôs compiler as a ‚Äúprocedural‚Äù one that takes in code and alters the state of the runtime environment accordingly.#2017-09-1417:01dadairI have a shared namespace for shared records, then I build sessions like so: (r/mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x 'rules.y)#2017-09-1417:02dadairyou need to make sure you are requiring the namespace too before making the session, I've run into that before#2017-09-1417:03dadairso either put rules.shared into the (ns .. (:require ..)) or do an explicit (require 'rules.shared)#2017-09-1421:02mmerThanks - what if you have helper functions that need the shared? Do you lead them into the session as well? i.e. if a rule uses a function (private-ref? ?value) its namespace have to be made available to the session?#2017-09-1421:02mmerThanks for the reply, BTW?#2017-09-1422:00dadairshared functions can live in the shared namespace#2017-09-1422:00dadairthen in rules.x you can require rules.shared so you can use the functions#2017-09-1422:01dadairI only call (mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x ..) in a "core" namespace#2017-09-1422:02dadairso for example, rules.x, rules.y, and rules.z can require and use records/functions from rules.shared, and then in some other namespace rules.engine, you can require all the namespaces and call the mk-session function: (r/mk-session 'rules.shared 'rules.x ..)#2017-09-1422:02dadairthat's how I've avoided circular dependencies#2017-09-1422:10mmerThanks - re-organised the project as you said. I am still getting the issue where the first record typr encountered by the rules engine in the session is saying that the Record type can't be found. This namespace stuff is so hard to handle with the level of error messages from clojure#2017-09-1422:26Oliver GeorgeThanks for the tips @mikerod#2017-09-1422:49dadairdepends how you are using Operation#2017-09-1422:49dadaircan you post an example rule?#2017-09-1422:53dadairor the exact line of the error?#2017-09-1710:52mmerMore details:#2017-09-1710:54mmerThis must be something very simple about classpaths etc that I am not grasping. The Operation is defined as:#2017-09-1710:54mmer(defrecord Operation [assemblyName name src])#2017-09-1719:19mmerThe erro I am getting is: ClassNotFoundException Thing java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass (URLClassLoader.java:381) - I am trying to isolate the issue into a simple set of files - hence the reference to Thing rather than Operation#2017-09-1721:02mikerod@mmer I don‚Äôt see enough information here to be able to see what the problem coulud be#2017-09-1721:02mikerodthe class not found‚Äôs name is AssemblyOperation which you don‚Äôt even refer to in the rule debug-rules#2017-09-1721:02mikerodSo I‚Äôm not sure how they are connected#2017-09-1721:03mikerodHowever, if classes are missing, I‚Äôd make sure you are appropriately requiring all necessary namespaces, including those that define types via things like defrecord#2017-09-1722:06mmerHi @mikerod - in trying to get a simple example out I have confused you all. Sorry. I now have a very simple project which is showing the issue.#2017-09-1722:09mmer(apply-rules "name" "description") and I get the errors#2017-09-1722:09mmerClassNotFoundException Thing java.net.URLClassLoader.findClass (URLClassLoader.java:381)#2017-09-1722:10mmerEverything to my eyes looks OK and follows the scheme of project layout that avoids cyclical dependencies, yet I can't get the reference to the rule to see the record defined in the shared files.#2017-09-1722:16mikerod@mmer when defining types via defrecord (and similarly, deftype), a :refer from a :require does not import the class name to be used shorthand. So you need to refer to the class either by it‚Äôs fully qualified name, or add something like 
(:import [rules.shared Thing])
to your rules namespaces using the class#2017-09-1815:12wparkerhttps://stackoverflow.com/questions/7143406/what-are-the-differences-among-require-import-and-use has an (IMO) nice concise summary of the differences @mmer. One other potential gotcha - if you define a record with hyphens in the namespace path, the Java class created will have underscores in the corresponding class name, and import needs the Java class name#2017-09-1815:16mmerThanks - Just what I needed.#2017-09-1905:27devn@mmer we built a lib such that you can require a single ns and have access to the records via an alias in addition to some other niceties like inheriting fields and specs on those fields from a parent fact#2017-09-1905:30devnfact/my-fact, (deffact abc (alias abc) :a integer? (variant qrs (alias qrs) :q ::some-spec)))#2017-09-1915:41mmerWhere is this library?#2017-09-1917:44devn@mmer closed source at the moment but will talk to folks about opening it up#2017-09-1918:48mmerok#2017-09-2200:56dadairDo facts inserted by rules with accumulators in the LHS observe truth maintenance retractions if the accumulator changes? i.e., if I have a max accumulator, and 5 facts are inserted, will the RHS facts be retracted for the four facts that aren't the max?#2017-09-2214:40wparker@U0E2EQFME: Yes, accumulator conditions will adjust as necessary to respect truth maintenance. This test is a concrete example: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/common/clara/test_accumulation.cljc#L1102#2017-09-2217:22dadairawesome thanks!#2017-09-2516:45ennI have this clause in an LHS: 
[?last-performed-date <- (acc/max :date)
   :from [fact/test-result
          (= ?test-id test-id)]]
