Because the initial value of the max accumulator is nil, it never fires when there are no test-result facts. Am I missing some idiomatic way to have it fire in that case? Do I need to write my own accumulator with a different initial value? Can I do this with :or?#2017-09-2519:52mikerod@enn you should just structure the rules in a way to handle the missing case#2017-09-2519:52mikerodsince acc/max doesn‚Äôt necessarily make sense for no facts - that may not always be the behavior that was desired#2017-09-2519:53mikerodYou could give it an :initial-value if you wanted to I suppose though#2017-09-2519:53mikerod
[?last-performed-date <- (assoc (acc/max :date) :initial-value <my-date>)
   :from [fact/test-result
          (= ?test-id test-id)]]
not sure it will always be clear what happened though#2017-09-2519:57enn@mikerod thanks--I ended up adding an [:or ... [:not [fact/test-result (= ?test-id test-id)]]]1#2017-09-2521:16nickowsyIs there a way to use accumulate with multiple fact_contraints? For example, if I have the facts 
{:e 2, :a :type, :v :dog}
{:e 2, :a :age, :v  12}
{:e 3, :a :type, :v :cat}
{:e 3, :a :age, :v 2}
{:e 4, :a :type, :v :dog}
{:e 4, :a :age, :v 10}
I would like to acc/all :type facts, matching :type is :dog and :age > 4. The :fact-type-fn is :a.#2017-09-2521:33mikerod
[:type
 (= (:v this) :dog)
 (= ?id (:e this))]

[?all <- (acc/all)
 :from [:age
        (= ?id (:e this))
        (> (:v this) 4)]
@nickowsy perhaps?#2017-09-2521:33mikerodSo an accumulator that does a join with another fact#2017-09-2521:40nickowsy@mikerod, cool thanks. I had something similar but was seeing the rule run multiple times. Once for each 
[:type
 (= (:v this) :dog)
 (= ?id (:e this))]
match#2017-09-2521:42mikerod@nickowsy yes, it would#2017-09-2821:48souenzzoHow to print/debug all fired rules?#2017-09-2823:39dadairhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/inspection/#2017-09-2823:39dadair@souenzzo#2017-09-2900:53Oliver GeorgeIn my early experimentation with clara I ended up with infinite loops when firing rules. They were non-terminating due to rules which are directly or indirectly affected by the facts they insert.#2017-09-2900:54Oliver GeorgeI went looking for documentation around this. I can't see anything apart from an issue about a :no-loop flag.#2017-09-2900:55Oliver GeorgeDirect question: is Clara smart enough to avoid infinite loops based on bad rules?#2017-09-2912:59souenzzo@dadair not sure if I understand. But my rules was in a loop inside the fire-rules.#2017-09-2915:09mikerod@olivergeorge are you asking if Clara can solve the Halting problem?#2017-09-2915:09mikerodüòõ#2017-09-2915:10mikerodJoking aside: No Clara can‚Äôt really detect the loops#2017-09-2915:10mikerodThe RHS can do arbitrary things#2017-09-2915:10mikerodThere is no way to know that something that ‚Äúlooks like a cycle‚Äù at runtime isn‚Äôt going to eventually stop cycling#2017-09-2915:11mikerodClara could assume if a cycle of rules was happening ‚Äútoo many times‚Äù that it should stop#2017-09-2915:12mikerodIn Drools (popular Java-based rules engine that I often reference since it was used a lot in the industry) there was a ‚Äúfire until halt‚Äù sort of method I believe it was called. This allowed to have a sort of ‚Äútimeout‚Äù feature that the rules would stop if they reached a certain threshold of time, steps, # rule firings, etc. So something like that is feasible to implement, but not in Clara right now.#2017-09-2915:13mikerodI do tend to try to avoid using something like :no-loop too and instead setup the rules in a way where they logically won‚Äôt loop. :no-loop starts to go against the logical truth maintenance in some cases.#2017-09-2915:14mikerodUnderstandably, there are cases where it is sort of hard to think about how you can make the rule logic you want not form a logical loop.#2017-09-2915:59wparkerThere is work logged for Clara to assume by default that after a certain number of iterations of looping that the rules were written incorrectly and throw an exception: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/275#2017-09-2916:01wparkerI agree with @mikerod ‚Äòs comments - perhaps another way of thinking about it is that if you just write a normal infinitely recursive function, Clojure or any other programming language can throw a StackOverflowException but can‚Äôt automatically recover from it - the language would have to guess what the programmer actually wanted to do in order to accomplish that#2017-09-2916:02wparkerI see Clara‚Äôs handling of infinitely looping rules as similar - there‚Äôs no way for Clara to guess what the user actually wanted to do#2017-09-2916:03mikerodCool, forgot you logged that issue before#2017-09-2921:58dadairIs there a way for someone to override what is printed when an exception is thrown? I have a fact with a very large map and when an exception is thrown it tries to print it as a binding and the REPL basically becomes unresponsive.#2017-09-2922:37mikerod@dadair I‚Äôve had similar issues before#2017-09-2922:38mikerodTrying to think of a workaround#2017-09-2922:39mikerodI think printing the bindings directly in the exception message can be a little ambitious since sometimes there are really large bindings. They can be really big due to things like acc/all too#2017-09-2922:39mikerodFrom the REPL, you may be able to get by with try + catch around when you run the rules?#2017-09-2922:39mikerodso catch the exception to not let it print its default dump#2017-09-2922:40mikerodif you are encountering the error using something like clojure.test it automatically catches and prints exceptions I think. You may be able to override that behavior as well#2017-09-3001:00souenzzoDoes "query" is a slow operation? For lage sets, witch shoud be optimal? - One big query with "all"(possible) facts, with some "garbage" and use just what I really need - Many little query, with just what I really need,#2017-10-0104:54wparkerQueries are really just rules without a RHS, at least in the current implementation. There are some optimizations that could be done on queries that aren‚Äôt valid for rules; for my part none of my use-cases have yet had enough of a problem to warrant spending the time implementing them. Note that the results are calculated during fire-rules, and calling ‚Äúquery‚Äù is really just a map get operation. Filters that can be expressed as values of bindings can end up being expressed as just map gets if the query parameters are set appropriately. Otherwise, to be honest its hard to say much about perf without knowing more specifics. My personal bias would be to express as much as possible in declarative logic e.g. ‚Äúlittle queries‚Äù and then address any concrete perf problems that come up, but obviously the optimal strategy depends a lot on your use-case.#2017-10-0102:56Oliver GeorgeThanks @mikerod & @wparker. No great surprise. I did wonder if keeping track of inputs for truth maintenance provided a mechanism to detect a loop. e.g. If one of my inputs is based on my output then raise exception.#2017-10-0103:40mikerodYeah I‚Äôm not sure. There may be some possibility for the truth maintenance to detect a cycle in the automatic retraction stuff. Haven‚Äôt thought that one through before. #2017-10-0518:52dghas anyone ever seen an exception from (explain-activations session) when the rules are all working well? 
UnsupportedOperationException nth not supported on this type: PersistentArrayMap  clojure.lang.RT.nthFrom (RT.java:947)
#2017-10-0519:01dgit seems like explain-activations may just be broken. it expects (:matches explanation) to be a vector of [fact condition] but it's actually a map of {:fact .. :condition ... }#2017-10-0519:03ennI have a clause like this: 
[:not
   [:and
    (x (= ?foo foo))
    (y (= ?foo bar))]]
When it fires, I get this error: > Using variable that is not previously bound‚Ä¶. Note that variables used in negations are not bound for subsequent rules since the negation can never match. To my thinking, the y clause is not a subsequent rule since it‚Äôs part of the same :and. I want the clause to match cases where this combination of x and y facts doesn‚Äôt exist, though an individual x or y fact may exist. How can I express this?#2017-10-0519:47mikerod@dg looks like you took care of that with https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/346 ?#2017-10-0519:48dgyeah#2017-10-0519:53mikerod@enn So Clara (similar to some other rete-based engines) convert the logical structures to DNF (disjunctive normal form). This is typically done to simplify the Rete tree construction and data flow.#2017-10-0519:53mikerodSo in this case, it‚Äôd be NOT (X AND Y) converted to NOT X OR NOT Y and the OR divides the two clauses into distinct chunks. To deal with this, there is typical special handling for ‚Äúnegated conjunctions‚Äù.#2017-10-0519:53mikerodI wouldn‚Äôt expect this behavior since Clara has some special handling of a negated conjunction like this.#2017-10-0519:53mikerodIs your rule more complex than just what you posted here?#2017-10-0520:04enn@mikerod yes, a bit more complex--here‚Äôs a more accurate version of that clause, and there are also other clauses in the rule: 
[:not
   [:and
    (x
     (= ?foo foo))
    (y
     ((set (map :id ?foo)) foo_id)
     (= ?previously_bound_lvar other_id))]]
#2017-10-0520:04ennI wonder if the set membership check was messing things up?#2017-10-0520:04ennI ended up working around it by getting all values of x.foo in an accumulator, then doing a :not clause checking those values (if any) against y.foo_id#2017-10-0520:05mikerod> I wonder if the set membership check was messing things up? I don‚Äôt think it should#2017-10-0520:05mikerodSo the :not clause is not nested within anything else though right?#2017-10-0520:05ennno#2017-10-0520:07mikerodI‚Äôd have to mess around with that one to see what may be teh issue#2017-10-0520:07mikerodHowever, https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/342 could also be related to that sort of logic. There was some edge cases to how it was handled.#2017-10-0520:07mikerodThis isn‚Äôt the same as the binding not being present in the rule though#2017-10-0520:08ennIt‚Äôs interesting to hear that it should work. I‚Äôll see if I can come up with a minimal test case, and open a ticket if so.#2017-10-0520:12mikerodthat‚Äôd be good to see#2017-10-0520:17mikerod
(r/mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:not
                     [:and
                      [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]]])])
#2017-10-0520:17mikerod
ExceptionInfo Using variable that is not previously bound. This can happen when an expression uses a previously unbound variable, or if a variable is referenced in a nested part of a parent expression, such as (or (= ?my-expression my-field) ...). 
Note that variables used in negations are not bound for subsequent
                                    rules since the negation can never match.
Production: 
{:lhs [[:not [:and {:type :x, :constraints [(= ?z (:z this))]}]]], :params #{}}
Unbound variables: #{?z}  clojure.core/ex-info (core.clj:4593)
#2017-10-0520:18mikerodThat is pretty minimal#2017-10-0520:33mikerod@enn I think the issue is that Clara it not allowing a condition within a negation to introduce a new bound variable#2017-10-0520:35mikerodThis gets even more minimal: 
(mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:not [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]])])
fails due to Unbound variables: #{?z} yet this is ok: 
(mk-session
 [(dsl/parse-query []
                   [[:y ( = ?z (:z this))]
                    [:not [:x (= ?z (:z this))]]])])
#2017-10-0520:35mikerodThe case of a single condition making a bound variable within a negation doesn‚Äôt make sense. However, in negated conjunction like in your previous example it does. I think this may be an edge case that Clara isn‚Äôt appropriately handling.#2017-10-0520:36mikerodI can log the issue#2017-10-0520:45mikerodLogged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/347#2017-10-0521:27ennThank you!#2017-10-0521:33afurmanovHi, I wonder if I have facts like Shape, Rectangle, Square, what would be recommended way to query all shapes?#2017-10-0521:58afurmanovI am new to Clojure/Clara, and what I am trying to achieve is to make query find-all-shapes to return rectangles as well as squares: 
(ns dsl.test
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]
    ))

(defrecord Shape [center])
(defrecord Rectangle [center width height])
(defrecord Square [center width])


(defquery find-all-shapes
  []
  [?result <- Shape]
  )

(println (-> (mk-session 'dsl.test)
           (insert
             (->Rectangle [1 1] 2 3)
             (->Square [3 3] 5))
           (fire-rules)
           (query find-all-shapes)))
#2017-10-0521:59afurmanovFrom clara documentation I guess I have to make Shape an ancestor of Rectangle and Square, but not sure how to do this and wether it is right direction at all.#2017-10-0522:00mikerod@alex.furmanov Clara‚Äôs defaults are to use the type and ancestors fn‚Äôs from Clojure#2017-10-0522:01mikerodSo you can work it into those in several different ways#2017-10-0522:01mikerodI‚Äôm not sure if you are using clj or cljs#2017-10-0522:01afurmanovclj#2017-10-0522:02mikerodif you are using clj and like defrecord to define your types you could just make a marker interface and use the standard Java type hierarchy 
(definterface Shape)
(defrecord Rectangle [center width height] Shape)
<etc>
#2017-10-0522:02mikerodYou could also utilize Clojure‚Äôs derive#2017-10-0522:03mikerodFrom your example it isn‚Äôt completely clear, but I don‚Äôt think you actually have facts that are actually the type Shape e.g. (->Shape [1 1]) right?#2017-10-0522:04afurmanovNo, the real case is different: facts are indications of some sort of progress.#2017-10-0522:06afurmanovSome could be as simple as counter, others are pairs [invites, money], other type of progress possible#2017-10-0522:07afurmanovThanks, @mikerod! The (definterface ...) works!#2017-10-0522:11mikerodNo problem. Technical note: for Clojure I would choose definterface as the way to mark the record hierarchy just because using defprotocol for it‚Äôs underlying generated interface is a bit of a gray area. You could get away with defprotocol as well though. It has edge cases though and it may be better to avoid.#2017-10-0522:14mikerodIf you are still interested, what I mean is, e.g. 
(defprotocol Shape)

(extend-type String Shape)
Doesn‚Äôt mean that String‚Äôs are now considered to be Shape‚Äôs by the built-in Clojure type hierarchy. Also, the protocol will leave a var by the name of Shape that will clash with the classname produced in your ns and that is confusing as well.#2017-10-0522:25afurmanovI did not know that, thanks for explanations!#2017-10-0523:41afurmanovHow to call interface method in LHS constraint? 
(definterface IProgress
  (^int counter [])
  (^int customer [])
  )

(defrecord SpecialIProgress [counter_ customer_ details] IProgress
  (counter [this] (+ counter_ 1))
  (customer [this] 1)
  )

(defquery find-all-i-progresses
  []
;;  [?result <- IProgress (= 1 .customer)] ;; DOES NOT WORK
  [?result <- IProgress]
  )

(println (-> (mk-session 'dsl.test)
  (insert
    (->SpecialIProgress 2 1 "2 out of 3"))
  (fire-rules)
  (query find-all-i-progresses)))
#2017-10-0523:42afurmanovIf I uncomment [?result <- IProgress (= 1 .customer)] line I am getting an error: "Unable to resolve symbol: .customer in this context"#2017-10-0523:44afurmanovCannot use customer in constraint either, same type of error#2017-10-0523:47afurmanovThis: https://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/definterface#example-5568aadfe4b03e2132e7d175 is saying that "Using an interface, only the dot form of the method is available with defrecord"#2017-10-0613:16zylox.customer is a method isnt it?#2017-10-0613:16zyloxhave you tried (= 1 (.customer this))#2017-10-0613:18zyloxjust tried it with your code and it worked for me#2017-10-0613:19zylox@alex.furmanov#2017-10-0613:44huwigsI have a question about accumulators ‚Äî is there a reason to do aggregation in a clara accumulator vs. in a RHS of something that uses all to get the values?#2017-10-0613:45huwigsuse case is a value computed from each fact that is then averaged#2017-10-0614:13afurmanovThanks @zylox - that is indeed working!#2017-10-0614:14mikerod@steve313 Technically there may be performance advantages in that you are allowing the engine to have potential optimizations to avoid doing unnecessary work. However, some of that would relate to how performant the accumulator implementation is.#2017-10-0614:15huwigsthanks#2017-10-0614:15mikerodAlso, you keep things a bit more structured and declarative to pull as much out of the RHS as you can#2017-10-0614:15mikerodHowever, there are times when the RHS may be justified just due to it being too complicated to try to fit into an accumulator. There is somewhat of a judgement call at times.#2017-10-0614:15mikerodIt‚Äôs a good question for sure. I‚Äôve seen it come up fairly often.#2017-10-0614:20huwigsI am still early in the learning curve; think I figured out how to do the LHS relatively simply#2017-10-0614:20mikerodthat‚Äôs good#2017-10-0614:21mikerodOne pattern that is easy to fall into, when new to trying to implement logic via rules, is to have a tendency to put a lot of code in the RHS#2017-10-0614:21mikerodwhich sort of defeats the purpose. Accumulators are a bit of a more complex case, but in general it is often beneficial to try to keep the RHS as minimal as possible. Typically just ‚Äúinsert some facts‚Äù#2017-10-0615:09huwigsI have pretty large tables of values‚Ä¶ do people find that it‚Äôs often necessary to do some ‚Äúfact‚Äù lookups outside of the engine?#2017-10-0616:05zyloxNot really no, but im not 100% sure what you mean.#2017-10-0616:19huwigsWell, there are facts related to combinations of values (i.e. if a person is female, 18, and single, the value of some new fact should be X, but if they are male, 29, and married, the value of some new fact should be Y) ‚Äî seems like I could use unification and declare each one of those mappings to be facts (->MyValue :female 18 :single X), (->MyValue :male 29 :married Y)#2017-10-0616:19huwigsor i could just look up those values in an RHS that takes a Person fact#2017-10-0616:19dadairCouldn't you use a DSL to parse your table into rules?#2017-10-0616:20dadairOr you could have condition facts#2017-10-0616:20huwigsI‚Äôm sure I could generate rules from the table values but I‚Äôm not sure if that is a good approach#2017-10-0616:20huwigssome tables have thousands or tens of thousands of rows#2017-10-0617:47mikerod@steve313 I am trying to understand the situation still. It isn‚Äôt clear to me what a row of this table represents or what information it has#2017-10-0617:47mikerodany dummy example?#2017-10-0617:49huwigsThe table itself is structured like (k1, k2, k3, v1, v2, v3, v4, v5)‚Ä¶ imagine something like that#2017-10-0617:49huwigser, like this:#2017-10-0617:49huwigs`#2017-10-0617:51huwigsFor many many permutations of k1,k2,k3#2017-10-0617:52huwigsnot sure if that snippet came through? slack saying i ran out of space#2017-10-0617:52huwigs
k1  k2  k3  v1  v2  v3  v4  v5  v6  v7  v8
17  F   S   2.1647  3.8128  2.9743  1.4490  2.7630  0.3837  3.4900  1.1400  3.1700
18  F   S   2.8955  3.4350  1.4777  1.4490  2.4809  0.9656  2.9640  1.1058  2.6980
19  F   S   2.2341  2.7573  1.3664  1.4490  2.2500  0.8800  2.5947  1.1058  2.3622
20  F   S   1.8131  2.1821  1.9299  1.4490  1.7000  0.8900  2.2692  1.0944  2.0646
21  F   S   1.7448  2.0645  1.9294  1.4490  1.6500  0.8800  2.2176  1.1286  2.0196
#2017-10-0617:53huwigsnow, in the rules engine we have facts that can provide (k1, k2, k3) values and want to know what a v1 value for that combination is#2017-10-0617:54huwigsright now i just looked it up in a map i read from the file in an rhs#2017-10-0617:54mikerodok, that does make the idea clearer to me to think about#2017-10-0617:54huwigsbut in theory those could all be facts#2017-10-0617:54mikerodYou could put the table as a fact#2017-10-0617:54mikerodIt‚Äôs still a bit odd since the table would be big of course#2017-10-0617:55mikerodHowever, I‚Äôm not too sure it would even be an issue to just put each row in as a fact#2017-10-0617:55mikerodand then do a join between Person to one of those rows based on the k-criteria#2017-10-0617:55mikerodFrom the looks of it, these would be = based joins#2017-10-0617:56mikerodWhich are going to be the most efficient type in the engine too#2017-10-0617:56huwigsWell, I am ignoring the <lowest and >highest for the first column#2017-10-0617:56mikerodClara will automatically hash on binding keys and use that hash-based lookup for equal-based joins#2017-10-0617:57huwigsthere are values that aren‚Äôt strict equality based for that. I can probably hack it so the engine would only use equality based#2017-10-0617:57mikerodSo if the majority are equal based you may be fine still. Not completely sure though.#2017-10-0617:57huwigsyeah the comparison ones are edge cases#2017-10-0617:57mikerodHowever, if it is like 10K sort of facts doing < comparisons#2017-10-0617:57mikerodI‚Äôm not convinced you‚Äôd see much perf issues anwyasy#2017-10-0617:58mikerodIt may be a good idea to use a different fact type#2017-10-0617:58mikerodfor the ones that aren‚Äôt equal based#2017-10-0617:58mikerodmay help partition up the network#2017-10-0617:59mikerodsome of this is just high-level talk to. so may be too vague for you to go off of#2017-10-0618:00mikerodbut at a really high level#2017-10-0618:00mikerodsay you have 10K people - call that P#2017-10-0618:00mikerodand 100K rows that are eq join capable - call that E#2017-10-0618:00mikerodThen only 100 rows that are more expensive than eq - call it F#2017-10-0618:01mikerodYou‚Äôll have the P joining to E part will all be done with hash-based lookups/joins#2017-10-0618:01mikerodso you‚Äôll just have P x F comparisons on the non-eq, ‚Äúmore expensive‚Äù join tests#2017-10-0618:01mikerodSo the P, E factor is ‚Äúconstant‚Äù#2017-10-0618:02mikerodBut the non-eq-based table rows I‚Äôd put under a differnet fact type since that would ensure partitioning into groups like this#2017-10-0618:02mikerodignore my ‚Äúmore expensive‚Äù phrase#2017-10-0618:03huwigsso if we have a fact type for the E and a fact type for the F cases#2017-10-0618:03mikerodnot that relevant, it‚Äôs more about the multiplier#2017-10-0618:03huwigswould there be two rules, one joining PxE and one joining PxF ?#2017-10-0618:03mikerodyeah#2017-10-0618:03huwigsor use :or in one rule?#2017-10-0618:03mikerodI‚Äôd probably do 2 rules#2017-10-0618:03mikerod:or may be able to get you equivalent, but it may just be less readable#2017-10-0618:04huwigsright#2017-10-0618:04mikerodor more confusing#2017-10-0618:04mikerod:or is for the most part ‚Äúsyntax sugar‚Äù#2017-10-0618:04mikerodit isn‚Äôt short-circuiting#2017-10-0618:04huwigsOK#2017-10-0618:04mikerodit splits at that point and all the data flow goes down both ‚Äúbranches‚Äù of logic#2017-10-0618:05mikerodthe only reason I‚Äôd use :or in a case like this is something like#2017-10-0618:06mikerod
(r/defrule tester
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id)]
  [:or
   <your P,E and P,F joins here using the result from A,B above>]
=>
<etc>)
#2017-10-0618:06mikerodMeaning if you had some more conditions needed by both joins#2017-10-0618:07mikerodUsing :or above makes it so the network will share the work done in the prior conditions in the rule before the :or. So ‚Äúnode sharing‚Äù, as it is called in Rete terminology.#2017-10-0618:07mikerodIf you do it in separate rules, there still may be node sharing though. Clara tries to detect duplicate conditions.#2017-10-0618:07huwigsOK#2017-10-0618:07huwigsIt probably reads better as multiple rules almost always?#2017-10-0618:07mikerodJust pointing out times when :or may be nice. It also lets you not write stuff twice.#2017-10-0618:08mikerodI tend to say avoid :or unless you have noticeable/annoying duplication#2017-10-0618:08mikerodof previous conditions before the :or branching#2017-10-0618:09mikerodand back on your topic#2017-10-0618:09mikerodif you have 10-100K rows in a table, I may think inserting all these facts is fine#2017-10-0618:09mikerodif it were like 1 million rows, then maybe be a bit more concerned#2017-10-0618:10mikerodand I‚Äôd still probably try it and profile/ take note of the runtime degradation before trying a non-fact based approach#2017-10-0618:12mikerodAlso, it‚Äôs good to be aware of your ‚Äúhot spots‚Äù. A rule like 
(r/defrule joining
  [P (= ?age age)]
  [F (< ?age (:threshold this))]
=>
<etc>)
Is going to evaluate (< ?age (:threshold this)) (number of P) X (number of F) times#2017-10-0618:12mikerodso if that is a big number, then it becomes a hot spot and you may end up just being able to improve whatever test is done tehre#2017-10-0618:12huwigsOK. So if many of these facts would be reused from case to case, is the right thing to do to load the standard facts (from the tables above), keep around a binding to the initial session, and then for each subsequent set of queries, reuse the initial session?#2017-10-0618:12mikerodOr eliminate P facts that you know won‚Äôt match F (because they match something else with eq already perhaps).#2017-10-0618:12huwigsassuming that works on account of persistent data structures etc., just don‚Äôt want to load stuff from files many times#2017-10-0618:13mikerodI think what you said makes sense#2017-10-0618:13mikerodas long as your rules aren‚Äôt changing#2017-10-0618:13huwigsnope#2017-10-0618:13mikerodyou can reuse an ‚Äúinitially loaded‚Äù working memory state for those rules for different runs of new facts#2017-10-0618:13mikeroddefinitely a big win of Clara‚Äôs persistent, immutable working memory approach#2017-10-0620:56souenzzoThere is some way to dedup on insert? Example, if I insert (insert! ^{:type :foo}{:foo 33}) and then (insert! ^{:type :foo}{:foo 33}), then querty all :foo get just one?#2017-10-0620:57souenzzoYes, I know that (= ^{:type :foo}{} ^{:type :bar}{}) ;=> true#2017-10-0621:01wparker@souenzzo if you‚Äôre using queries, you could put an accumulator or an :exists on your query conditions to remove duplication in your results#2017-10-0621:06souenzzoIt's not about query... It's about session Duplicated facts are fire'ing rules in a loop..#2017-10-0621:10mikerod@souenzzo one approach I‚Äôve done#2017-10-0621:10mikerodintroduce an ‚Äúintermediate fact‚Äù#2017-10-0621:10mikerodthat can be duplicated#2017-10-0621:11mikerodthen have a rule that uses an accumulator acc/all on those possible duplicates#2017-10-0621:11mikerodand inserts only one in the presence of any number of them#2017-10-0621:12souenzzoGot it. I will try;#2017-10-0621:13mikerodAssuming you want to go from X facts to B facts, but do not want duplicates of B ‚Äúdownstream‚Äù: 
(r/defrule a-rule
  [X (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Intermediate ?v)))

(r/defrule aggregate-rule
  [?all <- (acc/all) :from [Intermediate]]
  [:test (seq ?all)]
  =>
  ;; Assume everything in `?all` is `=` otherwise do some merge, etc
  (r/insert! (map->B (first ?all))))

(r/defrule b-rule
  [B]
  =>
  <etc>)
#2017-10-0912:59souenzzoThis method is not working because I need acc both Intermediate and 'B`, to ensure that there are no repeated elements#2017-10-0621:15mikerodI‚Äôd use better naming though üòõ#2017-10-0912:59souenzzoThis method is not working because I need acc both Intermediate and 'B`, to ensure that there are no repeated elements#2017-10-0914:35zyloxwhy. no amount of intermediates can insert more than one B under this pattern. If you are saying you want to insert B only if there is only distinct Intermediates, you will need to use a smarter accumulator.#2017-10-1120:21devnWho's gonna be at the conj?#2017-10-1120:21devnAnyone?#2017-10-1120:24mikerod@devn not me this time around unfortunately#2017-10-1120:24devnah, too bad#2017-10-1120:24mikerodI‚Äôm jealous too. An anniversary#2017-10-1120:24mikerodand lots of good speakers#2017-10-1120:24devnthere wil be cake#2017-10-1120:24devnwill*#2017-10-1120:24mikerodI‚Äôve never been on a cake one#2017-10-1200:59ryanbrushUnfortunately I'm not able to make it, either. Too many things going on this fall.#2017-10-1309:02mmerIs there a way to change facts that have been inserted - what I want to do is to change the Records to include more information as it becomes available.#2017-10-1312:43mmerAnother question - is it possible to reference the name of a rule in a rule?#2017-10-1315:23zyloxas for the first question, you would want to retract the original and insert the newer one. This will require some logic outside of the rules network. Clara assumes immutability in its facts im pretty sure.#2017-10-1315:25zyloxsecond one: What are you wanting to do with a rule reference? You should be relying on the consequences of the right hand side of said rule on the state of the facts in the session to infer things. Maybe if you had a more specific case of what you are trying to do i can provide more specific advice there.#2017-10-1315:51mikerod> as for the first question, you would want to retract the original and insert the newer one. This will require some logic outside of the rules network. Clara assumes immutability in its facts im pretty sure. Yeah, I think that is common. If you aren‚Äôt concerned with a constantly growing working memory, i.e. append-only, you can get by with doing it all in rules#2017-10-1315:51mikerodIt seems to me that Clara should offer something to better support the ‚Äúupdate‚Äù pattern#2017-10-1315:53mikerodSomething like: 
(r/defrule update-fact
  [?current <- FactType (= ?id id)]
  [?update <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [UpdateFact (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/retract! ?current) ;; or if you wanted to remove updates altogether - with no accumulator on LHS `(apply r/retract! [?current ?update])`
  (r/insert! (do-update ?current ?update)))
To me seems like a pretty natural thing to do, but it violates truth maintenance since the supporting facts ?current and ?update are retracted that logically supported the r/insert!#2017-10-1315:54mikerodHowever, r/retract! is a bit at odds with Truth maintenance since it is ‚Äúorder-dependent‚Äù#2017-10-1315:54mikerodif you r/retract! something, but later the rule is found to be invalidated by some other retractions, you‚Äôd expect the r/retract! operation to be rolled back#2017-10-1316:02mikerodif you do append-only style, I think something like this works though: 
(defrecord UpdateFact [id timestamp stuff])
(defrecord FactType [id timestamp x y])
(defrecord FactTypeSnapshot [id timestamp x y])

(r/defrule current-fact
  [?current <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [FactTypeSnapshot (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (map->FactType ?current)))

(r/defrule update-fact-type

  [?update <- (acc/all) :from [UpdateFact (= ?id id) (= ?ts timestamp)]]
  [?current <- FactType (= ?id id) (< timestamp ?ts)]
  =>

  ;; Inserts a `FactTypeSnapshot w/ updates applied and `:timestamp` = `?ts`
  (r/insert! (do-update ?current ?update ?ts)))

(r/defrule using-fact-type
  [FactType (= ?id id) (= ?x x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (prn ?x))
#2017-10-1316:11mikerodThe key is to have way to represent snapshots of a fact over time - the FactTypeSnapshot, a way to select the one you want to use in rules - the FactType, a way to apply updates - via UpdateFact to those facts in a way that doesn‚Äôt cause a logical loop. Didn‚Äôt test this specifically, but I believe the idea plays out alright (for append-only working memory). Externally may tend to be smoother, as @zylox said, so often I‚Äôd go with that. I wonder if Clara could provide some sort of helpers for that though 
;;; Add a query to your ruleset to fetch facts you want to update 
(r/defquery find-fact [find-id]
  [?fact <- FactType (= id find-id)])

;;; Example external update fn
(defn do-update [session update]

  ;; Assumes :id uniquely identifies facts here
  (let [old (first (mapv :?fact (r/query sesssion find-fact :id (:id update))))]
    (-> session
        (r/retract old)
        (r/insert (update-fact old update))
        r/fire-rules)))
#2017-10-1414:22mmer@zylox Thanks for the reply.#2017-10-1415:20mmerSorry another simple question - do all facts have to be records?#2017-10-1418:21mikerod@mmer no. Clara allows for you to provide your own :fact-type-fn, for arbitrary ‚Äútype dispatch‚Äù, as well as :ancestors-fn for setting up ‚Äútype hierarchies‚Äù. This is all in much the same was as Clojure‚Äôs ad hoc hierarchies work via derive and isa? etc#2017-10-1418:21mikerodBy default, Clara uses clojure.core/type as to map a fact to type#2017-10-1418:21mikerodand clojure.core/ancestors to determine the isa? style relationships#2017-10-1418:21mikerodSo changing nothing, you can use plain maps with :type metadata#2017-10-1418:23mikerod
(r/defrule my-rule
 [:my-fact-type (= (:x this) ?x)]
 =>
 (println "hello"))

(-> (r/mk-session [my-rule])
     (r/insert (with-meta {:x 10} {:type :my-fact-type}))
    r/fire-rules)
#2017-10-1418:24mikerodHere are some docs on it http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2017-10-1513:43mmerAs usual thanks#2017-10-2119:24wadi.chemkhiHello#2017-10-2119:25wadi.chemkhii find my self having to restart the repl every time i change the rules in a different namespace#2017-10-2119:25wadi.chemkhii require it with :reload#2017-10-2119:26wadi.chemkhibut still changes are ignored#2017-10-2119:27wadi.chemkhii have a main namespace with (defsession my-session 'myapp.corerules 'myapp.module.morerules)#2017-10-2119:42wadi.chemkhii'm new both to clojure and clara#2017-10-2119:42wadi.chemkhiis there a way to simplify the workflow#2017-10-2120:12ryanbrush@wadi.chemkhi By default Clara caches rule sessions for efficiency, but this' isn't great for a REPL-based workflow. I like to set :cache false when working from the REPL to avoid this. The page is a bit old, but there's an example here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Using-Clara-from-the-REPL#2017-10-2120:13wadi.chemkhithnx @ryanbrush üòÑ#2017-10-2120:16ryanbrushSure thing!#2017-10-2122:00wadi.chemkhiwith clojurescript is it possible to define facts in different namespaces and have defsession work properly and require everything ?#2017-10-2122:00wadi.chemkhior do i need to require all facts from each rules namespace#2017-10-2122:00wadi.chemkhi?#2017-10-2122:05ryanbrushI don't use the Clojurescript version much but it should be as long everything is properly required.#2017-10-2122:10wadi.chemkhiI see, thnx again @ryanbrush#2017-10-2500:58souenzzo{:salience java.lang.Long/MIN_VALUE} is a bad idea?? It's a "final" accumulator.#2017-10-2504:30devn@souenzzo in what sense do you mean?#2017-10-2504:33devnWhy do you think it might be a bad idea?#2017-10-2512:18souenzzoThere is another way to tell "this should be the last one"?#2017-10-2514:20wparker@souenzzo using MIN_VALUE would work, it just wouldn‚Äôt necessarily be the last thing if you accidentally added another rule with the same salience value. If the rulesets are small and/or you‚Äôre the only one working on them that might not be a problem. For our large rulesets with lots of people working on them we find it convenient to have salience with domain-specific categories defined in a single location. If you do need other functionality the salience function is user-configurable, although it defaults to a simple numeric comparison.#2017-11-0120:49wparkerClara-rules release 0.16.1 is now available on Clojars. This contains several bugfixes and other minor improvements relative to 0.16.0. See the changelog for further details. As always please log an issue if you encounter regressions or other problems. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#2017-11-0120:53wparkerAlso, thanks to everyone who contributed to the release - @zylox @ethanc \@dgoeke#2017-11-0617:14souenzzoCan you put a time on each rule? Or a route to view the profile/debug the rules? There is something slow in my engine but I'm not sure how to find what it is.#2017-11-0617:29dadairmaybe run your engine under a profiler like VisualVM? can see what methods may be using the most time and go from there?#2017-11-0620:27wparkerIf the problem is a function in your rules (RHS, accumulator function, etc.) that‚Äôs taking a lot of time then something like VisualVM would likely be helpful. That‚Äôs where I‚Äôd start. If the problem is that the rules are firing in a bad/suboptimal way then Clara‚Äôs tracing could provide some info, but that is harder to use. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.cljc, the discussion on https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/344 around potential tracing enhancements could give some insight into how it works as well#2017-11-0622:16souenzzo@wparker I made a macro that wrap rhs inside a time-like macro, that time RHS and store it's time on a global atom (just for use on repl). It allow's me to see how many times each rule is fired, how many time each "burn" takes, avg, "total time" from each rule. Simple and usefull üòÑ#2017-11-0622:16souenzzo(now I'm using my-ns/defrule in place of clara.rules/defrule)#2017-11-0622:37wparkerGlad you‚Äôve found a working solution @souenzzo FYI, there are some cases where Clara could repeatedly add a rule to the queue of things waiting to be fired, remove it, add it again, etc. without ever actually firing it (and thus avoiding that macro) but my guess is those cases are a small though nontrivial minority of perf problems#2017-11-0622:45souenzzo@wparker I'm just trying to find any slow rhs. Insert or not insert, use or not, not matters. I find a single rule that takes 100x more time that any other. I think that not matter if it will be used or not, in this case.#2017-11-0715:49wparkerExcellent, sounds like you‚Äôve found your performance problem. üëç#2017-11-0622:38wparkerso that sounds like it would work most of the time#2017-11-1316:43Geoffrey GaillardHi ! I have troubles understanding how destructuring works in clara. If I understand the documentation correctly, I would expect this rule to match any record of type Foo and bind the symbol foo to the record itself, so I can use it afterward. 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [foo]]
  =>
  (do-something-with  foo))
I always get an Unable to resolve symbol: foo in this context, where context is the RHS. Am I missing something ?#2017-11-1317:07mikerod@ggaillard the destructured bound symbols are scoped locally to the expressions of the single condition doing the destructuring bind#2017-11-1317:08mikerodYou have to bind a variable to use throughout other conditions or the rule and/or the RHS#2017-11-1317:08mikerod
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [foo] (= ?foo foo)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?foo))
#2017-11-1317:11mikerodIn this case, it isn‚Äôt too useful#2017-11-1317:11mikerodThis would make more sense 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [?foo <- Foo]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?foo))
#2017-11-1317:12Geoffrey GaillardOh I get it ! Thank you !#2017-11-1317:12mikerodtimes like: 
(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo [{:keys [x y]}] (< 10 x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?y))
are where it may be more useful#2017-11-1317:14mikerodAlso note that when using Clojure records (i.e. defrecord classes) and/or, on the JVM side, Java POJOs adhering to the Java bean spec, Clara automatically makes the field names visible in the local scope of a condition‚Äôs experssions 
(defrecord Foo [x y])

(defrule do-something-with-foo
  [Foo (< 10 x) (= ?y y)]
  =>
  (do-something-with  ?y))
Would work without the explicit destructuring syntax#2017-11-1317:24Geoffrey GaillardI was using your last example until now to extract my records' fields, and since I missed the <- part of facts expressions it quickly became inconvenient when I needed to work with every fields ‚Ä¶ Thanks for this clarification üôÇ#2017-11-1318:46mikerod@dave.dixon that is surprising to me#2017-11-1318:47mikerodI want to take a look#2017-11-1319:00mikerod@dave.dixon I think there is some sort of compilation issue happening with that rule#2017-11-1319:00mikerod
(defrule lost-game
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Loser)))
#2017-11-1319:00mikerodworksaround it#2017-11-1319:00mikerodI‚Äôm not sure the cause still#2017-11-1319:02sparkofreason@mikerod Thanks. I had several puzzling cases like this, will try the work-around when I get home #2017-11-1319:02mikerodTo me it is looking likely to be worthy of logging an issue to clara github though#2017-11-1319:02mikerodif you have more examples of different shapes, that‚Äôd be interesting too#2017-11-1319:07zyloxIs the test node making a binding somehow instead?....thatd be weird#2017-11-1319:10mikerod@zylox I think it is misintepreting it somehow along those lines#2017-11-1319:10mikerodno good#2017-11-1319:10mikerodI looked a a bit in clara.rules.compiler but I don‚Äôt see the issue yet#2017-11-1319:11mikerodIf you look at the rulebase for the network without the do (the problem case), the TestNode is a beta root with no parents#2017-11-1319:12mikerodAnd it‚Äôs children are the accumulate nodes#2017-11-1319:12mikerodThis made me suspicious of the function clara.rules.compiler/sort-conditions which does a topological type of sort of accumulators that rearranges some conditions#2017-11-1319:12mikerodThe topo sort is supposed ensure that any used variable binding is pushed below it‚Äôs creation unification binding condition#2017-11-1319:15mikerodAdding the do in the :test node pushes it down as a child of the accumulate nodes in the network and then it works#2017-11-1319:22mikerodIt may be completely a problem with the sort, as the below demonstrates 
(ns test.ns
  (:require [clara.rules :as r]
            [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
            [clara.rules.compiler :as com]))

(defrecord Ship [])
(defrecord Destroyed [])
(defrecord Loser [])

(r/defrule lost-game-fixed
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]                           ;; Notice the `do` surrounding form is important for the sort
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Loser)))

(r/defrule lost-game-broken
  [?ships <- (acc/count) :from [Ship]]
  [?destroyed <- (acc/count) :from [Destroyed]]
  [:test (= ?ships ?destroyed)]                                  ;; Condition with problem, doesn't work without surrounding form (`do` above)
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Loser)))


(com/sort-conditions (-> lost-game-fixed :lhs))
(comment
  ({:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Ship, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?ships}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Destroyed, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?destroyed}
   {:constraints [(do (= ?ships ?destroyed))]}))

(com/sort-conditions (-> lost-game-broken :lhs))
(comment
  ({:constraints [(= ?ships ?destroyed)]}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Ship, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?ships}
   {:accumulator (clara.rules.accumulators/count), :from {:type test.ns.Destroyed, :constraints []}, :result-binding :?destroyed}))
#2017-11-1319:22mikerodUnless I‚Äôm missing something else prior to this#2017-11-1319:30zyloxjuxt#2017-11-1319:48zyloxseems to be that classify-variables considers it an equality-expression?, resulting in them being considered "bound", but "unbound" in the workaround case#2017-11-1320:17zyloxand when they are bound, this fn https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L790 will consider it satisfied because #{} is a subset of #{?ships ?destroyed}, meaning newly-satisfied will contain the test constraint (https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L797) and be put in the front of the order in the into at the end https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L828#2017-11-1320:19zyloxim not sure of a good way to fix this. i can see why it thinks its a bound variable.#2017-11-1320:28sparkofreasonThat fixed it, as well as the other cases, which were essentially the same, with an equality check inside of [:test].#2017-11-1320:33wparkerThe compilation of this rule does seem to be wrong. When I inspect the rule network the :test condition seems to completely not exist in the network. Gist with the pretty-printed network: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/a3adaa3db730229bc01586009bb7178a#2017-11-1320:35wparkerHowever, if I use join-filter-equals it is there: https://gist.github.com/WilliamParker/347ba6ca3f7e0afc2c9f183e0731111e#2017-11-1320:35wparkerJoin-filter-equals just dispatches to =:#2017-11-1320:36wparker
(defn join-filter-equals
  "Intended to be a test function that is the same as equals, but is not visible to Clara as such
  and thus forces usage of join filters instead of hash joins"
  [& args]
  (apply = args))
it is a helper function for Clara‚Äôs tests#2017-11-1320:36wparkerSame idea really as wrapping in a do like @mikerod did#2017-11-1320:38wparkerClara has special cases around constraints having = as the first symbol in order to create variable bindings, but when the first symbol is something else if becomes a ‚Äúnormal‚Äù call to clojure.core/=. @zylox is probably on the right track here with looking at different paths depending on whether equality-expression? returns true#2017-11-1320:40wparkerI‚Äôll need to look more closely at it to have an informed opinion on the exact cause and what to do about it but this does look like a bug to me @dave.dixon You should be able to avoid it for the moment with strategies that prevent = from being the first symbol in a :test constraint for the moment though#2017-11-1322:13wparkerI logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/357 for this @dave.dixon @zylox @mikerod#2017-11-1322:15mikerod@wparker thanks for making it#2017-11-1322:15mikerodthe only thing maybe worth adding is my comment showing how the sort conditions comes out incorrect#2017-11-1322:15mikerodI can add as a comment though, or perhaps it isn‚Äôt necessary since everyone looking at it already knows anyways üòõ#2017-11-1322:15wparkerFeel free to comment on it with thoughts anyone üôÇ#2017-11-1322:16wparkerI haven‚Äôt dug too deeply into it yet#2017-11-1322:25mikerodsame#2017-11-1418:21zyloxwhen are you getting that exception#2017-11-1418:23zyloxsession creation time it would appear#2017-11-1418:33sparkofreasonYes, it's at session creation.#2017-11-1418:36zyloxya sort-conditions specifically it would appear. im not as versed on queries though#2017-11-1418:37zyloxi cant get parameters to work unless they are used in a binding though. that doesnt seem right.#2017-11-1418:45zylox
(clara.rules/defquery ship-destroyed-at?
          [:?point]
          [?destroyed <- Destroyed (= ?ship ship)]
          [?placement <- ValidPlacement 
           (= ?ship ship)
           ((spaces this) ?point)])
for the record this doesnt seem to work either so its not the test node#2017-11-1418:45mikerodYeah, my first recommendation was going to be to not use a :test node when it isn‚Äôt necessary (although I‚Äôd still expect that to work)#2017-11-1418:45mikerodHowever, @zylox has found that that is still a problem#2017-11-1418:47zyloxif i had to guess, the check this exception uses is too special cased and doesnt consider parameters.#2017-11-1418:47zyloxits the whole unbound vs bound thing again#2017-11-1418:48zyloxso its at least partially related to the thing from yesterday#2017-11-1418:51ryanbrushThe above queries won't work because ?point is not bound, although we could be more clear in our error messaging here.#2017-11-1418:52ryanbrushThe :?point is a query parameter, which just does a lookup. A query parameter is not "bound" when the rule engine is processing...it is simple used to look up bound values.#2017-11-1418:52ryanbrushSince ?point is never bound in the query itself, we get that error message.#2017-11-1418:54ryanbrushThese semantics are a bit confusing in this case because we're conflating query parameters (which do not bind a variable) with variables that must be bound with an (= ?my-variable ...) or similar expression.#2017-11-1418:58mikerodWoops, that makes sense to me. I blanked about how they were supposed to work here.#2017-11-1419:00sparkofreasonSo presumably the way to attack this is to make a new fact using those conditions, rather than trying to just query?#2017-11-1419:06zyloxClearly I need to brush up on queries#2017-11-1419:06zylox...pun not intended#2017-11-1419:38ryanbrush@dave.dixon Separating this out into another fact makes sense. I'm not quite sure what your objective for these rules is, but any approach that explicitly binds ?point in the query logic (not just the parameter) should work.#2017-11-1423:03sparkofreasonThat worked great, thanks.#2017-11-1922:29sparkofreasonSorry if this is documented somewhere, but I didn't catch it. Is there some best practice around handling fact identity for updates? For example, if have (defrecord Person [name address]), and I want to update the address, or perhaps even insert the same Person (by value) twice. Is there some way to tell clara to use name to identify the Person and change the replace the existing fact, or do I have to explicitly retract the existing instance? Or am I totally missing something for modeling this situation?#2017-11-1923:30mikerod> do I have to explicitly retract the existing instance? Yes, the idea is to do this sort of change explicitly#2017-11-1923:31mikerodand there is no concept of mutating a fact ‚Äúin place‚Äù#2017-11-1923:31mikerodThere are several ways to approach the problem#2017-11-1923:34mikerod@dave.dixon one idea is if you don‚Äôt actually care about deleting old data (perhaps you want to have it for historical rules etc), you could put an intermediary between external ‚Äúperson data at a point in time‚Äù vs the ‚Äúcurrent person‚Äù being processed: 
(r/defrule current-person
  [?latest <- latest-person-acc :from [PersonSnapshot (= ?name name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Person ?latest)))
#2017-11-1923:34mikerodThis is if you made some sort of latest-person-acc that chose the latest by some criteria of yours (like a PersonSnapshot timestamp)#2017-11-1923:34mikerodYou could use the clara.rules.accumulators/max for this#2017-11-1923:35mikerod
(r/defrule current-person
  [?latest <- (acc/max :timestamp) :from [PersonSnapshot (= ?name name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->Person ?latest)))
#2017-11-1923:36mikerodYou may not want to leave facts in though due to a concern, like memory use or something. Then a common way to deal with the update is somewhat external to the rules processing themselves#2017-11-1923:48mikerod
(defrecord Person [name x])

(r/defquery person-with-name [:?name]
  [?p <- Person (= ?name name)])

(def init
  (-> (r/mk-session [person-with-name])
      (r/insert (->Person "joe" 10)
                (->Person "mary" 20))
      r/fire-rules))

(defn find-person-by-name [session pname]
  ;; Assumes name is unique (you could do something different)
  (-> session
      (r/query person-with-name :?name pname)
      first
      :?p))

(defn update-person [session new-person]
  (let [existing (find-person-by-name session (:name new-person))]
    (-> session
        (r/retract existing)
        (r/insert new-person)
        r/fire-rules)))

(def updated
  (update-person init (->Person "joe" 50)))



;; Then try:

(find-person-by-name init "joe")
(find-person-by-name updated "joe")
#2017-11-1923:49mikerodThat sort of pattern would allow you take rm and old version of the person and insert an update#2017-11-1923:49mikerodand it avoids getting into situations within the engine where you have to deal with logical loops in the truth maintenance system and/or unconditional inserts, RHS retracts, etc#2017-11-1923:50mikerodYou could impl the update-person differently where you just make a change to the existing fact to get some data structural sharing too though instead of a brand new fact like I had#2017-11-1923:52mikerode.g. 
(defn update-person [session new-person-data]
  (let [existing (find-person-by-name session (:name new-person-data))
        up (merge existing new-person-data)]
    (-> session
        (r/retract existing)
        (r/insert up)
        r/fire-rules)))

;; e.g.
(update-person init {:name "joe" :x 50})
#2017-11-2000:31sparkofreason@mikerod Thanks for the excellent and detailed answer!#2017-11-2317:33sparkofreasonI think I found the problem. The call to resolve-vars at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/macros.clj#L183 only binds the Clojure namespace. At this point in compilation, the CLJS namespace is not correct. Adding this to the binding fixes the issue: cljs.analyzer/*cljs-ns* (:ns-name production)#2017-12-0213:51mikerodIt‚Äôs on Twitter, but I thought it was cool enough to share here too: Clara on the ThoughtWorks Technology Radar https://www.thoughtworks.com/es/radar/languages-and-frameworks/clara-rules#2017-12-0223:59alex-dixonJust came to say congratulations!#2017-12-1320:11dadairIs there any way to get cloverage coverage statistics for clara defrules?#2017-12-1322:47wparkerI suspect that Clara does enough code generation and evaluation behind the scenes to confuse tooling like Cloverage, at least without some modification to specifically support Clara, but it isn‚Äôt something I‚Äôve looked into. I don‚Äôt think the rules network could be effectively statically analyzed but perhaps something could be created that looked at what rules were interacted with; that information is available via Clara‚Äôs tracing#2017-12-1401:56mikerodI‚Äôm not even sure how Cloverage performs its analysis. Is it via tools.analyzer ?#2017-12-1418:16dadairI'm not exactly sure how it works; but a search in the repo for tools.analyzer returns empty#2017-12-1418:17dadairI'm mostly just interested in seeing what rules are firing during tests, to make sure I have sufficient tests.#2017-12-1420:10devn@U0E2EQFME you could do some reading of the inspected session #2017-12-1420:10devnOr maybe attach a tracing listener to track the rules fired #2017-12-1420:10devnThat information should be available via either method #2017-12-1420:20mikerodYeah, I think I looked at it before and it didn‚Äôt use analyzer. Not sure how it can check coverage. Especially via macros.#2017-12-1420:20mikerodperhaps magic#2017-12-1920:04mikerod@amarjeet you cut it off I think#2017-12-1920:07mikerodIt only shows about 5 lines#2017-12-1921:27wparker@mikerod I can see a larger snippet after I expand it in my OS X Slack client. @amarjeet I‚Äôd have to see lines creating sessions and inserting facts to fully understand what you‚Äôre doing, but it sounds like you may believe that a fact {:some :value} will match a condition like [{:some :value}]. This is not the case; Clara uses the fact type, not the fact itself, to match on conditions. So for example {:some :value} would match [java.util.Map] by default, though you can customize the function used for this dispatch. This is documented at http://clara-rules.org; I can‚Äôt hit the site right now but the page‚Äôs markdown source is https://github.com/cerner/clara-site/blob/gh-pages/_docs/fact_type_customization.md#2017-12-1921:28mikerod@wparker I can see it on the side bar (same client as you), not sure why it won‚Äôt expand otherwise. Anyways, irrelevant than woops.#2017-12-2005:50amarjeet@wparker#2017-12-2014:50mikerod@amarjeet thatnks for sharing more there#2017-12-2014:50mikerodSo the first level of discrimination in the rules network is going always ‚Äúfact type‚Äù#2017-12-2014:51mikerodHowever, the combination of :fact-type-fn and :ancestors-fn give you flexibility into what that means#2017-12-2014:52mikerodThe default :fact-type-fn is Clojure‚Äôs clojure.core/type, which is just (or (get (meta x) :type) (class x))#2017-12-2014:52mikerodThe default :ancestors-fn is clojure.core/ancestors which respects the ‚Äúglobal hierarchy‚Äù in Clj which can be altered via things like derive#2017-12-2014:53mikerod:ancestors-fn is just for making the supertype subtype relationships that factor into the fact type dispatch#2017-12-2014:53mikerodYou don‚Äôt necessarily have to have a ‚Äúfact type‚Äù if you really don‚Äôt want, or you can make it something that is based on the data of the map entities you have#2017-12-2014:54mikerod(def session-one (mk-session 'modelxt.absmodel :fact-type :name)) for example, although that isn‚Äôt very suitable for the rule add-entity that you have#2017-12-2016:03amarjeethmm, understood#2017-12-2016:04amarjeetWill re-look at the fact-type-fn/ancestors-fn#2017-12-2016:05amarjeetthanks @mikerod#2017-12-2016:08mikerodNo problem#2017-12-2202:02cflemingIs Clara‚Äôs fact destructuring as described here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ the same as Clojure‚Äôs destructuring?#2017-12-2202:17mikerod@cfleming the part of the syntax shown there uses Clojure destructuring. It basically ends up being a clojure function arglist that takes a single object. #2017-12-2202:18mikerodBut yes. It just ‚Äúflows through‚Äù to standard destructuring. #2017-12-2202:18cflemingOk, great, thanks.#2017-12-2202:18mikerodNo problem. #2017-12-2202:24cfleming@mikerod One more question while I have you - in the doc, is FACT_CONSTRAINT always a Fact Expression as defined in the doc, or is it any condition?#2017-12-2202:25cfleming(I‚Äôm working on specs for the Clara macros right now)#2017-12-2202:27mikerodtaking a look#2017-12-2202:28mikerodI don‚Äôt see a FACT_CONSTRAINT referenced in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ ?#2017-12-2202:28mikerodnevermind see it#2017-12-2202:29cflemingIt‚Äôs in Boolean Expressions and also Accumulators#2017-12-2202:30mikerodOk, it is a fact expression as referred to above#2017-12-2202:31cflemingGreat, thanks.#2017-12-2202:31cflemingHopefully I‚Äôll have something basic working soon, I‚Äôll push it for comments - there are still a bunch of TODOs in there.#2017-12-2202:31mikerodThere may be times when it is odd to do something like bind a fact to a variable, but I think the syntax typically allows these cases - even if they don‚Äôt end up being useful.#2017-12-2202:31mikerodThat is cool. Sounds interesting#2017-12-2202:32mikerodI‚Äôll try to give a look at it too once you have it out there.#2017-12-2202:32cflemingGreat, thanks - this is re: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/367#2017-12-2202:32mikerodI‚Äôm still catching up on the GitHub conversation from earlier#2017-12-2202:32cflemingCool, no rush.#2017-12-2203:09cflemingI‚Äôve pushed https://github.com/cursive-ide/clara-specs#2017-12-2203:10cflemingIt contains a first cut at specs to match the macros in the Clara DSL - they match all the examples from the documentation correctly as far as I can tell.#2017-12-2203:10cflemingThere are still some TODOs in there which weren‚Äôt clear to me from the doc, mostly stubbed out with any?#2017-12-2203:11cflemingMy next task is to try it on the clara-examples repo and make sure it works for the examples there too.#2017-12-2203:12cfleming@alex-dixon @mikerod ^^ FYI#2017-12-2203:19mikerod@cfleming nice. I see a few things to tweak but mostly it is looking pretty close to what I‚Äôd think is right#2017-12-2203:19cflemingGreat, thanks - feel free to file an issue or just let me know what to change and I‚Äôll update it.#2017-12-2203:21cflemingI‚Äôll have to figure out how the symbol resolution should work for unification variables too.#2017-12-2203:21cfleming(in Cursive, that is, not required for the specs).#2017-12-2203:21mikerodTomorrow I can give some better notes. So that‚Äôs a harder one I think. #2017-12-2203:23mikerodYeah RHS is just like an implicit do#2017-12-2203:23mikerodBlock#2017-12-2203:23cflemingOk.#2017-12-2203:24cflemingBut I guess it should always have at least one form?#2017-12-2203:24mikerodYeah I believe the RHS needs at least one form. #2017-12-2203:25mikerodIf it didn‚Äôt it wouldn‚Äôt be a useful rule at least. Hah#2017-12-2203:25cflemingHehe#2017-12-2203:25mikerodThanks for trying this out!#2017-12-2203:26cflemingAlso, in the defquery doc it shows CONDITION repeated inside []#2017-12-2219:14mikerodThis is just a mistake in the docs. it should be the same as a rule in this part of a query#2017-12-2219:16mikerodwhat you have @ https://github.com/cursive-ide/clara-specs/commit/fa9f7aca57b7a4735d356f54e22399efc4534f72#diff-21ed98cbfbc6578b6ba48146b1f5b9aaR44 looks right#2017-12-2302:08cflemingGreat, thanks Mike#2017-12-2302:09cflemingLooks like these are pretty close to correct then. So it wouldn‚Äôt be the first of that sort. #2017-12-2302:28mikerodWe should reference your repo in the github issue on Clara related to this spec‚Äôing too to be sure everyone sees it#2017-12-2302:31mikerodI‚Äôm sure people will like to get some cursive support from this too.
