Have better understanding now. Your note helped üôÇ#2017-12-2213:31souenzzoThere is docs about props? http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/ :salience is the unique "relevant" value inside this map?#2017-12-2214:15mikerod@souenzzo I‚Äôm not sure if there are docs about all props#2017-12-2214:16mikerodIt is a map of keyword to anything. :salience is one supported one. The only other I can think of is :no-loop#2017-12-2214:18mikerodand usually you shouldn‚Äôt need to worry about :no-loop#2017-12-2214:25souenzzoI'm annotating some data to use on inspect. outside a name conflict, should not be a problem, right?#2017-12-2214:26mikerodYou want to put additional information in the props map for your own purposes you mean?#2017-12-2214:27souenzzoYep#2017-12-2214:27mikerodI think that should be ok. You probably want to do something like use namespaced keywords though as keys#2017-12-2218:14alex-dixon@mikerod Could no loop could be used as a modify? Like if I wanted to increment each match at most once per fire rules?#2017-12-2218:35mikerod@alex-dixon like:#2017-12-2218:36mikerod
(r/defrule demo
  {:no-loop true}
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (r/insert! (update ?a :some-val inc)))
#2017-12-2218:36mikerod?#2017-12-2218:36mikerodand perhaps with a RHS (r/retract! ?a) before - actually not sure on this part - it is a secondary part of the question#2017-12-2218:40alex-dixonWith retract yeah. To simulate mutation #2017-12-2218:50mikerodIt may be feasible, something you‚Äôd want to be careful for proliferating everywhere#2017-12-2218:50mikerodwith r/retract! I actually dont‚Äô know#2017-12-2218:50mikerodI can‚Äôt remember if :no-loop will stop a truth maintenance retraction sort of loop - perhaps you‚Äôve tried?#2017-12-2218:51mikerodI‚Äôve mentioned on here before as well, if you don‚Äôt have a big concern with an always growing set of facts in working memory, you don‚Äôt need to retract. You can just ‚Äúmodify‚Äù and only base downstream logic on the ‚Äúlatest‚Äù#2017-12-2218:52mikerodhowever, for something long running or with many of these changes, memory use would get too high#2017-12-2222:20alex-dixon@mikerod This is the first I‚Äôve heard of no loop! I‚Äôm excited by it. Here‚Äôs an issue you raised a few years ago, looks like it led to truth maintenance being brought under the ‚Äúno loop‚Äù umbrella as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/99#2017-12-2223:04mikerod@alex-dixon oh nice. The memory has returned to me now (after reading that issue and comments again) hah#2017-12-2223:05mikerodIt‚Äôd be interesting to see how doing something like you said would go then#2017-12-2223:05mikerodif you retract the fact and insert the updated version of it#2017-12-2223:06mikerodthen all other rules that were based (or transitively based) only that removed fact would be retracted. However, the new updated version of the fact would then be available to rebuild those downstream results#2017-12-2223:06mikerodThat ma work out alright.#2017-12-2223:10mikerod@alex-dixon but be aware there are some edge cases to RHS retracts still.#2017-12-2223:10mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/321 are 2 I can immediately find#2017-12-2223:18alex-dixonI‚Äôm trying to understand the difference with that behavior and insert logical vs insert unconditional with an explicit retraction‚Ä¶.kind of a head spinner. It seems a lot of the landmines and complexity are tied up with insert logical. Would you agree?#2017-12-2223:35mikerod@alex-dixon Hmm. I think sticking to all logical insert is a reduction of complexity#2017-12-2223:36mikerodThere are just cases when it is difficult to express what you want with only the built-in logical truth maintenance.#2017-12-2223:36mikerodDoing things like unconditional insert and RHS retracts are subversions to the truth maintenance system (aka TMS). With that comes difficulty#2017-12-2223:37mikerodThe reason TMS and logical insertion are so useful is that they allow for a much larger degree of rule order evaluation independence.#2017-12-2223:37mikerodI think what Clara may be lacking most is a way to explicitly ‚Äúupdate‚Äù a fact.#2017-12-2223:38mikerodThe more I think of it coming up, the more it seems like it‚Äôd be a nice first-class thing that ensured that it had well defined semantics with how it interacted with TMS.#2017-12-2223:39mikerodHowever, I have mentioned before, that you can also make an external process that handles ‚Äúupdates‚Äù or retractions - leaving the rules part all logical insert + TMS.#2017-12-2223:39mikerodHowever, that is still a manual thing right now. I‚Äôve posted on here a few times what that sort of thing looks like though.#2017-12-2300:46alex-dixonInteresting. And yeah seems we‚Äôre talking about the same with update/modify. I‚Äôm only slightly familiar with it from Drools.#2017-12-2300:48alex-dixonI searched the slack history at clojureverse and wasn‚Äôt able to find your explanation üòû. Sounds very intriguing. I‚Äôll keep looking and thinking about this over the holiday. Thanks so much for your responses they give me a lot to think about üôÇ#2017-12-2300:48mikerodI think I‚Äôll just make a blog post on the external update thing#2017-12-2300:49mikerodYeah, Drools had an update mechanism. I think they had some interesting optimizations done with it. Even more so in 6+ of it when they had a large overhaul to how the fact propagation of the rule network worked I think.#2017-12-2300:50mikerodI used to spend quite a bit of time trying to parse through the Drools codebase. It‚Äôs pretty ‚Äúintense‚Äù though üòõ#2017-12-2316:24alex-dixonHave you read Clara‚Äôs source? üòÑ#2017-12-2316:25mikerodHaha. Oh yes. I‚Äôm all caught up on that one. #2017-12-2316:22alex-dixonIs 6+ with the Phreak algorithm instead of Rete?#2017-12-2316:23alex-dixonSorry‚Ä¶I should just google that‚Ä¶.:)#2017-12-2316:25mikerodYep#2017-12-2316:26mikerodI don‚Äôt know that I fully consider it separate. But they do. It does have a lot of modifications over rete. However all modern rete impl‚Äôs do. #2017-12-2316:27mikerodThere are some good ideas there though. I think Clara is competitive with the optimization it has though in many cases. #2017-12-2316:29mikerodDrools 5 vs 6 added a lot of things at once. It makes it hard to know which ones are paying off the most. At least from what is public. I think the most important optimization was just the batched fact propagation across the network. That is done in Drools 6 phreak via a ‚Äúlazy‚Äù sort of evaluation of rules. #2017-12-2316:30mikerodClara could potentially do a bit better with lazy propagation. However just having the batched propagation seems to work pretty well already. #2017-12-2316:31alex-dixonI thought Phreak was more eager#2017-12-2316:33alex-dixonOverall I‚Äôm under the impression Clara was written with distributed computing in mind‚Ä¶I don‚Äôt know if other rule engines compete with that, and to me it seems like a ridiculously powerful feature#2017-12-2316:40mikerodHmm. It should be more lazy. Hah. There are lots of blogs on it by Drools people. Good blogs really. They put out some good content that is helpful more generally#2017-12-2316:41mikerodBut yes Clara does a good job in terms of its flexibility to be used in different ways. #2017-12-2316:41mikerodSome good abstractions in place. #2017-12-2316:46alex-dixonHave you used clara-storm or have any desire to run Clara across multiple instances?#2017-12-2316:57mikerodThat was Something Ryan put together early on with Clara. I believe he said it was mostly an experiment or demonstration of how it might be done. Not a production worthy product. #2017-12-2316:58mikerodAnd early on I think he had some thoughts about where to apply it but went in a different direction instead. I haven‚Äôt had the need but I‚Äôve spent a little time thinking about it. I think it‚Äôd be cool to see Clara used across Something like distributed processes#2017-12-2318:07ryanbrushYeah, Storm support was just an experiment for a need that never really materialized so we didn't pursue it further. The internals of Clara were designed to support a distributed working memory, so it could be something we pick up at some point.#2017-12-2318:19alex-dixonAll tests are passing last I checked üôÇ#2017-12-2318:22alex-dixonI‚Äôve been interested in two applications related to it. Mainly stream processing with Kafka but also web workers in the browser#2017-12-2320:16ryanbrushThe test coverage in that project is pretty weak, though. We're using Clara in Spark now, but are keeping working memory local to each worker...basically our workload lets us do groupby operations to group needed facts into a common process and then using Clara there.#2017-12-2400:44mikerod@alex-dixon I made a blog post on the topic of ‚Äúfact updates‚Äù in Clara @ http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html Perhaps something like it could be added to Clara docs later.#2017-12-2400:44mikerodIt is basically just reiterating things I‚Äôve discussed before in this Slack channel on the topic. We discussed this a little a day or so ago.#2017-12-2400:45alex-dixonAwesome. Thanks. Will read and share#2017-12-2400:46mikerodcool. feel free to let me know if you see problems with it or anything too#2017-12-2416:18alex-dixonVery well written. Really impressed at how quickly you were able to produce that‚Ä¶ üôÇ#2017-12-2416:24mikerodThanks!#2017-12-2416:31alex-dixonI haven‚Äôt figured out a good solution for ‚Äúdefault values‚Äù of facts. E.g. I have some rules I‚Äôm working on now for precept-devtools where I‚Äôm trying to allow the user to view history for a rule. When the user first selects ‚Äúshow history‚Äù, I want to provide a default (e.g. the first rule firing). After that I want the user to be able to switch through the selected history. I‚Äôd like to have one ‚Äúselected history‚Äù fact. If it doesn‚Äôt exist because the user hasn‚Äôt set it, it should be derived from other facts. If the user sets it though, then ‚Äúselected history‚Äù should be whatever the user says.#2017-12-2416:33mikerodThat sounds like you could encode that as 2 separate rules that both insert the selected history fact#2017-12-2416:33alex-dixonTo get a default I‚Äôm writing something like ‚Äú[:not {SelectedHistory} => (insert-unconditional! [SelectedHistory 0])‚Äù#2017-12-2416:33mikerodOne rule would only fire if some user provided fact is not present. #2017-12-2416:33mikerodYeah. Use a different fact type as the ‚Äútrigger‚Äù#2017-12-2416:34mikerodAnd no need for unconditional #2017-12-2416:36mikerod
[:not [SelectHistoryEvent]]
=>
(insert! (->SelectedHistory 0))
#2017-12-2416:37mikerodThe other rule would be the same, but would use the event to build the SelectedHistory with the provided value#2017-12-2416:37mikerodAnd if you want the ability to retract/toggle do some sort of external retract like I described in blog perhaps.#2017-12-2416:38alex-dixonOk. I‚Äôll try that. Thanks#2017-12-2417:45mikerodTime to write a ‚Äúdefaulting facts‚Äù blog! üòõ#2017-12-2419:01alex-dixonSorry‚Ä¶.don‚Äôt mean to create work for you. I‚Äôm still figuring out patterns. I think UI might be different from the way Clara is normally used? Maybe not but there are facts coming from the outside virtually all the time and I‚Äôve often wondered if that‚Äôs significantly different from the use case at Cerner#2017-12-2419:24mikerodOh no not a problem. I want to do things like write more blogs anyways. Hah. But yeah I think the UI usage of Clara pushes new things up to the forefront. But that is a good thing#2017-12-2419:25mikerodI‚Äôm doing quite a bit of UI things recently and I think some stuff you‚Äôve been doing seems really interesting. I really want to look at it a bit more soon. #2017-12-2715:14alex-dixonThanks! That means a lot coming from you üôÇ. If it‚Äôd make things easier or faster maybe we could screenshare or just chat and go over example UI rules. Your feedback on some of the patterns we‚Äôve used in Precept so far would be invaluable#2017-12-2717:20mikerodYeah, that could work. I‚Äôll try to find some time available soon for something like that. I want to do a little bit of a read through of precept to have some insight too. I like to read open-source libs doing interesting things anyways.#2017-12-2402:27sparkofreasonBrain bubble: clara and onyx might be a great match for distributed processing. #2017-12-2422:32sparkofreasonAfter reading this (https://clojurians-log.clojureverse.org/clara/2015-12-11.html) and @mikerod's article (http://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html), I think there may be something there. It's all sky pie at this point, but it certainly seems like the network should be translatable to an onyx job. Onyx has fault tolerance for stateful tasks, and has taken a pretty good beating from jepsen.#2017-12-2521:15alex-dixonThanks for the links. Read both and very helpful. This was the inspiration for me: https://www.confluent.io/blog/turning-the-database-inside-out-with-apache-samza/#2017-12-2521:18alex-dixonI‚Äôve only worked with Kafka a bit, but I like it a lot. Its weakness right now seems to be ‚Äúmaterialized views‚Äù and stream processing in general. There‚Äôs ksql and kafka-streams to deal with joins between topics, but neither seem as good a solution as a rules engine#2017-12-3000:26sparkofreasonAgreed. I think Kafka is suitable as a source of facts, but the rules engine gives you both logic and materialized views for "complex event processing". If we could implement the distributed working menu in Onyx and feed the whole thing with Kafka, it seems pretty cool.#2017-12-2710:59amarjeetWhen i inspect a session, the value of :fact->explanations key is always nil, despite facts being inserted into the session. My goal is to check what all facts are in the session. Help? CC: @mikerod#2017-12-2711:03amarjeetThe session->fact-graph too returns nil: {:forward-edges {}, :backward-edges {}}#2017-12-2714:59mikerod@amarjeet I think I‚Äôd need more of an example to see what you mean#2017-12-2715:00mikerodHowever, if you are just doing this for some sort of debugging, you could also add a query that matched any fact and use that to see what is in the session. This query could be a performance issue in a production usage though,.#2017-12-2715:05amarjeetI was debugging basically, so with queries I can test things#2017-12-2715:05amarjeetin the process of debugging, I tried inspect and fact-graph...thats when I came across nil values#2017-12-2715:06amarjeetBut, queries clearly shows that facts are there. So, now just wondering if :fact-explanation or fact-graph should be looked at or not?#2017-12-2715:28mikerod@amarjeet your code snipet looks wrong. Perhaps just a typo? You have (insert-all facts base-session) when it should be (insert-all base-session facts) - base-session is first arg#2017-12-2715:32mikerodAlso, I only see 2 def in your example. One for base-session and one for mysession. I don‚Äôt see what you called to try inspecting and looking at the inspection results. That‚Äôd be useful too. Pending the above comment I had was just a typo#2017-12-2716:03mikerod@amarjeet did you call fire-rules on the mysession?#2017-12-2716:04amarjeetno actually#2017-12-2716:04amarjeetI see thats the problem? Because, I just tried with fire-rules, and I see the facts#2017-12-2716:06amarjeetBut, without firing the rules, the insertion is happening#2017-12-2716:07amarjeetwith fire-rules, only matched facts are being returned under the fact->explanation#2017-12-2716:07amarjeetI thought, with inspect, I could see all inserted facts, not just the matched ones#2017-12-2716:10mikerod@amarjeet I think in general you shouldn‚Äôt assume much about the state of working memory prior to fire-rules#2017-12-2716:11mikerodTake that as a general principle. Things are done sometimes ‚Äúlazily‚Äù in some respects#2017-12-2716:11mikerodThat doesn‚Äôt answer the 2nd part of your question as to what is missing post-rule firing though#2017-12-2716:14amarjeethmm, understood the issue now regarding 'before fire-rule' part.#2017-12-2716:20amarjeetI re-checked, post fire-rules, I can see only matched facts, not all inserted ones (in that session)#2017-12-2716:32mikerodI‚Äôll have to take a look at things a bit to have a better answer on that#2017-12-2716:33amarjeetcool cool, thanks much#2017-12-2717:10mikerod@amarjeet it seems the purpose of the key :fact->explanations is to explain derived facts within working memory#2017-12-2717:10mikerodnot facts explicitly given via an external insert or insert-all#2017-12-2717:10amarjeetokay, that makes sense then#2017-12-2717:11mikerodYou can dig out that info in some sense#2017-12-2717:11amarjeetyeah#2017-12-2717:11mikerodTake for example: 
:fact->explanations
{#clara.test_rules.B{}
[{:rule {:ns-name clara.test-rules, :lhs [{:type clara.test_rules.A, :constraints []}], :rhs (do (insert! (->B))), :name "clara.test-rules/test-a"},
:explanation #clara.tools.inspect.Explanation{:matches ({:fact #clara.test_rules.A{}, :condition {:type clara.test_rules.A, :constraints []}}), :bindings {}}}]}
#2017-12-2717:11mikerodclara.test_rules.B is the derived fact#2017-12-2717:12mikerodthe value under it is a list of rules deriving it. There‚Äôd be more than one if multiple of these facts were = in working memory.#2017-12-2717:13amarjeetyes, I did got that when I checked with fire-rules#2017-12-2717:13amarjeetunderstood it now#2017-12-2717:14mikerod
(into []
      (comp cat
            (map :explanation)
            (mapcat :matches)
            (map :fact))
      (vals (:fact->explanations inspect-results)))
combined with (keys (:fact->explanations inspect-results)) sort of gets you there#2017-12-2717:15mikerodAlso, an important consideration is that Clara doesn‚Äôt hold references to any inserted facts that cannot contribute to any rule#2017-12-2717:15mikerodSo those effectively are not in working memory at all anymore#2017-12-2717:15amarjeethmm, yeah, got it#2017-12-2717:16amarjeetmakes sense now#2017-12-2717:16mikerod
(defrecord A [])

(defrule not-using-a
  [:not-a]
  =>
  (insert! {:not-a true}))

(-> (mk-session [not-using-a])
    (insert (->A))
    fire-rules)
#2017-12-2717:16mikerodyou‚Äôd find no references to A fact instance in working memory at all#2017-12-2717:16mikerod@alex-dixon has done some more interesting things with session inspection I believe. He may have thoughts on this though.#2017-12-2717:17mikerodOn the topic of analyzing all facts inserted or that sort of thing. Then again, for dev only, if you are using the typical type hierarchy you could just do 
(defquery find-any-fact []
   [?f <- Object])
#2017-12-2717:20amarjeetyeah, this testing trick works, I tried testing with different types of queries.#2017-12-2717:23alex-dixonhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/master/src/cljc/precept/listeners.cljc#2017-12-2717:24alex-dixonExample of abusing clara.listeners üòä#2017-12-2717:29alex-dixonIt‚Äôs a tremendously well designed interface. This is just one implementation. We set up a core async pipeline to process insertions from outside the session (see in precept.core if interested). Each time there‚Äôs an insert we add and remove a listener and divide the listener ops into additions and removals#2017-12-2717:31alex-dixonFrom there we apply the ops to an atom that represents ‚Äúcurrent state‚Äù#2017-12-2717:34alex-dixonPart of motivation over a query is that queries become part of the rete network so having one that matches on everything wasn‚Äôt performant#2017-12-2718:27alex-dixon@amarjeet Just making sure you saw this in case it might be helpful#2017-12-2718:28amarjeetoh, just saw, gonna look at it#2017-12-2718:29amarjeetthanks üôÇ#2017-12-2916:50amarjeet@alex-dixon In general, the approach behind precept is interesting. I m gonna dig into it a bit. A few months ago I was thinking about logic-based UIs, using core.logic, before I had explored Clara. I think, understanding precept will help.#2017-12-2916:51alex-dixon@amarjeet Awesome. Don‚Äôt hesitate to ask any questions you may have I‚Äôm happy to answer as best I can. You can DM me or there‚Äôs also a #precept channel if you like üôÇ#2017-12-2916:52amarjeetoh, great, will join the precept channel as well#2018-01-0219:37wparker@mikerod @alex-dixon I see that there was some discussion of patterns for updating facts; just a heads up/reminder of the ‚Äúcancelling‚Äù functionality added in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/249 and documented at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L38 It doesn‚Äôt really solve the hassles of updates though, more of a perf optimization. Also, we haven‚Äôt ended using it at Cerner yet due to the work involved in testing, so there could well be problems I missed.#2018-01-0219:47alex-dixonThanks for bringing this up again. This is really exciting. I only skimmed 249 but will review it more later. If I‚Äôm understanding correctly the modify would increase performance because it would basically be ‚Äúmutable data structures‚Äù. I really, really at the same time don‚Äôt like the sounds of that ‚Ä¶but if it allows us to easily trade immutability for performance in certain situations then it seems like a great feature#2018-01-0219:49wparkerThe mutability is purely internal to Clara, not user-facing. Or at least if it is user-facing that would be a bug. üôÇ#2018-01-0219:50wparkerSimilar to the way the memory is mutable internally, but that isn‚Äôt shown to the user#2018-01-0219:51alex-dixonAh! Ok. I was thinking about a (modify!) which I think was discussed if only briefly#2018-01-0221:24mikerod@wparker yes, this thing you wrote came to mind and then I realized you actually had parts of it already merged to master. I forgot you didn‚Äôt just have it on a branch.#2018-01-0221:24mikerodHowever, it is not the same thing as the update! or modify! proposal I was considering.#2018-01-0221:25mikerodI think there is likely some value for the engine to explicitly ‚Äúunderstand‚Äù the idea of doing a RHS retract + insert of an entity that logically represents the ‚Äúsame fact‚Äù.#2018-01-0221:25mikerodReasoning is: 1) RHS retract is clunky right now and even worse has some fairly broken behavior with truth maintenance/batched logical insertion etc. 2) Optimizations similar to your ‚Äúupdate facts‚Äù optimizations posted above here may also be applicable.#2018-01-0221:26mikerodDrools does have some optimization to the path of modifying a fact in place - via some of the property reactive hooks. I think Drools also has an explicit ‚Äúmodify‚Äù sort of statement that gives it awareness of a fact in working memory that needs to change.#2018-01-0221:27mikerodIn our case, we‚Äôd not do any in-place mutation of course (structural sharing is good though). I think something like a modify! or, I prefer, update! could be done in a way that was sure to have well defined behavior with the truth maintenance as well as batching behavior of logical inserts etc#2018-01-0221:28mikerodI think the update! scenario is one of prominent use-cases for retract! on the RHS. Although I think there are other reasons to retract, such as ‚Äúno longer relevant event‚Äù scenarios perhaps, so retract! isn‚Äôt completely useless still (and needs to get fixed to behave sanely with batched inserts and truth maintenance).#2018-01-0221:37wparkerYeah, I realize there‚Äôs some other stuff being discussed. I‚Äôll have to read up on those features in Drools. Re updates and truth maintenance - it isn‚Äôt clear to me what sorts of semantics would make sense to manually mess with a logically inserted fact. My intuition there is that manual modification to something that is logically derived doesn‚Äôt make sense, since if A implies B, then A should continue to imply B until/unless A changes.#2018-01-0221:38wparkerI realize that isn‚Äôt the current implementation though - I‚Äôve toyed with changing things so that a RHS retract of a logically inserted fact simply wouldn‚Äôt happen in the same way that an external retract of a fact not in the session doesn‚Äôt do anything. The fact that it does do something now always seemed like a leaky impl detail/bug to me actually#2018-01-0221:44mikerodI think there is a lot of value to be had in the ability to ‚Äúupdate a fact‚Äù#2018-01-0221:44mikerodWhich would require something like a retract/insert at some level conceptually to the rest of the network - something may not be affected by the thing that changed though#2018-01-0221:45mikerodand with truth maintenance and all logical inserts (something I think is very valuable), it gets near impossible to actually retract something because you immediately invalidate it against the truth maintenance#2018-01-0221:46mikerodI think something liek this: 
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc)))
#2018-01-0221:46mikerodThe truth maintenance should not have an issue with this. and it should propagate and participate in the truth maintenance downstream as expected#2018-01-0221:47mikerodmore interesting even#2018-01-0221:47mikerod
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A (= value 10)]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc)))
Here the update! actually contradicts the LHS condition - I still think that should be ok#2018-01-0221:47mikerodIt should participate in a well-defined way with the truth maintenance is the point.#2018-01-0221:48mikerodThen there would have to be considertaion of something like: 
(defrule update-it
  [?a <- A (= value 10)]
  =>
  (update! ?a #(update % :value inc))
  (insert! (->B)))
#2018-01-0221:49mikerodHere you have a new fact that relies on truth maintenance and this rule as it‚Äôs ‚Äúlogical support‚Äù. It‚Äôs a tougher case to consider due to the LHS no longer being true. I‚Äôm thinking the token should be constructed in a way taht makes the updated ?a support the new B#2018-01-0221:52mikerodI might agree that retraction of a logically derived fact doesn‚Äôt make sense. You could always just retract the ‚Äúroot facts‚Äù that caused it. I do think that would make sense to be able to be done in the RHS and behave as expected with respect to the batched insertions of other rules in the same activation group though#2018-01-0222:20wparkerBy ‚Äúbatched insertions‚Äù do you mean the stuff in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 ?#2018-01-0222:28mikerodyep#2018-01-0219:48alex-dixon@wparker Also over the break @mikerod and I discussed short circuiting the evaluation of LHS along with Drools‚Äô ‚Äúproperty reactive‚Äù#2018-01-0221:52mikerodThis one is unrelated a bit to our other thread concerning update!.#2018-01-0221:53mikerodIt shouldn‚Äôt be too difficult to have Clara do something like ‚Äúunlinking‚Äù conditions from evaluation when required prior conditions haven‚Äôt been satisfied yet.#2018-01-0221:54mikerodA good example of the problem is something like: 
(defrule do-things
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id) (expensive-constraint x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C)))
Clara will currently do the (expensive-constraint x) when Bs are inserted, with no A in working memory at all, even if this condition is only used in this rule#2018-01-0221:56mikerodYou can write rules to avoid it like: 
(defrule find-things
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [?b <- B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (insert! (->ReadyB ?b)))

(defrule do-things
  [ReadyB (expensive-constraint x)]
  =>
  (insert! (->C)))
#2018-01-0221:56mikerodHowever, that is not super obvious and also may not always be so straightforward to correctly split#2018-01-0222:22wparkerIf you have ideas on how to implement that in a simple way I‚Äôd be interested. üôÇ It seems like it could get complicated though.#2018-01-0222:24wparkerOn a possibly similar note, I‚Äôve toyed with changing the structure where a rule only has one parent before - if there are independent conditions, they don‚Äôt inherently need to propagate through each other. That would be a lot of work to change though#2018-01-0222:29mikerodI think the case you are describing is interesting. I‚Äôm not sure how great it is to have a rule with unrelated conditions, but I know that idea comes up for doing things like aggregations onto a larger ‚Äúaggregated fact‚Äù#2018-01-0222:30mikerodIn terms of what I mentioned above, I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôd be that difficult#2018-01-0222:30mikerodI am at least thinking about it like:#2018-01-0222:30mikerod1) during compilation, track if rule conditions rely on others#2018-01-0222:31mikerod2) during rule evaluation, avoid testing conditions if their upstream dependencies haven‚Äôt yet had any matches. Just batch the facts to test ‚Äúlater‚Äù#2018-01-0222:31mikerod3) the batch is ‚Äúflushed‚Äù when the condition is reached via the left activation#2018-01-0222:31mikerodNegation nodes sort of work by batching fact evaluation already#2018-01-0222:32mikerodI think it may not be too terribly difficult at least. Of course I haven‚Äôt tried at all yet üòõ#2018-01-0222:30tcarlsHmm -- the railroad diagram link in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/guide appears to be broken.#2018-01-0222:41ryanbrush@tcarls Thanks. All of that content now lives over on the web site at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/, so we need to delete/redirect those wiki pages.#2018-01-0402:26cflemingI have some questions about the fact-expr grammar over here: https://github.com/cursive-ide/clara-specs/issues/4#2018-01-0402:28cflemingActually, looking at the schema I see that FactCondition :type is s/Any, bummer.#2018-01-0412:54mikerod@cfleming Yeah, I can see where that is difficult and yes the ‚Äúfact type‚Äù being anything makes things complicated#2018-01-0412:55mikerodI‚Äôm pretty sure you can break Clara parsing if you try to use a fact type that seems too much like something else.#2018-01-0412:56mikerodOne thing that is interesting and probably should be part of the spec (I don‚Äôt believe it is now), is that variable bindings should always start with ‚Äú?‚Äù#2018-01-0412:56mikerodSo in the case of the fact binding, it is the ::variable-binding from that PR#2018-01-0412:57mikerodAnd perhaps we should just list a few things that a fact type should not be, like it shouldn‚Äôt be a symbol that starts with a ‚Äú?‚Äù#2018-01-0412:57mikerodI think it may not be ok for it to be a vector either. I seem to recall a bad parse example from long back where a fact type as a vector would mess up things.#2018-01-0413:25tcarlsAre there suggested patterns for rules that can require potentially-expensive lookups? If I have a rule that depends on content that could be retrieved from an API call / database hit / etc., is there a way to trigger that retrieval (and insert any facts it results in) only when the rule's other conditions are satisfied?#2018-01-0413:32mikerod@tcarls that‚Äôs funny you bring that up since this topic came up fairly recently here#2018-01-0413:32mikerodIn short: I think in the future Clara could do better to avoid doing work when required previous conditions aren‚Äôt yet satisfied.#2018-01-0413:32mikerodHowever, there is a workaround pattern:#2018-01-0413:34mikerod
;; Say you have this:
(defrule original
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [B (= ?id id) (do-expensive-thing x)]
  =>
  (insert (->C)))


It can be transformed to this:
(defrule part-1
  [A (= ?id id)]
  [?b <- B (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (insert (->MatchedB ?b)))

(defrule part-2
  [MatchedB (do-expensive-thing x)]
  =>
  (insert (->C)))
#2018-01-0413:38mikerodIf you are in a situation where there may be some thrash of insert/retracts of A and B (from example) due to the truth maintenance of the network, then you can also consider adding either :salience or setup ‚Äúactivation groups‚Äù for rules like part-2. However, I‚Äôd only do that if there is actually a situation where it could be an issue.#2018-01-0413:50tcarlsThank you -- that's useful advice.#2018-01-0413:55mikerodSome details on salience and activations groups is written here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/ If you end up needing it. However, like I said, avoid it if unnecessary. It is additional complexity to deal with.#2018-01-0422:22sparkofreasonIs there a way to establish a conditional relationship between facts outside of a rule RHS? The case I'm thinking of is something like an article app, where articles have comments. Selecting an article makes it "active", and also triggers a request to fetch comments from the server. When the async request completes, comments will be inserted. It would be slick if retracting the active article fact also automagically retracted the inserted comments, but since the response handler for the comments request executes outside of a rule context, I don't see an obvious way to enforce that logical connection.#2018-01-0422:48zyloxYou could write something fairly easily to "deactivate" them (by joining the comment fact to the article and inserting an ActiveComment or something) but that wouldnt retract the base comment fact which could lead to build up over time. I don't know of any way to do what you are talking about without an external handler atm#2018-01-0422:50zyloxthey would have to come in on the same data object into the session which doesnt match the timeline you describe#2018-01-0514:57mikerod@dave.dixon I think that works. The only caveat is just that there are a few outstanding issues with RHS retract!. There are some edge cases with how they may work with logical insertions. I think it doesn‚Äôt typically come up. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/229 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/321 I mention both in http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2018-01-0515:01mikerodOther than that though, the rules above seem reasonable. That is something I‚Äôd expect should work. To the point @zylox made: It looks like you do have some sort of external retract that is removing the ActiveArticle in your example.#2018-01-0515:03zyloxYa, i was approaching it from the perspective of using truth maintenance for it because of the "outside of a rule RHS?". glad you found something that works for you.#2018-01-0515:05sparkofreasonYes, ActiveArticle is removed externally. It does work nicely.#2018-01-0515:15sparkofreason::handle-cancelled-response is arguably just "nice to have", catches the case of ActiveArticle changing before the response to the comments request is received. If one ran into the edge-cases around retract! I think you could just have some sort of periodic clean-up of dangling CommentsResponse facts.#2018-01-0515:19mikerodI like it overall. I really would like to try to get the edge cases of retract! removed. The issue it has is mostly how it interacts with the truth maintenance of other rules that are firing in the same ‚Äúcycle‚Äù#2018-01-0515:20mikerodThe removal of the CommentsResponse cleans up all the Comment due to truth maintenance, which is nice.#2018-01-0515:20mikerodOh, I guess the ActiveArticle does too - woops. But either way, it is nice to be able to cleanup old facts liek that#2018-01-0615:44alex-dixonMay not have had enough coffee yet but‚Ä¶.how do I do something like this without getting an unbound variable error? 
[SomeFact (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]
[:not [:and [Fact1 (= e ?e) (= a ?a)]
                   [Fact2 (= e ?e) (= b ?b]]]
#2018-01-0617:06mikerod@alex-dixon I am not sure if @wparker has an issue logged on this subject but odd things can happen sometime in rule compilation due to how Clara compiler converts these Boolean conditions to disjunctive normal form. DNF#2018-01-0617:07mikerodSo the conditions in the :and are being split by an :or. #2018-01-0617:12mikerodI need to look a bit though. Thought the case above was covered. #2018-01-0617:12mikerodBasic negated conjunctions should be supported. #2018-01-0617:14alex-dixonHm ok#2018-01-0617:14alex-dixonBy the way is [:not {:exists valid in any way?#2018-01-0617:16alex-dixon@mikerod or is that just equivalent to [:not .. ] ?#2018-01-0617:22mikerodShould mean the same thing. #2018-01-0617:22mikerodNot sure if it works out that way though. I want to look at what is compiled in your example about to see why you‚Äôd have an inbound variable issue #2018-01-0617:23mikerodI am not on laptop now. Will be in a few. #2018-01-0617:23mikerod(I don‚Äôt run Clara repl experiments on my phone unfortunately)#2018-01-0618:37alex-dixonOk. Started working on spec stuff. Equally stuck there so let me know lol#2018-01-0621:59mikerod@alex-dixon See https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/347#2018-01-0621:59alex-dixonWas just looking at it hah#2018-01-0622:00mikerodThere are severael issues here. The work that was done before only worked in a fairly small set of situations#2018-01-0622:00alex-dixonSo that‚Äôs identical#2018-01-0622:01mikerodif you can, the workaround is to just move out the conjunction to a different rule I believe#2018-01-0622:01alex-dixonOk. Let me unwind my attempts that aren‚Äôt working and attempt that#2018-01-0622:02mikerod
(defrule r1
  
   [Fact1 (= e ?e) (= a ?a)]
   [Fact2 (= e ?e) (= b ?b)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Fact3 ?e ?a ?b)))


(defrule r2
  [SomeFact (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]
  [:not [Fact3 (= a ?a) (= b ?b)]]
  =>
  (prn {:a ?a
        :b ?b
        :e ?e}))
#2018-01-0622:02mikerodI believe that is the extraction#2018-01-0622:03mikerodThat would pair all Fact1 and Fact2 facts together in the r1 join to make the Fact3 facts#2018-01-0622:03mikerodThen r2 would be looking for the non-existence of any of those join results to match the same a and b of a SomeFact fact#2018-01-0622:04alex-dixonJust to clarify my understanding is the :and necessary in r1?#2018-01-0622:13mikerod@alex-dixon no, sorry#2018-01-0622:14mikerodI just quickly extracted it and forgot I had the :and there still#2018-01-0622:14mikerodI‚Äôd leave it out üòõ#2018-01-0622:14mikerodedited to avoid more confusion#2018-01-0622:15alex-dixonWill try asap. Had to take a break #2018-01-0622:15alex-dixonThanks for your responses#2018-01-0622:17mikerodNo problem. That is unfortunate that there are still several caveats to nesting conditions within negation#2018-01-0622:17mikerodA lot of the time it can be solved by just pulling everything complex out of the :not and put it into a different rule where an ‚Äúbridge‚Äù/intermediate fact is used to communicate the logic across the rules#2018-01-0622:18mikerodI read through some of the outstanding issues on negation. However, I thought that I remember Will mentioning that he maybe had a few more broad concerns with the current way of dealing with them#2018-01-0622:19mikerodBasically, the currently process is to extract rules out from within the :not transparently#2018-01-0622:19mikerodIn a way that is similar to what I proposed that you do in the above.#2018-01-0622:21mikerodI‚Äôm surprised that https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/347 is still an issue though.   [?temp <- [Temperature (= ?location location)]]
  [?wind <- (acc/all) :from [WindSpeed (= ?location location)]]
  =>
  ;; do something
)

[?order <- [WorkOrder (= ?clientid clientid)
              (= scale :big)
              (< (days-between requestdate duedate) 14)]]
=>
CompilerException clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo: Type [WorkOrder (= ?clientid clientid) (= scale :big) (< (days-between requestdate duedate) 14)] is a vector and appears to contain expressions. Is there an extraneous set of brackets in the condition?
#2018-01-0801:13mikerodIt‚Äôd consider the whole thing to be the ‚Äúfact type‚Äù. Which is related to the issue of ambiguity of syntax when you allow any arbitrary structure for a fact type. We discussed this on some issue recently#2018-01-0801:13cflemingAs the unofficial ranter about macro error messages, that‚Äôs a very nice message indeed.#2018-01-0801:14mikerodOh nice. Yeah I guess that case was special cased. Due to it being fairly easy to mistakenly do#2018-01-0815:51wparker@mikerod I haven‚Äôt gotten around to doing a comprehensive writeup, but basically I was looking at how to address https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/343 and ran into what I think are some issues with to-dnf. Basically since the :or operation is actually more of a union in the set theory sense, I think the to-dnf transforms can end up messing with cardinality. For example, [:not [:and A B]] is equivalent to [:or [:not A] [:not B]] in a boolean sense, but the second can match twice and the first can‚Äôt in the context of Clara.#2018-01-0816:12mikerod@wparker thanks. I remember the topic better now.#2018-01-0901:48cflemingIn the example query: 
(defquery get-promotions
  "Query to find promotions for the purchase."
  [:?type]
  [?promotion <- Promotion (= ?type type)])
#2018-01-0901:49cflemingDoes the parameter :?type create a unification variable? i.e. are the param and the local variable ?type then the same thing?#2018-01-0901:49cflemingI‚Äôm not sure I‚Äôm explaining that correctly.#2018-01-0903:18mikerod@cfleming the keyword arg allows the caller to bind a value to the variable. The same variable name as a symbol then should appear somewhere in the query conditions. #2018-01-0903:18mikerodSo I think that is what you were saying. #2018-01-0909:55cfleming@mikerod Thanks, that‚Äôs what I meant, yes.#2018-01-0914:48wparkerPut differently: looking at the example in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/queries/ if you removed the :?type from the get-promotions query definition you wouldn‚Äôt have ‚Äú:?type :lunch‚Äù in the arguments in this call: (query session get-promotions :?type :lunch) @cfleming#2018-01-0919:31wparkerClara-rules 0.17.0 is released and on Clojars. This release is most significant for ClojureScript users, both because of a ClojureScript-specific bugfix and some enhancements with more impact to the ClojureScript side, but there are some enhancements for Clojure as well. See the changelog for details. Thanks to @dave.dixon and @alex-dixon for their contributions to the release.#2018-01-0922:09zyloxare the dixon's related#2018-01-0922:09zyloxa question for the ages#2018-01-1014:26sparkofreasonNot to my knowledge. But we do seem to think alike üòâ#2018-01-1200:08alex-dixonHigh praise#2018-01-1014:29zyloxdarn#2018-01-1200:11alex-dixonDo any changes proposed in https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/373 affect short circuiting the evaluation of all LHS conditions? My understanding is that if the first condition doesn‚Äôt match the remaining ones are still processed#2018-01-1213:27mikerod@alex-dixon right now the alpha network is ‚Äúeagerly‚Äù evaluated#2018-01-1213:27mikerodSo constraints within conditions that are independent of a join with another condition#2018-01-1213:29mikerodClara has had this sort of ‚Äúre-ordering‚Äù property since way back (maybe always) now. The discusses we have had before about trying to be ‚Äúlazier‚Äù in evaluation by not evaluating any part of a condition if the prior conditions were satisfied, would be affected by this re-ordering logic#2018-01-1217:22alex-dixonThanks. Printed out ch 2 of the paper you recommended. It‚Äôs awesome. Working my way through. Will try to avoid asking you to explain rete to me in the interim:blush: That said: If Clara‚Äôs reordering doesn‚Äôt honor the order of conditions in the lhs as they are written (even if just for alphas) would any of the changes in @wparker ‚Äòs proposal make it so the developer‚Äôs ordering is honored when evaluating a lhs? My understanding is that‚Äôs part of the proposal, but only for Boolean conditions. If that‚Äôs right and it‚Äôs developed, could the behavior be extended to apply to all conditions using much of the same code? Outside Boolean conditions, would this be a massive breaking change? I think so just want to confirm. I‚Äôm asking because I think there would be an appreciable performance difference between the two for CEP. I think Drools made changes along these lines for that reason #2018-01-1218:09mikerod@alex-dixon I think the re-ordering (or not) is still being discussed in the 373 linked above. There already is re-ordering happening. It sounds like there may be some lean towards not needing to do that anymore. You should check out some of the comments in that issue now. I did mention the lazier evaluation thing there, but there are still concerns I‚Äôd have with that overall.#2018-01-1218:11mikerodAnd yes, that paper is good. I first heard of it from Ryan putting a reference to it in the Clara GitHub repo @ https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Introduction#the-rules-engine#2018-01-1218:34sparkofreasonIf I were to call insert! from within an async callback for an effect triggered on the rhs of a rule, I assume that the context would be goofy and result in an exception or other undesirable behavior. Is there a best practice for capturing that context? The use case would be leveraging truth maintenance for facts inserted async, e.g. results from an http request. #2018-01-1219:35mikerod@dave.dixon I‚Äôd expect the async response to be do an external insert when it is done#2018-01-1219:35mikerodYou‚Äôd ‚Äúcapture context‚Äù just via the variable bindings you passed to the async call#2018-01-1219:36mikerodOh, woops, missed part of your purpose#2018-01-1219:36mikerodI think you‚Äôd have to model the fact that you caused the effect externally as a fact for TMS to help you. Example:#2018-01-1219:43mikerodI don‚Äôt really like the maybe-undo-async-thing part of that. It doesn‚Äôt know which DownstreamResult may now be invalid and offloads it all to the external fn ext-maybe-undo-async-thing#2018-01-1219:43mikerodI think there may be a better way around that#2018-01-1219:47mikerodI made it so original-rule is always satisfied via the accumulator#2018-01-1219:47mikerodSo you can carry that information forward on which path you should take#2018-01-1219:47sparkofreasonYes, that's how I'm doing it now. Like you say, it's fine when all the relationships are clean, but otherwise gets messy. #2018-01-1219:47sparkofreasonReferring to the first example. #2018-01-1219:48mikerodSo in my 2nd example, you can actually filter DownstreamResult if you track which bs they originally were associated with via that information being conveyed externally and back on the inserted new facts#2018-01-1219:48mikerodIt isn‚Äôt perfect, you still have to make an association on the facts, however, I think it could be practical#2018-01-1219:48mikerodThis is regarding one part of the overall problem#2018-01-1219:49mikerodYou also have the problem of when the async request is finished, ensuring it inserts to the session that it came from in its final state#2018-01-1219:49mikerodso after the fire-rules that triggered the async request has completed#2018-01-1219:49mikerodIn a single-thread, I think that is not an issue#2018-01-1219:50mikerodAnd you may be doing this single-threadedly#2018-01-1219:50mikerodThe async call though would need to have a way to access the session when it is finished#2018-01-1219:54sparkofreasonI have a way of handling session. But what I really want is to be able to do the final insert such that the fact is a logical consequence of the rule lhs. Not sure if that actually is meaningful given how rete works. #2018-01-1319:02alex-dixonI‚Äôm not sure whether using Clara‚Äôs truth maintenance directly allows that, but you should be able to simulate it using unconditional inserts/retracts, other rules, and facts that represent the async event cycle. A poor attempt: 
(defrule make-request-when
  [?task <- AsyncTask]
  =>
  (retract! ?task)
  (insert-unconditional (->AsyncRequest ?task))
 (async-side-effect! my-session ?task)

(defn async-side-effect! [session fact] (request! fact (fn [err res] 
(if err (insert session (->AsyncTaskError err fact)
(insert session (->AsyncTaskSuccess res fact))

(defrule on-async-task-success
  [?success <- AsyncTaskSuccess ?res ?fact]
  [?request <- AsyncTaskRequest ?fact]
=>
(retract! ?success ?request)
(insert-unconditional! (->SomeFactRepresentingResponseFromThisKindOfRequest ?res)
 
  ;; similarly with error
#2018-01-1319:26sparkofreasonI have something similar, and it works nicely. But it would be nice if I could avoid the manual truth maintenance. #2018-01-1221:16mikerodI don‚Äôt think anything built-in would allow you to reliable have an actual ‚Äúhandle‚Äù on the mutable session state during fire rules for an insert! to go off later yet, still correctly be tracked with TMS#2018-01-1221:16mikerodthere‚Äôd be quite a bit of complications for the engine to try to support that even I think#2018-01-1221:16mikerodNot to mention the fire-rules wouldn‚Äôt be able to be ‚Äúdone‚Äù until all async actions were done#2018-01-1221:17mikerodand it‚Äôd have concurrency issues in a multi-threaded environment#2018-01-1221:59sparkofreasonAgreed. Maybe the right(ish) answer is to model facts as something like a promise. The semantics and behavior would have to be constrained, so it isn't just mutating facts behind your back without properly updating the session. But the basic concept seems like a way forward, because conditionally inserting a promise as a fact means it and whatever value it returns will get retracted when TMS requires it.#2018-01-1222:02sparkofreasonThe thing I'm trying to avoid is having to manually perform truth management for facts inserted as the result of async effects. In the big picture, those facts are logical consequents of whatever condition triggered the async effect.#2018-01-1222:46mikerodYeah,I think the case is interesting#2018-01-1319:02alex-dixonI‚Äôm not sure whether using Clara‚Äôs truth maintenance directly allows that, but you should be able to simulate it using unconditional inserts/retracts, other rules, and facts that represent the async event cycle. A poor attempt: 
(defrule make-request-when
  [?task <- AsyncTask]
  =>
  (retract! ?task)
  (insert-unconditional (->AsyncRequest ?task))
 (async-side-effect! my-session ?task)

(defn async-side-effect! [session fact] (request! fact (fn [err res] 
(if err (insert session (->AsyncTaskError err fact)
(insert session (->AsyncTaskSuccess res fact))

(defrule on-async-task-success
  [?success <- AsyncTaskSuccess ?res ?fact]
  [?request <- AsyncTaskRequest ?fact]
=>
(retract! ?success ?request)
(insert-unconditional! (->SomeFactRepresentingResponseFromThisKindOfRequest ?res)
 
  ;; similarly with error
#2018-01-1316:02sparkofreasonI took a shot at forcing conditional inserts in the async handler, if only as an exercise to understand the code better. I got as far as actually getting the insert to occur, basically grabbing the *rule-context* and making it available to the handler, and adding an overload of fire-rules that would accept that as an extra parameter. The rule context was modified so it only contained non-empty :batched-logical-insertions with the facts being inserted as a logical consequence of the rule triggering the async effect. clara.rules.engine/*fire-rules* then also had an extra arity to deal with externally supplied rule context. At this point, I guessed that this approach probably wouldn't work in general, because it looks to me like the :token in the rule context contains the fact bindings which are the logical antecedent. If any of those facts had been retracted in the session between the request and response of the async effect, I assume that clara.rules.memory/add-insertions! would be unhappy, as the token would be inconsistent with the state of working memory. Is that correct?#2018-01-1316:52mikerodYeah. I don‚Äôt think that‚Äôd be very tractable. #2018-01-1316:52mikerodAlso working memory is in a mutable state. I think things could easily become inconsistent. #2018-01-1318:13sparkofreasonMakes sense.#2018-01-1318:14sparkofreasonIs there a way to force a rule to fire, even if the fact values don't change? I'm playing around with using an atom to solve this case, but of course the atom reference doesn't change when the atom is reset, only the wrapped value changes, so the rule won't fire after the first time.#2018-01-1319:06alex-dixon@dave.dixon > Is there a way to force a rule to fire, even if the fact values don‚Äôt change? No offense intended at all but that seems off to a bad start even to me‚Ä¶. üòÑ What are you trying to do?#2018-01-1319:24sparkofreasonYeah, it sounds bad. I'm trying to get the rhs to evaluate when a fact refers to an atom and the atom value changes. #2018-01-1319:27alex-dixonInteresting. [encounter-actions/EncounterFindingChanged ..] ;; short -- throws ex
[justice.models.core.actions.encounter.EncounterFindingChanged ..] ;; long

If you could make like a small example where it isn‚Äôt working that‚Äôd be nice to see. #2018-01-1320:36dadair
(ns abc.other)

(defrecord SupportRequest [client level])

(defrecord ClientRepresentative [name client])

;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;;

(ns abc.core
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]
            [abc.other :as other]))

(defrule is-important
  "Find important support requests."
  [abc.other.SupportRequest (= :high level)] ;; full path here works; change to other/SupportRequest and an exception is thrown
  =>
  (println "High support requested!"))

(defrule notify-client-rep
  "Find the client representative and request support."
  [abc.other.SupportRequest (= ?client client)]
  [abc.other.ClientRepresentative (= ?client client) (= ?name name)]
  =>
  (println "Notify" ?name "that"
          ?client "has a new support request!"))

(-> (mk-session 'abc.core)
    (insert (other/->ClientRepresentative "Alice" "Acme")
            (other/->SupportRequest "Acme" :high))
    (fire-rules))
#2018-01-1320:37dadairthe above example reproduces the problem#2018-01-1320:38mikerodRecord types in clojure are referred to by their Java Class name#2018-01-1320:39mikerodYou have to use import for those. #2018-01-1320:39dadairah right#2018-01-1320:39mikerodThey don‚Äôt support ns aliasing. Their builder functions do but not the type class itsel#2018-01-1320:39mikerodSort of a clj quirk that is unfortunate. #2018-01-1320:39mikerodClara is just using clj for the symbol resolution there though. #2018-01-1320:42dadairI always forget about imports, thanks!#2018-01-1323:22alex-dixon@dave.dixon so in the one that works are there different time facts with different time values?#2018-01-1323:24sparkofreason@alex-dixon I haven't tried multiple time facts. I think it should work correctly with upsert, though. Retracting existing fact would lead to retraction of the generated Tag facts, and the subsequent insert would generate an updated set.#2018-01-1323:27sparkofreasonI was hoping to get away from having auxiliary unconditional facts like Time. The other version of async is structurally similar, but there the external fact is Response, which is correlated via a rule with the original Request. There's an additional rule that forces retract of Response when the corresponding Request no longer exists.#2018-01-1323:29sparkofreasonGiven that both approaches require unconditional inserts, the Request/`Response` pattern is arguably cleaner, as the atom approach requires some extra coordination outside of the rulebase to correctly update the session when the atom value changes.#2018-01-1323:37alex-dixonI‚Äôll definitely keep this in mind as I try to do similar things. Wish I could be more help but it gets hard for me to reason about and I find my thinking tending toward more immutable approaches which seems like the opposite of the overall approach (fewer intermediate facts/garbage). I‚Äôll try to experiment next time I‚Äôm at a laptop #2018-01-1323:38alex-dixonCurious, did you try a callback in the rhs and logical insert? Seem to recall that being your first approach. If so what happened? Loss of session context?#2018-01-1400:29sparkofreasonI have it working with a callback and unconditional insert. I don't think there's a way to do a logical insert in the context of the callback. The session has already moved forward, could have been modified further by the time the callback is called, etc.#2018-01-1414:43alex-dixonI haven‚Äôt played around with it much. Typically I do the same as you I think‚Ä¶.wait to handle it on the next fire-rules iteration, but that can be problematic in certain cases. So I‚Äôm kind of curious about being able to park/block within the RHS but I haven‚Äôt thought about it much. It might be convenient for Javascript but in a parallel or multiple thread environment‚Ä¶I dunno. I forget the case I ran into where I really did want to stop the world / rule activations until I could get a result, but I feel like that‚Äôs more an error in my thinking than a feature I need to figure out how to support. Don‚Äôt know though#2018-01-1400:42sparkofreasonPart of what I was finding was that beyond the simple request/response case there was a proliferation of auxiliary fact types to deal with requests from the UI. For example, if the user toggled the "Favorite" button on an article, I would insert a FavoritedArticle fact, which in turn triggered Request to be inserted, along with a rule to handle the response to that Request. I also had to add clean up rules to get rid of these FavoritedArticle facts when the page changed, as well as properly manage upsertion vs. insertion, etc. It was all starting to feel a bit fiddly. But I think you could actually do this with the same Request/`Response` pattern, just replacing making an HTTP request with rendering the UI which will generate the Response.#2018-01-1414:34alex-dixonSo for precept I implemented something like the following. Below is somewhat similar to Redux in Javascript which also reifies this and request/response/fail for api calls for front-end state management. 
(defrecord Action [type payload])

(defrule actions-only-survive-one-call-to-fire-rules
{:salience -100}
 [?fact <- Action]
=>
(retract! Action)

(defrule on-article-favorited
{:salience 100}
[Action (= ?type :article-favorited) (= ?payload payload)]
=>
;; Still have the async dance but Action facts are automatically cleaned up at the end
(do)
#2018-01-1415:36sparkofreasonRight. I'm trying to do this without salience, just to see where it takes me in terms of design, possible changes to clara, etc. One thing that has fallen out is that I think the fact-based immutable history approach of precept is probably the way to go, as opposed to using whole entities as facts and trying to update "in place".#2018-01-1417:39alex-dixonWould you consider agenda groups? I‚Äôve very little experience with systems that use them but we try to simulate them partially in precept by using Clara‚Äôs :activation-groups and :activation-group-sort-fn http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/#2018-01-1417:40alex-dixonSo we have :group :cleanup I think, which is given least precedence in the sort fn#2018-01-1417:47alex-dixonI still run into wanting update in place but I‚Äôm on the fence about it because immutability is easier for me to understand. Case that comes up a lot is a default value: 
(rule when-no-user-selected-article
 [:not SelectedArticleId]
  [?most-recent <- (acc/min :time :returns-fact true) :from [Article]]
=>
(insert! (->SelectedArticleId (:id ?most-recent)))
#2018-01-1417:49alex-dixonSo that loops#2018-01-1417:57alex-dixonThere‚Äôs a :no-loop prop that‚Äôs relatively undocumented. Haven‚Äôt played with it but seems like it would solve this case. A (modify!) wouldn‚Äôt I guess because the SelectedArticleId doesn‚Äôt exist. If it did as something like (SelectedArticleId :unset) then you could match on (= id :unset) and (modify! ?selected-article :id (:id ?most-recent))#2018-01-1420:28sparkofreasonI need to think about it. But I really am trying, as an exercise, to see what happens if you constrain yourself solely to the logical consistency implied by clara. I think I'm converging on something, but I've thought that before only to trip over an ugly fact that ruined my beautiful theory.#2018-01-1420:30sparkofreasonBTW, the "real world" example app (conduit) is proving to be a great way to exercise this stuff. You might find it useful for precept development. https://github.com/jacekschae/conduit#2018-01-1420:32alex-dixonYeah was thinking same! Would be nice to see it and Clara on their official list as well#2018-01-1518:02alex-dixon@dave.dixon just curious Re part of issue 371: if you had something like s/querydef would you still want ns kw names for defquery?#2018-01-1518:05sparkofreasonWhat is s/querydef?#2018-01-1518:06alex-dixonDoesn‚Äôt exist. üôÇ Thinking it could be like s/fdef for queries#2018-01-1518:26sparkofreasonThat's a good idea. But I'd still want keyword names. It's not a big deal, just a nice option to give more flexibility to DSL authors. I have it working in my local branch in CLJS, pretty minor change.#2018-01-1518:29alex-dixonWhat do the vars end up being named? e.g. (defquery ::some-alias/my-spec ..) => #‚Äôrule-ns/ ‚Ä¶ ?#2018-01-1518:38sparkofreasonThere are no vars. I'm not defining the queries as ns-level defs. They're grouped inside of a named object, and that symbol winds up holding the collection of productions that is provided to defsession.#2018-01-1520:21alex-dixonLike most of your suggestions and changes I like that. Using defs/the ns as a kind of data structure is something I like sometimes and not others#2018-01-1520:24alex-dixonIs that part of your proposal? If not how would you envision this working for users of Clara? Would it affect session reloading?#2018-01-1521:28sparkofreasonI'm putting together my own DSL that has those characteristics, not proposing to alter the existing rules DSL packaged with clara. I handle reloading in the implementation of my DSL. Since rules are just grouped in vars, it's pretty straightforward, don't have to deal with the subtleties of CLJS namespace reloading etc.#2018-01-1603:43dadairis there a way to compose accumulators outside of writing a custom reducer? e.g., I want to get the latest timestamp of all facts, so some combination of (acc/all) and (acc/max :tx)#2018-01-1606:33mikerod@dadair there isn‚Äôt anything directly for that. On a case by case you may able to get the behavior you want from an accumulator like the max above. #2018-01-1606:35mikerodIf you had a unique ID on all facts for example, you could just do ?l <- (acc/max :tx) :from [A (= id? ?id)] #2018-01-1606:36mikerodI‚Äôm not sure that makes much sense though. acc/max is intended to find the max among all facts. Accumulators are mostly for reasoning about aggregates. I may have misunderstood your usage you were looking for. #2018-01-1606:54dadairThe rule engine I work on takes the general from (state, action) -> actions, where action and actions are actions to perform (in aggregate) to transition state to a new state (basically the RE is a reduce, but instead of reducing to a new state, it returns ‚Äúdiff‚Äù operations through querying the resulting state that external service(s) can use to transition the state). A difficulty that I‚Äôve had in general with this pattern is that I need to track changes to state as rules propagate, and then insert output actions based on those changes. So for example, given an initial entity A {:id 1, :x true}, there may be cascading changes over the (short) life of the session that cause it to transition to any number of {true,false} values. I always want the stable result, so I have added tx values to track ‚Äútime‚Äù. Given that, I may have a rule that ‚Äúsubscribes‚Äù to a number of those facts (e.g., all :ids), but I want the max :tx of each of those entities.#2018-01-1606:55dadairIn summary: [?entities <- (acc/all) :from [TimestampedEntity]] ;; ?entities => [{:id 1, :x true, :tx 1} {:id 1, :x false, :tx 2} {:id 2, :x true, :tx 3}] but I only want the latest :tx for each unique entity, so desired: ?entities => [{:id 1, :x false, :tx 2} {:id 2, :x true, :tx 3}]#2018-01-1607:00dadaire.g., to calculate a ratio of true entities over all entities (but only for their final states)#2018-01-1616:02mikerod@dadair if you use a variable binding bound to the :id field then the accumulator will give you the latest :tx per :id #2018-01-1616:04mikerod
[?latest <- (acc/max :tx) :from [TsEntity (= ?id id)]]
#2018-01-1616:05mikerodThat‚Äôs the ‚Äúlatest :tx ‚Äú of each fact group where they are grouped by :id #2018-01-1702:15cflemingWhat is the logic by which class members from fact types are used to create local variables for the constraints?#2018-01-1702:16cflemingIn clara.examples.java.shopping, there are some examples [Customer (= true VIP)] and [Order (> total 200)]. I assume VIP is mapped to the isVIP() method and total is mapped to the getTotal() method?#2018-01-1702:17cflemingAre the rules around this defined anywhere, or could someone point me to the relevant DSL code?#2018-01-1702:21alex-dixon@cfleming https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/941b776221690edab4904e3728715d0680bd6121/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L308#2018-01-1702:22cfleming@alex-dixon Isn‚Äôt that dealing with unification vars?#2018-01-1702:22cflemingOh, it looks like field-name->accessors-used, right?#2018-01-1702:24alex-dixonhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L149#2018-01-1702:26alex-dixon@cfleming Er. get-fields a few down from there what you‚Äôre looking for?#2018-01-1702:26cflemingYes, I think so - thanks!#2018-01-1823:11zyloxso you essentially want a history as long as all members of that history are present#2018-01-1823:12zyloxgiven how much the tms relies on present state alone that would be quite a doozy#2018-01-1823:20sparkofreasonYeah, digging around the code, I'm not sure it even makes sense with how rete works. It seems like it would require some modification.#2018-01-1823:21sparkofreasonSeems similar to a join-node, but has to appear in a different place in the network or something.#2018-01-1823:22zyloxyou could envisions something like layered sessions that join their nodes (3d memory from a visulization point of view) and query "downward" but thats all a ton of work#2018-01-1823:23zyloxbut ya i agree....doesnt really mesh with rete imo#2018-01-1915:04mikerod@dave.dixon I mostly never would recommend many patterns that make pervasive use of insert-unconditional!#2018-01-1915:05mikerodThe one case I keep seeing that is difficult to work around is when needing to retract internally for something like ‚Äúold events‚Äù. Other than that, I think it‚Äôs best to avoid. Even then, there are several RHS retract related issues outstanding that can be seen in the GitHub#2018-01-1915:05mikerodI‚Äôm looking at your example to see if I see anything you could do#2018-01-1915:41mikerodWoops missing a part in that, will edit#2018-01-1915:58sparkofreason@mikerod Interesting. Let me ponder that.#2018-01-1915:59mikerodI am missing a part still. Trying to get that done. The concept I think can work though in terms of marking a timestamp at each stage. However, the above fails because it is letting TMS remove the intermediary collections from previous runs#2018-01-1916:00mikerodI think you have to signal each ‚Äústage‚Äù as an explicit fact though. Without something like that, the network never knows what each conceptual step is to you. It doesn‚Äôt distinguish one fire-rules from another really#2018-01-1916:00mikerodSo usually when that sort of info is missing, you end up adding it as a fact to represent the idea#2018-01-1916:52mikerod@dave.dixon I updated it now#2018-01-1916:53mikerodIt is hard to say that it exactly captures what you want. If you look at :before-retract though, you get the multiple accumulated groups idea that you were wanting#2018-01-1916:53mikerodJust requires each fact to be externally stamped with the same ‚Äútimestamp‚Äù as the ‚Äúfire event‚Äù that they were inserted with#2018-01-1916:53mikerodI couldn‚Äôt work out a way for rules to express that stamping due to logical TMS.#2018-01-1916:53mikerodRetracting is slightly harder, since you need to retract all matching facts across all timestamps (at least from your sort of example)#2018-01-1916:54mikerodThis retraction results in all prior groups being updated as well to remove the fact that is gone. That isn‚Äôt exactly what you wanted I dont‚Äô think, but it conveys somewhat similar information.#2018-01-1916:57mikerodThe accumulation for Nums could tag it with the FireEvent ts it went with. Then that could be used to do a duplicate removal and/or ‚Äúnewest‚Äù result lookup on the :before-retract vs :after-retract#2018-01-1918:57wparker@dave.dixon Perhaps a model like the following might work if you‚Äôre OK with accumulating some ‚Äúgarbage‚Äù over time. 
- Logically insert a "Request" fact.
- Have a query like [Request (= ?id id)] [:not [RequestResponse (= ?id id)]].
- The client would externally insert a RequestResponse fact when it wanted to "close" a request.
- A todo could be done like [Request (= ?id id)] [:not [RequestResponse (= ?id id)]] => (insert! (->ToDo ?id)).
Then further logic downstream could dispatch on the TODOs as required, say if too many were outstanding.
If you need to clean up garbage, it almost sounds like you‚Äôre asking about retracting a fact without removing downstream insertions due to it.. is that on target at all?#2018-01-1919:28sparkofreason@wparker I think in your 4th bullet you would remove the :not. But otherwise, that's basically it. The "garbage" is okay, I'm experimenting with rulesets that enforce logical consistency over time, e.g. of some process of interacting with the user and an external server. So the "garbage" is really the history. What I'm finding is that you generally have some "anchor" facts from which the rest of the process logic flows, so when you change the anchor the "garbage" gets collected. For example, in the conduit example, an anchor fact is the filter which retrieves a set of articles from the server, So articles wind up inserted with conditional dependence on the filter fact. Then the user can do a number of things, like change the favorite status of an article, edit if they are the author, etc. So all of that history gets accumulated, but when you change the filter it's all retracted.#2018-01-1919:32sparkofreason@wparker It wasn't specifically that I was looking to retract a fact without removing downstream insertions, rather modify the set of facts that went into an accumulator without retracting downstream insertions created by previous activations of the accumulator rule. It makes sense from a purely logical standpoint (I think), but the semantics of accumulators in the rule network are slightly different - not wrong, just making a different logical assertion, and one that is feasible within rule network architecture.#2018-01-2901:18tcarlsIf I have records having a field used for ordering -- like a timestamp -- and want to make rules that reason about or refer to "the immediately preceding X", or "the most recent X to have attribute Y", is Clara well-suited to the purpose?#2018-01-2901:18tcarls("immediately preceding" relative to another record, that is, as opposed to, say, an accumulator reflecting the globally most recent insert/assertion).#2018-01-2902:54dadairIt can be, I‚Äôm currently using it to reason about entities that change over time. I have to admit though that I don‚Äôt find it that easy to model (although I could be doing things horribly wrong).#2018-01-2902:56dadaire.g., I have entities of type A that can change over time (tracked through a timestamp), and other entities of type B that can change over time in response to the changes to type A (that is, there is a relation B = f(A)), and other entities of type C = f(B) that also change over time in response to changes in B#2018-01-2902:57dadairI find the rules I‚Äôm writing to be quite.. cumbersome, and I find myself inserting special facts just to facilitate rule propagation, to prevent e.g., infinite activations#2018-01-2902:59dadairhowever, the challenges I face come from the /fact/ that changes are inserted as a consequence of rules, if all history was known prior to rule activation, and I wasn‚Äôt inserting new facts from rules (that is, growing/extending time within a given session‚Äôs fire-rules), and I was simply querying certain states throughout a known and unchanging history, that would be perfectly suitable#2018-01-2915:20mikerod@tcarls I think that @dadair has some good things to think about in terms of what you are trying to accomplish. Some of it varies according to the situation. Here is an example that I think meets at least one part of your question though 
(defrule immediately-preceding
  [A (= timestamp ?ts)]
  [?preceding <- (acc/max :timestamp :returns-fact true) :from [B (< timestamp ?ts)]]
  =>
  <etc>)
#2018-01-2915:21mikerodYou can use an accumulator that constrains the facts that it accumulates over. By doing this, you can match things more specific/localized/‚Äúparameterized‚Äù, rather than ‚Äúglobal‚Äù accumulations.#2018-01-2916:03tcarls@mikerod, that's extremely helpful; thank you.#2018-01-3016:05afurmanovHello, I have question about acc/all behavior, the following snippet of code: 
(ns rules-acc-all
  (require [clara.rules :as rules]
           [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc]
           [clojure.pprint :refer [pprint]]))

(defrecord Customer [id])
(defrecord Reward [id])
(defrecord CustomerReward [id customer-id reward-id])

(rules/defrule quals
  [Customer (= ?C id)]
  [Reward (= ?R id) (= id "bonus-1")]
  ;;[?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= id ?I) (= ?C customer-id)]]
  [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= ?C customer-id)]]
  =>
  (pprint {"?items" ?items}))


(let [session (-> (rules/mk-session 'rules-acc-all)
                  (rules/insert (->Customer "customer-1")
                                (->Reward "bonus-1")
                                (->Reward "offer-1")
                                (->Reward "offer-2")
                                (->CustomerReward "cr-1" "customer-1" "offer-1")
                                (->CustomerReward "cr-2" "customer-1" "offer-2")))
      fired (rules/fire-rules session)]
  )
#2018-01-3016:05afurmanovPrints 
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-1", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-1"}
  {:id "cr-2", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-2"}]}
#2018-01-3016:06afurmanovi.e. ?items contain two elements.#2018-01-3016:07afurmanovHowever if condition [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= ?C customer-id)]] is replaced with [?items <- (acc/all) :from [CustomerReward (= id ?I) (= ?C customer-id)]] (pretty much same with unification added for CustomerReward (= id ?I) the the output would be:#2018-01-3016:07afurmanov
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-1", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-1"}]}
{"?items"
 [{:id "cr-2", :customer-id "customer-1", :reward-id "offer-2"}]}
#2018-01-3016:07afurmanovI.e. ?items contain single element, but rule gets triggered twice.#2018-01-3016:09afurmanovI am trying to wrap my mind around this, but cannot - those two rules set look pretty much same to me#2018-01-3017:01sparkofreasonI believe it's because when you specify (= id ?I) in the accumulator, clara will now make a unique binding for each unique value of id, so the rule fires once for each id of CustomerReward rather than accumulating over all CustomerReward's with different id's.#2018-01-3017:12afurmanovThanks @dave.dixon - that kind of explains it. I guess my confusion was due thinking that binding (= id ?I) is kind of "local" to accumulator, in other words it works as sub-select in SQL, however it appears such binding makes ?I "available" to "outer scope", i.e. I could refer it for unification in clauses which are siblings of accumulator.#2018-01-3017:13sparkofreasonCorrect. Or you could refer to ?I in the RHS of the rule, where it would have to be unique.#2018-01-3017:13afurmanovYep, then it makes sense#2018-01-3102:07tcarlsI'm seeing rules no longer firing after I reloaded the namespace that contains them in the REPL, even if I create an entirely new session with (mk-session :cache false). What am I missing?#2018-01-3104:45dadair@tcarls might need a code example, numerous things could be happening, depending on the state of the namespace#2018-01-3116:11tcarls@dadair, in hindsight, I'm pretty sure what's happening is caused by new defrecords being run, but trying to run rules against data from an atom that includes (expensive-to-calculate) cached previous instances of input data. Going to move the definitions into their own namespace; I expect that'll help.#2018-01-3116:12mikerod@tcarls that is common#2018-01-3116:13mikerodThe potemkin lib had some extensions to defrecord and other related macros to avoid that sort of redefinition of classes to help with reloading workflows in the REPL#2018-01-3116:13mikerodI think one workaround people do for Clara has been to do defrecord in a separate ns that you don‚Äôt plan to reload much#2018-01-3116:14mikerodSo the rules don‚Äôt get mismatched definitions of the ‚Äúsame class‚Äù#2018-01-3122:19tcarlsOne thing that's surprising me in using Clara is how one needs to take explicit steps to avoid getting two equal records created if arriving at the same fact via two different rules.#2018-01-3122:40mikerod@tcarls yeah, there are pro‚Äôs and con‚Äôs to that#2018-01-3122:40mikerodThere are definitely use-cases where ‚Äúcardinality‚Äù matters#2018-01-3122:41mikerodI‚Äôve had quite a few of those before. So if you ‚Äúremoved the duplicates‚Äù you‚Äôd fail to meet the needs of someone who wanted to count things#2018-01-3122:41mikerodFor whatever purpose#2018-01-3122:42mikerodIn Drools (popular Java-based rules engine), they went with ‚Äúlogical inserts‚Äù never are duplicated, but ‚Äúunconditional inserts‚Äù are duplicated if they are not identical?#2018-01-3122:42mikerodIt was nice, when you really just didn‚Äôt want duplicates, but difficult to work with when you did#2018-01-3122:42mikerodIn Clara, if you need some ‚Äúsingle count‚Äù fact in the end, you can just use an aggregation sort of rule#2018-01-3122:45mikerodI do think it could be interesting if Clara had an options where it made working memory ‚Äúset-like‚Äù and duplicates didn‚Äôt show up. There are definitely costs to doing this though.#2018-01-3123:18tcarlsheadscratch#2018-01-3123:24tcarls
{:lhs [{:type pdfsort.types.Warning, :constraints [], :fact-binding :?warning}], :params #{}, :name "pdfsort.core/get-warnings"} is invalid or not included in the rule base.
...seems to be happening consistently for me right now when invoking code from lein run, but not when invoking the same functions from Emacs/Cider.#2018-01-3123:33dadair@tcarls where is the mk-session you‚Äôre using (e.g., same ns as the rule? other ns?), and what does the function call look like?#2018-01-3123:33dadairand can you post a snippet of the rule?#2018-02-0100:30tcarls@dadair, same ns, called from the -main function with :cache false. The get-warnings rule is basically as simple as the above implies -- it just retrieves every single record we have of type Warning with no filters/joins/etc: (r/defquery get-warnings [] [?warning <- Warning])#2018-02-0100:48tcarlsHmm. Unrelated issue, but I have a theory on why I'm getting more fact insertions than I expected. Looking through the explain output... 
{:ns-name pdfsort.core,
   :lhs
   [{:type pdfsort.types.Document,
     :constraints [(= ?type (or name-type header-type))],
     :fact-binding :?doc}],
   :rhs (do (r/insert! (->DocumentType ?doc ?type))),
   :name "pdfsort.core/use-document-type"}
I expected the (or name-type header-type) to mean that we bind the first non-falsey item of name-type or header-type to ?type, but it looks like it actually results in both paths being followed. Changing it to (if name-type name-type header-type) results in the initially-expected behavior, of performing one DocumentType insertion per Document.#2018-02-0115:50wparker@U2V9F98N8 I‚Äôd expect the or in the above rule to be short-circuiting i.e. just clojure.core/or. Something like this is a Clara-specific non-short-circuiting or: 
[:or [DocumentType1] [DocumentType2]]
