but that doesn‚Äôt apply to the case you describe; note the keyword :or not the function invocation of ‚Äúor‚Äù. If you can create a reproducing case it would be helpful if you could log a GitHub issue - tbh I suspect something else is going on, but you never know#2018-02-0221:16mjmeintjesWhat's the best way to ensure that a fact doesn't get inserted twice. Is there a way to ensure that duplicate facts don't get inserted into the same session?#2018-02-0221:30mikerod@mjmeintjes I talked about this in a few posts above if you can see them?#2018-02-0221:30mikerodI discussed ‚Äúcardinality‚Äù of equal facts in clara and ways to work with it#2018-02-0221:30mikerodand tradeoffs etc#2018-02-0221:40mjmeintjesThanks for the information. I was thinking more about how to efficiently update the session - for example, I have a list of rows from the database. Before firing the rules I need to make sure that all the db rows are included in the session. However, I do not want all the rules to be inserted each time (which causes lots of duplicates), and I also don't want the session to be recreated each time. What I've done now is create a query to retrieve the already inserted rules from the session, and then I'm comparing that against the db rows, and then I only insert the new ones. I was just wondering whether that is the best solution.#2018-02-0221:45mikerod@mjmeintjes I think that is a fine way to do it. I think there may be a potential enhancement to clara to do something like an ‚Äúupdate‚Äù of facts and/or a ‚Äúmode‚Äù that had the working memory act in a set-based way there weren‚Äôt duplicates. For now though, the external query idea is good if it can work for you#2018-02-0221:48mjmeintjesYeah, being able to efficiently update the session would be great, as each time I've used Clara that's something that I've run up against. The only problem with the query approach is that queries are only updated once fire-rules has run, which means you can still get duplicates if you aren't careful to run fire-rules before inserting any new data.#2018-02-0221:52mikerod@mjmeintjes Yeah, you should never query prior to fire-rules. I‚Äôd call that an ‚Äúundefined‚Äù state#2018-02-0221:52mikerodClara does some ‚Äúlazy‚Äù sort of batching that isn‚Äôt forced until fire-rules. It can do some good optimizations with this and could even get more ‚Äúlazy‚Äù in the future I‚Äôd think.#2018-02-0221:53mikerodI think it can be difficult to do ‚Äúlogical updates‚Äù to facts with what Clara currently offers#2018-02-0221:54mikerodit relies basically entirely on the caller to query facts and figure out what inserts/retracts to make externally. That is if the rules are going to be written in a way that can smoothly work with the truth maintenance system and logical inserts (ie not insert-unconditional! and right-hand-side based retract!).#2018-02-0221:54mikerodThese sort of discussions have came up quite a bit here lately.#2018-02-0221:55mikerodI wrote this a while back http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html Not sure if it is really useful to you. You seem to already have a setup you‚Äôve been using to do your de-duping anyways#2018-02-0221:56mjmeintjesThanks for that post, I'll have a read. Love reading information about Clara, as it is such a great programming model. Always trying to find places to use it.#2018-02-0221:57mikerodWell that‚Äôs good.#2018-02-0221:57mikerodYeah, I‚Äôd like to try out some ideas to deal with these sorts of things. I think some sort of rule-triggered ‚Äúupdate‚Äù would be interesting.#2018-02-0221:58mikerodAs well as externally specified updates#2018-02-0221:58mikerodThe challenge would be to do so in a way that interacted in a well-defined way with the truth maintenance system and logically inserted/retracted facts.#2018-02-0222:24mjmeintjesThanks, useful post, helped clarify/validate the approach I'm taking.#2018-02-0222:25mikerodOh, good#2018-02-0503:58cflemingBTW Cursive 1.6.3-eap3 is out now, which contains support for Clara! Many thanks to @mikerod and @alex-dixon for help with that. I‚Äôm interested in any feedback, as always, either here or over in #cursive.#2018-02-0510:53urzdsHi!#2018-02-0602:07sparkofreasonIs there any documentation of the :exists feature? I saw some discussion about it on google groups and maybe in an issue, but haven't found much else.#2018-02-0615:02mikerod@dave.dixon not sure if there are any docs on it#2018-02-0615:02mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/130 has some discussion#2018-02-0615:03mikerodthat‚Äôs the best I‚Äôve found as far as docs on it#2018-02-0615:03mikerod(didn‚Äôt do an exhaustive search)#2018-02-0615:12wparker@dave.dixon I don‚Äôt see any docs on it based on a search for ‚Äúexists‚Äù in the clara-site repo. Having doc would be desirable. In the meantime it is really a pretty form of syntax sugar - you can just mentally make the substitution the compiler does at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L618 if you‚Äôre trying to understand the behavior#2018-02-0615:41sparkofreason@wparker Thanks. So looking at that, [:not [:exists ...]] should work as expected, i.e. that "no fact satisfying the conditions exists" as opposed to "maybe some fact exists that doesn't satisfy the conditions"?#2018-02-0615:43wparkerUnfortunately not at the moment; see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/329#2018-02-0615:44wparkerIn the case of :not :exists there isn‚Äôt much reason to write it like that though, as I mentioned on the issue#2018-02-0615:44sparkofreasonAh. Okay, I thought maybe I was just writing the expression, wrong. I'll take a look at the discussion.#2018-02-0615:44wparkeras a general API concern, it is something that seems like it should work.. but haven‚Äôt gotten around to fixing it#2018-02-0616:40sparkofreasonIt does seem to work. I was having some issues and thought this may be the culprit, but it was other things (which had nothing to do with clara per se). I was a little suspicious of that binding inside the negation as well, but is seems to operate as intended, i.e. "There is no Request fact equal to the Request entry on the Response fact".#2018-02-0621:46sparkofreasonIt looks like the current behavior of parameterized queries is to just return an empty seq if all of the arguments are not bound in the call to query. It would be useful sometimes if leaving out a parameter just treated it as unbound, though I think you could only get away with this when the parameters are used in simple equality constraints, e.g. [?:foo] [Foo (= ?foo foo)]. I can get this behavior by wrapping query, but was wondering if there was a way to achieve it directly in clara.#2018-02-0716:55wparker@dave.dixon the query params are defined at query creation time and then used to key the results for the query in a map. This results in the actual call to ‚Äúquery‚Äù basically just being a map lookup. If arbitrary keys could be missing, I don‚Äôt think you could look things up that way without creating a lookup table for every possible permutation of absent and present bindings during fire-rules time, which could become costly. Looking at the code it seems perhaps we could add logic allowing the user to either pass all present params or none, providing all results regardless of bindings in the later case. Relevant code sections: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1959 for the query implementation in the engine, note the mem/get-tokens call. In QueryNode note the memory calls as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L431 with the join-bindings coming from the param-keys via this: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L149 Then see get-tokens and get-tokens-all: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/memory.cljc#L451 ; get-tokens-all would ignore the bindings#2018-02-0718:05sparkofreason@wparker Thanks, good insight on working memory. It looks like the inspect function illustrates how to get at the bindings via get-tokens-all.#2018-02-0814:34alex-dixonAnyone tried the new Cursive yet?#2018-02-0814:56zyloxive been using it#2018-02-0814:56zyloxthough i havent had tooo much time to actually code in it#2018-02-0815:03zyloxbut it works#2018-02-0815:06alex-dixonAwesome. Think it might be available in non-eap now. Haven‚Äôt tried yet#2018-02-0815:08zyloxah, ya im still on eap#2018-02-0818:09cfleming@alex-dixon Yes, 1.6.3 went out yesterday.#2018-02-1216:16yyonchoHere is simplified example of what I am trying to accomplish: I have fact FnHolder which contains how the Temperature facts will be compared/processed. I want to have a rule which produces another fact from the FnHolder and the Temperature but it doesn't trigger the depending rules when a new Temperature which doesn't change the produced value(thus I cannot do the accumulation in the body). This behavior is similar to acc/max which does not trigger if a non-maximal Temperature is inserted. Ideally I would have been able to write the following code but it doesn't run since ?fn is not visible in the custom-accum block. Can you advice? code (defrecord Temperature [location temperature]) (defrecord FnHolder [location other-params]) (defrule chaning [?fn <- FnHolder (= location ?loc)] [?t <- (custom-accum ?fn) :from [Temperature]] => ;; insert facts... ) code#2018-02-1217:53mikerod@yyoncho I don‚Äôt have an immediate complete answer to that question, but perhaps you could accomplish what you are wanting with a :test condition after the accumulation. Accumulate with something that doesn‚Äôt need to be ‚Äúparameterized‚Äù.#2018-02-1217:54mikerodAnother possibility is to use a sort of joined fact. I‚Äôm not sure how appropriate it will be for you, but it would look like:#2018-02-1217:55mikerod
(defrecord Temperature [location temperature])
(defrecord FnHolder [location other-params])
(defrecord TempWithFn [temp fn-holder])

(defrule combine
  [?fn <- FnHolder  (= location ?loc)]
  [?t <- Temperature]
  =>
  (insert (->TempWithFn ?t ?fn)))

(defrule chaning
  [?t <- (custom-accum :fn-holder) :from [TempWithFn]]
  =>
  ;; insert facts...
)
#2018-02-1217:56mikerodI think the custom-accum doesn‚Äôt really need the :fn-holder key anymore though. it has the whole fact with all that info on it.#2018-02-1307:15yyoncho@mikerod if I do that I will be able to process the Temperature facts one by one in FnHolder which won't work since FnHolder is stateful processing over the whole collection of Temperature facts, e. g. find the max Temperature for particular day of the week.#2018-02-1922:43souenzzo48260 facts is something that I can call "huge"? Or there is other problem on my rules?#2018-02-1922:44souenzzo(my application hangs/out-of-memory/stranges exceptions on fire-rules)#2018-02-2000:23mikerod@souenzzo I wouldn‚Äôt normally expect that number of facts to be much of a problem#2018-02-2000:24mikerodhowever, you can certainly write rules in a way that cause a problem (for smaller numbers even)#2018-02-2015:39wparker@souenzzo what do you mean by ‚Äústrange exceptions‚Äù? In terms of number of facts, the only real limit in Clara should be the memory available.. but of course if you have problematic rules (not necessarily incorrectly written, just poorly performing) you can run into problems. If you can find a reproducing case that seems like it performs more poorly than it should feel free to log an issue. We‚Äôve mostly optimized Clara against the examples we have at Cerner but representative benchmarks of other workloads could be interesting/useful.#2018-02-2813:51wdullaerI'm doing some stress testing of clara and i'm seeing some weird behaviour#2018-02-2813:51wdullaerthe background is that I want to build a sort of access control engine#2018-02-2813:52wdullaerthere are 3 fact types: a consent, a processor and a processingallowed fact#2018-02-2813:52wdullaerthere's just one rule which inserts processingallowed if there is sufficient amount of concent for a given processor#2018-02-2813:53wdullaerwhen I insert 1 million random consents, firing the rules takes just a few seconds#2018-02-2813:53wdullaerif I insert 1 million more into the previous session, firing the rules takes over an hour (I never waiting long enough for it to complete)#2018-02-2813:54wdullaerif I insert 2 million random consents in an empty session, firing the rules still only takes a few seconds#2018-02-2813:56wdullaerwhile this isn't a truly realistic scenario (updates to consent would arrive in batches of a few 100 once initialised), I'm still kind of surprised by this behaviour#2018-02-2814:57mikerod@wdullaer that is interesting. it would seem that the insert 1 mil then 1 mil later is triggering some heavy ‚Äúretraction‚Äù work#2018-02-2814:57mikerodHowever, with that sort of time being taken up, it‚Äôd be good to have some profiling#2018-02-2814:58wdullaerthere is no rule which retracts facts#2018-02-2814:58mikerodUnless you can reproduce it in a small case, which may not be easy. I wonder if you could do some CPU sampling snapshot while it is running excessively via a tool like ‚Äúvisual vm‚Äù or similar#2018-02-2814:58wdullaerI haven't found a good way to do detailed profiling / tracing yet, so all suggestions are welcome üôÇ#2018-02-2814:58mikerodWell, retracts can happen due to logical inserts (normal insert! in Clara). Also, accumulators may be updated and have to retract previous results. There are quite a few reasons to have ‚Äúimplicit‚Äù retracts happening in working memory#2018-02-2814:59wdullaermake sense#2018-02-2814:59wdullaerI am using an all accumulator in the rule#2018-02-2814:59mikerodVisualVM is free. I‚Äôve used it mostly just since it was good enough for seeing many things like this.#2018-02-2814:59wdullaerbut the funny thing is that it works just fine when doing 2 million in bulk on an empty session#2018-02-2815:00wdullaerI'll give that a spin#2018-02-2815:00mikerodThat isn‚Äôt entirely surprising to me - if you‚Äôve found a bad retraction sort of scenario#2018-02-2815:00mikerodIn bulk, Clara does a lot of work in batches#2018-02-2815:00mikerodWhich has one benefit of avoiding ‚Äúrework‚Äù - aka retractions/insertions to update ‚Äúincorrect‚Äù earlier working memory states#2018-02-2815:01wdullaerI'm comparing 2 million in 1 go, vs 2 batches of 1 million#2018-02-2815:01wdullaer(I was expecting memory usage to be a bottleneck, but it's doing pretty fine on that front)#2018-02-2815:01wdullaeranyway, visualvm it is üôÇ#2018-02-2815:01mikerodSo running with the VisualVM idea. 1) Download it, 2) open it, 3) find your JVM process (it has a list on in the UI) running the bad performance case with#2018-02-2815:02mikerod(4) click ‚ÄúSampler‚Äù tab (5) click ‚ÄúCPU‚Äù (6) start running whatever is taking a long time#2018-02-2815:03mikerod(7) let it run for a bit, perhaps like a minute or so, then click ‚Äúsnapshot‚Äù#2018-02-2815:03wdullaerüëç#2018-02-2815:05mikerodOnce you have a snapshot, you can dig around the callstack to see where the time is. If you want help with that, you can perhaps explain what is taking such a long time in the Clara functions of the callstack and perhaps I (or someone) will know enough by that. Or you can you can ‚Äúexport to‚Äù via an icon in the UI and it‚Äôll give you an nps file to share. If you have proprietary stuff (I don‚Äôt think much proprietary info shows up in these though, but still.) you don‚Äôt want to show, you could try to just find good screenshots that cut the callstack down to just the Clara functions parts.#2018-02-2815:05wdullaerI have to run now, but I'll do the test later today and post back with the results#2018-02-2815:05wdullaerthanks a lot already!#2018-02-2815:05mikerodIt‚Äôs probably not a bad idea to get some familiarity with digging through some cpu sampling snapshot results though. Can definitely be useful for finding bottlenecks quickly#2018-02-2815:05mikerodNo problem#2018-02-2816:21wparker@wdullaer are you inserting the facts like this: 
(-> session (insert first-fact) .... (insert millionth-fact))
or like this: 
(insert session [first-fact .. millionth-fact]
It seems odd to me that simply breaking a single batch into two would have such a huge performance impact - OTOH smaller batching could do it. Arguably Clara should try to batch the first case together anyway, but it doesn‚Äôt. See how facts are added into the ‚Äúpending-operations‚Äù on insertion at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1818 and removed from the queue in fire-rules at https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1870#2018-02-2816:26wparkerIf a simple division into two batches really does increase runtime like that I‚Äôd be curious to see a reproducing case and if there is some performance optimization we could do - at first glance it doesn‚Äôt seem like it should happen, but as always it is hard to say without a concrete case. On profiling, seconding mikerod‚Äôs suggestion of VisualVM. Another possible route would be to look at the trace of the rule execution for a smaller number of facts - manual examination wouldn‚Äôt be practical for millions of facts, but a batch of 2 facts vs 2 batches of 1 fact each might show insights. I‚Äôd probably start with VisualVM though especially since traces generally require some understanding of Clara‚Äôs internals to yield much insight. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.17.0/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/tracing.cljc#2018-02-2816:32mikerod@wparker sounded like he had batches of 1 million. so not really ‚Äúsmall‚Äù hah#2018-02-2816:32mikerodhowever, I was thinking that the scenario was ‚Äúinsert 1 million, then fire‚Äù, later on, ‚Äúinsert 1 million, then fire‚Äù#2018-02-2817:10wdullaerthat's exactly it#2018-02-2816:32mikerodTrying to reuse and old session state basically#2018-02-2816:33mikerodIt certainly sounds like the batching behavior was critical to the performance of the scenario they were having.#2018-02-2816:34mikerodIt seems that there is potentially found some bad performing case in terms of updating working memory state that this uncovered. Also, I think I assumed this was on the JVM. Not sure if that was actually stated before. I‚Äôm guessing so with the millions of facts and the discussion around using visualvm#2018-02-2816:34wparkerMy point was that I think it would be possible to think the batch was a million, but actually end up being one at a time when rules fire, so just wanted to make sure that it was batched#2018-02-2816:34mikerodyeah, true#2018-02-2816:35wparkerPerhaps Clara should probably take (-> session (insert A) (insert B) fire-rules) and turn it into a single batch - but I think it is 2 at present#2018-02-2816:35mikerodYeah#2018-02-2816:36mikerodIf they were inserting a million things though, they probably did it in a single insert#2018-02-2816:36mikerodotherwise they‚Äôd have to do something like (reduce insert session million-things)#2018-02-2816:36mikerodI don‚Äôt think they‚Äôd write out a million (insert thing1) by hand üòõ#2018-02-2816:36wparkeranyway a VisualVM snapshot would be informative, spending time in memory updates would be a possible culprit#2018-02-2816:40mikerodyeah, I thought it would be good to se#2018-02-2816:40mikerodhopefully some can be obtained#2018-02-2816:41mikerodI agree in general though that Clara should just batch the work from multiple insert calls#2018-02-2816:41mikerodShould batch as much as possible#2018-02-2816:42alex-dixonWould insert-all be preferable here?#2018-02-2816:43mikerodIf you have a big collection of things to insert, yes insert-all#2018-02-2816:43mikerodor you call insert via varargs if you have compile-time known ones#2018-02-2816:44mikerodYou could also do apply insert, but no reason too since insert-all exists#2018-02-2816:44mikerodBatched propagation through the rete network can be a big performance boost#2018-02-2816:44mikerodSo it‚Äôs best to be as batch‚Äôful as you can be#2018-02-2816:46alex-dixonA while ago I think I noticed retracts were slow. Not the result of insert logical though#2018-02-2816:46mikerodto clarify, external retract or RHS retract!?#2018-02-2816:48mikerodFor no good reason (that I‚Äôm aware of) there isn‚Äôt a retract-all for external retraction right now. So you should use apply retract if you have a batch there.#2018-02-2818:56alex-dixonExternal #2018-02-2819:05mikerodSo yep, apply retract#2018-02-2819:06mikerod(we should get a retract-all added for convenience and symmetry with insert#2018-02-2819:06alex-dixonFaster than doseq?#2018-02-2819:07mikerodI don‚Äôt know how you would doseq external retract - returns a new version of the session, not mutation#2018-02-2819:07mikerodIf you have a collection of facts to externally retract Instead of (reduce retract session facts) do (apply retract session facts)#2018-02-2817:12wdullaerhere's roughly what's happening:#2018-02-2817:13wdullaer
(->session 
    (insert-all (generate-consents 1000000 test-purposes test-attributes))
    (fire-rules)
    (insert-all (generate-consents 1000000 test-purposes test-attributes))
    (fire-rules))
#2018-02-2817:13wdullaerwith some log statements to see where I am#2018-02-2817:13wdullaerthis is on the jvm#2018-02-2817:14wdullaerI still have to take the snapshot#2018-02-2817:14wdullaermaybe I'll try to reduce the code to the size of a gist so I can share it#2018-02-2817:16mikerod> maybe I‚Äôll try to reduce the code to the size of a gist so I can share it Yeah, that is best-case scenario#2018-02-2817:32wdullaerI'll report back tomorrow#2018-03-0108:33wdullaerSo I fired up visualVM#2018-03-0108:34wdullaerand it seems to be spending all the time in clara.rules.engine$retract_accumulated.invoke()#2018-03-0108:35wdullaerwhich lines up with the theory that implicit retractions are causing this#2018-03-0108:36wdullaerI can share the snapshot if that would be interesting for people#2018-03-0108:36wdullaerI'll spend some time trimming the example down to a bare bones app I can put in a gist#2018-03-0112:49wdullaerthe gist can be found here: https://gist.github.com/wdullaer/cecf88b3266ba0ac90b4f060eefe5208#2018-03-0112:49wdullaerwhen making this I noticed that the 2 million case is not exactly the same as 2x 1 million, because of how the attributes are randomly generated#2018-03-0112:50wdullaer2x 1 million will generate much more consent for a given personId#2018-03-0112:50wdullaer(giving the accumulator more work)#2018-03-0112:50wdullaer2x 1 million goes fast enough if I make sure they generate distinct sets#2018-03-0112:51wdullaerhowever 1x 2 million tweaked to have the same overlap in consent as 2x 1 million still goes an order of magnitude faster#2018-03-0112:52wdullaerI know clara doesn't deduplicate facts, but I think in this case that would prevent me from running into this scenario#2018-03-0114:10mikerod@wdullaer thanks for the details#2018-03-0114:10mikerodI will take a look. It may be about an hour or so though. Doing a few other things at the moment.#2018-03-0114:11wdullaerno worries, take all the time you need#2018-03-0114:11wdullaerI can supply the vm snapshot as well (just need to find a quick place to upload it)#2018-03-0114:11mikerodYeah, if you have one you can share, that‚Äôd be good to take a glance at.#2018-03-0114:11mikerodHow to share hmm#2018-03-0114:13wdullaerI'll put it into dropbox, just a sec#2018-03-0114:14wdullaerhttps://www.dropbox.com/s/no6h9pwa03hzt7w/clara-perf.nps?dl=0#2018-03-0114:14mikerodok#2018-03-0116:23mikerod@wdullaer I‚Äôve only got to look at this briefly so far today#2018-03-0116:25mikerodIt seems like these collections created via acc/distinct would be fairly large. Also, there are many of them after the first 1mil facts. There‚Äôd be a big acc/distinct collection associated with each personId + purpose grouped Consent facts. When the next 1mil facts come in, I believe they will contribute to many (or perhaps even all) of those same big collections.#2018-03-0116:26mikerodThe work from the first 1 mil facts is stored in working memory. Clara builds the new collections on the 2nd wave of inserts. It then must remove the old accumulated work it did from working memory - in order to replace it with the updates.#2018-03-0116:26mikerodI think the fact that there are many of these large collections in working memory is making it get really expensive to remove them all from working memory. Clara tries to be efficient in finding and removing things in memory. I think huge collections may be a pitfall.#2018-03-0116:28mikerodI‚Äôd like to look a little deeper at it, but haven‚Äôt been able to yet. I‚Äôm not sure what a reasonable workaround may be, other than inserting everything in one batch (as you‚Äôve found).#2018-03-0116:28mikerodIt‚Äôs an interesting case to explore some more for sure.#2018-03-0117:41wdullaerthanks for the input#2018-03-0117:41wdullaerI can see how this is a worst case scenario#2018-03-0117:43wdullaerwe probably won‚Äôt see this amount of massive updates in a real life scenario, and if it does (say a big data migration), we can always consider starting from scratch#2018-03-0117:43wdullaerit was a bit surprising that updating these structures is a lot more expensive than creating them#2018-03-0117:44wdullaerif I can help in any way here, just let me know#2018-03-0117:44wdullaerI have a few other benchmarks I‚Äôm going to run over the coming days as well#2018-03-0117:58mikerodI need to look deeper at what is happening to have a stronger sense of what could be done#2018-03-0119:10wparkerI‚Äôve logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/385 for this @mikerod @wdullaer , I‚Äôd suggest that we post findings there when we have them#2018-03-0119:15wparkerFrom the snapshot it looks like the memory is the bottleneck, which isn‚Äôt too surprising. From my first glance over it I suspect there are some performance optimizations we can make for cases like this, but it may be a bit before I have time to write my thoughts down in a sufficiently articulate form. The benchmark and snapshot are really helpful and make diagnosing things like this much easier - thanks for that. It is useful to have benchmarks of realistic rule patterns that stress-test Clara.#2018-03-0209:52wdullaerthe insert 1 million is realistic, the update 1 million slightly less so#2018-03-0209:53wdullaerthanks for all the help so far!#2018-03-0216:10alex-dixon@wparker @mikerod Thanks for the clarification on https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/386. Re: breaking changes, Precept recently experienced some with 0.17.0 and realized I should probably speak up about anything that might affect the implementation since I‚Äôm the only one that would really know üôÇ Sorry if I‚Äôm being overly concerned. It‚Äôs hard for me to investigate the effects of changes in detail myself due to time constraints lately, and hard in general since to me there‚Äôs a fair amount of complexity at work in Clara üôÇ#2018-03-0216:18wparker@alex-dixon what sorts of breaking changes? Have you tracked down the cause(s)? I totally understand not wanting to be blindsided by breaking changes and am glad you‚Äôre looking over the issue list. üôÇ If we created a regression of some kind or need to more clearly communicate public vs private boundaries of some API(s) in Clara that‚Äôd be good info to have.#2018-03-0216:22alex-dixonMeh. It‚Äôs my responsibility. You guys do a great job. It‚Äôs been inspiring to me to see how much effort is put into backward compatibility. I‚Äôve narrowed it down to a couple of commits but since it‚Äôs not something that‚Äôs fun to solve I haven‚Äôt looked very far üòÑ https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/issues/112#2018-03-0216:29alex-dixonBasically I had some rules that I baked into every Precept session and in 0.17 they‚Äôre not making it in. Relevant spots in Precept code (which echoes Clara‚Äôs implementation considerably) may include: https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/master/src/clj/precept/macros.clj#L87 https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/690ba6cd30064901ce830b67ca92caaab9a68c93/src/cljc/precept/rules.cljc#L38#2018-03-0216:31alex-dixonPretty confident I can figure it out‚Ä¶seems related to namespace resolution changes that fix rules not being able to see vars defined in their namespace in CLJS. That‚Äôs definitely a fix I want so just need to take some time to make this work on my end#2018-03-0216:32wparkerYeah, just giving it a fast glance it seems like you‚Äôre doing custom stuff with loading rules and such, and the changes in 359 could have impacted that somehow (again without looking at it in any detail). 359 was an obvious bug that needed to be fixed, but if we broke something else with it that ought to work let us know#2018-03-0219:37ProbablyJody@wdullaer for a workaround in your use case, would it make sense to first filter the consents? Your example shows 1/10th as many persons as events. Shrinking the search space by explicitly filtering the duplicates may speed things up.#2018-03-0219:42ProbablyJodySo adding an additional defrecord DistinctConsent and a new rule to map from Consent to DistinctConsent The rest of the rules would just use DistinctConsent going forward#2018-03-0219:42ProbablyJodyas an example#2018-03-0219:42wdullaeryes, I‚Äôll probably try to prevent duplicate consent from being created#2018-03-0219:43wdullaerthat‚Äôs also a cool way to handle it actually, I thought about querying before inserting#2018-03-0219:43ProbablyJodyacc/distinct will still be managing a large object for retractions#2018-03-0219:44ProbablyJodybut it will be smaller than the cross product of Consents and Processors#2018-03-0219:45wdullaerI don‚Äôt fully control how many consent items we‚Äôll have for a given user#2018-03-0219:45wdullaerit depends on the granularity at which this will be recorded and that is not fully within my control#2018-03-0219:46ProbablyJodyBut you expect duplicate consents?#2018-03-0219:46wdullaermost certainly#2018-03-0219:46ProbablyJodycool#2018-03-0219:58ProbablyJodyanother thought (possibly in addition to the previous one) was to explode the Processor facts into something like DesiredConsent [processorId purpose attribute], use a rule to match them to a Consent and dump into another intermediate fact ApprovedDesiredConsent [processorId personId purpose attribute]. Then accumulate and match your ApprovedDesiredConsent to the Processor. I haven‚Äôt tested it, so I don‚Äôt know if it‚Äôs more performant, but the idea/hope is that you‚Äôd accumulate less when creating the AllowedProcessor#2018-03-0220:29wdullaerI‚Äôll experiment with some of these on Monday#2018-03-0220:29wdullaerthe easiest I think is to just ensure that no duplicate consents are asserted, which I think I can do out of band (the consent will intially be put on a log)#2018-03-0306:13Oliver GeorgeNewbie question... I'm struggling to write a rule which boils down to "This or that".#2018-03-0306:13Oliver George
(defrecord This [x])
  (defrecord That [y])
  (defrule this-or-that
    "Print This if fact exists, else print That."
    [:or [?x <- This] [?x <- That]]
    =>
    (println :this-or-that ?x))

  (-> (mk-session 'labs-costs-clara.core)
      (insert
        (->This 1)
        (->That 2))
      (fire-rules))
#2018-03-0306:13Oliver GeorgeThis will print twice which isn't what I'm after.#2018-03-0306:14Oliver George(my real example is patching data... if X exists use it else use some other facts to fill in the gap)#2018-03-0306:14zyloxya, or isnt a xor, it can indeed follow both paths#2018-03-0306:14zyloxi tend to think of it as if you had two disjunct rules#2018-03-0306:14zyloxbecause that is pretty close to what it does#2018-03-0306:15zyloxif you want one but not the other...well you are going to want to use two rules with :not on This in one and That on the other#2018-03-0306:15Oliver GeorgeThat makes sense. My rules got a bit verbose which is what got me wondering.#2018-03-0306:15Oliver GeorgeThanks#2018-03-0306:16Oliver GeorgeThe only alternative I could imagine was some kind of maybe accumulator#2018-03-0306:16Oliver George(e.g. distinct but expecting one fact)#2018-03-0306:17zyloxare you expecting only one, or potentially many#2018-03-0306:17Oliver GeorgeMy code was really "if summary value exists use it, else calculate from many other facts" but that's not critical to the general question.#2018-03-0306:18Oliver GeorgeThanks for your thoughts @zylox that makes me feel more confident#2018-03-0306:20zyloxgotcha. id suggest something like 
(defrule with-summary
  ""
  [Summary (= ?data data)]
  =>
  (println ?data))

(defrule without-summary
  ""
  [:not [Summary]]
  [?others <- (acc/all) :from [SecondaryFacts]]
  
  =>
  (println ?others))
then#2018-03-0306:20zyloxbest of luck#2018-03-0306:20Oliver GeorgeThank you#2018-03-0306:21zyloxwithout all the horrible syntax errors i just edited out haha#2018-03-0416:29sekaohey, has anyone tried clara with clojurescript 1.10.126? i'm getting a bunch of arity warnings about MapEntry and at runtime i'm getting Maximum call stack size exceeded from schema.core (where mapentry is defined)#2018-03-0416:30sekaoi'm guessing schema is not playing well with it. i noticed in their changelog that they had to fix some MapEntry warnings in 1.1.6, but clara is already using that version so this must be a new problem#2018-03-0416:46alex-dixon@sekao Haven‚Äôt tried that version. I‚Äôm on 1.9.854#2018-03-0416:47alex-dixonI‚Äôve had problems with the schema library in the past though. I think I got around it by excluding clara‚Äôs version and using a newer one. That might not work in this case though#2018-03-0416:47alex-dixonWhat version of Clara are you using?#2018-03-0416:49sekaoi'm using 0.17.0 but it happens with master as well. i just mentioned it on the clojurescript channel and it sounds like it is conflicting with MapEntry in cljs.core#2018-03-0419:20mikerod@sekao so this is a schema issue with the new cljs version then?#2018-03-0419:31sekaoyep it seems so#2018-03-0419:33mikerodAlright. Hmm. I guess schema needs to get fixed...#2018-03-0419:33sekaois it still actively maintained?#2018-03-0420:49mikerod@sekao yeah I wasn‚Äôt sure on that. #2018-03-0420:50mikerodI think they at least probably still take pull requests#2018-03-1418:20afurmanovWhy this code 
(ns experiments.a
  (:require [clara.rules :as rules]

            [clojure.pprint :refer [pprint]]))

(defrecord A [id])

(rules/defrule create-a-if-not-exists
  ""
  [:not [A]]
  =>
  (println "creating A")
  (rules/insert! (->A "a")))

(-> (rules/mk-session)
    (rules/fire-rules))
#2018-03-1418:20afurmanovcreates infinite recursion?#2018-03-1418:27ethancThe initial state of the session makes the LHS of your rule evaluate as true thus it inserts an A, which then makes your rule's LHS evaluate as false causing the truth maintenance of clara to logically retract the A that was insert. repeat#2018-03-1418:27ethancforever#2018-03-1418:28ethanc@alex.furmanov#2018-03-1418:28zylox"ok i'll insert a if there is no A. Inserting. Ok now lets look at the state of things. Oh there is an A. Retract That thing i inserted. Ok now lets look at the state of things. Oh there is no A. Time to insert A...." ~ Internal monologue of the session repeat ad infinitum#2018-03-1418:30zyloxhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ truth maintenance is the name of the game#2018-03-1418:35afurmanovThanks!#2018-03-1815:10sparkofreasonThe trace listener feature is very helpful for finding the cause of loops.#2018-03-2116:01talgiatis there a way to query for all types but one?#2018-03-2116:05mikerod@talgiat the main problem I‚Äôd see with doing something like that is that the query may become a performance problem#2018-03-2116:05mikerodIt would be heavily hit since it‚Äôs working memory will change any time any fact in working memory is inserted/retracted (including from truth maintenance)#2018-03-2116:07mikerodYou could probably do what you ask though: 
(r/defquery []
  [?o <- Object]
  [:test (not (isa? (type ?o) ExcludedType))])
#2018-03-2116:07mikerodIf you have a custom :fact-type-fn you could still accomplish similar#2018-03-2116:30talgiatI do have a :fact-type-fn#2018-03-2117:01mikerod@talgiat you‚Äôd have to define an hierarchy then more than likely#2018-03-2117:02mikerodSee http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2018-03-2117:02mikerodPotentially you could derive all your types to a common ancestor type.#2018-03-2117:03mikerodYou could leave out the excluded type from that grouping too, and then your query would just be r/defquery my-q [] [?x <- :parent-type]#2018-03-2117:12talgiatyeah, thought about that#2018-03-2117:13talgiatprob. better with records implementing a common protocol that will be the parent#2018-03-2118:02mikerod@talgiat it can go either way really#2018-03-2819:51talgiatIs there a way to have a short circuiting :or in clara, not sure why it is designed that way#2018-03-2819:52mikerod@talgiat they aren‚Äôt meant for that. They are mostly just syntax sugar for multiple rules#2018-03-2819:53mikerodIn the case of you were sharing the stuff around the :or (prior conditions) and the RHS#2018-03-2819:53mikerodyou can implement a ‚Äúshort circuit ‚Äù pattern via multiple rules by making rules that are prioritized over one another#2018-03-2819:53talgiatcan you give an example?#2018-03-2819:56mikerodhere is one I made for unrelated reasons mostly https://gist.github.com/mrrodriguez/6a6f8373b25d69826b3efe154c928fac#2018-03-2819:56mikerodI can probably do a shorter one in a min#2018-03-2819:57talgiatyeah this example is in response to my colleague#2018-03-2819:57talgiatwe‚Äôre working on the same problem#2018-03-2819:58talgiatjust seems kinda hackish#2018-03-2819:58talgiatalso you need to know about the other rules#2018-03-2819:58mikerod
(r/defrule short-circuit
  [X] ;; whatever here
  =>
  (r/insert! <your fact here>
             :rule-marker/short-circuit))

(defrule fallback
  [:not [:rule-marker/short-circuit]]
  [Y]
  =>
  (r/insert! <your fact here>))
#2018-03-2819:58mikerodI see#2018-03-2819:59mikerodI don‚Äôt know that I see it as hackish. I do understand it could be brittle to more rules added#2018-03-2819:59talgiathere is what we have#2018-03-2819:59talgiat`#2018-03-2819:59talgiat(defrule premium-video [Video (= ?id id)] [:or [PremiumChannels (= id ?id)] [LessThanTwoHours (= id ?id)] [PremiumTopics (= id ?id)]] => (insert! (create-rule-result ->MarketplacePremiumVideoContent ?id (->Rule 1 ‚ÄúPremium Video‚Äù :points 6)))))#2018-03-2819:59talgiat`#2018-03-2819:59talgiatignore the create rule-result#2018-03-2819:59mikerodhowever a big short-circuiting :or would also be just order dependent on all the logic pushed into it#2018-03-2820:00mikerodanother thing you can do#2018-03-2820:00mikerodIs let the :or fire as much as it can#2018-03-2820:00mikerodthen reconcile in a separate rule to ‚Äúchoose the best‚Äù#2018-03-2820:00talgiatthere is no best per se#2018-03-2820:00talgiatthey are all equal importance#2018-03-2820:01mikerodso what is the reason to want short-circuit#2018-03-2820:01mikerodDo you just not want multiple facts inserted?#2018-03-2820:01talgiat`#2018-03-2820:01talgiat
(defrule premium-video
  [Video (= ?id id)]
  [:not [MarketplacePremiumVideoContent (= id ?id)]]
  [:or
    [PremiumChannels (= id ?id)]
    [LessThanTwoHours (= id ?id)]
    [PremiumTopics (= id ?id)]]
  =>
  (insert! (create-rule-result ->MarketplacePremiumVideoContent ?id (->Rule 1 "Premium Video" :points 6)))))
#2018-03-2820:01talgiatI tried this#2018-03-2820:01talgiatbut it went to an infinite loop#2018-03-2820:01talgiatnot sure why#2018-03-2820:01talgiatyeah I just want one fact to be inserted#2018-03-2820:02mikerod
(r/defrule rule-with-or
  [:or
   [A]
   [B]
   [C]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->FoundIt)))

(r/defrule aggregate-found
  [?found <- (acc/all) :from [FoundIt]]
 [:test (seq ?found)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (do-aggregation ?found)))
#2018-03-2820:02mikerodInsert a middle-fact#2018-03-2820:02mikerodthat you aggregate to a single fact#2018-03-2820:02mikerodfor ‚Äúdownstream‚Äù rules to only see 1 fact#2018-03-2820:02mikerodthis can be either a merge or just pick one if they are all the same, etc#2018-03-2820:03mikerod
(r/defrule aggregate-found
  [?found <- (acc/all) :from [FoundIt]]
 [:test (seq ?found)]
  =>
;; They are all the same, so I dont' care
  (r/insert! (first ?found)))
#2018-03-2820:03mikerodI should add a non-empty check to just avoid useless fires#2018-03-2820:05mikerod> but it went to an infinite loop I believe your rule is invalidating itself#2018-03-2820:05mikerodlogically#2018-03-2820:05mikerodhowever, I don‚Äôt know for sure not knowing what create-rule-result does#2018-03-2820:05talgiatit just creates a record and adds some other metadata to it#2018-03-2820:05mikerodif somehow the RHS (or later rule) leads to a MarketplacePremiumVideoContent to be inserted with that ?id then you‚Äôd get a loop#2018-03-2820:06mikerodbecause it‚Äôd get inserted, which would make the :not become false#2018-03-2820:06mikerodso it‚Äôd be retracted#2018-03-2820:06mikerodbut then :not would be true again, so it‚Äôd get reinserted, but then :not would be false again, so it‚Äôd be retracted - and repeat#2018-03-2820:06talgiatI see#2018-03-2820:06talgiatyeah, a bit of a mind bender#2018-03-2820:06talgiatüôÇ#2018-03-2820:06mikerodit‚Äôs best to try to think of the rules as declarative and order-independent#2018-03-2820:07mikerodwhere possible#2018-03-2820:07talgiatat least for people who are not used to rule engines or logic programming#2018-03-2820:07mikerodand their job is to bring working memory into a steady and logically consistent state with all of the LHS of all rules#2018-03-2820:07mikerodIt can be a trick sometimes#2018-03-2820:08talgiatthe multiple inserts don‚Äôt impact our end results correctness#2018-03-2820:08talgiatI just noticed it when testing and didn‚Äôt understand why#2018-03-2820:08talgiatbut thanks so much for the clarification#2018-03-2820:09mikerodyeah, I find the ‚Äúaggregating‚Äù to one idea common#2018-03-2820:09mikerodI think the main takeaway is that the rules don‚Äôt short-circuit or control ‚Äúduplcates‚Äù for you#2018-03-2820:09mikerodit lets you decide what makes sense there#2018-03-2820:10mikerodI‚Äôd say though, don‚Äôt be afraid to introduce ‚Äúintermediate facts‚Äù#2018-03-2820:10mikerodto tie multiple rules together#2018-03-2820:10talgiatYeah that makes sense#2018-03-2820:11mikerodSo rule-with-multiple-duplicate-inserts-possible and aggregate-the-duplicates rules with an intermediate/ephemeral fact between the two#2018-03-2820:11mikerodthen most other ‚Äúdownstream‚Äù rules just take the aggregated selection fact#2018-03-2820:11mikerodLater on, there may be more complex reasoning in the aggregate-the-duplicates than just ‚Äútake one‚Äù#2018-03-2820:12talgiatyeah in our case it really doesn‚Äôt matter#2018-03-2820:12mikerodif for example, they are no longer complete duplicates, or perhaps you want to count how many times it was ‚Äútrue‚Äù by counting the duplicates#2018-03-2820:12mikerodsure#2018-03-2820:12talgiatbut I see the point#2018-03-2820:12mikerodIt‚Äôs been discussed before to have a working-memory-as-a-set sort of Clara mode#2018-03-2820:12talgiatI just think it‚Äôll helpful to have a real or#2018-03-2820:12talgiatinstead of doing the heavy lifting yourself#2018-03-2820:13talgiatlike a purposeful or#2018-03-2820:13mikerodwhere there were never duplicates inserted, etc. Drools does that by default with logical insert (managed by truth maintenance). However, it does have a performance cost to manage a set for working memory (frequent hash code calculations etc) and also, it isn‚Äôt always what people want#2018-03-2820:13mikerodsometimes ‚Äúcardinality‚Äù of duplicate facts inserted can matter to the rule logic#2018-03-2820:13talgiattrue it can#2018-03-2820:14mikerodSomething like a ‚Äúshort circuit‚Äù or could be done#2018-03-2820:14talgiatbut can‚Äôt I control which behavior I want#2018-03-2820:14mikerodEasiest would be to just have it generate several rules#2018-03-2820:14mikerodthat all do the ‚Äútiered‚Äù blocking pattern one one another#2018-03-2820:14mikerodjust generically#2018-03-2820:15mikerodalso, there is nothing stopping you from making a higher-level macro that did the short-circuit rule generation pattern to normal Clara rules#2018-03-2820:16mikerodIf you were sufficiently motivated and had enough places you foudn it useful hah#2018-03-2820:28talgiatYeah, can do a macro#2018-03-2820:35wparkerAgreed on all @mikerod‚Äôs comments - I just wanted to mention that you don‚Äôt necessarily have to use a macro generating ‚Äúdefrule‚Äù calls, Clara can take rules as data structures if you prefer to go that way (easier in clj than cljs though)#2018-03-2820:37wparkerIt seems the infinite looping behavior has tripped a lot of people up - we should probably add a page to the http://clara-rules.org site on that somewhere. I‚Äôve also logged an issue before to fail in that scenario analogously to StackOverflowException, just haven‚Äôt ever gotten around to it#2018-04-0303:26alex-dixonMay have seen this. Was the proposal for a max number of iterations per rule?#2018-03-2820:39wparkerMy personal mental model of rules is (I think similar to his) that when using truth maintenance they are like statements that ‚Äúfor each join of things in these sets, these other things must exist‚Äù. Declarative logic, like SQL or even Excel#2018-04-0221:51Geoffrey GaillardI have some business processes that end up reading/saving data from and to a relational database. Some of my logic is pure, and some of it need this shared mutable state. Is there an idiomatic or clean way to handle side effects in clara ? It would be great if I could, for example, rollback a transaction in my database when the fact that caused the corresponding side effect is retracted ‚Ä¶ don't know if it's a sane way to tackle the problem thought‚Ä¶#2018-04-0302:38mikerod@ggaillard when you perform the side-effect, you can insert a fact that indicates that the side effect was performed#2018-04-0302:38mikerodyou can then have a rule that uses that to ‚Äúretract‚Äù the side effects#2018-04-0302:39mikerodyou likely need to make these effects ‚Äúidempotent‚Äù so they can be replaced multiple times without causing issues#2018-04-0302:42mikerodmaybe something like 
(r/defrule do-thing
  [A (= v :something) (= ?id id)]
  =>
  (do-side-effect ?a)
  (r/insert! (->DidSideEffectFor ?id)))

(r/defrule undo-thing
  [?effect-data <- DidSideEffectFor (= ?id id)]
  [:not [A (= ?id id)]]
  =>
  (retract-side-effect ?effect-data))
Assumes you have a way to link facts up, like an ID. This doesn‚Äôt attempt to remove the DidSideEffectFor facts. So if this is a long running process, this may start to add up as too much data in memory#2018-04-0302:42mikerodIf that‚Äôs the case, you may just want to handle the side-effects externally and clean up the DidSideEffectFor as well#2018-04-0302:47mikerodMy post on ways to update facts may be somewhat related to, if you are interested http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2018-04-0309:26Geoffrey GaillardAwesome answer! Thank you!#2018-04-0419:19wparkerClara-rules 0.18.0 is released. The release includes performance optimizations, a bugfix in error handling code, and new APIs targeted at ClojureScript library/platform developers consuming Clara. The release adds a new listening method that anyone creating a custom listener will need to implement, but the implementation can just be an empty body so it is an easy uplift. Additionally, the :rule-matches key in session inspection will now only have rules that led to logical insertions, with a new :unfiltered-rule-matches key now optionally available with a superset of the data previously in the :rule-matches. For a discussion of the rationale behind this change see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/386#2018-04-0520:54sparkofreasonFellow clarians (?): linked is a draft of an article of describing some of the fun I've been having using clara for UX. Any feedback greatly appreciated. https://sparkofreason.gitbooks.io/maali/content/#2018-04-0522:24sparkofreasonPlease DM or comment in the git book unless the topic is of broader relevance to clara.#2018-04-0920:19whilohi#2018-04-0920:20whiloi have just stumbled over factui and finally realized that clara is like reactive dataflow base programming#2018-04-0920:20whilohttps://github.com/frankmcsherry/differential-dataflow#2018-04-0920:20whiloi am working on datahike: https://github.com/replikativ/datahike and am wondering how i would stream datoms properly into clients with factui#2018-04-0922:27whiloone idea would be to make clara's memory durable and do a joint database#2018-04-0922:41whiloso a simple approach would realize the web after tomorrow scenario of @tonsky http://tonsky.me/blog/the-web-after-tomorrow/#2018-04-0922:43whiloon a next step one can introduce CRDTs for intermediary result sets. this would allow local and offline edits in p2p fashion, which can occur with a parallel addition of the fact to the main central database that will acknowledge the intermediary result set#2018-04-0922:47whilothe latter is necessary for the facts to be joinable in a synchronized fashion with other parts of the system. that would yield a very good tradeoff for data driven application development in my opinion#2018-04-0922:49whiloi can provide a durable sorted-map with the hitchhiker tree as a fast and transparent building blog: https://github.com/datacrypt-project/hitchhiker-tree#2018-04-0922:49whilooperations can be done in memory and flushed at distinct points in time#2018-04-0922:51whilojust to be clear the hitchhiker-tree is not from me, but david greenberg, but i have ported it to clojurescript with core.async and have used it to make datascript durable in datahike#2018-04-0922:54whiloi guess i would have to implement IPersistentMemory, IMemoryReader and ITransientMemory for durability, right?#2018-04-0922:54whiloi am not sure whether this makes sense in your opinion, would be nice to chat a bit about how do it right#2018-04-1018:57mikerod@whilo I‚Äôm not completely up-to-speed on all of the various references you posted here. I can at least (for now) add a bit of light on the ‚Äúdurability‚Äù side of things. Clara does currently have some (fairly raw) support for session and working memory durability. More on that can be read about first @ http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/durability/#2018-04-1018:57mikerodMuch of the working memory side of the durability implementation is up to your particular use-case#2018-04-1018:58mikerodClara does provide a Fressian backed impl of durability for the Clara infrastructure part of the rule sessions themselves#2018-04-1018:58mikerodit offloads all facts in working memory to a separate protocol, that the consumer would implement to effectively serialize their facts.#2018-04-1018:59mikerodSince I‚Äôm not familiar with each of the points you mention above though, this may or may not suit the goals you have#2018-04-1018:59mikerodI need to read a bit deeper into some of your links to have anything else to say on the subject I think#2018-04-1019:01mikerodIt seems to me that you may be interested in a way to store facts in a way that are out-of-memory, perhaps because the set of facts will grow to potentially too many to fit all in memory at once.#2018-04-1019:02mikerodIn that case, the durability alone won‚Äôt be enough. I think you‚Äôd then have to do a custom implementation of the memory layer of Clara, as you‚Äôve mentioned. In Clara‚Äôs early days, Ryan Brush (the creator of Clara) had a demo project that prototyped how Clara‚Äôs working memory could be realized over a distribution cluster using Apache Storm#2018-04-1019:03mikerodhttps://github.com/rbrush/clara-storm This isn‚Äôt maintained and very likely doesn‚Äôt work now. However, perhaps it is inspiration or at least related to some of your ideas you‚Äôve mentioned above.#2018-04-1221:05whilo@mikerod ok thanks üôÇ#2018-04-1221:07whiloactually i would like to have a datahike database somewhere central, stream data out of it in some places that pre-computes datalog queries for clients and writes them to CRDTs which are then replicated. the client can then use these replicated CRDTs to render its views and write to them offline in many cases while sending to the server as well. anyway, i will think it through a bit more and get more familiar with clara.#2018-05-0715:53jimbobHas anyone explored the area of exploration for why rules left-hand-side did not meet the rules prerequisites for firing of the RHS?#2018-05-0716:05mikerod@ben.borders In a way yes. That is, if I understand your question.#2018-05-0716:06mikerodNot directly that though, instead you could consider a pattern to create complementary rules to the primary rules. These complementary rules were meant to catch the opposite case of the assertions.#2018-05-0716:09jimbobyes, thats exactly it.#2018-05-0716:11jimbobInteresting.. im assuming then there are multiple complements to each core ‚Äúrule‚Äù. maybe the # of complements = the number of left hand constrints or something similar? unless your compllement rule that is generated has more complex logic#2018-05-0716:11mikerodI think the structure of generated rules may depend on which sorts of things you need to capture#2018-05-0716:12mikerodYou could end up writing rules in an alternative fixed format that can generated several ‚Äútiers‚Äù of rules from it. so there was the typically rule where you tried to match, but then there were tiers of unsatisfied matches where different parts of the rule were successively removed#2018-05-0716:15jimbobah interesting, so you made the rules very granular so that the complements might be easier to generate?#2018-05-0716:15jimbobwell.. the main rule you cared about at least.#2018-05-0716:17mikerodIn that example, you can see it‚Äôd get carried away if you tried to capture everything perhaps#2018-05-0716:18mikerodbut maybe you could split the ‚Äúconstraints‚Äù you want to test for into logical ‚Äúchunks‚Äù#2018-05-0716:18mikerodAnd when it comes to joining to other facts, you can do somewhat similar things#2018-05-0716:19mikerodbut you have to capture the case that facts you are joining to may not be satisfied themselves#2018-05-0716:22mikerodSo you have to basically just come up with a way to structure these aspects you care about, then probably write something to generate the rules via some extra metadata markup on what is hand-written#2018-05-0716:23mikerodI don‚Äôt think it is a trivial problem to solve and is going to end up being domain dependent. I think that this may also bring up another interesting question though regarding perhaps comparing the forward-chaining (as used in Clara) vs a backwards chaining approach to the problem#2018-05-0716:27jimbobdefinitely! Thanks Mike this helps a lot!#2018-05-0716:27jimbob@alex.furmanov#2018-05-0716:28mikerodNo problem#2018-05-0916:26wparker@ben.borders the :condition-matches in session inspection might be of interest as well: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.18.0/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/inspect.cljc#L183#2018-05-0916:28jimbobgreat point!#2018-05-0916:31wparkerSo that should be the matches on constraints that don‚Äôt depend on joins - if you do [Fact (and (= field 1) (< field2 ?binding-from-ancestor))] you‚Äôre forcing those constraints together in Clara‚Äôs view, where [Fact (= field 1) (< field2 ?binding-from-ancestor)] keeps them separate#2018-05-0916:31wparkerThe latter is also better for perf reasons, Clara can optimize it more#2018-05-0916:32wparkerAlso note that :condition-matches doesn‚Äôt work for accumulator conditions yet: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/293#2018-05-1223:03devnAnyone here familiar with any work or have ideas on taking a medium to large rulebase, and then teasing out the underlying order?#2018-05-1223:04devnBy, for instance, running a bunch of examples through, and capturing logical "groupings" of rule firings? By namespace, for instance.#2018-05-1322:22wparker@devn Would the fact-graph functionality help? https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/fact_graph.cljc I know I never got around to building graphical tools on top of it and frankly probably won‚Äôt at this point, but even in a REPL or with text-based visualization maybe it could be useful. The main ways you‚Äôd get at that sort of info would be session inspection (which the fact graph functionality uses internally) or listeners such as tracing - since the resulting data is just Clojure data you could process it as appropriate to make it more easily understood in your use case. To be honest though, my first thought is that if you need to go from the actual rule firing patterns backwards to the logical order, something is probably suboptimal about the organization of the codebase in question. Code organization is a tricky thing to get right and IMO highly domain-dependent but FWIW the rulebases I‚Äôve worked with tended to either be DAGs or have broad groupings of rules that could be sketched out with their relationships to each other on a single piece of paper (with each of those groupings potentially containing other groupings and so forth)#2018-05-1322:25alex-dixonMaybe attach a listener and accumulate rule names#2018-05-1406:18devn@wparker for large-ish rule sets, visualization is an extremely tricky problem in my experience#2018-05-1406:19devnOnce it gets past 25-30 fact types and 100+ rules it‚Äôs a mess#2018-05-1406:22devnThe graph I‚Äôve produced, even with distinct edges is huge and mostly incomprehensible. #2018-05-1406:25devnImagine this scenario: you walk up to a system like this, and you know nothing about the ‚Äústeps‚Äù that exist within the maze of fact types and rules that operate over them. Assume that 99% of rules produce a fact on the RHS.#2018-05-1406:26devnWhat you want, is to try and tease out the clusters of logic.#2018-05-1406:32devnThere are so many variables that make this problem difficult to generalize.#2018-05-1406:45devnFor instance, whether people write fat or skinny rules, whether they have a few types with a lot of fields or a number of facts with variants, etc#2018-05-1423:04devn@wparker to your point though about code organization. yeah, that's really important.#2018-05-1423:07devnwe have ~28 files containing rules#2018-05-1423:08alex-dixonI‚Äôve made some devtools for Precept. There could be some reuse for Clara if there‚Äôs interest#2018-05-1423:09devn@alex-dixon interested in taking a look!#2018-05-1423:10devn@alex-dixon where should i look for that code?#2018-05-1423:10devnor is there a simple example around that i could use to see what's there?#2018-05-1423:14alex-dixonThe visual part is in a private repo I need to make public. The code that gets the data from the session is here https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/pull/113#2018-05-1423:15devncool!#2018-05-1423:15alex-dixonThe basic approach is to attach a listener and put what it gives you onto a core async channel #2018-05-1423:16devnsequential rule operation log, state history over time, etc. are all interesting to me#2018-05-1423:17devn@alex-dixon this is exciting. thanks for your work.#2018-05-1423:19alex-dixonThanks üòä. Thanks. I‚Äôm curious about your use case. Not sure how to approach the same with Clara when sessions can be used a lot differently than with ui#2018-05-1423:34devn@alex-dixon one obvious one would be for development/debugging. i want to scrub through what is matching and where.#2018-05-1423:37devnit might also be helpful for finding any nasty cases where we walk down a big branch of logic only to undo all of it due to truth maintenance. perhaps we missed a constraint.#2018-05-1712:01dominicmI'm trying to figure out Clara with tuples, partially as I've been brainwashed by Datomic, and partially because I think I like the independence. Clara lets you configure the sort of facts it can work with if you want to do something like tuples. Some of this is explained in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ #2018-05-1712:39mikerodIf precept is using tuples already, could look there for example too. #2018-05-1712:41dominicmI did the type customisation for a tuple, it's working out okay, however my rules are full of a lot of destructuring sugar: 
(defrule app-asg-min-size
  [:box/type [[e a v]] (= v :server) (= ?app e)]
  [?tup <- :min-size [[e a v]] (= e ?app)]
  =>
  (let [[e a v] ?tup]
    (insert!
      [(str e "-asg") :min-size v])))
#2018-05-1712:42dominicmprecept does seem to have something to allow queries like this one: 
(rule todo-is-visible
  [[_ :visibility-filter :active]]
  [[?e :todo/done false]]
  =>
  (println "The todo with this entity id is visible: " ?e)

I believe the protocol method signature there changes in 0.18.0 so that‚Äôs probably it without looking at the code at the moment. It should be an easy uplift though since the new info passed was a superset of the previous (i.e. arguments were added not removed). Then you‚Äôd get more concise Clara syntax at least#2018-05-1714:12alex-dixon@dominicm Hey. I‚Äôd like the devtools I‚Äôve been working on to be compatible with Clara, but I‚Äôm somewhat uncomfortable with thinking of that being part of the core, so I was wondering about the group‚Äôs thoughts on revitalizing something like clara.tools to house things like that#2018-05-1714:27mikerod@alex-dixon to me it made sense to have it be a separate library like the clara.tools concept#2018-05-1714:28alex-dixonNow that dominic brings it up, I‚Äôm also curious whether Clara would be interested in a Datalog syntax implementation. And yes‚Ä¶I might have asked this a year ago but there‚Äôs reasons I didn‚Äôt. Namely I didn‚Äôt know Clojure at the time, hadn‚Äôt really contributed at all to open source, and like now I‚Äôm sort of intimidated by Clara‚Äôs codebase and not that confident in my ability to work efficiently in it#2018-05-1714:28dominicm@alex-dixon no idea, I just picked latest and started there.#2018-05-1714:28dominicmDatomic syntax for clara in an isolated library would be nice, from a total beginner's pov.#2018-05-1714:29mikerod@alex-dixon It doesn‚Äôt have to be in that same repo though really unless you had particular reasoning for that. I haven‚Äôt had a chance to look at the devtools stuff that was discussed here the other day. It sounded interesting though#2018-05-1714:33mikerod> Datomic syntax for clara in an isolated library would be nice, from a total beginner‚Äôs pov. I agree that that sounds cool#2018-05-1714:33mikerodProbably would be applicable to people in the clj-ecosystem looking into Clara too if that was the sort of data models they were already using. Interesting if Precept already has that layer implemented#2018-05-1714:35alex-dixonThe devtools were conceived in isolation, so before I‚Äôd work on porting some of it to Clara I‚Äôd really want to know what would be useful for people. As it stands, you can view the history of a rule, history of a fact, ‚Äúevent log‚Äù (all inserts and retractions in order), see explanations for all of those (the rule conditions that were defined, the facts they matched on, the bindings of the variables, what was inserted or retracted), whether something was inserted or removed unconditionally, logically, or the result of schema enforcement, if it was schema enforcement which existing fact triggered the schema enforcement and the relevant schema rule, added and removed facts for a particular rule firing (i.e. diff), and the total set of facts that exist in the session at the end of any rule firing#2018-05-1714:36alex-dixonIt‚Äôs implemented as a client and server‚Ä¶the client for visualization, the server for receiving messages from the inspected session/app over socket#2018-05-1714:46mikerod@alex-dixon sounds really useful. You should make it public in a github repo or something for people to try out üôÇ#2018-05-1714:58alex-dixonYeah haha‚Ä¶I definitely will, I‚Äôve been dragging my feet because I‚Äôm not completely happy with it#2018-05-1715:34mikerodcall it alpha üòõ#2018-05-1716:07dominicmI have been using the fact graph for fact history, it's been a pretty cool demo. I wired it up to rhizome pretty easily, and was able to see that X created asg Y, and asg Y has property Z because of Rule A#2018-05-1716:20zyloxim certainly interested as well. i agree with @mikerod, just mark it alpha. works for spec right üòõ#2018-05-1716:22dominicmthe alpha stuff works very well, as long as your namespaces are .alpha too#2018-05-1716:35alex-dixonI‚Äôll try to publish it this weekend, maybe just mentioning it here will make that easier üôÇ#2018-05-1716:35alex-dixonThanks for the encouragement and feedback#2018-05-1807:47dominicmhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/ Is it possible to set a fact type in such a way that this isn't needed?#2018-05-1810:13wparker@dominicm Could you give a minimal failing example? That doesn‚Äôt sound like something that should happen but we might be thinking about different things.#2018-05-1807:52dominicmThat might not be my problem actually. But when my type-fn is :a I get an error about alpha nodes if I try and refer to e.#2018-05-1813:11mikerod@dominicm I don‚Äôt see any context in your question. Did you post an example? You said where ‚Äúthis isn‚Äôt needed‚Äù, what were you referring to? #2018-05-1813:14mikerodFYI I posted an example snippet overriding the fact type for something like tuples above. Well I put them in maps for key access by name. #2018-05-1813:16mikerodYou can‚Äôt refer to bare symbols that ‚Äúrepresent‚Äù lookup keys in a rule condition if you are asking that though with regard to ‚Äúreferring to e. Clara currently only offers special syntactic access directly to record or ‚ÄúJava bean‚Äù field/accessors. If you are using generic types it doesn‚Äôt attempt to resolve like the symbol e to (:e this) This may be what you‚Äôre asking#2018-05-1813:17mikerodIt‚Äôd actually be interesting to explore making Clara offer that sort of syntax though on more generic data. #2018-05-1814:02dominicmSorry. I got distracted when I got in and forgot to post it. On phone again, once I'm at the keyboard I will do it.#2018-05-1814:57sveriHi, can someone point me to some literature on how to write my own rules engine? I have trouble finding usefull stuff.#2018-05-1815:00zyloxclara is heavily based on this paper if you really want to write your own "engine" http://reports-archive.adm.cs.cmu.edu/anon/1995/CMU-CS-95-113.pdf#2018-05-1815:01sveriI am just curious, thank you @zylox#2018-05-1815:01mikerodCaveat: that paper is really old. There are many modern day rete extensions that Clara uses too. The paper is really good at explaining the foundations of rete though. #2018-05-1815:01zyloxalso just about any info you can get on rete will be intersting#2018-05-1815:02mikerodThe Drools/Jboss people also had some good blogs out there regarding rete. #2018-05-1815:03mikerodThen there is also this great blog about Clara/rete here http://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html (I wrote it üòõ ) #2018-05-1815:05sveri@mikerod thank to you too#2018-05-1815:07dominicm
(ns roll-alt
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]
    [clara.tools.fact-graph :as fg]
    [clara.rules.accumulators :as accum]
    [rhizome.viz :as rhizome]))

(defrecord D [e a v])

(defrule todos-done-invisible
  ;; [:todo/title (= ?e e)]
  [:todo/done (= (:v this) false) (= ?e (:e this))]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->D ?e :todo/visible true)))

(comment
  (-> (mk-session
        :fact-type-fn :a
        :ancestors-fn (constantly [:all]))
      (insert
        (->D "foo" :todo/title "FOO!")
        (->D "foo" :todo/title "FOOBAR!")
        (->D "foo" :todo/done true)
        (->D "blah" :todo/done false))
      (fire-rules)
      (query visible-datoms)))
@mikerod the first line in the defrule doesn't work.#2018-05-1815:16mikerod@dominicm that seems related to the explanation I at least attempted to give above about when you can refer to ‚Äúfield name‚Äù symbols directly in a rule#2018-05-1815:16mikerodClara compiler cannot statically/compile time know what those symbols mean since the rule condition has a custom type that can‚Äôt be introspected#2018-05-1815:17mikerodIt‚Äôd be interesting if Clara added support for you to explicitly state ‚Äúfields‚Äù that go with custom fact types. But nothing like that right now. You‚Äôd have to do (:e this) instead of e or use destructuring as you have in the past#2018-05-1815:20mikerodWhen rules have records or other types of classes directly in the rule condition Clara compiler will reflect on the class to determine its available field names. When it can do that, you can refer to field names directly as their name symbol. #2018-05-1815:29dominicm> Clara compiler cannot statically/compile time know what those symbols mean since the rule condition has a custom type that can‚Äôt be introspected That explains it to me, that's entirely what I was missing. It obviously worked when I wrote the form this way: 
(defrule todos-done-invisible
  [?d <- D (= a :todo/title)]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->D (:e ?d) :todo/visible true)))
Which has a trade-off.#2018-05-1815:30dominicmI was a bit confused because it was still a record, ergo it should work (in my head).#2018-05-1815:30dominicmI looked for something to provide a custom keys function, and when I didn't find it, I presumed I was missing something.#2018-05-1815:45mikerod@dominicm It‚Äôd be interesting to have a fn that takes your custom ‚Äútype‚Äù and returns a set of ‚Äúfield keys‚Äù#2018-05-1815:45mikerodand that‚Äôd be caleld when the compiler was compiling rules and then it‚Äôd allow for the shorter accessors#2018-05-1815:45mikerodYeah, Clara just has built-in special casing to class types since they have reflection utilities available to find out how to resolve those symbols#2018-05-1815:46mikerodI‚Äôll add that you probably don‚Äôt want to write all your rules against a single type like D, so that isn‚Äôt a pattern I‚Äôd advocate#2018-05-1815:46mikerodIt‚Äôd lead to a lot of thrash in the rules since every insert/retract would potentially affect every rule#2018-05-1815:46mikerodThe fact type serves as, what I‚Äôd call, the first level of discrimination/partitioning in the network.#2018-05-1816:14dominicmMy data set isn't particularly large I think. I'm struggling to come up with good fact types for my domain. But that's likely a thing on my side.#2018-05-1816:35dominicmThe problem I have is that I'm operating in a large domain, and I'm asserting facts on a per-key level, instead of whole entities.#2018-05-1816:36dominicmI suppose I could generate something like S3BucketFact which takes an id, key and value. They are just what the rules refer to to match things, join things, and check other constraints. All of this is probably too vague though. I don‚Äôt have a good enough understand of what your data might be looking like and the sorts of things you want to do with it.#2018-05-1818:45mikerodThis now does make me wonder what sort of ‚Äúfact type‚Äùs are used in #precept#2018-05-1823:01alex-dixonWe use fact type fn :a https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept/blob/712868374f7339910e1c90596ec41c26283693d7/src/clj/precept/macros.clj#L48#2018-05-1818:52dominicmI've been thinking the same, and also how certain problems of querying are solved, particularly around duplicate entities, potentially. (defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?dbi <- AWSDBInstance]
  [?dbox <- DatabaseBox]
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (insert!
    (->AWSDBInstanceEngine ?dbi ?v)))
This inserts 2 AWSDBInstanceEngine rules, I think I understand why, it's due to how the dataset is being queried. Do rule engines / Does clara provide anything around stopping the insertion of facts twice here? I'm quite happy to "defend" on the LHS, rather than attempt to deduplicate on the RHS. I'm somewhat trying to avoid having to figure out conflict resolution in my final state.#2018-05-1921:17mikerod@dominicm I haven‚Äôt been able to look at anything today. I can quickly answe your last question though: Clara doesn‚Äôt try to prevent duplicates. That‚Äôs up to your logical structuring. You can often do something like an accumulate all sort of rule to ‚Äúde dupe ‚Äú or aggregate your duplicate facts and choose how to merge it. So you‚Äôd let some ‚Äúintermediate type‚Äù be duplicated but have some downstream aggregate/merged type result from them and then be used in subsequent rules#2018-05-1921:18mikerodIt‚Äôd be interesting to have a mode for Clara to prevent duplicates. However there are practical use cases for actually wanting duplicates too. So the default I feel is sane. Think something about logic that cares about cardinality of matches etc. Also removing duplicates tends to be performance overhead. #2018-05-1921:21dominicm@mikerod yeah, I actually want the many cardinality in some cases. I was hoping there might be a way to structure the rule such that there was no duplicates in the query.#2018-05-1921:24mikerodI could give good example if not on phone. Hah#2018-05-1921:24alex-dixon
(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?dbi <- AWSDBInstance]
  [?dbox <- DatabaseBox]
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
[:not AWSDBInstanceEngine ?dbi ?v]
Maybe something like this? Sry on phone also #2018-05-1921:24mikerodI tend to just let the rules insert duplicates. But make it a intermediate fact type. Then have a single rule that aggregates it. #2018-05-1921:25mikerodThere are negation patterns too. Like @alex-dixon just said. You just have to watch out for making a logical infinite loop#2018-05-1921:28mikerod
Defrule example

Lhs Logic

=>

Insert IntermediateThing data from rule

Defrule aggregate-dups 

?all <- acc/all :from IntermediateThing (= ?id is)

=>

Insert RealThing (merge-somehow ?all)
#2018-05-1921:29mikerodPseudo code#2018-05-1921:36dominicmAppreciate the help here. I'll take a shot at this tomorrow#2018-05-1921:38alex-dixonNb I think my example above would loop with insert logical, not if you were to use insert unconditional #2018-05-1922:09dominicmI'm worried about unconditional insert, because I don't want ordering to become a problem. The intermediate facts also feel "icky", I think because they expose a part of the LHS which isn't able to match the user's view of the world. It feels more incidental, and less domain.#2018-05-1922:41mikerodI like to be able to avoid unconditional inserts. But there are reasons where it can‚Äôt be easily avoided currently. Those are mostly around expressing removing old facts etc. I typically don‚Äôt use it though. #2018-05-1922:41mikerodI don‚Äôt see intermediate facts as a bad thing. I think it is really common. #2018-05-1922:41mikerodOften have to express intermediate concepts to connect rules for more complex logical conditions. At least in my experience with the rules I‚Äôve needed to write. #2018-05-2008:40dominicmI seem to have identified a big misunderstanding on my part: 
(ns bugB
  (:require
    [clara.rules :refer :all]))

(defrecord DatabaseBox [id])
(defrecord AWSDBInstance [id])

(defrecord DatabaseBoxEngine [e v])
(defrecord AWSDBInstanceEngine [e v])
(defrecord RollCreatedFor [e v])

(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi) (= v ?dbox)]
  [DatabaseBoxEngine (= e ?dbox) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (println ?dbi ?dbox ?v))

(comment
  (clear-ns-productions!)
  (let [foo (->DatabaseBox "foo")
        foo-db (->AWSDBInstance "foo")
        foo-db-backup (->AWSDBInstance "foo-backup")]
    (-> (mk-session)
        (insert
          foo
          (->DatabaseBoxEngine foo :postgres)
          foo-db
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db foo)
          foo-db-backup
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db-backup foo-db)
          (->RollCreatedFor foo-db-backup foo))
        (fire-rules))))
I cannot understand why this prints #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres (among the 2 other results, I expect of AWSDBInstace with a DatabaseBox). I particularly don't understand how it finds a DatabaseBoxEngine where e is an AWSDBInstance?#2018-05-2008:41dominicmThe total output:

#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id foo} :postgres
#bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo-backup} #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id foo} :postgres
#2018-05-2017:32alex-dixonLooks like the only a database box engine has an e of foo record and if that‚Äôs your only rule there‚Äôs no way it should match on two different fact types when the fact type function is type#2018-05-2017:54dominicm@alex-dixon sorry, I'm struggling to understand.
