(defrule DatabaseBox-Engine
  [?a <- RollCreatedFor (= e ?dbi) (= v ?dbox)]
  [?b <- DatabaseBoxEngine (= ?dbox e) (= ?v v)]
  =>
  (prn ?a ?b))

=>

; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}, :v #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo-backup"}, :v #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
; #bugB.RollCreatedFor{:e #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo-backup"}, :v #bugB.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}} #bugB.DatabaseBoxEngine{:e #bugB.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}, :v :postgres}
#2018-05-2018:21alex-dixonOk so the fact types are right I was mistaken on that#2018-05-2018:52dominicmI suppose that in [?b <- DatabaseBoxEngine (= ?dbox e) (= ?v v)] The (= ?dbox e) is being ignored.#2018-05-2022:11thegeez
(= (->DatabaseBox "foo")
     (->AWSDBInstance "foo")) ;; => false
  (.equals (->DatabaseBox "foo")
           (->AWSDBInstance "foo")) ;; => true
So there is probably some confusion in some of the java collections used within clara#2018-05-2023:06thegeez@dominicm the problem is here: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/platform.cljc#L11 Replace the group-by-seq with 
(seq (group-by f coll))
and it works properly again#2018-05-2023:07thegeez
(platform/group-by-seq vector
                         [(->DatabaseBox "foo")
                          (->AWSDBInstance "foo")])
  ;; =>   [[[#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"} #clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}]]]

  (defn group-by-seq [f coll]
    (seq (group-by f coll)))
  (group-by-seq vector
                [(->DatabaseBox "foo")
                 (->AWSDBInstance "foo")])
  ;; => ([[#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.DatabaseBox{:id "foo"}]] [[#clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}] [#clara_bug.core.AWSDBInstance{:id "foo"}]])
#2018-05-2105:29dominicmThat equality is crazy! Thanks!#2018-05-2105:39dominicmhttps://dev.clojure.org/jira/browse/CLJ-867#2018-05-2105:59dominicmhttp://clojuredocs.org/clojure.core/defrecord > and will defined Java .hashCode and .equals consistent with the contract for java.util.Map. Looks like this is intentional#2018-05-2107:56dominicm
(definterface Foo
  (getB []))

(deftype C [a]
  Foo
  (getB [this] a))

(deftype B [a]
  Foo
  (getB [this] a))
Onto java beans I go!#2018-05-2110:52mikerodClara just uses clojure =. Not sure the issue above? Clojure = takes type into consideration with records. #2018-05-2110:54dominicm@mikerod The code that @thegeez referred to uses a java.util.HashMap, which uses java's notion of equality.#2018-05-2110:58dominicmFortunately for me, I am in an intersection of 2 points: 1) My data is all the same keys 2) I use macros for generating my types So I've been able to switch to beans with deftype rather trivially, and that's resolved everything.#2018-05-2111:52mikerod@dominicm that‚Äôs interesting. I don‚Äôt know how you were encountering the use of platform/group-by-seq though. It does sound to me like there could be potential edge cases around platform/group-by-seq though on the jvm-impl since it does make use of Java collections to (a) preserve consistent order (b) do the grouping and order preservation efficiently.#2018-05-2112:02thegeez@mikerod if the promise is that clojure = is used, than @dominicm‚Äôs example shows a bug#2018-05-2112:05thegeez
(defrecord ClauseOne [b])
(defrecord ClauseTwo [b])

(defrule rule-one
  [ClauseOne (= ?b b)]
  [ClauseTwo (= ?b b)]
 =>
  (println "Match found:" ?b )
  )

(defrecord WrapAlice [num])
(defrecord WrapBob [num])

(comment
  (clear-ns-productions!)
  (let [alice (->WrapAlice 1)
        bob (->WrapBob 1)]
    (println "(= alice bob)" (= alice bob))
    (println "(.equals alice bob)" (.equals alice bob))
    (-> (mk-session)
        (insert
         (->ClauseOne alice)
         ;; Line below is important, without it the wrong behavior does not surface
         (->ClauseTwo alice)
         (->ClauseTwo bob)
         )
        (fire-rules)
        ))
  ;;(= alice bob) false
  ;;(.equals alice bob) true
  ;; Match found: #clara_bug.core.WrapAlice{:num 1}
  ;; Match found: #clara_bug.core.WrapBob{:num 1} ;; <- should not happen
  )
#2018-05-2112:47mikerod@thegeez I think this actually is a bug#2018-05-2112:47mikerodI had suspicion of it being one as soon as I saw this discussion above regarding platform/group-by-seq#2018-05-2112:49mikerodplatform/group-by-seq was added on the JVM-Clara to make the operation of grouping more efficient, as well as to have deterministic ordering of the seq it returns on each run to avoid variance in rule performance. The use of Java collections for this can cause subtle problems when the bindings of fact fields are record types that are Object.equals() from Java, but not clojure.core/=. This is the case with Clj record since their Java-interop form uses Java map equality instead of incorporating the type.#2018-05-2112:55thegeez@mikerod this might be of use: https://github.com/ztellman/bizarro-collections to get a speedy group-by-seq with the semantics of clojure =#2018-05-2112:55mikerodI believe the issue is fairly isolated to the platform/group-by-seq. I think the solution would be to stop using a Java-based equality hashmap impl. A clj based one would be needed instead. It may be slightly tricky to do to keep similar performance characteristics. (it‚Äôs a hot spot in the rule engine).#2018-05-2112:56mikerod@thegeez maybe, but we need a ‚Äúlinked hash map‚Äù#2018-05-2112:56mikerodthe deterministic ‚Äúorder preservation‚Äù is an important characteristic#2018-05-2112:57mikerodI believe the bizarro only has hash map (unordered)#2018-05-2112:58mikeroda java.util.LinkedHashMap is used to do the grouping by operations, then it is seq‚Äôed in platform/group-by-seq. The order the seq comes out, we want to be the same given the same input, independently from one process/machine to another (really, the Java runtime execution)#2018-05-2112:59mikerodIf we didn‚Äôt need the order preservation part, we could just use a clj transient map and likely not have a problem with performance#2018-05-2113:00mikerodOne solution would just be to write some sort of collection in Clara to fit this goal. That maybe the smoothest path forward.#2018-05-2113:03dominicmhttps://github.com/amalloy/ordered supports transients.#2018-05-2113:03thegeezI don't know of one of the shelve#2018-05-2113:04thegeezBut when does the case occur that the order is different between process? And when do these two different orderings meet?#2018-05-2113:19mikerod@dominicm @thegeez I logged https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/393 - fixed link#2018-05-2113:19mikerodit has quite a bit of detail on this#2018-05-2113:20mikeroddeterminism from one JVM instance to another is pretty important in some production scenarios#2018-05-2113:20mikerodplatform/group-by-seq is hit in a hot spot in the engine - it has a fairly large effect on performance#2018-05-2113:21mikerodthe order of its results can play a large role in the activity that takes place within the engines evaluation of the network facts#2018-05-2113:21mikerodIf the order changes from run to run, then the performance characteristics change too. This can make it hard to track down a bottleneck that comes up only on occasion#2018-05-2113:22mikerodAlso, different orders of evaluation could potentially even lead to things like exceptions thrown in defects in written rules. However, may only sometimes these defects would manifest themselves - aka hard to reproduce problems#2018-05-2113:22mikerodA while back, all known places within Clara‚Äôs engine evaluation and compiler were made deterministic run-over-run to alleviate these issues#2018-05-2113:27thegeezThis is quickly going beyond what I know of rules systems, which is very little. I'm only surprised to see the "order changes from run to run", I would expect the ordering to be arbitrary, but the same from run to run with the same input data#2018-05-2113:44mikerod@thegeez the ordering guarantees are arbitrary from a user-level semantics#2018-05-2113:44mikerodand the outputs are produced in a deterministic way from that level#2018-05-2113:44mikerodI‚Äôm talking on more of a low-level evaluation within the engine#2018-05-2113:44mikerodIt is basically opaque to the user-level semantics#2018-05-2113:45mikerodhowever, it has real world implications, (a) deterministic performance characteristics (b) deterministic order things actually are evaluated (mostly useful to reproduce error cases)#2018-05-2113:46mikerodThings get more involved if you consider using the truth maintenance system within Clara, ie performing a typical clara.rules/insert! on a rule right-hand side (RHS).#2018-05-2113:46mikerodThe engine works to put the system into a consistent logical state#2018-05-2113:46mikerodThe ‚Äúworks‚Äù part, is where time is spent#2018-05-2113:47mikerodThere are different orders/paths to take to reach the same consistent logical state, depending on how rules are chosen for evaluation, how facts are propagated from node to node in the internal network etc#2018-05-2113:47mikerodThe determinism I‚Äôm talking about is in being deterministic in those inner choices taken#2018-05-2113:55thegeezIf "defsomething A, defsomething B, execute" should do the same as "defsomething B, defsomething A, execute" I would expect the usage of a HashMap instead of a LinkedHashMap, with its insertion-order preserving. That part is still fuzzy in my thinking#2018-05-2114:09mikerod@thegeez I guess I‚Äôm not able to explain it correctly#2018-05-2114:09mikerodYes, they can do the same thing, however, the way they accomplish it may be different depending on the order#2018-05-2114:10mikerodhash map can arbitrarily change the order#2018-05-2114:10mikerodand it does#2018-05-2114:10mikerodFor example, we had correct rules running in a production case before. However, about 1 in 10 times, it performed about 100x worse#2018-05-2114:10mikerodthat 1 in 10 time, was when the hash map ordered 2 groups in a flipped way#2018-05-2114:11mikerodthe engine then went on to do extra work, it hit a performance bottleneck case#2018-05-2114:11mikerodit still was functionally correct, it just went down a ‚Äúbad path‚Äù performance-wise#2018-05-2114:11mikerodfixing the determinism allowed the case to be pinpointed and recreated in a consistent way, the bottleneck was then fixed#2018-05-2114:12mikerodThere are many places within the engine evaluation where the ‚Äúorder things are done‚Äù can make measurable performance differences. Even if the outcome is always the same no matter the order.#2018-05-2114:13mikerodIt is hard to explain most of these, since they are detailed things about the engine/network/fact propagation#2018-05-2114:14mikerodAlso, truth maintenance can evaluate a rule, evaluated its RHS actions, like insert!, but then later, realize that that rule isn‚Äôt satisfied anymore due to some other rule that evaluated. The engine can ‚Äúretract‚Äù the work done by the rule in that case.#2018-05-2114:14mikerodThere are cases (many) where it‚Äôd be better to never have evaluated that rule at all, it wasted time#2018-05-2114:15mikerodThe situation is really that the engine can at times ‚Äúspeculatively‚Äù evaluate a rule that is later found to be invalidated by other rules. There are ways for user-level directed rule orderings, and also there are engine-level ‚Äúheuristics‚Äù or similar that attempt to avoid premature evaluation#2018-05-2114:15mikerodSo a rule could have a RHS that says (throw (Exception.))#2018-05-2114:16mikerodThis rule may never be true after fire-rules, however, during the truth maintenance cycle, it could actually be evaluated#2018-05-2114:16mikerodSo if you have non-determinism in that cycle, you may only sometimes hit the exception side-effect#2018-05-2114:17mikerodIt doesn‚Äôt (and likely wouldn‚Äôt) be something trivial like that. It could be something less obvious like (insert! (call-my-fn-that-has-a-defect-for-some-args ?x))#2018-05-2114:17mikerodIf that rule sometimes evaluated, but needs to retract later by the truth maintenance, and this only happens 1 in 10 times, you may have a 1 in 10 times sort of scenario you are trying to recreate to debug your defect in your rules#2018-05-2114:18mikerodThis will manifest itself in cases like, our tests fail arbitrarily at times when run on our build servers, but when we rerun the build/retest the error is gone#2018-05-2114:19mikerodThe determinism of ordering used within these areas of Clara help both of these scenarios, the performance situations, and the finding failures scenarios situation#2018-05-2116:06thegeez@mikerod Thanks for the explanation#2018-05-2116:12alex-dixon@mikerod ditto that was great#2018-05-2116:12zyloxwe should probably codify that mentality somwhere because we do think of it as first class here when considering changes#2018-05-2116:12zylox(here being cerner)#2018-05-2116:13zyloxnot sure where though. When writing rules it shouldnt be a consideration or a concern to the user#2018-05-2120:00curtis.shafferengine behavior? or guiding principles perhaps?#2018-05-2120:03wparkerI think https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md is intended for that purpose in the GitHub templates, perhaps something there?#2018-05-2120:22zyloxthat makes a degree of sense to me#2018-05-2315:51jdtHello all, I've been trying a bit of clara-rules to assess it for a project. I'm having some trouble with with-tracing though.#2018-05-2315:52jdtIf I omit the with-tracing call fire-rules does its work. If I add with-tracing before it, fire-rules no longer works (none of my rules are fired).#2018-05-2315:53jdtIf I move with-tracing before (insert ...) I get lots of traces.#2018-05-2315:53jdtWhat am I doing wrong?#2018-05-2315:54jdtI'm using [com.cerner/clara-rules "0.18.0"]#2018-05-2315:54jdtand clojure 1.9#2018-05-2315:55jdtI don't want to trace the rete activity on the initial insert, just the activities of fire-rules and the working memory alterations there.#2018-05-2317:11mikerod@dave.tenny it‚Äôs an interesting point you bring up, but I don‚Äôt think it really makes sense to only ‚Äúpartially‚Äù have with-tracing enabled#2018-05-2317:12mikerodAll session interactions prior to fire-rules are susceptible to lazy evaluation and batching.#2018-05-2317:12mikerodIn general, I‚Äôd stress to not rely on any stateful information of a session that has had inserts/retracts performed on it, but no fire-rules#2018-05-2317:13jdtHeh, not sure I was trying to make a point. I didn't understand why fire-rules didn't work based on the placement of with-tracing. Since my rules weren't firing.#2018-05-2317:13mikerodI‚Äôd actually rather it be the case that the API threw an exception if you tried to query or do something like with-tracing when it was in an inconsistent/lazy/batched state prior to fire-rules#2018-05-2317:13jdtNaively (since I am naive here), I just figured my session would be upgraded to do tracing.#2018-05-2317:13mikerodIt‚Äôs an interesting point regarding the limitations of with-tracing and lazy/batched insert/retract behavior I meant#2018-05-2317:14mikerodI certainly haven‚Äôt dug into details to diagnose your specific issue, but I‚Äôd imaging the with-tracing added late, after the insert missed some listener information it needed#2018-05-2317:14jdtSo how should I be using with-tracing here?#2018-05-2317:14mikerodOnly add it when you have a session that doesn‚Äôt have insert, insert-all, or retract calls possibly still pending on it#2018-05-2317:15mikerodso either (a) right after your mk-session, or (b) right after a fire-rules#2018-05-2317:15jdtI'm doing insert! and retract! in my rule RHS's, but but the only insert was as shown, before the with-tracing call.#2018-05-2317:15mikerodbut you won‚Äôt get tracing ‚Äúonly for the fire-rules actions that took place, you‚Äôll get a complete picture, you can looking into tracing details to find out specific things, like facts inserted due to rules firing etc (at least to some degree)#2018-05-2317:18mikerod@dave.tenny you did this? 
(-> (mk-session)
	(with-tracing)
	(insert ...)
	(fire-rules))
#2018-05-2317:19jdtYes, that way I get tracing, and fire-rules works as expected.#2018-05-2317:19mikerodthat‚Äôs the way to use it#2018-05-2317:20jdtok, thanks#2018-05-2317:20mikerodSo I don‚Äôt know what your question is beyond that and beyond what I said about it being misleading in the API to let you add it at arbitrary points#2018-05-2317:20jdtI'm trying to get the network activity after the initial bulk load of facts.#2018-05-2317:20mikerodI think it‚Äôd be better to reject an attempt to add it at the ‚Äúwrong times‚Äù, enhancement#2018-05-2317:20jdtAnd when I do that, by moving the trace after the facts are loaded, my fire-rules don't work.#2018-05-2317:21mikerodyeah, it doesn‚Äôt work on that principle#2018-05-2317:21jdtok, good to know, still learning#2018-05-2317:22jdtThat begs the question of when it is safe to use it. Say I make a session, load data, run rules, query results. Then I want to change the data in the session and run it again with tracing. Will it work then? Or is it always safe to use with-tracing after fire-rules calls?#2018-05-2317:22mikerodI‚Äôm not actually sure there is a way to look at the listener information and know the different between a fact inserted externally, via insert and a fact inserted from a RHS, via insert!. I don‚Äôt know of one off hand.#2018-05-2317:23mikerod> Or is it always safe to use with-tracing after fire-rules calls? I think so and expect so. If it has issues, it‚Äôd be interesting to discuss them. Also, I don‚Äôt have any reason to think that it should ever change the semantics of the rules, you may just get bad/invalid tracing results#2018-05-2317:24mikerodEarlier you said it caused your rules to not fire correctly, I‚Äôm skeptical on that#2018-05-2317:24mikerodthe tracing may not have accurately reported the rule firings, but they probably still fired#2018-05-2317:24mikerodyou can test that assumption, by adding a defquery to your session#2018-05-2317:24jdtre: firing, my rules had printlnin them, which didn't print when the with-tracing was done after the insert.#2018-05-2317:24mikerodand then using a query on the RHS insert! facts that you think didn‚Äôt get inserted#2018-05-2317:25mikerodYeah, if you can reproduce that case at all, that‚Äôd be valuable#2018-05-2317:25jdtOkay, well it's pretty simple, I'll see what I can do.#2018-05-2317:25mikerodI don‚Äôt expect with-tracing to be able to interfere with evaluation in that way#2018-05-2317:26mikerod@dave.tenny found it#2018-05-2317:26mikerodyeah, so with-tracing does appear to wipe out pending work#2018-05-2317:27mikerodso you‚Äôre right, it‚Äôd cause trouble like you saw#2018-05-2317:27mikerodafter fire-rules should be safe - there is no pending work#2018-05-2317:28mikerodit may be a ‚Äúgood thing‚Äù that with-tracing wipes out pending work since it makes a session that it can actually trace#2018-05-2317:29mikerodwell, idk about that, it‚Äôs just a weird situation hah - either needs docs or to throw an exception or something I think üôÇ#2018-05-2317:29jdtSounds like the documentation should be a bit clearer about restrictions though to avoid noob run-ins like mine.#2018-05-2317:29mikerodYes, it is too mysterious#2018-05-2317:33jdtI'm just trying to wrap my head around other things, like the Truth Maintenance capabilities that may or may not have been present in the OPS5 systems I was using 30 years ago. I'm pretty rusty at this. Retracting the preconditions that led to the state of the RHS doing the retraction seems to mean I need to fire rules, query my reults on the session afterward, make changes, then rinse-lather-repeat, where it used to be I'd do more stuff in the RHS clauses. Thus my attempts at ... modular ... tracing.#2018-05-2317:35jdtSo a bit of catching up for me. I'm investigating clara for the job dispatch logic of a new scheduler I'm writing.#2018-05-2317:35jdtMeanwhile thanks for the help.#2018-05-2317:37mikerodsure#2018-05-2317:38mikerod@alex-dixon has done a lot with Clara‚Äôs tracing by extending it for his own purposes in the #precept library. Perhaps you can find some inspiration there.#2018-05-2317:38mikerodhttps://github.com/CoNarrative/precept#2018-05-2317:43alex-dixonI think I ended up using the listeners namespace only. I forget at the moment how it relates to clara‚Äôs tracing#2018-05-2317:44mikerod@alex-dixon oh, tracing just organizes the data coming from listeners I believe#2018-05-2317:45mikerodwait no, tracing is a default impl over listeners#2018-05-2317:45alex-dixonAh ok. That what I seem to remember but thought I may have been confusing it with explanations #2018-05-2317:45mikerod(sort of the same as I said)#2018-05-2317:45mikerodyeah, explanations/inspect are above all that#2018-05-2317:46alex-dixonYet listeners is very user friendly imho. Though I may have ran into some private things I wanted public #2018-05-2317:48alex-dixonIt is nice to have it boxed up and ready to use just at the same time the listeners ns is highly usable in and of itself I mean#2018-05-2318:08alex-dixon@dave.tenny If you end up poking around Precept at all I‚Äôd recommend the issue 19 branch#2018-05-2318:09jdtWill keep that in mind, so far have only looked at Clara-rules.#2018-05-2319:18jdt(defquery my-query ...) followed by a what is typically another function wrapping the query with a call to (query session my-query) gets old. Is there w away to do a lexical defquery equivalent at the point I'd call query?#2018-05-2319:24zyloxdefquery more or less sets up an endpoint in your rules network, it needs to be known before hand#2018-05-2319:25zyloxquery goes and grabs the list it generates at when things are fired, it doesnt go calculate it then (to my knowlege)#2018-05-2319:37zyloxyou can, and i would not reccomend this outside of development, create a defquery for Object that just grabs everything in the session and then filter that as you see fit.#2018-05-2320:35mikerod@dave.tenny I‚Äôve only partially read your example so far, but one immediate piece of feedback, don‚Äôt query until after fire-rules#2018-05-2320:35mikerodthink of query the same as with-tracing earlier, you have to only do it on ‚Äúconsistent‚Äù states of a session#2018-05-2320:36mikerodClara does some delayed evaluation for performance reasons. Any inserts/retracts that occur prior to a fire-rule cannot be relied upon and I‚Äôd consider the session to be in an ‚Äúundefined‚Äù state#2018-05-2320:37mikerodI‚Äôd actually prefer Clara to change for query to either (a) throw exception if called prior to a fire-rules or return something that indicates it is not ready yet.#2018-05-2320:38mikerodClara takes advantaged of batched insertion and also potentially a few other things, so it does not eagerly perform things like insert or retract. The evaluation is typically pushed to batch up the facts propagating through the network. This can play a major role in performance.#2018-05-2320:39mikerodYou mentioned OPS5, which you likely wouldn‚Äôt have seen behavior like this long ago. It is more common now. Drools is a popular JVM-based rules engine and it similarly has delayed evaluation of things prior to rule firing due to similar concerns.#2018-05-2320:40mikerodThis issue seems to somewhat often trip people up though. So I don‚Äôt think it is clear enough.#2018-05-2320:41mikerodFor your second question > ;why are my counters still there, I retracted them? I think it is because (query % counters) doesn‚Äôt return what you are thinking it does#2018-05-2320:41mikerodIt doesn‚Äôt return the bare counter fact, instead it returns a bindings map from the query, so it returns something like: 
{:?counter <the counter fact>}
#2018-05-2320:42mikerodso you‚Äôd probably have to do something like 
(#(apply retract % (map :?counter (query % counters))))
#2018-05-2320:42jdtOh sorry, forgot to include the output#2018-05-2320:42jdtIt works, just not as expected#2018-05-2320:42jdtHere comes the output#2018-05-2320:43mikerodthat output looks consistent with the explanation I just gave#2018-05-2320:44mikerodso try to apply the things I mentioned#2018-05-2320:45jdtAh, that fixes it#2018-05-2320:45jdt(map :?counter ...)#2018-05-2320:45mikerodüéâ#2018-05-2516:57jdtI'm guessing the second [Derived 1] is retracted after insertion, though that isn't what I want, in fact in my POC rule set I'm doing an insert-unconditional! because the fact must survive, subsequent retraction, but I still only one exactly one instance to be inserted, i.e. one-time initialization.#2018-05-2517:04mikerod@dave.tenny you know you‚Äôre inserting a vector there right?#2018-05-2517:04mikerodJust noticed that this seems odd (insert! [Derived ?x])#2018-05-2517:04jdtLol, I looked at it thinking "something isn't right here" too#2018-05-2517:04jdtJust too Friday-minded to see it, thanks for looking#2018-05-2517:04mikerodhowever, with insert! I think you may get in an infinite loop#2018-05-2517:05mikerodbecause your rule becomes a logical contradiction#2018-05-2517:05mikerodSo I think there are just several different topics with this example, üòõ#2018-05-2517:05jdtyes indeed, infinite loop#2018-05-2517:06mikerodyou can do an insert-unconditional! of course#2018-05-2517:06jdtAmending the snippet#2018-05-2517:06mikerodI‚Äôm not a huge fan of those, because they cause rules to become more order dependent‚Äô#2018-05-2517:06mikerodHowever, there are times where they are difficult to avoid I know#2018-05-2517:07jdtIn my case, I need to add a fact to the system, once to "initialize" the absense of a missing fact. The fact needs to survive truth maintenace because I am going to retract the basis for creating it, but not the need for using it later on#2018-05-2517:07mikerodYour snippet now has no code, only output#2018-05-2517:08jdtyeah, once sec, reposting the snippet, there was no "edit"#2018-05-2517:10jdtI deleted the first snippet, it shouldn't exist at all in slack, actually.#2018-05-2517:11jdtAnyway, I'm clearly not yet in the mindset of thinking the way clara wants me to think. I'd expect a rule like [:not [Foo]] => (insert-unconditional! (->Foo)) to fire exactly once, but clearly my assumptions are wrong.#2018-05-2517:13alex-dixonWouldn‚Äôt call that a bad assumption but that rule effectively means when not foo foo and when foo not foo#2018-05-2517:14mikerodif you use insert! the behavior is a contradiction, with insert-unconditional! it is different#2018-05-2517:14mikerodThere is also a property you can add to rules, I don‚Äôt typically like to add it though, but it is :no-loop#2018-05-2517:15alex-dixonOops. with unconditional it should operate as you stated I think#2018-05-2517:15mikerodit may be able to stop a logical loop from a contradicting rule like you have here with insert!, but I‚Äôd have to mess with that again#2018-05-2517:15jdtOops, yes, my code snippet iwth the infinite loop isn't interesting. When I use insert-unconditional it's still firing more than once#2018-05-2517:15mikerod@alex-dixon I haven‚Äôt seen an insert-unconditional! example yet üòõ#2018-05-2517:15jdtDoing the code snippet and output again, apologies#2018-05-2517:15mikerodinsert-unconditional! will result in a firing for each of your Fact objects, so 3 is rigth#2018-05-2517:16alex-dixonWhat about not exists?#2018-05-2517:16jdtI thought [:not [Foo]] was a not-exist check?#2018-05-2517:17mikerodThe rules do not treat the working memory as something like a set. It allows ‚Äúduplicates‚Äù. There are useful cases for that - scratch this#2018-05-2517:17mikerodoh, I see what you mean#2018-05-2517:18mikerod@dave.tenny you‚Äôre correct in what :not is#2018-05-2517:20mikerodI think it may be an ‚Äúedge case‚Äù on insert-unconditional! behavior in the engine. I‚Äôd probably call it incorrect how the engine is behaving#2018-05-2517:20jdtI'm confused because on the one hand, the RHS of one rule can impact the firing of another rule. But in this case it's like both checks for a [Derived 1] correpesponding to a [Fact 1] took place at the same time, neither aware of the others effect, and unsure how to bridge that.#2018-05-2517:21mikerodLike I said, I‚Äôm not a fan of insert-unconditional! and try to not use it much because I think it makes things have order dependence and always trickier to reason about as far as ‚Äúglobal logical consistency‚Äù across the rules#2018-05-2517:21jdt(reminds me of MVCC transactions, which can be a good thing ... in a database üòâ )#2018-05-2517:21mikerodHowever, in this case, I think it is behaving poorly with batched inserts#2018-05-2517:22mikerodI think all 3 matches are staged independent of one another and all perform insert-unconditional! at the ‚Äúsame time‚Äù#2018-05-2517:22mikerodsince they are unconditional, the truth maintenance isn‚Äôt used to remove the logical inconsistencies#2018-05-2517:23mikerodthis is a tougher case to me conceptually to think about#2018-05-2517:23mikerodas far as a ‚Äúfix‚Äù would go#2018-05-2517:24jdtOkay, well, I'll remedy my immediate problem by doing what is fundamentally an initialization step outside of the rule firing and add my initialization outside of the firings (i.e. not in an RHS via insert!, but via insert externally.#2018-05-2517:24alex-dixonWondering if behavior is different if derived is inserted without ?x...maybe y instead #2018-05-2517:25jdtI'm definitely still struggling with these little things, though logic principles of [not x] => [x] is a good way ot look at it in my thinking for the future.#2018-05-2517:26mikerod@dave.tenny oftentimes, and I‚Äôve said this quite a bit here before, I try to separate the desire of ‚Äúcardinality‚Äù into a different rule from the rule that has the logic to derive the fact in question#2018-05-2517:26jdtThis particular one is very unfortunate though, if it worked it was much nicer and more foolproof when done via a rule firing.#2018-05-2517:27mikerodSo instead of worrying about a rule producing too many of something, I let it produce them, and reconcile them with a separate rule and an accumulator#2018-05-2517:27alex-dixon@mikerod what‚Äôs the upside to the batched unconditional insertions implementation? Is it possible to still attain those benefits without eliciting behavior like this?#2018-05-2517:27mikerodthis case is a bit different in a way, but if your real concern is only that you don‚Äôt want 2 Derived :y 1 facts, it applies#2018-05-2517:27mikerod@alex-dixon batched <anything> upside is basically always performance#2018-05-2517:28mikerodand the performance can be really significant#2018-05-2517:28mikerodHowever, in the unconditional case, it now concerns me a bit since the truth maintenance won‚Äôt ‚Äúfix it‚Äù when different unconditional inserts cause the other to become untrue#2018-05-2517:29mikerodhowever, that is a really gray area to me. if it did behave right, how would it choose which unconditional insert wins, when they contradict each other? In the general case.#2018-05-2517:29mikerodI guess it would just have to be order-dependent#2018-05-2517:30jdtOn an unrelated topic, can you recommend tools for pretty-printing/organizing inspect and get-trace output to assist with reading it? I made my first attempt at decoding that stuff to debug, but as a raw clojure nested structure it's rough going for a first try.#2018-05-2517:31mikerod@dave.tenny @alex-dixon is going to release a tool to show tracing stuff nicer üòõ#2018-05-2517:32mikerodJoking.. but he has said he had a better visualization thing. The trace results will be pretty verbose and clj data structures. Inspect was supposed to have a few friendlier printers I think. I haven‚Äôt used inspect much.#2018-05-2517:34jdtOf course what I really want is a simple movie-mode rule tracing with verbose-mode description of clause evaluation impact on rule consideration/rejection. Heh, or is that [:test (do (prn "here I am") true)] in the LHS?#2018-05-2517:35mikerod@dave.tenny yeah, you can print stuff. I think the tracing output can be used alright, but it‚Äôs mostly just composing functions on it to show it however is useful.#2018-05-2517:36mikerodI don‚Äôt have any great pointers there still beyond that#2018-05-2517:36jdtHaven't seen any "tips and tricks" documentation for the sorts of things a newbie could use for debugging#2018-05-2517:36jdtif it's out there#2018-05-2517:42mikerodYeah, I think this may be something that is lacking (and would be really nice to have).#2018-05-2517:42mikerodThe most docs I see are just from http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/inspection/#2018-05-2519:28alex-dixon@mikerod It‚Äôs not better according to me. And yeah‚Ä¶I‚Äôm working on it again this weekend üôÇ#2018-05-2519:31alex-dixonMight open an issue in Clara about adding Datalog syntax as a separate clara library. For something like the precept devtools concept I‚Äôm not sure how that would work‚Ä¶.would need to think about it or have some direction from others. A lot of the way I thought about it was Precept-specific. I think the main difference is that there‚Äôs framework to manage session transitions, so there‚Äôs code that‚Äôs aware of when rules are firing and when they‚Äôre done firing that allows them to be identified and numbered#2018-05-2519:31alex-dixonSorry if that‚Äôs incoherent#2018-05-2522:20mikerod@alex-dixon Yeah, I‚Äôd have to think about that more too. I get what you are saying though I think.#2018-05-2802:16alex-dixonI think I‚Äôm about ready to release an alpha preview of precept devtools to anyone who‚Äôs interested#2018-05-2803:05alex-dixon@devn https://github.com/CoNarrative/precept-devtools#2018-05-2803:08alex-dixonIf at all possible I‚Äôd prefer not to publicize it (yet) until I make some improvements to the readme and a few other things#2018-05-2803:14alex-dixonI‚Äôd definitely appreciate any feedback though#2018-05-3012:57jdtI'm just building this little prototype rule-based scheduler in clara to see if it will handle things at scale. It won't have many rules, but it will have a pragmatic maximum of 1-2 million base facts before firing the rule engine. Am I wasting my time, or will that overwhelm the system? (The bulk of the facts are job requests, from which we then infer things like whether there's a worker with adequate resources, round robin behaviors, and so on.)#2018-05-3013:12jdt(I'm building the new intermediate binding of WorkerViableJob and ActiveUserJobCount, I just wondered if there wasn't a way to correlate the two records in the :and subclause that considers them without the use if an intermediate fact).#2018-05-3015:48mikerod@dave.tenny I‚Äôd perhaps worry about that being a fairly slow way to do what you are saying given that you have so many facts in the session#2018-05-3015:49jdt"that" being using a rules system?#2018-05-3015:49mikerodI think if you have enough memory for that many objects, then the rules could perform alright. However, you will have to look out for bad algorithmic complexity in some rules if they are going to be processed over a very large amount of facts, like if you do some wide-open joins between sets of facts with size N and size M, you‚Äôll get NxM comparisons in the join criteria#2018-05-3015:49jdtyeah, trying to keep things tightly joined, and avoid derived facts that I don't need where possible#2018-05-3015:50mikerodOh, I mean the rule you gave above may be slow, if there are millions of WorkerViableJob and ActiveUserJobCount#2018-05-3015:50jdtNo, there's only millions of raw job request.#2018-05-3015:50mikerodI think that a rules engine, such as Clara, may be capable of having reasonable perf characteristics, but you‚Äôd have to be careful for the ‚Äúhot spots‚Äù#2018-05-3015:50jdtThere are relatively fiew WorkerViableJobs (those are jobs for which we know we have worker resources available, and we limit those to a small number of oldest/most-applicable jobs in any fire-rules run)#2018-05-3015:50mikerodIt‚Äôs best to quickly filter down to a smaller set of facts before performing the more involved joins between sets of facts#2018-05-3015:51mikerodI would not fear intermediate facts either#2018-05-3015:51mikerodI think it‚Äôll help your rule given above even#2018-05-3015:52jdtYeah, already fixed that by asserting facts representing bindings of the clause.#2018-05-3015:52jdtI just wondered if there was a better way#2018-05-3015:53jdtI also repeatedly fall into the trap of [:not A] => A in my rules, because I only want to make an A if some other particular thing isn't true. Finding my way around it, but feels like I fight the problem a lot, whether or not the inserted A is unconditional.#2018-05-3015:53mikerodperhaps#2018-05-3015:54jdtEven though I don't have too many rules now, there's actually a lot we want to do in our job management, affinities, special cases for "new job submitters" to give them optimal user experience in interacting with the jobs whose results they want, etc.#2018-05-3015:55jdtSo that's why I'm spending a bit too much time to see if this is viable, I think rules could be a real win here.#2018-05-3015:55mikerodSo in your above example, I wonder if you could make use of an accumulator like: 
[?lowest <- (acc/min :n-jobs) :from [ActiveUserJobCount (= ?job-type job-type)]]
#2018-05-3015:55mikerodhowever, I don‚Äôt know that I immediately get the full semantics (like what the RHS) does#2018-05-3015:55mikerodbut doing that would give you the min job count for a given :job-type in terms of the ActiveUserJobCount facts#2018-05-3015:56mikerodFor this one: > I also repeatedly fall into the trap of [:not A] => A in my rules, because I only want to make an A if some other particular thing isn‚Äôt true I don‚Äôt know of a fix-all. It‚Äôs a case by case thing. Not sure what sort of scenario keeps getting you into it.#2018-05-3015:56jdtFor one of m y [:not A] => A scenarios I tried [acc/count ... and checked for count < than the limit I wanted, but the problem is it won't fire if the count is zero, even if the accumulator initializes with zero#2018-05-3015:58jdtMy scenarios are things like "this job is something we want to proceed with if some other job isn't eligible", a gross generalism, could be any fact, not just jobs. It often boils down to counting situations. E.g. only dispatch at most two at a time on a worker in one fire-rules loop.#2018-05-3015:58jdtMy approach now is to generate very minimal sets of candidates in a fire-rules session, then query the results, dispatch jobs, update relevant counters-as-facts, then run fire-rules again in a loop.#2018-05-3015:59jdtThe counters I need to maintain are mainly worker resource availability and active user job counts partitioned by type of job.#2018-05-3015:59jdtOkay, well, hopefully I'm nearing some kind of first load test, we'll see what happens.#2018-05-3016:00jdtAdvice always appreciated.#2018-05-3017:11wparker@jdt The Clara count accumulator should fire with an initial value of 0. Do you have an example where it does not? Also keep in mind that you can create your own accumulators with arbitrary domain-specific logic. So say "choose the top two at most" could be done. My instinct here is that it sounds like the problems you describe might be addressable with accumulators without any insert-unconditional logic, although as always hard to say without knowing the problem space. It sounds like @mikerod was suggesting that as well.#2018-05-3017:13wparkerSee the writing accumulators section at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/#2018-05-3017:14wparkerAlso regarding the cost of joins, that varies depending on the type of join, I'd suggest reading http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/hash_joins/ if you're working with millions of facts#2018-05-3017:59jdtI thought the behavior I observed with the acc/count condition not firing seemed consistent with the documented behavior on this page: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/, however I suspect I read it wrong and they were talking about other accumulators not firing when there weren't facts matching the condition, instead of acc/count. I don't have the example in code any more so will have to revisit it later if necessary. Meanwhile I'll checkout those other links you posted.#2018-05-3018:38mikerod@dave.tenny if an accumulator has a ‚Äútruthy‚Äù :initial-value, it‚Äôs condition in a rule will be considered satisfied even if no facts exists to match the accumulators fact match criteria#2018-05-3018:39mikeroddefault :initial-value is nil, so the default would not be true, however acc/count initializes to 0, so a condition that uses it will be satisfied when no facts match the condition.#2018-05-3018:40mikerode.g. [?count <- (acc/count) :from [NoMatchEver]] would bind ?count to 0 and the condition would be satisfied.#2018-05-3018:40jdtI definitely had a [?x <- (acc/count ...)] that was not being successful, or at least a [:test (do (prn ...) true) ] following that accum condition was not printed, but perhaps they're not evaluated sequentially. My rule definitely wasn't firing, but again I no longer have the code to reason about it.#2018-05-3018:41mikerodweird, I‚Äôd have to see it#2018-05-3113:06wparker@dave.tenny perhaps your example created new bindings, in that case Clara‚Äôs accumulators won‚Äôt fire without facts even given an initial value. i.e. for [?result <- (acc/all) :from [Fact (= ?a a)]] if ?a isn‚Äôt created elsewhere you need facts to give ?a a meaning so the accumulator won‚Äôt fire without them. This is in the accumulator docs pages I posted before IIRC, I think there are some examples in the clara-examples project too#2018-05-3113:09mikerod@wparker I forgot that that was ever changed. I thought they still fire always even without a binding#2018-05-3113:09mikerodI see what you are saying in the docs though#2018-05-3113:16wparkerI can find it in the history later#2018-05-3113:18wparkernote that only applies if the binding in question is new though - if a previous condition creates it the accumulator will still fire with the initial value#2018-05-3113:18wparkerIt is a bit confusing.. but otherwise IMO you end up with bindings that don‚Äôt make much logical sense#2018-05-3113:25mikerodYep, thanks for clarifying#2018-05-3117:24wparkerLooks like the work was done under https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/102 unfortunately the discussion there is less than simple to understand. PRs https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/204 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/208 https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/210#2018-06-0116:09jdtSo thanks to all for the help so far, but unless I can solve this "if some fact insert this other fact ONCE" problem I'm about ready to throw in the towel. It's really like I want each rule firing to be sensitive to the prior rule firings in a single call to (fire-rules), but that isn't what happens.#2018-06-0116:12zyloxyou absoultely are fighting the engine if you do an insert-unconditional based on an inference, but still want logical retractions. Why are you using unconditional again? i havent followed all the conversations.#2018-06-0116:13jdtthat's just one way to do it, but it wouldn't work because that rule is going to fire twice and both firings will NOT see the Derived asserted by the first firing#2018-06-0116:13jdtSo it's not even about truth maintenance so much as WHEN the LHS is evaluated#2018-06-0116:14zyloxoh..hmm#2018-06-0116:15jdtI'm open to any reasonable way to do it, but given LHS matching those two facts I inserted, the result needs to be ONE derived.#2018-06-0116:15zyloxI guess i dont understand why you need it only inserted once and not that the final state is one in the session.#2018-06-0116:15zyloxbecause you are going to absolutely end up with two if you are using unconditional#2018-06-0116:16jdtMaybe all I need to do is replace the [Fact (= ?ftype ftype)] with use of an accumulator and predicate to express the "if there is some", and fire the rule once, haven't tried that#2018-06-0116:16jdtCan you give a sample of the merge logic?#2018-06-0116:17jdtOops, I see you did, I think#2018-06-0116:17mikerodthe rules don‚Äôt assume what a ‚Äúduplicate‚Äù means to you or what you want to do with them. You need an extra rule to configure that yourself.#2018-06-0116:17mikerodExample, Maybe you wanted to know how many duplicates you had#2018-06-0116:17mikerodyou could then have (defrecord Derived [ftype matches-count])#2018-06-0116:18mikerodThen 
(defrule merge-derived
  [?all <- (acc/all) :from [::derived-intermediate (= ?ftype (-> this :derived :ftype))]]
  =>
;; Merging to one, but include the count of the "duplicates" for whatever reason
  (insert! (-> ?all first :derived (assoc :matches-count (count ?all))))
#2018-06-0116:18jdtok, digesting this, back to drawing board#2018-06-0117:02mikerod@dave.tenny Yep, I don‚Äôt see a reason for it there#2018-06-0117:02mikerodI didn‚Äôt use it in the merge-derived rule either#2018-06-0118:14jdtThat use of with-meta and :type is interesting to know about when doing type based dispatches.#2018-06-0118:14jdtInteresting tip#2018-06-0118:29jdtAnbody got an emacs cider clojure mode switch to adjust LHS condition indentation? My clauses don't seem to want to indent to the level of the prior clause.#2018-06-0118:29jdtRather, bindings/predicates, not the clauses.#2018-06-0119:33mikerodI don‚Äôt have special indentation rules#2018-06-0119:33mikerodit indents less than ideal for vectors I‚Äôd say#2018-06-0119:33mikerodI‚Äôve mostly just let it happen#2018-06-0121:50mikerod@dave.tenny I agree it isn‚Äôt ideal#2018-06-0121:50mikerodfor multiline, I typically go with: 
[WorkerViableJob 
    (= ?user-id user-id)
    (= ?job-type job-type)]
#2018-06-0122:05alex-dixonClojure in general I find it helps to just give up on making lines short#2018-06-0122:08alex-dixonMost rules I‚Äôve written have positional syntax so everything on one line works well‚Ä¶joins typically line up nicely. In Clara I‚Äôd probably do the same for the same reason‚Ä¶try to group things vertically by joins#2018-06-0214:05alex-dixon@mikerod Regarding datalog syntax for Clara: Would you want it to be schema based? The implementation I have only enforces a datomic schema‚Äôs cardinality and uniqueness ‚Ä¶ nothing related to types. It enables upsert behavior, which may or may not be desirable for Clara users. Cardinality and uniqueness indices are checked and updated before inserting or retracting facts (within the insert/retract functions), and if anything should be upserted then the appropriate retracts and inserts are made. Only one to one facts are indexed at this time, since there‚Äôs no uniqueness or cardinality enforcement that applies to one to many. Overall I tried to follow Datomic‚Äôs semantics on this: https://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/schema.html#operational-schema-attributes, https://docs.datomic.com/on-prem/schema.html#required-schema-attributes. If a fact is not mentioned in a schema it defaults to one to one cardinality. I think that could be changed easily if you wanted‚Ä¶the idea there was facts are typically one to one for UI and we didn‚Äôt want to force users type out cardinality for every fact.#2018-06-0214:13alex-dixonThis would affect the implementation at the session-ish level. None of this has to be part of a LocalSession and I don‚Äôt think it should be, but I‚Äôm toying with a LocalDatalogSession that takes a LocalSession and ‚Äúindexes‚Äù argument so the indexes can travel with a session. It should be possible to use with insert/retract per the normal api (`(-> session (insert facts) (fire-rules))`) though the insert/retract functions would need be datalog specific (`(clara.rules.datalog/insert)`) if enforcing a schema the way I described#2018-06-0413:10mikerod@alex-dixon that‚Äôs interesting. When I‚Äôve mentioned support for the datalog syntax before, I was only thinking of it at a syntactic level - like an alternative DSL. The one thing I wasn‚Äôt sure of in that was how the fact-type-fn would work (what would it be?). It sounds like you‚Äôre considering an approach that is a bit more integrated with the semantics of these structures. That may be a reasonable thing to do. I haven‚Äôt worked with this sort of thing enough to have any big insight. What you describe above seems like something that may be useful and reasonable to me.#2018-06-0414:45alex-dixon@mikerod > The one thing I wasn‚Äôt sure of in that was how the fact-type-fn would work (what would it be?) Precept uses :a with a Tuple record [e a v t] (t is an incremented fact id). We use the clojure‚Äôs (derive) to associate cardinality and uniqueness with :a keywords. Clara receives the hierarchy via the :ancestors-fn option in order to be able to match on :all attributes. Every :a descends from :all so you can write conditions that will obtain across attributes (e.g. [?e :all 42]). The ancestry is also used outside Clara for maintaining e-a-v and a-v-e indexes. When facts are inserted or retracted it lets us determine their cardinality and uniqueness constraints. Based on that and the current indexes we determine whether inserts and retracts should be performed so that the schema can be adhered to, or whether an error should be thrown. Over the weekend I worked on a design that doesn‚Äôt use global vars for the indexes and ancestors hierarchy. I haven‚Äôt figured it out yet. insert! seems like the real challenge. It‚Äôs not part of the ISession protocol and only takes facts as arguments. My best guess is that we should bind a session‚Äôs indexes and ancestry to a dynamic var (like session-context) when fire rules is called on it. Then we could read from it from within an insert! implementation and update the indexes there. I think that‚Äôd require something like a LocalDatalogSession that could take these extra arguments in its constructor.#2018-06-0415:11mikerod@alex-dixon this makes sense to me.#2018-06-0415:11mikerodI was thinking that the :a may be the best fact type too, wasn‚Äôt sure. And good point on deriving from :all#2018-06-0512:57jdtAny tips on analyzing where I'm spending time in rules? (for example, which rules).#2018-06-0513:10mikerod@dave.tenny should be possible to use Clara tracing to take a look at something like that. Although it‚Äôs exploratory to find what you want given the data structures it returns. You could get something like count of times things were evaluated that way. #2018-06-0513:10mikerodIt‚Äôd be nice if Clara had more supporting functions for this purpose though. #2018-06-0513:13jdtThere are some minimum number of queries in addition to the above rules.#2018-06-0513:16jdtBetween each fire-rules the dispatcher will select one job per job type (so 15 in this numbers case), dispatch it, update the ActiveUserJobCount, WorkerResource, facts, and retract the dispatched JobRequest facts.#2018-06-0513:17jdtSo I'm averaging about 1-3 seconds per job dispatch, and whacking the hell out of my CPU. (Memory footprint is good however... surprise!)#2018-06-0513:23jdtI had originally hoped to do the fact maintenance for active user job counts (used for round robin eligibility consideration), and worker resource stats (to track remaining worker capacity), in the RHS of rules. But I gave that up early in the process because it was a side-effect oriented process with a bunch of [:not A] => A scenarios, which might have been doable, but it was really the timing of the rule LHS evaluations that killed it, since LHS evaluations are perceptually "in parallel" and not sequential with respect to cause and effect for a given rule.#2018-06-0513:24jdtSo I compute some eligible things, then do the dispatching and accounting between calls to fire-rules, then do it all over again (always saving and continuing from the updated session).#2018-06-0513:44mikerod> but it was really the timing of the rule LHS evaluations that killed it, since LHS evaluations are perceptually ‚Äúin parallel‚Äù and not sequential with respect to cause and effect for a given rule. Only the case for insert-unconditional! (and possibly even a defect), but yeah. if you have to extract these facts after they are ‚Äúdone‚Äù it may make most sense to be an external thing anyways.#2018-06-0513:44mikerod@dave.tenny I can look at your rules from above some, sounds too slow#2018-06-0513:45jdtHappy to share the whole module, nothing but some pretty rules and ugly code to do the bookkeeping and setup mock data and such#2018-06-0513:46mikerodwhen something takes long in that range of seconds (like 10+) I tend to do a cpu sampling#2018-06-0513:46jdtJob dispatch and completion is all about accounting then trying again with updated rules.#2018-06-0513:46mikerodWith a profiler, I tend to use visualVM because it is good enough for this situation#2018-06-0513:46mikerodsometimes it gives quicker leads to what is causing issues. Sometimes it is too opaque unless you know the rule engine internals, but not necessarily always#2018-06-0513:46jdtYeah, I'm having problems with VisualVM on my Linux system becuase of some JNI/Jar problem I can't figure out, and HPROF sampling is usually useless#2018-06-0513:47mikerodbut also, doing some just blunt counting of times that certain conditions in rules and/or rule RHS were fired sometimes can give you the outliers as well#2018-06-0513:47mikerodHmm#2018-06-0513:47mikerodYeah, VisualVM with ‚Äúcpu sampler‚Äù is what I have used. if things are whacky there, not sure hah#2018-06-0513:47jdtYeah, I'm looking at instrumenting, is it possible to capture the time spent, via instrumentation, in each LHS condition?#2018-06-0513:47mikerodwell, time will obviously go to the instrumentation/tracing you do#2018-06-0513:48mikerodbut if you do something like just gather counts#2018-06-0513:48mikerodthat is not time-sensitive anyways#2018-06-0513:48jdtRe the rules, any obvious stupid hash-join failures or things that might be better done in predicates or with accumulators?#2018-06-0513:48mikerodwhen I‚Äôve tried ‚Äúcounting condition/rhs‚Äù firings before in bad performance cases, there are often outliers#2018-06-0513:48mikerodLike most things evaluation perhaps no more than 1k times for example#2018-06-0513:48mikerodbut then you find something that evaluates like 1 mil times#2018-06-0513:49mikerodtypically its something like that#2018-06-0513:49jdtIn my case I'm worried it's the tests in the conditions that are firing a lot, but I'll get more data.#2018-06-0513:49mikerodSo even your rule like worker-viable-jobs may be pretty heavy#2018-06-0513:50mikerodI‚Äôm just looking over what you had and your sort of fact counts#2018-06-0513:50jdtFor example, if I'm doing N^2 firings on the worker-viable-jobs conditions for the 100k job requests and 45 worker-resource facts.#2018-06-0513:50mikerodyou have 100K job requests facts and 45 workers, and you also have a :not in that rule#2018-06-0513:50mikerodso you are something like 100K x 100K x 45 territory#2018-06-0513:51jdtRight, is there a way to achieve the semantics there without the combinatorics?#2018-06-0513:51mikerodprobably just doing millions of comparisons with clj = and < etc and it adds up#2018-06-0513:51mikerodyes, I think there is a way out of it#2018-06-0513:52jdtThis is where, if I could update the worker resources in the RHS and immediately prune the possibilities for the next firing of worker-viable-job it would have been a win, but that doesn't work because all the worker-viable-jobs are going to fire regardless of whether I update the worker resources because of that seemingly parallel LHS evaluation protocol.#2018-06-0513:52mikerodExtract a rule, find the oldest jobs first, then only bring those into the join with WorkerResource rule here#2018-06-0513:53mikerodin general, you have a lot of JobRequest facts to deal with. You want to avoid any rule that may do a join across that set of facts with itself#2018-06-0513:53mikerodI‚Äôm not sure how memory and thread factor into an ‚Äúoldest job‚Äù situation#2018-06-0513:53mikerodso hard to give you an example#2018-06-0513:53jdtExcept we'll still need to potentially consider the next oldest, and so on, until we find one that fits the avaialble worker resources, so does an extra rule really help?#2018-06-0513:54mikerod
[:not [JobRequest (< job-id ?job-id) 
                    (= ?job-type job-type)
                    (= ?user-id user-id)
                    (<= threads ?threads)
                    (<= memory ?memory)]]
#2018-06-0513:54jdtThe memory and thread tests are to test only for jobs that can actually execute on the worker resources, i.e. for which enough resources exist.#2018-06-0513:54jdtThat's the "viable" part of the semantics#2018-06-0513:55mikerodthe rule can help, just have to figure out what the correct rule is#2018-06-0513:55mikerodthinking about it#2018-06-0513:55jdtAny advice for a beginner on how to effectively use the tracing API here? The one time I tried it there was too much data to process, and that was on the simplest most minimal amount of facts.#2018-06-0513:57jdtre: the "oldest job" stuff, I was wondering if accumulators would in any way help, I have no idea how they're implemented w.r..t incremental fact maintenance.#2018-06-0514:11mikerod> Any advice for a beginner on how to effectively use the tracing API here? The one time I tried it there was too much data to process, and that was on the simplest most minimal amount of facts. I haven‚Äôt used it as much as I‚Äôd expect. I was used to rolling my own stuff prior to when tracing stuff was introduced. However, for counting, I believe you can do something like: 
(let [traced (-> (clara.rules/mk-session <your rules>)
                 (clara.tools.tracing/with-tracing)
                 (insert <your facts>)
                 fire-rules
                 clara.tools.tracing/get-trace)]
  (frequencies (map :node-id traced)))
#2018-06-0514:12mikerodor perhaps better sorted: 
(let [tr (-> (clara.rules/mk-session [temp-rule])
                                       (t/with-tracing)
                                       (insert (->Temperature 10 "MCI")
                                               (->Temperature 20 "MCI"))
                                       (fire-rules)
                                       (t/get-trace )
                                       )]
                            (->>  (map :node-id tr)
                                  frequencies
                                  (sort-by val)
                                  reverse))
#2018-06-0514:13mikerodonce you know the highest count :node-ids you can look those up in the rulebase associated with the session#2018-06-0514:13jdtexcellent, thanks#2018-06-0514:16mikerod
(let [session (-> (clara.rules/mk-session <your rules>)
                  (t/with-tracing)
                  (insert <your facts>)
                  (fire-rules))

      trace (t/get-trace session)
      node-id <whatever node id in question from `trace`>


      {:keys [rulebase]} (clara.rules.engine/components session)
      {:keys [id-to-node]} rulebase]
  (get id-to-node node-id) )
This is how you could look up the node-id to try to find what node in the engine it is#2018-06-0514:16mikeroda node will be a defrecord of stuff, not all that readable to you, but you should be able to recognize aspects of it and align it back to your rules typically#2018-06-0515:09jdtThanks Mike, I'll have a look#2018-06-0516:38jdt@mikerod as I am still new at accumulators, I'm trying to discern the purpose of the ?user-id binding on line 30 in the above snippet. Is it used so that the rule will fire once for each distinct user id? Does it work given that ?user-id is not otherwise bound?#2018-06-0516:43mikerod@dave.tenny > Is it used so that the rule will fire once for each distinct user id? yes, in that‚Äôs its purpose in that example#2018-06-0516:44mikerodwhich makes me realize I had a typo there, it should have been (= ?user-id (-> this :worker-viable-job :user-id)) since it was nested one level lower, will update. Sorry if that caused confusion.#2018-06-0516:46mikerodAccumulators behavior with field-level bindings like that is explained more in http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/accumulators/#2018-06-0516:53jdtI'm getting null pointer exceptions on calls to < that I think are the accumulator, but are maybe something else, unfortunately the stack trace doesn't not clue me in other than it's in (fire-rules), pretty much. However the acc/min isn't documented to accept a :initial-value argument, so it's probably something else. Just in case something obvious is missing above.#2018-06-0516:58jdtAh wait, maybe it's because I removed an explicit binding of :user-id in the candidate rule.#2018-06-0516:59mikerod@dave.tenny more typo‚Äôs because I forgot the thing was neste#2018-06-0517:00mikerod(acc/min (comp :job-id :worker-viable-job) :returns-fact true), I updated the snippet above to reflect that#2018-06-0517:00mikerodif :job-id may be nil though, would have to defend against it#2018-06-1502:25hiredmanI've just started exploring with Clara, and don't have a ton of experience with rules systems, and I've run into a surprise. When I have a rule something like [Foo (= x 1)] (not [Foo (= x 2)]) => (insert! (->Foo 2)) it goes in to an infinite loop#2018-06-1503:21mikerod@hiredman insert! Is a conditional insert. These inserts are monitored by a ‚Äútruth maintenance system‚Äù (aka TMS). The goal of the TMS is to keep all of the rules and their consequences in a logically consistent state#2018-06-1503:21mikerodSo the rule you put above is a logical contradiction. #2018-06-1503:21mikerodThere are workarounds. Depending on what it is you are trying to achieve. #2018-06-1503:23mikerodAlso the TMS is useful to be able to express large numbers of rules in a declarative/non order dependent way. You don‚Äôt have to worry about ‚Äúwhen something was inserted‚Äù to be careful to not check for it ‚Äúbefore it was inserted‚Äù and that sort of thing. It leads to a less brittle system. #2018-06-1503:23mikerodThe concept of a TMS has been around in many of the more modern rule systems. #2018-06-1518:15hiredman@mikerod thanks, makes sense, I hadn't connected those dots#2018-06-1518:24mikerod@hiredman I will say that the engine going into an infinite loop without trying to help isn‚Äôt really user-friendly. The action a rule does on the right-hand side (aka RHS) of the => is arbitrary from the rules engine perspective, so it cannot ‚Äúknow it is in an infinite loop‚Äù. However, something could reasonably be added to allow a configurable upper limit on the times you‚Äôd allow what may ‚Äúlook like a loop‚Äù to be allowed until the engine halted and reported a possible error. For now though, it could be documented as a FAQ or something as well.#2018-06-1518:24mikerodeg ‚ÄúIf the engine seems to be in an infinite loop, this is commonly the cause‚Ä¶‚Äù#2018-06-1518:29mikerodThere are cases that you may think it is hard to see how to not need a rule like you have above. Some of those can actually be tricky to express, but in many cases that I‚Äôve seen, accumulators can be used to achieve the semantics desired, or a new fact type that is used for the derived fact that is different from what is deriving it eg instead of 
[:not [Foo (= x 2)]] => (insert! (->Foo 2))
Something like 
[:not [Foo (= x 2)]] => (insert! (->DerivedFoo 2))
#2018-06-1615:58sparkofreasonJust a quick brain-bubble on this topic: I wonder if there could be a sort of "debug mode" where during fire-rules a graph is built for the causal relationships, e.g. Fact A -> Rule B -> Fact C -> Rule D... That graph could be analyzed for cycles. Haven't thought this through at all, and would guess it isn't perfect, but perhaps better than nothing?#2018-06-1616:36alex-dixonI think for Clojure :no-loop true can be provided in the properties map. I‚Äôve heard it mentioned a couple times#2018-06-1616:37alex-dixonhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/8c4898498b5bff7a231f5c5ce74d56ab84453a53/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1108#2018-06-1617:47mikerod@dave.dixon the thing is that it isn‚Äôt clear it is actually looping just because it goes through the same rule path a few times. RHS can do arbitrary logic. Including have different paths they may take via conditionals. #2018-06-1617:47mikerodSome sort of general warnings could be nice perhaps that suggest that ‚Äúmaybe‚Äù there is a loop though#2018-06-1617:50mikerod@alex-dixon yep. It exists. Don‚Äôt generally recommend it unless the use case really makes sense to use it. #2018-06-1617:50mikerodTypically it‚Äôs best to solve the problems just purely via the logical TMS if practical. #2018-06-1617:52sparkofreasonYeah, it's another version of the halting problem. But it might be a nice way to get some visibility on the causal structure, and highlight loops that are unexpected.#2018-06-1618:03mikerodYes indeed#2018-06-2517:58tony.kayHi, is it ok to use *current-session*? it isn‚Äôt documented, but it would be handy to run queries during rule execution‚Ä¶or is that just a bad idea?#2018-06-2518:30mikerod@tony.kay sounds like a bad idea üòõ#2018-06-2518:30mikerodAre you wanting to use it for debugging or for more than that?#2018-06-2518:31tony.kaySo, we have facts that are stored in a datomic-fashion‚Ä¶so ‚Äúinsert‚Äù needs to know if the fact (as an E/A pair) is already present so we can retract the old value before inserting the new one#2018-06-2518:31mikerodThe thing is (a) it isn‚Äôt documented/impl detail, so would be subject to breaking changes (b) but even more worrisome is that there isn‚Äôt any strong guarantees about rules firing order or if a rule will be fired/retracted/re-fired etc So arbitrarily looking into the *current-session* could cause problems#2018-06-2518:31tony.kayso, we need to know what is in the current session#2018-06-2518:32tony.kayyeah, I understand that, but rule firing order doesn‚Äôt matter in that case‚Ä¶I need to know if a fact is in there right as that rule fires#2018-06-2518:32mikerodI think that http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html relates to this concept of safely ‚Äúupdating‚Äù facts#2018-06-2518:32mikerodalthough it doesn‚Äôt provide an ideal solution#2018-06-2518:33mikerodYou can use things like insert-unconditional! and also :no-loop properties on a defrule to attempt to do things like you are describing. However, I try to avoid those since they become more imperative/order-dependent etc in nature. Also, they can have interactions at odds with the rest of the truth maintenance system.#2018-06-2518:33mikerodIn the post linked above, I mention ‚ÄúApproach 1: Append only updates‚Äù#2018-06-2518:34mikerodthat‚Äôs the easiest, but can run up against memory limits depending on how you are using things#2018-06-2518:35mikerodI didn‚Äôt explain in that post, but I think the ‚ÄúApproach 1: Append only updates‚Äù could be extended to have an external process/fn that cleans up old UpdatingFactSnapshot later (using a query to access them externally).#2018-06-2518:37tony.kaycool, thanks. I‚Äôll read the article. I‚Äôm sure I‚Äôm missing somehting about the TMS that I‚Äôm not clear on üôÇ Hopefully that‚Äôll get me squared up#2018-06-2519:01tony.kay@mikerod so, in the project I‚Äôm helping with, they are not using the logic tracking facility‚Ä¶so invalidating a truth does not auto-retract anything. Perhaps this is a problem that should be addressed as well, but does that affect your answer at all?#2018-06-2519:01tony.kay(e.g. they are using unconditional inserts)#2018-06-2519:02tony.kayoh, I guess you mentioned that‚Ä¶unconditional#2018-06-2519:02mikerodIf you use unconditional inserts, those rules will rely on order of firing#2018-06-2519:02tony.kayI lost track while reading the article üòú#2018-06-2519:02mikerodsince the rules won‚Äôt try to ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù for inconsistencies if a rule fires in the ‚Äúwrong order‚Äù#2018-06-2519:03mikerodbut if you are opting out of truth maintenance, then yeah, you can do unconditional things#2018-06-2519:03tony.kayok, I‚Äôll try to get to the bottom of why they want to opt-out as well#2018-06-2519:03tony.kayI agree it would be nice to reason about things in isolation#2018-06-2519:04mikerod
(defrule udpate-it
  [?old-one <- A (= ?e e) (= ?a a)]
  [?new-one <- NewA (= ?e e) (= ?a a)]
  =>
  (retract! ?old-one)
  (insert-unconditional! (map->A ?new-one)))
#2018-06-2519:05mikerodI‚Äôd worry a bit about pervasive use of unconditional inserts#2018-06-2519:05mikerodit misses out on one fairly large advantage of the rules engine - which is a declarative logical truth maintenance system.#2018-06-2519:05mikerodIf unconditional is used, it‚Äôd be best to a least to try to isolate it to some fringe ‚Äúlayer‚Äù of the logic#2018-06-2519:16tony.kayyeah, these are more derived new facts‚Ä¶but I see your point about invalidating the condition of the rule you‚Äôre running#2018-06-2613:43baptiste-from-parishello friends, is there a way to save the entire LocalSession in a db#2018-06-2614:20dominicmIs this related to #portkey in some way? üòÑ#2018-06-2613:44baptiste-from-parisI mean serialize/deserialise for later analyse#2018-06-2613:45mikerod@baptiste-from-paris there is some support for this. It‚Äôs referred to as durability in the Clara codebase. You do have to implement a protocol though to serialize the working memory facts that are specific to your domain of use#2018-06-2613:46baptiste-from-parisnice üôÇ#2018-06-2613:46mikerodAlso, the durability is currently targeted at being fast for serialization, but especially for deserialization. It doesn‚Äôt attempt to be able to deal with evolution to the stored data structures. If you have a change of rules, or a change of Clara version, sometime you may have to rerun rules and re-serialize. #2018-06-2613:47baptiste-from-parisok, got it#2018-06-2613:47mikerodWell to clarify, any change in rules requires a new run. A change in Clara version may or may not. It just depends on what changes. #2018-06-2613:47baptiste-from-parisyes offcourse#2018-06-2613:48baptiste-from-paristhanks for your time üôÇ#2018-06-2613:48mikerodhttp://www.clara-rules.org/docs/durability/#2018-06-2613:48baptiste-from-pariswas on it, but I had to ask the communuty üòâ#2018-06-2615:22jeremyHow might I accumulate facts of the same type to test if they are: all contain the same value and any contain a certain value?#2018-06-2615:34mikerod@jeremy642 Sounds like 2 separate things, if so#2018-06-2615:34mikerod
;; ?all contain the same value for :val
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?val val)]]


;; ?all has at least one containing :some-val for :val
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A]]
[:test (some #(= :some-val (:val %))
             ?all)]
#2018-06-2615:34jeremyYes üòõ#2018-06-2615:34mikerodHowever, the 2nd accumulator is weird, not sure why you want to accumulate like that#2018-06-2615:34mikerodbut perhaps#2018-06-2615:35mikerod‚Äúany contain a certain value‚Äù sounds like a typical rule match#2018-06-2615:35mikerod[?all <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?val val)]] and this will group each A where they have the same value for val#2018-06-2615:35jeremyYes it is.#2018-06-2615:36mikerodit‚Äôll match and propagate for each grouping possible#2018-06-2615:36jeremyYeah, I think any would be a typical rule match.#2018-06-2615:36jeremyI think my mind was just farting on it.#2018-06-2615:37jeremyBut on the all, does that work if there is a fact of the same type with a diff value?#2018-06-2615:37jeremyA : 1, A : 1, A : 2, it shouldn't match since all As don't have the same value.#2018-06-2615:39jeremyMaybe it'd be more like the 2nd one#2018-06-2615:39jeremyWhere you accumulate them all together, then apply a test to them.#2018-06-2616:34jeremyGot it :thumbsup: Feel so accomplished when a rule works.#2018-06-2619:23jeremyDid any of the visualization stuff that Ryan talks about in his videos get released?#2018-06-2623:34tony.kayI‚Äôm not seeing anything in the docs that would allow you to separate rule sets, and defrule seems global‚Ä¶is there support (planned) for having ‚Äúrule sets‚Äù for different things, or is the idea that you just keep your domains separate by having facts that don‚Äôt cross over and trust that the optimizations in the engine will make it mostly ‚Äúnot matter‚Äù when your rule set gets big because it covers 10 different domains?#2018-06-2700:00mikerod@jeremy642 I believe what you are referring to was a bit of an experimental project and not actively maintained. #2018-06-2700:01mikerodIt maybe this https://github.com/rbrush/clara-tools#2018-06-2700:03mikerod@tony.kay you can provided collections of rule structures to mk-session. It doesn‚Äôt only accept namespaces. You can also define a var that holds a collection of rules and give it metadata :production-seq. So that single var name can be passed. #2018-06-2700:03mikerodDifferent ways to do things. Depending on your goals. #2018-06-2700:04mikerodHowever sometimes it can be fine to combine into larger rule sets. Rules that don‚Äôt match facts won‚Äôt contribute much to runtime. #2018-06-2700:13tony.kayAh, I misunderstood how mk-session worked‚Ä¶my bad#2018-06-2700:54mikerod No problem!#2018-06-2702:22jeremy@mikerod Thanks#2018-06-2717:20jeremyI have a bunch of rules that derive some final state fact. What I run into is that multiple rules might match and in the end I get multiple results. So in the standard decision tree, there is order to the final state precedence. Would it be appropriate to add a priority property to these final state results and then query on that priority to narrow it down to a single result?#2018-06-2717:58mikerod@jeremy642 that is one approach#2018-06-2717:58mikerodI think I‚Äôve answered variations of this question a lot of times, but don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs saved anywhere#2018-06-2717:58jeremyüôÇ#2018-06-2717:58mikerodyou can prioritize rules by building a tiered structure to them#2018-06-2717:58mikerodor you can let them all fire#2018-06-2717:58mikerodinsert some ‚Äúintermediate fact‚Äù#2018-06-2717:59mikerodthen have 1 more rule to accumulate all ‚Äúintermediate facts‚Äù and insert your final fact based on the aggregate of them#2018-06-2717:59mikerodI can give examlpes in a bit if needed#2018-06-2717:59mikerodI guess I have one example of one approach here https://gist.github.com/mrrodriguez/6a6f8373b25d69826b3efe154c928fac#file-clara_tiered_fact_update_rules-clj#2018-06-2718:11jeremyThanks. I'll check it out and play with it.#2018-06-2919:27Daniel HinesHello all. What is the current status of dynamically generated rules in CLJS with Clara? I saw this thread: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/clara-rules/9x-dIBM1hoo, but the last bit of activity was several years ago, and I can't tell where things landed.#2018-06-2920:34mikerod@d4hines I don‚Äôt know of any activity on it really#2018-06-2920:34mikerodRules are compiled in clj. The compiler uses eval#2018-06-2920:35mikerodWhat are you wanting to explore in this regard?#2018-06-2920:38Daniel HinesI know a major goal of Clara is to "take back rules for the developer", but a major goal of a project I'm working on is to be able to update rules on the fly based on changing business logic. It sounds like that would require deploying a new build, correct?#2018-06-2920:39mikerodThe thread you linked to discussed it some, but you could have a server that compilers rules and sends it back to client#2018-06-2920:39mikerodif you are wanting to have a client in cljs#2018-06-2920:40mikerodNot sure what your non-developer constraints are - what would they be editing in?#2018-06-2920:40mikerodeg (1) a repl (2) some sort of browser-based UI etc#2018-06-2920:42Daniel HinesWell, I was definitely leaning towards (2), but having seen an example of instaparse creating clara rules, it might be neat to create a dsl such that the source of truth for the rules is a text file, in which case a fancy UI might not be as necessary.#2018-06-2920:44mikerodYou can make rulesets in a dynamic way#2018-06-2920:45mikerodSo bring in some text files, convert format to Clara rules data format, compile them (and ensure you have the right compiling-context for var resolution etc)#2018-06-2920:45mikerodYou can do mk-session with collections of rule/query structures#2018-06-2920:45mikerodSo they do not have to be bound to Clojure namespaces/vars#2018-06-2920:46mikerodSo you could build a more dynamic process around that.#2018-06-2920:48Daniel HinesI'm not sure I follow, but that's probably due to my unfamiliarity with Clara in general.#2018-06-2921:33mikerodHmm#2018-06-2921:33mikerodI can try to come up with an example#2018-06-2921:43dominicmDoes self hosted Clojure script work?#2018-06-2921:43mikerodnope#2018-06-2921:43mikerodsome Clara namespaces are only clj#2018-06-2921:43mikerod(not cljc)#2018-06-2921:44mikerodIt‚Äôd be cool to make it self-host compatible though üòõ#2018-06-2921:44mikerodadds a bit of a new layer of trickiness to parts of it, macros etc#2018-06-2921:44dominicmYeah. You can build rules in more dynamic ways when useful. #2018-06-3002:27mikerodhttp://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ A bit older post but related shows interesting things that can be done. Another one depending on what kind of setup you ultimately want could involve figwheel I think. I‚Äôve had some success getting live reload to work by redefining the session var in cljs and manipulating the keys in the cljs compiler env that Clara stores productions in. I only had it working for changes to source code though#2018-07-1602:03alex-dixonStupid question time: Is it possible to use Rete with disk storage only for working sets that can‚Äôt fit into memory? Would there be any advantage to using it as part of a database implementation?#2018-07-1608:34wparker@alex-dixon There isn't any reason in principle why you can't use disk storage in a Clara memory implementation. It would obviously be less performant than in memory storage; if every Rete operation resulted in a random disk seek it could be pretty poor at a guess. I've toyed with the idea of a memory implementation dumping overflow to disk before though with some kind of heuristics for what to keep in memory. There could be complications to work through if you're trying to basically serialize random objects too.#2018-07-1618:17alex-dixon> I‚Äôve toyed with the idea of a memory implementation dumping overflow to disk before though with some kind of heuristics for what to keep in memory Heh, I was thinking about the same thing yesterday üôÇ I haven‚Äôt been able to find any papers or mention of Rete being used with a persistence layer. Do you know of any?#2018-07-1619:09wparker@alex-dixon No, I don‚Äôt know of any offhand. My (completely untested üôÇ ) guess would be that avoiding internal retractions from truth maintenance would be a big part of it. Maybe if the data were appropriately structured you could use a local database to back the memory - is that what you were getting at with ‚ÄúWould there be any advantage to using it as part of a database implementation?‚Äù#2018-07-1620:40hiredmanthere is presentation from, uh, maybe it was at a clojurewest, the presenter discusses implementing a rules system on top of a database, it does away with, maybe just alpha nodes, in rete because it expects database indices to do basically the same thing#2018-07-1620:42hiredmanhttps://github.com/threatgrid/naga#2018-07-1817:15alex-dixon@hiredman thanks! The readme says in memory only but plans for persistence with an rdf triple store or graph database. I‚Äôll look into it more#2018-07-1817:22alex-dixon@wparker That was poorly phrased but basically yeah.
