More specifically I‚Äôm trying to figure out whether Clara or rete in general could be implemented as a hybrid in memory and persistent db like Datomic that uses rete for in memory processing as well as for querying persistent data that can never fit into memory. #2018-07-1817:24alex-dixonHaving rules writing to persistent storage would be key too#2018-07-1822:34mikerod@alex-dixon seems doable#2018-07-1822:35mikerodbut not without a bunch of effort if you were going to try to implement a memory that works well/performant doing that#2018-07-1822:35mikerodLong ago, Ryan did an example storm cluster-based Clara impl of memory. it was experimental but did show how memory could be extended potentially#2018-07-1822:38alex-dixonThanks. Yeah I‚Äôve been looking at that. It‚Äôs not clear to me what‚Äôs going on there. Best I could figure out is storm is doing a lot of the work#2018-07-1822:39mikerodyeah, it‚Äôd require storm understanding I‚Äôm sure#2018-07-1822:39mikerodand it isn‚Äôt really the same thing#2018-07-1822:40mikerodYou could certainly try to hook a memory impl up to have facts potentially in slower storage, you‚Äôd just have to deal with that serialization stuff and also the concern of how to make it not super slow#2018-07-1822:40mikerodalso, accumulators are an issue#2018-07-1822:41mikerodif you are dealing in numbers of facts too large for memory, but then you try to do an accumulator that needs to see them all at once#2018-07-1822:42mikerodI watched the naga talk before too. It was interesting. It seemed a bit more special-purposed than Clara, but still cool to think about#2018-07-1822:46alex-dixonI‚Äôm thinking of using RocksDB specifically https://github.com/facebook/rocksdb/wiki/Performance-Benchmarks#2018-07-1823:26mikerodnever saw that one#2018-07-1823:26mikerodlooks like it could be interesting to experiment with the idea though#2018-08-0103:34Garrett HopperDoes it make sense to have singleton facts in my network? Whenver I update one of these I retract the previous fact and insert the updated fact.#2018-08-0113:40mikerod@ghopper maybe something I wrote a while back can go through some of those situations http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2018-08-0113:41mikerodif you are just wanting to skim, perhaps see ‚ÄúApproach 1: Append only updates‚Äù and ‚ÄúApproach 2: Externally managed updates‚Äù sections#2018-08-0114:19Garrett HopperThanks, @mikerod!#2018-08-0821:22jeremy@mikerod Do you know if there is a way to go from Java -> Clojure when rules are keywords and not records/java beans?#2018-08-0821:28ennI have a Clara rulebase that, for comprehensibility reasons, I‚Äôd like to split into ‚Äúphases.‚Äù So, phase 1 gets a bunch of facts, the rules fire, and new facts are generated. Somehow, this becomes the input to phase 2, which fires a new set of rules, generating new facts. Etc. I‚Äôm not sure what the best way is to pass the output of one phase into the next. Originally I was thinking I‚Äôd just take the session from phase 1 and use that as the starting point for phase 2. But unless I‚Äôm missing something, it‚Äôs not possible to load new rules into an extant session. So I guess what I need to do is to just grab all the ‚Äúoutput‚Äù facts out of phase 1 and insert them into a new session for phase 2. Is there a simpler way to do this than by writing (and then executing) a query for each and every fact type?#2018-08-0821:30mikerod@enn > So I guess what I need to do is to just grab all the ‚Äúoutput‚Äù facts out of phase 1 and insert them into a new session for phase 2. Is there a simpler way to do this than by writing (and then executing) a query for each and every fact type? I think this is likely a smoother approach (there is an alternative I can mention in a min) As far as worrying about querying for too many types, maybe you can make a ‚Äúparent‚Äù type for the output types you care about and just have a query on that parent type.#2018-08-0821:32mikerodAnother possibility is to just use one session with all the rules. I‚Äôm not sure what about your logic makes it where you‚Äôd want some rules to be separate from others. Are you worried about them running too early or something, performance?, etc#2018-08-0821:34mikerodI don‚Äôt understand your situation enough, but there is something called ‚Äúactivation groups‚Äù that can also be considered in some cases that may relate to yours https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.18.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L328-L331#2018-08-0821:35ennNo, they‚Äôre all in one session now and it works fine performance-wise. It‚Äôs more about making it easier for the programmer to understand the universe of rules and fact types in play at a given point in the code.#2018-08-0821:39ennAnd making it easy to ensure that an intermediate fact type (used to derive some other final result) does not get inadvertently referenced outside of its intended scope#2018-08-0821:40ennMaybe my whole idea is antithetical to the idea that a rules engine hides some of the order-of-execution concerns of regular code? I‚Äôm not sure.#2018-08-0821:49mikerodYeah, I understand your reasoning then#2018-08-0821:49mikerodYou can separate them to independent rulesets if that helps reasoning#2018-08-0821:49mikerodthere would be a slight cost of taking facts from queries of one session and inserting again into another session, but that may not really be a concern#2018-08-0821:50mikerodbut yeah, order independence is a key idea#2018-08-0821:50mikerodand I‚Äôd also sort of argue that rules should be able to somewhat function in aggregation with one another#2018-08-0821:50mikerodwhere they can all share related information when relevant, but they are also fine when the information they need isn‚Äôt present etc#2018-08-0821:51mikerod> And making it easy to ensure that an intermediate fact type (used to derive some other final result) does not get inadvertently referenced outside of its intended scope I think this is the most interesting concern though.#2018-08-0821:52mikerodIf everything gets lumped together, I can see how it could become problematic if you were wanting to have a better control on scope#2018-08-0821:30mikerod@jeremy642 I don‚Äôt think I understand the question. You want to use rules with ‚Äúkeyword‚Äù sort of type dispatch, but on underlying Java objects? Maybe show a dummy example or something.#2018-08-0821:31jeremyI have rules built on a keyword type dispatch. I wasn't sure if there might be a way to create them from Java.#2018-08-0821:32jeremyMore a question on Java -> Clojure interop I guess than clara-rules. How I might go about creating the necessary type map for clara-rules from Java.#2018-08-0821:33jeremy#2018-08-0821:35mikerod@jeremy642 you can provide a custom fact-type-fn (and ancestors-fn if relevant) http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/fact_type_customization/#2018-08-0821:36mikerodThis may be what you are looking for. e.g. the fact-type-fn could take an arbitrary (Java) object and map it to some keyword/alternative typing system you have within the rules#2018-08-0821:38mikerodA likely incomplete example, but perhaps inspiration to think about.#2018-08-0821:39mikerodI‚Äôm not sure if you already have a custom fact-type-fn or not though. You might since I see you have a map with :weather-fact-type#2018-08-0821:39mikerodClara‚Äôs default is clojure.core/type, which is implemented as (or (get (meta x) :type) (class x))#2018-08-0821:40jeremyYeah I was just thinking of a way to take Java Maps and Convert it to Keyword Key Map in the fact-type-fn?#2018-08-0821:40mikeroddepending on what is priority, you may flip the if above and do alternative things. I was just showing the idea of what could be done at least.#2018-08-0821:40jeremyCurrently the custom fact-type-fn looks for :type or something like that. I'll have to grab the work laptop. This just came to me off the top of my head.#2018-08-0821:41mikerodso for the fact-type-fn you just need to return the type (a keyword in your case I think)#2018-08-0821:41jeremyYep#2018-08-0821:41mikerodbut if you want to also work with the Java data as clj maps, like this: (< (:temperature this) 0), you‚Äôd have to convert the facts themselves coming into the session#2018-08-0821:41mikerodwhich is different than the fact-type-fn#2018-08-0821:42jeremyYeah that's how the rules work with them currently.#2018-08-0821:42mikerodthe fact-type-fn doesn‚Äôt transform the facts that are used during constraint matching. It just gives a value that is used as the ‚Äúfact type‚Äù partitioning of the network#2018-08-0821:42jeremyHmm ok#2018-08-0821:42mikerodI‚Äôve wrote Clara rules a bunch with external Java type data#2018-08-0821:43mikerodWhat I‚Äôve done typically is to have some fairly basic rules to match those types and apply any sort of useful filtering if performance was a conern#2018-08-0821:43mikerodbut then just had the RHS insert a clj type to use in all the rest of the rules#2018-08-0821:43mikerodso the rule was sort of a transformation/mapping from Java to CLJ data structures#2018-08-0821:44jeremyAhh, might be a decent idea.#2018-08-0821:45mikerod
(defrule find-java-things
  [JavaThing (= x ?x)]
  =>
  (insert! {:fact-type :thing
            :x ?x}))
#2018-08-0821:45mikerodbut if you need the JavaThing in the end, for the query consumer#2018-08-0821:45mikerodyou can attach it to the facts#2018-08-0821:45mikerodeither as a first-class field, or metadata#2018-08-0821:45jeremyI was thinking about keeping the rules in a seperate jar. And allowing Java applications and Clojure applications import and use the rules in that jar. The question was just how to define the facts when the rules were all in Clojure and no beans were provided that allowed Java to create them.#2018-08-0821:45mikerod
(defrule find-java-things
  [?j <- JavaThing (= x ?x)]
  =>
  (insert! (with-meta {:fact-type :thing
                       :x ?x}
             {:source ?j})))
#2018-08-0821:46mikerodIf it‚Äôs a classpath issue, where you won‚Äôt know the types ahead of time you‚Äôll have to be more tricky#2018-08-0821:46mikerodand also, you are going to hit reflection stuff I‚Äôd think that way#2018-08-0821:47mikerodor you write your core set of rules in a type-independent rule set/session#2018-08-0821:48mikerodand you have to write a separate ruleset that does know about specific type mapping parts - or maybe you don‚Äôt need rules for that transformation layer at all.#2018-08-0821:49jeremyI thought about just writing a interface for Java to call and create facts, insert into engine. But the rule engine itself would most likely need to be run in clojure and not instantiated from Java so it's pretty self contained. It'd save me the hassle of dealing with java vs clojure types.#2018-08-0821:51jeremyJava doesn't really need much control over the engine. Just to insert facts and get response from the queries.#2018-08-0822:09mikerodyeah, hard to say without fully understanding the setup you have#2018-08-0916:47wparker@jeremy642 @mikerod this might be useful in combination with Mike‚Äôs suggestion of using Java objects as facts that you could translate into Clojure objects if desired: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/java/ Basically Clara has a wrapper that you can use instead of needing to do the interop glue work yourself. In case you weren‚Äôt already aware.#2018-08-0916:49wparkerAlso FYI Clara will use the bean properties on Java objects to allow field use by name in the DSL, that isn‚Äôt just for records#2018-08-0916:50wparkeri.e. Object A has a ‚ÄúgetB‚Äù method, you can just refer to ‚Äúb‚Äù in a condition like [A (= b some-value)]#2018-08-0916:51jeremyMy rules implementation does not use Java types for fact types. So the question was how to handle the interop.#2018-08-0916:51jeremy
(defrule new-return
  "The service is a new return."
  [:approval-status (= (:value this) :new-return)]
  =>
  (insert! {:type :rule/result
            :id :new-return
            :priority 2}))
#2018-08-0916:52jeremy
(r/insert {:type :approval-status :value :new-return})
is how I would insert using clojure.#2018-08-0916:53jeremyWithout changing the rules to beans or defining the facts with defrecords. The big ?? was how to allow Java to create maps with the keyword format that matched the rules properly.#2018-08-0916:54wparkerPerhaps write a rule that matches on Java maps and translates them, then inserts the result? That way you could just insert the Java map into the session#2018-08-0916:55wparkerThat rule could then just not do anything if only Clojure maps were in the session#2018-08-0916:56jeremySo that's one thought. I could write new rules that's sole job was to convert say a Java map if matches to a clojure map.#2018-08-0916:57jeremyI haven't progressed on any implementation yet. Been busy but I have some ideas to play with.#2018-08-0916:57jeremy:thumbsup:#2018-08-0917:02wparkerNote that Clojure maps also implement Java‚Äôs map, so you‚Äôd need to guard against an infinite loop there (i.e. require that it a Java Map but not a Clojure map)#2018-08-0917:14jeremyThanks#2018-08-0917:15jeremyI noticed that clara-rules is on the tech radar by thoughtworks. https://www.thoughtworks.com/radar/languages-and-frameworks#2018-08-0922:57mikerodSaw this one back when it was new on there. Pretty cool though! #2018-08-1006:30henrikI‚Äôm working on an ingestion pipeline for scholarly material. It takes XML files and adds them to a (Datomic) database. There‚Äôs a ton of little decisions to be made along the way. Depending on the publisher, the type of material, the presence of related material already in the database, the subject matter, the presence or absence of a myriad of little attributes in the file itself, and so on, the ingestion process behaves differently. This means tons and tons of conditionals all over the place, and it quickly gets hard to get an overview. I‚Äôve been contemplating ways to extract this decision making process into its own place. Would Clara be a suitable tool for this?#2018-08-1010:21wparker@U06B8J0AJ that sounds like a plausible use-case. Much depends on how much involved the logic is - IMO a rules engine has some upfront cost to bring in especially if the team hasn‚Äôt used one before, but at a certain complexity of business logic it helps a lot. Clara does what it can to help by ‚Äúplaying nicely‚Äù with the rest of the Clojure ecosystem e.g. by being simple Clojure code rather than an entirely separate framework with its own IDEs etc., but it still is a different way of thinking and is a nontrivial component to introduce to a system. FWIW the analysis in the ThoughtWorks radar linked above seems on-target to me. My guess would be that something like you describe would work best with a rules engine if large chunks of logic can be computed before needing to return to the stateful pipeline, but as always it is hard to say since so often it is the details that are most important.#2018-08-1017:50devnhowdy folks#2018-08-1017:50devnim interested in partial condition matches#2018-08-1017:50devni want to answer the question: what conditions didn't match for a given rule#2018-08-1017:51devni'm not sure this is possible at the moment#2018-08-1019:30wparkerCould you give a concrete example @devn? I'm not sure what exactly you mean; session inspection has some things that might help.#2018-08-1020:09devn@wparker I'm looking to answer questions of "what LHS conditions for which rules weren't satisfiable?" My understanding may be incorrect, but I seem to recall the condition matches from session inspection not including information on when a rule's conditions were partially satisfied.#2018-08-1020:10devntruth: I keep avoiding working out a tracing listener setup that will give me the Real Ultimate Power‚Ñ¢ I desire#2018-08-1020:12devn@alex-dixon I am reminded of a previous conversation that was had here about making something akin to precept-devtools work with clara. However, I am failing to remember details. Which parts of precept-devtools would not be possible without modification to clara?#2018-08-1020:44alex-dixon@devn Pretty much all of it would need redone since it‚Äôs so Precept specific‚Ä¶#2018-08-1020:45alex-dixonClara‚Äôs listeners API is what you‚Äôre looking for though. You should be able to see every operation the rule engine does#2018-08-1020:45alex-dixonI‚Äôve only ever used the terminal node ones but they have everything‚Ä¶alpha activate, alpha retract‚Ä¶stuff I can‚Äôt remember#2018-08-1020:46alex-dixonIf you‚Äôre interested in CR or rule engines whatsoever it‚Äôll pay off I promise üôÇ#2018-08-1223:14devn@alex-dixon thanks for the reply. My coworkers and I are working on a (for now) private library called carla. We have a graph view and a rule summary view, a ‚Äúwho produces‚Äù and ‚Äúwho depends on‚Äù for facts. A tracing listener is coming.#2018-08-1223:16devnThe question that is most useful to answer for us is often ‚Äúwhy didn‚Äôt this occur?‚Äù (Aka what is the chain of dependent rules that weren‚Äôt satisfied, with a root cause)#2018-08-1223:16devnI‚Äôm reading a lot of precept code this weekend. Thanks again for putting out a great example of what can be achieved with tooling.#2018-08-1300:59alex-dixon@devn rofl Carla #2018-08-1301:00devnIt makes requires confusing, but hilarious #2018-08-1301:00alex-dixonThat sounds awesome. Hickey had a recent podcast interview where he seemed to emphasize the role of what a thing provides and what it requires #2018-08-1301:07alex-dixonTesting for a rule not firing seems hard but important from a practical standpoint #2018-08-1301:07alex-dixonFrom a more impractical one I guess we shouldn‚Äôt be writing rules expecting them to fire#2018-08-1710:38Petrus Theron@henrik I'm using Clara for something similar (low-cost housing bond approval process) and I'm curious how you are modelling things like review/verification requests#2018-08-1710:39Petrus Therone.g. certain kinds of documents need to be reviewed and/or signed by certain kinds of people (e.g. Mortgage Lawyer, vs Transfer Lawyer)#2018-08-1714:37Petrus TheronIs anyone using Clara or FactUI on its own, but with Datomic purely as a persistence layer? I'm dealing with really small-scale volume of records, I just want rapid dev and flexible workflows.#2018-08-1716:23mikerod@petrus I don‚Äôt understand what you are asking for there. Do you mean to store the state of the rule network working memory or just the resulting facts?#2018-08-1716:23mikerodThe resulting facts, can be whatever you want and stored wherever you want.#2018-08-1716:23mikerodSo I think you may be asking about persisting the state of the rule network‚Äôs working memory, but not sure if that‚Äôs what you meant.#2018-08-1918:14clyfeANN https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav#2018-08-1918:15clyfeClaraEAV is a thin layer over Clara-Rules API that simplifies working with EAV triplets#2018-08-1918:15clyfeMain benefit is updates are local to the attribute, maybe some of you find it useful.#2018-08-1920:05mikerod@claudius.nicolae nice. I‚Äôll have to take a look at that some more but seems pretty cool. I‚Äôve heard of people using(or wanting to) EAV data in Clara and this looks like it can help#2018-08-1920:09clyfeThanks! Credit mainly goes to the precept project, mine is just a rehash. Nevertheless it may be of use.#2018-08-1920:12clyfeThe guide explains it all pretty well https://cljdoc.xyz/d/clyfe/clara-eav/0.1.5/doc/guide#2018-08-1921:56mikerodOh nice. I‚Äôll read it. And yeah I knew Precept had done some interesting stuff around this. #2018-09-0617:48mikerod@claudius.nicolae (I believe you were the one who introduced this, but history has lost it) I finally read through the docs of https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav . I think it looks cool. I plan to read through some of the impl some to see how you‚Äôve accomplished some of this. I think the EAV-as-facts concept is a good one, especially in the Clojure community it seems. I know libs like precept have been doing it a while. It‚Äôs good to see a standalone impl now.#2018-10-0421:46ryanbrushJust a heads up: we've had a number of performance improvements and bug fixes merged to master since our last release, so it seems worthwhile to push another one. Unless there are objections, I'll plan on pushing 0.19.0 out of master in the near future.#2018-10-0422:58ryanbrushAnd Clara 0.19.0 is released and up on Clojars! You can see the changelog for details: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#2018-10-2314:07dhruv1hello. In clara, how can i write recursive queries?#2018-10-2314:07dhruv1here is an example of the data I have:#2018-10-2314:07dhruv1
{:type :foo
 :desc "'Foo' node"
 :parent :D}

{:type :D
 :desc "'D' node"
 :parent :C}

{:type :C
 :desc "'C' node"
 :parent :B}

{:type :B
 :desc "'B' node"
 :parent :A}

{:type :A
 :desc "'A' node"}
#2018-10-2314:09dhruv1here is what i would like the output of the query to look like:#2018-10-2314:10dhruv1
'(:?node {:type :foo
          :desc "'Foo' node"
          :parent :D}
         
       :?parents [{:type :D
                      :desc "'D' node"
                     :parent :C}

                    {:type :C
                     :desc "'C' node"
                     :parent :B}

                    {:type :B
                     :desc "'B' node"
                     :parent :A}

                    {:type :A
                     :desc "'A' node"}])
#2018-10-2314:11dhruv1is this possible with a clara query?#2018-10-2315:47eraserhdNot with just a query, you'll need to introduce some facts.#2018-10-2315:51eraserhdSo you'd have one rule that's (heavily abbreviating the code): [:test (no-children? ?node)] => (insert! (->TreeRep ?node ?node))). And one that's [:test (children? ?node)] ?children <- (acc/all) :from [Node (= parent ?node)] => (insert! (->TreeRep ?node (add-children ?node ?children))).#2018-10-2315:52eraserhdAssuming your graph is acyclic. If it isn't, this will be bad.#2018-10-2315:53eraserhdIt might be doable with one rule, actually. But the point is, AFAICT, there's no way to recurse without inserting facts.#2018-10-2316:01dhruv1Ah understood. #2018-10-2316:02dhruv1Will give that a go. Thank you!#2018-10-2316:12eraserhdOh, you want to (acc/all) :from [TreeRep ...], probably.#2018-10-2316:13eraserhdYou could also do this with a custom accumulator, but that would be much harder, I'm guessing.#2018-10-2316:16mikerod@eraserhd I was thinking along those same lines#2018-10-2316:16mikerodabout having to introduce some facts to model it#2018-10-2316:25eraserhdBy the way, üëã clara people! We are starting to rely heavily on this for work, and it is a good thing.#2018-10-2317:04mikerodNice. What sort of things are you using it for (if you can say) and clj or cljs? #2018-10-2317:16eraserhdclj, only#2018-10-2317:16eraserhdWe are storing data in Datomic, and importing the facts, and deriving a bunch of stuff from them.#2018-10-2317:17eraserhdThis includes constraint validation, what we are calling "synthetic attributes", which are computed attributes.#2018-10-2317:17eraserhdThis is all business data about the online degree programs we are hosting.#2018-10-2317:17eraserhdAnd this system drives the stand up of new systems.#2018-10-2317:20mikerodoh that‚Äôs cool#2018-10-2317:21mikerodthere was a datomic ‚Äúdatom‚Äù integration lib with clara#2018-10-2317:21mikerodwas that related or something you‚Äôve seen?#2018-10-2317:22eraserhdWe built our own, and we have a library we are attempting to Open Source ü§û#2018-10-2317:22eraserhdNot specifically about Datoms#2018-10-2317:22mikerodah ok#2018-10-2317:22mikerodI‚Äôm trying to find the github link I had for that before, but was interesting#2018-10-2317:23mikerodbut would be really interesting if you open sourced hah#2018-10-2317:23mikerodah yeah, it was this clara-eav https://github.com/clyfe/clara-eav#2018-10-2317:35eraserhd@U0LK1552A This actually looks pretty neat. Our library does a different thing, regarding bulk loading facts from datomic and caching intermediate sessions to save work. It seems like we could use them together.#2018-10-2317:39mikerodinteresting#2018-10-2317:39mikerodcaching intermediate sessions seems interesting too#2018-10-2317:39mikerodseems like some durability stuff I messed with before#2018-10-2317:40mikerod(well I wrote that stuff in clara originally to try some things out)#2018-10-2413:42eraserhdI found a paper about the LEAPS algorithm, which apparently out-performs RETE by using gasp laziness. I wonder if any LEAPS stuff was incorporated into Clara?#2018-10-2413:43eraserhdThis one: http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/download?doi=10.1.1.96.5371&amp;rep=rep1&amp;type=pdf#2018-10-2414:02mikerod@eraserhd I don‚Äôt see the date on this some reason#2018-10-2414:02eraserhdIt's old, like 94 or something.#2018-10-2414:02mikerodbut I know I‚Äôve read about LEAPS before.#2018-10-2414:03mikerodIt is comparing to the traditional rete used in the OPS5 and perhaps a few others at the time#2018-10-2414:03mikerodthings were quite a bit different in those I believe#2018-10-2414:03mikerodClara takes advantage of batch-oriented fact propagation#2018-10-2414:03mikerodI am of the opinion that that is the biggest perf win#2018-10-2414:04mikerodover any sort of laziness. However, Drools (popular JVM/Java based rules engine) went to a custom algo they decided was sufficiently different enough to get a new name#2018-10-2414:04mikerod‚ÄúPHREAK‚Äù#2018-10-2414:04mikerodin Drools 6, they wrote some good stuff on it#2018-10-2414:04mikerodbut it was meant to be lazier and to do things like cut parts of the rete tree off when they aren‚Äôt needed#2018-10-2414:05mikerodthe unfortunate part of that upgrade was that Drools went from eager and single fact propagation to this lazier and batched propagation#2018-10-2414:05mikerodand I think the batching is the bigger win#2018-10-2414:05mikerodSo the topic of being lazier in Clara has came up before#2018-10-2414:06mikerodbut hasn‚Äôt been done since it isn‚Äôt clear how much you really gain from that over the batched propagations.#2018-10-2414:06mikerodthat is assuming you have queries that you intend to use#2018-10-2414:06mikerodif you had like 10 queries and were only going to want to perform 1 of them a lot of the time or something like that, then there may be a bigger win to delaying things#2018-10-2414:06eraserhdI'm only a little way in, and I haven't seen the laziness part yet (even though it's claimed in the abstract). It so far has claimed that the biggest win is not needing to materialize facts in memory. I don't understand it yet.#2018-10-2414:07mikerodalso, keep in mind, these older papers#2018-10-2414:07mikerodthey have some good material for sure, but have to be aware of the environments there were dealing with#2018-10-2414:07mikerode.g. sometimes they are really emphasizing using minimal memory (was more constrained then), or higher allocation costs etc#2018-10-2414:08mikerodit‚Äôs just something to be aware of, still good material out there and most of it is pretty old#2018-10-2414:08mikerodalso, sometimes things are explaining a situation that is most helpful when dealing with a large number of rules, other times its for dealing with a large number of facts, and occasionally perhaps a large number of both is discussed#2018-10-2414:09eraserhdyup. But I read things like this as a hobby, honestly.#2018-10-2414:09eraserhdI'm not suddenly suggesting that we must implement this üòÑ#2018-10-2414:09mikerodno, it‚Äôs good to discuss and to think about#2018-10-2414:09eraserhdIn fact, it would be neat if there was a bibliography for Clara Rules.#2018-10-2414:10mikerodquite a bit of perf-related work has been done in Clara already#2018-10-2414:10mikerodsome of that was just impl details and other things were tweaks to propagation or often accumulators#2018-10-2414:11eraserhdNeat... I got that impression. It performs super well for us.#2018-10-2516:55wparker@eraserhd Agreed with @U0LK1552A‚Äôs previous comments - Another interesting way that this played out (both myself and Mike spent a while doing perf optimizations on Clara) is that in practice, it turned out that even for large cases (hundreds of thousands of facts/tens of thousands of rules) the constant factors seemed to be most important. Hashing turned out to be a large percentage of work performed for example. A lot of these optimizations (on the Clojure side) are in the memory.cljc namespace with lots of Java interop etc. That said, this was in use-cases where we didn‚Äôt really have lots of data that we were just going to end up discarding, and there‚Äôs definitely cases where more laziness could be useful.#2018-10-2414:12mikerodClara make some small mention to background here https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Introduction#the-rules-engine#2018-10-2414:12mikerodThe paper referenced there is http://reports-archive.adm.cs.cmu.edu/anon/1995/CMU-CS-95-113.pdf#2018-10-2414:12mikerodIt is concerned with the ops system I think. It‚Äôs long and not all that relevant to current stuff, but there are some nice fundamental chapters in it#2018-10-2414:13mikerodStarts with a very basic description of a simple rete impl, and then discusses some interesting ways to improve it, such as left and right unlinking#2018-10-2414:14mikerodand Drools has a lot of extra stuff going on that is left out of Clara, but they do have some good docs on approaches https://docs.jboss.org/drools/release/6.2.0.CR2/drools-docs/html/HybridReasoningChapter.html#ReteOO#2018-10-2414:16mikerodThat‚Äôs their newer one. Not the same as Clara, but there are some commonalities in some the ideas. It also may explain some of the deficiencies in the overly simple approach traditionally taken.#2018-10-2414:26eraserhdNice, thank you! I've queued all that up for bedtime reading.#2018-10-2414:38mikerodsure, sorry it isn‚Äôt super organized - reference dump#2018-10-2422:15jvtriguerosI'm trying out Clara, but I'm hitting an issue, perhaps I'm using it wrong, here's the simplest snippet that shows my issue: 
(defrecord Request [resource])

(defn condition
  [x y]
  (= x y))

(defrule some-rule
  [Request (condition ?resource resource)]
  =>
  (println ?resource))

(mk-session)
I'm getting an error about ?resource not being bound, however if I replace condition with = this works. I didn't see anything in the Boolean Expressions documentation about not being able to use other functions, however if that's the case, how does one go about doing this?#2018-10-2422:21souenzzo
[Request (= ?resource resource)]
[:test (condition? ?resource)]
=>
(prn ?resource)
#2018-10-2513:25ethancProbably not relevant and more of an FYI, but if the condition? is simply equality it could be done with a third argument to =. 
(r/defrule some-rule
  [Request (= ?resource resource "GET")]
  =>
  (println ?resource))
#2018-10-2513:42souenzzo
[Request (= resource "GET")]
=>
(prn "GET")
Onde it will only match if resource is GET üòÖ#2018-10-2513:43souenzzoyou can also do 
[?request <- Request (= resource "GET")]
=>
(prn ?request)
Will print the "full record"#2018-10-2513:59jvtriguerosThanks @U3KC48GHW ! This is actually something that I did need (for a different rule)#2018-10-2422:21souenzzo@jvtrigueros#2018-10-2422:33jvtriguerosHow does this work? In this contrived example condition takes two arguments but here it's just one. :thinking_face: Or perhaps you could point me to the literature for this#2018-10-2422:39souenzzo(= ?resource resource) it not a function call. it just a DSL to bind the value of resource (form record) to ?resorce (symbol)#2018-10-2422:47jvtriguerosAh gotcha, thank you! This points me in the right direction, I'll continue to play with Clara üòÉ#2018-10-2423:58souenzzosome functions you can use like (contains? #{:foo} resource)#2018-10-2513:33eraserhd@souenzzo wait, really? Is there a list of functions that Clara handles specially?#2018-10-2513:34eraserhdI mean, knows how to join, other than =?#2018-10-2513:46souenzzoI use = and contanis?. I learned it when I did not understand how clara works then never search for it.#2018-10-2513:57jvtriguerosAs a newcomer it‚Äôs not super clear which functions are built-in. This is definitely an advanced user library :)#2018-10-2514:22ethancI'm believe that the only functions that Clara handles specially are the equality expressions: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/compiler.clj#L213-L223#2018-10-2514:36mikerodYeah, = is the only special thing#2018-10-2514:37mikerodIt still means = too, but it can also be used for unification purposes/binding variables#2018-10-2514:37mikerodnothing is special about contains? (or anything else)#2018-10-2514:54wparkerAgreed with other comments that it is just = that is special when used as a top-level value in the constraint to create/join on bindings (starting with ?)#2018-10-2514:54wparkerthat has perf benefits in that those joins are done by hashing#2018-10-2514:55wparkerotherwise you can use arbitrary functions and they should behave the same as elsewhere#2018-10-2514:55jvtriguerosWhile reading the docs, it goes from straightforward to advanced very quickly. In http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/, I fully understand the free-lunch-with-gizmo because there's no ? binding, you're matching that an item is :gizmo, but then in the sophisticated example: 
(defrule grant-discount-months  
  [Purchase (= ?month (get-month date))]
  [DiscountMonth (= ?month month)]
  =>
  (insert! (->GrantDiscount :for-month ?month)))
The = doesn't have the same meaning (in the Purchase condition) as the straightforward example, but it does in the DiscountMonth condition?#2018-10-2514:57wparkerit has the same meaning in that it requires equality, but clojure.core/= won‚Äôt be called#2018-10-2514:57eraserhdNot quite.#2018-10-2514:58eraserhd= is unification. So, it requires the expression to be true. If there are variables in it that do not yet have a value, the variables are "assigned" such to make it true. If the variables are already assigned, it works like clojure.core/=#2018-10-2514:58mikerodThat‚Äôs a reasonable way to think about it#2018-10-2514:58mikerodbut Clara may optimize on it#2018-10-2514:58mikerodwhen unifying on a ? binding#2018-10-2514:58mikerodit uses it to build the rete graph#2018-10-2514:59jvtrigueros> = is unification This distinction is makes sense!#2018-10-2514:59mikerodmakes a hash-based match for nodes known to be doing = based bindings#2018-10-2514:59mikerodbut = is also just = when equating to constant values etc#2018-10-2514:59eraserhdIf there are many possible values for a variable, it can assign each value consecutively.#2018-10-2514:59mikerodyou can do [Purchase (= ?month month "JAN")] for example#2018-10-2514:59eraserhd(*and what @mikerod is saying is true, I'm only describing the semantics, it doesn't actually work like that.)#2018-10-2515:00mikerodyeah, semantics are most important#2018-10-2515:00mikerodjust making sure someone may not get carried away and try to print within clojure.core/= or something and wonder why it isn‚Äôt always called hah#2018-10-2515:00mikerodunlikely#2018-10-2515:01mikerod[Purchase (= ?month month "JAN")] binds the value of the field month to ?month, when (= month "JAN") (via clojure.core/=)#2018-10-2515:01mikerodOf course in this case, ?month would just be ‚ÄúJAN‚Äù#2018-10-2515:01mikerodso perhaps something a bit more useful than that üòõ#2018-10-2515:03wparkerThis page on the docs might be of interest: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/hash_joins/#2018-10-2515:04jvtriguerosWoah secret docs#2018-10-2515:06wparker‚Äú`=` is unification‚Äù => correct. Note that this is for top-level constraints though, when nested inside a constraint that isn‚Äôt the case i.e. [A (= ?b c)] vs [A (stuff (= ?b c))]#2018-10-2515:06wparkerHah not secret, just nested inside the ‚Äúperformance optimization‚Äù page#2018-10-2515:07wparkerOr more precisely on my last, that is true if you‚Äôre trying to create new bindings - it‚Äôs still unification semantically if you‚Äôre using bindings from before#2018-10-2515:09jvtrigueros> [A (= ?b c)] vs [A (stuff (= ?b c))] Yes! This is what I ran into immediately, I wanted to use my own equality function, but I got pointed to using :test instead.#2018-10-2515:10jvtriguerosBTW thank you all for helping me understand this!#2018-10-2515:23mikerodsome of the semantics around = can get weird, since it kind of plays 2 roles depending on context#2018-10-2515:23mikerodlike when how you can‚Äôt nest it within another call to do a unification#2018-10-2515:23mikerodbut most of the time not a big deal#2018-10-2522:01jvtriguerosIs it possible to transform the output of defquery or would I need to do that in a wrapper function? The RHS of a defrule is just Clojure but that doesn't seem to exist in defquerys#2018-10-2522:11mikerod@jvtrigueros defquery has no RHS#2018-10-2522:12mikerodyou can create facts in rules with defrule that do some transformations so there is less to transform once you get it from the query#2018-10-2522:12mikerodbut the query return val will just be the maps with the binding keys to the values they are bound to in the query#2018-10-2522:17jvtriguerosThanks! In the query docs, it suggests one can write a query like so: 
(query session get-by-last-name :last-name ‚ÄúJones‚Äù)
How would one write the defquery for that? 
(defquery get-by-last-name
  [:last-name]
  [?person <- Person (= last-name :last-name)])
#2018-10-2522:19jvtriguerosI'm only able to create defquerys that have ?: 
(defquery get-by-last-name
  [:?last-name]
  [?person <- Person (= last-name ?last-name)])
But then the query call wouldn't be using :last-name but :?last-name#2018-10-2615:52ethanc@jvtrigueros that is correct, the parameter of the query should be :?last-name, and would work similar to a filter on the ?last-name binding in the lhs of the query. Where did you find that example, it should probably be updated?#2018-10-2616:02ethancnvm, i found it: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L51#2018-10-2616:07jvtriguerosSweet! Thanks üôÇ#2018-10-2617:52eraserhdI'm curious about a number of Clara's language restrictions. For example, not being able to use :and inside not, not being able to use :and on the rhs of an accumulator.#2018-10-2617:53eraserhdAre these technical limitations of the underlying matching engine, or front-end limitations?#2018-10-2617:58zyloxya that one is a tangled web of very complicated issues...let me see if i can find the logged issues on them because there is a lot of good conversation on them#2018-10-2618:02zyloxhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/373 this is one of them#2018-10-2618:02zyloxhas a lot of references to other issues#2018-10-2618:03mikerodYep @zylox has a good point on the issues around the complexities. #2018-10-2618:05mikerodIn general negated conjunctions and rete have complexities due to the structure of the network#2018-10-2618:07mikerodMost of the times if things get weird in a rule doing this stuff I think you can typically just break the logic up across more rules to keep the structures simpler #2018-10-2618:52eraserhdHow cheap are intermediate facts? I mean, clojure records themselves are cheap, but is memory used by facts interesting? They are alpha-pruned, I assume.#2018-10-2618:53eraserhdThe idea of a NegatedCondition, for example, is that going to be more memory. (Also, I‚Äôm not sure how that could work, because it would need to join on a variable number of bindings.)#2018-10-2619:13mikerod@eraserhd they aren‚Äôt much overhead beyond the fact object itself#2018-10-2619:14mikerodYou can make a rule that does the conjunction and inserts a fact if it is true. Then a rule with a negation on that fact. Clara actually sometimes automatically does something similar to that. #2018-10-2619:15mikerodIntermediate facts in memory are about the same as just making a new record of whatever is what I meant. Cpu timewise just depends on what it interacts with. The actual working memory insert and retract operations are pretty fast (optimized it quite a bit)#2018-10-2619:15mikerodNot sure if that addresses all your questions there#2018-10-2619:15eraserhdI think so.#2018-10-2619:32mikerodWhen writing rules I typically go pretty heavy on intermediate facts#2018-10-2619:33mikerodWith preference on making simple rules that models smaller concepts at a time and then compose them together for main outcome models for query. If that makes any sense. #2018-10-2619:36zyloxsame here#2018-10-2620:06jimbobwhat if i have three rules that act on type A and they all output type B while ‚Äúmutating‚Äù some state in the fact. will the final fact be type B with all the ‚Äúmutations‚Äù?#2018-10-2620:12zyloxany time you mutate a fact in the rules network youve opened pandoras box#2018-10-2620:13zyloxif you mean creating new intermediate facts, you will have 3 B facts at the end#2018-10-2620:13zyloxbut the foundation of the rules network is immutability.#2018-10-2620:14zyloxyou could have a rule that pulls in those 3 B facts (probably with an accumulator), and inserts a FinalB fact that has their combined state. ive seen this pattern used to solve a number of things#2018-10-3118:32eraserhdHi! So we're debugging a performance issue, and it seems like, in our example, fast-token-compare taskes 142 seconds of self time, while PriorityQueue.remove() takes 139 seconds of self time.#2018-10-3118:33eraserhdIt's not clear from VisualVM's sampling, but it looks like this referring to the PriorityQueue.remove(Object) method, which is consistent with the fast-token-compare times.#2018-10-3118:34eraserhdThis method is linear for priority queue. It should be possible to wrap PriorityQueue to make it log(n) by checking when values are extracted. Is there some reason this won't work?#2018-10-3118:36eraserhdAlternately, are we doing something wrong to get runtime dominated by PriorityQueue.remove(Object)?#2018-10-3119:06mikerod@eraserhd > Alternately, are we doing something wrong to get runtime dominated by PriorityQueue.remove(Object)? Seems like there is a lot of thrash of rules getting activated, but then subsequently ‚Äúdeactivated‚Äù#2018-10-3119:06mikerod> This method is linear for priority queue. It should be possible to wrap PriorityQueue to make it log(n) by checking when values are extracted. Is there some reason this won‚Äôt work? I don‚Äôt understand what this is and how it‚Äôd make it log(n).#2018-10-3119:07mikerodand lastly, fast-token-compare may be slowing down due to large tokens in these rules that are struggling with if they are satisfied/not satisfied#2018-10-3119:07mikerodperhaps from large data accumulated via something like (acc/all)‚Äôs or similar#2018-10-3119:08eraserhd@mikerod if remove/1 stores objects in a hash set, then remove/0 and add/1 skip removed tokens, remove/1 becomes O(1) and I think remove/0 is still O(log N)#2018-10-3119:09mikerodWe mostly avoid hashing objects#2018-10-3119:09eraserhdDijkstra's algorithm is frequently implemented like this, because removing from the priority queue is expensive.#2018-10-3119:09mikerodbecause then you hit perf barriers with slow hash code impl‚Äôs#2018-10-3119:09mikerodand often that comes down to the facts being used in the session#2018-10-3119:10mikerodin the particular case where the prio queue is used, the object to remove is a new instance too, so wouldn‚Äôt be able to have a reusable cached hashcode#2018-10-3119:11eraserhdHmm.#2018-10-3119:11mikerodnot to say it isn‚Äôt worth consideration at any time, just saying hashing isn‚Äôt always as cheap as it seems#2018-10-3119:12mikerodfast-token-compare avoids deep equals most of the time too#2018-10-3119:12mikerodit uses identity-based equivalence as a first-pass, so via identical? in clj semantics#2018-10-3119:12mikerodand typically that is all that is needed to find things#2018-10-3119:12mikerodduring the fire-rules loop at least#2018-10-3119:12mikerodI‚Äôve seen this problem of large tokens being slow though#2018-10-3119:13mikerodthe activation stuff is what uses the prio queue, it has to do with how when rules are satisfied, they are ‚Äústaged‚Äù as available to have their RHS action executed at some future time#2018-10-3119:13mikerodit is a prio queue since you can have precedence on which rules should be staged ahead of one another - e.g. :salience#2018-10-3119:16mikerodI think there are some related issues out there (though not explained the same) https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/385#2018-10-3119:16mikerodwell, that‚Äôs the only one I see at the moment#2018-10-3119:17mikerodI know I‚Äôve messed around with this sort of problem before though, not sure I ever had a good answer#2018-10-3119:17mikerodsometimes you could just avoid a rule setup that is causing it though#2018-10-3119:17eraserhdThose stats look very much like ours.#2018-10-3119:17mikerodyour hashing thing could be attempted at least, just have to consider a lot of things if it ends up looking like a good path#2018-10-3119:18mikerodthe issue above talks about a ‚Äúdistinct accumulator‚Äù, I think that may be overly specific#2018-10-3119:18mikerodprobably a more general problem#2018-10-3119:18mikerodand I‚Äôm fairly sure you have big tokens involved#2018-10-3119:18mikeroda big token would come from a rule left-hand side (LHS) that had a lot of facts associated with a single activation of the rule#2018-10-3119:21mikerodTake for example something like 
(r/defrule big-activation-maker
  [?xs <- (acc/all) :from [X]]
  =>
  (do-stuff ?xs))
#2018-10-3119:21mikerodnow if you can get into a situation where the set of all X changes a lot#2018-10-3119:21mikerodand there are a lot of Xs in working memory overall#2018-10-3119:21mikerodthen this rule may keep activating/cancelling/re-activating, as the set of X grows - and each time there is a big token comparison to do these removals#2018-10-3119:22mikerodin a rule as simple as above, it typically wouldn‚Äôt thrash though#2018-10-3119:22mikerodMost of the time, the network‚Äôs ‚Äúbatched propagation‚Äù semantics would lead you to a situation where all the X are around in one go with only 1 rule activation resulting#2018-10-3119:22mikerodbut certain setups can cause thrashing when more conditions and things are involved#2018-10-3119:23mikerodperhaps the distinct accumulator case was a situations like this one, I just don‚Äôt remember#2018-10-3119:27eraserhdThis sounds like there is one thing we can write as a custom accumulator to avoid retriggering a whole slew of rules.#2018-10-3119:27mikerodperhaps#2018-10-3119:28ethancor play with salience, though as a last resort#2018-10-3119:28mikerodyeah, sometimes that‚Äôs useful#2018-10-3119:29mikerodsometimes you can look at the rules and sort of see where an accumulator rule may be getting retriggered in multiple phases of insert#2018-10-3119:29mikerodand try to prevent that, there is salience to help, as well as just potentially logical structuring#2018-11-0114:21eraserhdOK, so we've just found something really weird with accumulators: retract-fn is never used, though documented in acc/accum.#2018-11-0114:21eraserhdBecause retract-fn does not appear in the Accumulator record.#2018-11-0114:21eraserhdI'm going to guess this is not how it's supposed to work?#2018-11-0114:35mikerod@eraserhd odd that it isn‚Äôt on the record definition, not sure I know why there, but it is called when provided (well expected to be)#2018-11-0114:35mikeroddo you have a custom accumulator you are trying to work with?#2018-11-0114:36mikerodor did you try to add this to the existing acc/accum#2018-11-0114:36eraserhdWe are getting ready to build an accumulator with accum, and I was looking for how to extract those functions again so we can test drive it, and I found that retract-fn gets lost.#2018-11-0114:38eraserhduhhh, whoa. I had no idea that you could add arbitrary fields to a defrecord with map->X.#2018-11-0114:39mikerodyou are using clara.rules.accumulators/accum to build an accumulator?#2018-11-0114:39eraserhdNo, doing nothing but research at this point.#2018-11-0114:40mikerodyeah, defrecord in clj is often considered more of a perf optimization for a common group of fields you access, they work as regular maps in many cases, and having any number of keys is one of them. the keys not defined on the record are just accessed slower on the impl side#2018-11-0114:40mikerodand you can‚Äôt reflect for them etc#2018-11-0114:40mikerodclara.rules.accumulators/accum supports passing the :retract-fn in#2018-11-0114:40mikerodhave to be a bit careful on how you do retraction though if I recall correct#2018-11-0114:41mikerodif you don‚Äôt provide one, Clara will default to rebuilding things minus the facts retracted#2018-11-0114:41mikerod:retract-fn is meant for when you know how to more efficiently remove a retracted fact from your reduced structure#2018-11-0114:42mikerodIf you had an example situation where you think :retract-fn wasn‚Äôt used though, that‚Äôd be easier to look at and walk through#2018-11-0114:43mikerodohhhh, there may be cases where it isn‚Äôt used at all#2018-11-0114:44mikerodchecking, I‚Äôm forgetting things#2018-11-0114:44eraserhdWe have the ability to do more efficient retraction and combining, so we're writing a custom accumulator to get around the thrashing from yesterday. It also allows us to get rid of some intermediate facts that are frequently retracted.#2018-11-0114:47mikerodwhen you use the accumulator#2018-11-0114:47mikerodwhat sort of form does it have#2018-11-0114:48mikerod[?acc <- custom-acc :from [<this part>]]#2018-11-0114:49mikerodAre you using some joining conditions there like [X (test-something ?y z)], or just [X], or equality based join, like [X (= ?y z)]?#2018-11-0114:49mikerodThe point is there are 2 variants of accumulate nodes in the rules engine, one for the simpler join cases using = or no joining at all#2018-11-0114:49mikerodthat one is optimized for those cases because they can be done better#2018-11-0114:50mikerodthe other variant handles the rest, which are arbitrary other joining criteria#2018-11-0114:51mikerodAt this point, if I recall all the impl details correctly, providing your own :retract-fn is only a potential perf optimization. If you use the optimized, easier variant of an accumulator, it will be used, otherwise, it is ignored because it can‚Äôt be used from within the more generalized case#2018-11-0114:51mikerodor really, it can‚Äôt be used to help in the more general case, it would only be slower#2018-11-0115:10ProbablyJodyDoes the accumulator maintain the reduced value before being passed to the :convert-return-fn for the purposes of handing it to the :retract-fn?#2018-11-0115:10ProbablyJody(assuming both are defined)#2018-11-0115:12ProbablyJodyTo rephrase, should the :retract-fn expect the output of the :reduce-fn or the :convert-return-fn?#2018-11-0115:18mikerod@jody > To rephrase, should the :retract-fn expect the output of the :reduce-fn or the :convert-return-fn? It should expect the output of :reduce-fn#2018-11-0115:19mikerodit‚Äôs part of the ‚Äúreducing phase‚Äù, :convert-return-fn is only done after everything else#2018-11-0115:19mikerodUnder the current implementation (would have to double check), I don‚Äôt think working memory for the accumulate node ever maintains the :convert-return-fn value actually, just the :reduce-fn/`:retract-fn` returned value state#2018-11-0115:20mikerodthe reason is that the :convert-return-fn value is not considered useful to use for any subsequent changes#2018-11-0115:20mikerodthe reducing state is#2018-11-0119:31eraserhdIs it possible for an accumulator to get a net negative, e.g. more retractions than insertions. I'm wondering because maybe this is implied by the "combine" function?#2018-11-0120:03ProbablyJodyI believe the combine function is just a performance optimizer for the reduce phase. I‚Äôd expect a net-negative to represent a bug in truth maintenance. I might be mis-understanding the question though.#2018-11-0120:48eraserhdI mean, obviously, if you combine all batches, you can't have more retractions than insertions. But depending on how you are batching, you could have one batch with, say three insertions and another batch with two retractions. That would mean that two retractions were applied to the initial value in that case.#2018-11-0120:50eraserhdAlternately, you could say that Clara enforces that retractions occur in the same batch as insertions. I'm not sure how it could, though I don't understand how this is being called.#2018-11-0120:56eraserhdI guess one possibility is that Clara only uses this for joins where each reduced value is a selection of attributes, such that insertions and retractions are always sorted into the same batch. That actually makes the most sense.#2018-11-0121:39mikerod@eraserhd when retracting facts, with respect to an accumulator, the accumulator is only re-ran on facts that were retracted and were found to have previous matches#2018-11-0121:40mikerodso the facts retracted and processed by an accumulator, should only be facts that were processed by the same accumulator before, when they were inserted#2018-11-0121:41mikerodif you batched up retracts of facts that were not inserted yet, the accumulator wouldn‚Äôt need to retract anything#2018-11-0121:41mikerodand it wouldn‚Äôt try#2018-11-0121:41mikerodfacts are considered the ‚Äúsame‚Äù via =#2018-11-0121:42mikerodbut respecting cardinality of them#2018-11-0121:42mikerodie insert 2 = objects, retract 1, you still have 1 left#2018-11-0121:42mikerodif the retracted is identical? to 1 of = instances, that‚Äôd like be the one removed - but I think that‚Äôs more due to perf optimizations than anything#2018-11-0122:12eraserhd@mikerod OK, that makes sense. Thanks!#2018-11-0211:56wparker@eraserhd Agreed with @mikerod that the only facts which will be retracted are those that were provided before. Regarding the inefficiencies of accumulation with non-hash join conditions, I think that‚Äôs a more general problem than the :retract-fn actually. For example, I believe when a new fact matching the accumulation condition is added the previous facts will have the accumulator rerun on them in their entirety, whereas the simple case with no joins or only-hash based joins will store the previous result and add onto it. Contrast the following in AccumulateNode, the simple case: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1156 with the equivalent in AccumulateWithJoinFilterNode, the more complex case: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1525#2018-11-0211:58wparkerThe tricky thing is that Clara‚Äôs memory is set up to store the elements (facts coming into the current condition) and tokens (facts from ancestor conditions) separately, but in the case of these complex accumulator joins you‚Äôd really want to store them together for maximum efficiency. I don‚Äôt think there is any fundamental reason why this couldn‚Äôt be done though, it#2018-11-0211:58wparkerwould just be the work to do it and get it right/performant, plus durability changes probably if the memory structure changed#2018-11-0212:00wparkerClara does avoid downstream thrash from the complex accumulators still when the result didn‚Äôt actually change - see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/182 and the changes made there - but the internal calculation has some room for improvement perf-wise#2018-11-0212:03wparkerIf you want to understand how the accumulator logic works, some basic terms:#2018-11-0212:03wparker-right-activate: new facts matching the condition at hand#2018-11-0212:03wparker-right-retract: removal of facts matching the condition at hand#2018-11-0212:04wparker-left-activate: facts were added to ancestor conditions and need to be passed down the network#2018-11-0212:04wparkerleft-retract: facts were removed from ancestor conditions and need to be passed down the network#2018-11-0212:05wparkerAccumulateNode - simple no-condition or hash-join-only accumulation conditions#2018-11-0212:05wparkerAccumulateWithjoinFilterNode - accumulation condition with arbitrary filter logic taking facts from ancestor conditions as input#2018-11-0212:09wparkerprobably the best source of truth there is the code, fortunately it is a well commented area imo though i‚Äôm biased as i wrote many of those comments#2018-11-0212:10wparkerto be clear: when I say to understand how it works, i mean the algorithms at play - the docs should be sufficient for the behavior and if they‚Äôre not they should be improved#2018-11-0212:10wparkerhopefully this helps#2018-11-0212:11wparkerif you‚Äôre trying to get a case with complex accumulator joins to perform better, frankly my first reaction would be to use salience most likely#2018-11-0212:12wparkerif you‚Äôre using truth maintenance without side effects, the salience shouldn‚Äôt impact actual behavior so it doesn‚Äôt make the code harder to read/understand in that respect#2018-11-0213:44eraserhd@wparker thanks! This is all good info.#2018-11-0213:48eraserhdI'm guessing, in [Foo (= ?a a)] [?acc <- (acc/whatever) [Bar (= ?a a)]], Foo would be left and Bar would be right?#2018-11-0215:46mikerod@eraserhd basically yes#2018-11-0215:46mikerodleft is the matched-token-so-far in a rule LHS#2018-11-0215:47mikerodtokens consist of all facts involved in a match#2018-11-0215:48mikerodIn a LHS [A] [B] [C] if we were looking at the network node for the [C] condition, incoming C facts would be right-activate, left-activate to this node would be matched up A+`B`s - represented as a ‚Äútoken‚Äù#2018-11-0217:24wparkerAnd for the [B] condition, incoming B facts would be right-activate, left-activate would be tokens passed down from the [A] condition. For the [A] condition the right-activate would be incoming A facts, the left-activate would basically be a dummy placeholder. Does that make sense?#2018-11-0621:22eraserhdqueries are prioritized last (in terms of salience), I hope, right?#2018-11-0622:06mikerod@eraserhd I‚Äôm can‚Äôt think of a reason where it‚Äôd matter how queries are ‚Äúprioritized‚Äù#2018-11-0622:06mikerodthey just receive matches from facts that are currently in working memory#2018-11-0622:07mikerodpriority with :salience is about ordering when a rule is eligible to be fired#2018-11-0622:07mikerodaka perform the action specified on its RHS, so this concept does not apply to queries#2018-11-0622:08eraserhdhmm, so if I have rules that insert and retract things that are queried, the query results aren't updated by the firing of a pseudo-rule?#2018-11-0622:11eraserhd(bad sentence, but hopefully the question is clear)#2018-11-0622:29eraserhdOK, I see. They are their own thing.#2018-11-0623:07mikerodNot sure I understand that question. But in general always fire rules before query. Not sure if that helps. Hah#2018-11-0714:06wparker@eraserhd Not sure I understand the question either, but the API with queries is that if you call the query function on a rules session after firing rules, the query results will reflect all insertions/retractions prior to the fire-rules call. Under the hood, queries are basically a rule LHS and the results are computed as part of fire-rules - the query function in clara.rules really is more of a ‚Äúretrieve query results‚Äù function than a ‚Äúrun query‚Äù in that way. If your concern was performance, there are optimizations that could be made around deferring some query matching work to later in the fire-rules, thus avoiding the need to retract query matches that are invalidated, but that hasn‚Äôt been implemented. I‚Äôve found it isn‚Äôt often an issue and in the few cases where it was it was fairly easy to work around.#2018-11-1413:40nlessaHi, I am having performance problems in my set of rules. Probably some of the rules are performing bad. Is there any way to profile the time spent by each rule when firing-rules in a session? I couldn't find any obvious way to get this info using the inspect api.#2018-11-1414:17wparkerThe inspect api is targeted at understanding the end result of the rules, not performance. For performance problems you‚Äôll probably want a profiler or perhaps tracing. Tracing shows all the internal steps of the rules engine, and can produce a lot of data that is probably best sorted through with the REPL rather than manual inspection, but if a single rule is constantly re-firing it can make that clear. I‚Äôd probably start with a profiler though. Another approach could be to take separate parts of your use-case and see if you can find a simple subset with the perf problem, particularly one you can share that would be easier for someone else to look at.#2018-11-1414:17wparkerAre you on Clojure or ClojureScript?#2018-11-1414:20nlessaThanks, @wparker! Clojure.#2018-11-1416:40mikerod@nlessa and feel free to share profiler sample results with me (or anyone interested) (with anything propriety removes). Sometimes just seeing the Clara internals in a profiling snapshot can help point someone in the right direction. Not always though. #2018-11-1519:43eraserhddsl seems to parse a thing :exists as an operator, but it's not documented. This sounds like a missing feature we've wanted... is it true?#2018-11-1519:50ennGood catch on the missing docs. There was some discussion on the list when it was implemented, see https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/130 for details.#2018-11-1519:53mikerod@eraserhd @enn Yeah, if it isn‚Äôt documented seems like it probably should be#2018-11-1519:53mikerodgood find on the relevant issue#2018-11-1522:55eraserhd@claudius.nicolae We are going to start heavily using clara-eav, and we have three big pieces of functionality to contribute back.#2018-11-1522:56eraserhdWill you be at Clojure/conj?#2018-11-1920:07eraserhdI've been reading Rete algorithm stuff, and I've been wondering why I haven't seen references to this paper in them: http://citeseerx.ist.psu.edu/viewdoc/summary?doi=10.1.1.6.5507 -- (I couldn't remember the name of the paper until it appeared on the Clojure list just recently.)#2018-11-1920:08eraserhdIt seems like this is a bunch more thought that applies to how to build an alpha network than I've seen mentioned before.#2018-11-1920:16mikerod@eraserhd not familiar with this one.#2018-11-1920:17mikerodlooks like it‚Äôd take a bit to parse through it to see how the ideas relate to other rete things that are out there#2018-11-1920:23eraserhdI have yet to see anything about optimizing the order of alpha tests, except for specific things like hashing 8 ways to find an alpha memory when using triplets.#2018-11-1920:24eraserhdAFAICT, there's no cases of filtering with user tests before storing in an alpha memory, even, and I presume that's because it's hard to know when you can do that and not duplicate memories?#2018-11-1920:29mikerodClara‚Äôs alpha network partitions on how facts match the ‚Äútype‚Äù criteria first#2018-11-1920:30mikerodif you have alpha-side only constraints like [A (< x 5)]#2018-11-1920:30mikerodthose will be filtered as they come in and will not be stored in alpha mem if they don‚Äôt match#2018-11-1920:31mikerodand if you have variable bindings (via the overloaded = semantics), eg. [A (= ?x x)], facts in the alpha memory will be stored in a hash lookup keyed by that variable binding#2018-11-1920:31mikerodthose are the main alpha-side network details I can think of#2018-11-2017:02souenzzoCase A 
[:test (my-pred?)]
[MyFact [a] (= a ?a)]
=>
....
Case B 
[MyFact [a] (= a ?a)]
[:test (my-pred?)]
=>
....
With A, clara will call my-pred? at mk-session With B, clara will call my-pred? at fire-rules There is docs about this behavior?#2018-11-2017:45ethancI'm not sure there is any document referencing that behavior. It would be an odd scenario to have a test node that is independent of the other nodes in a production. A typical scenario would make that test node dependent on some upstream fact, thus making the test node evaluate some time during fire-rules#2018-11-2018:09souenzzo@ethanc can I disable it?#2018-11-2018:12ethancI'm not sure what you mean by disable it. From your example above i am assuming that my-pred? is some sort of stateful check, and if that is true then i would recommend against imbedding that sort of logic in the network itself, maybe moving it to the RHS of the rule.#2018-11-2018:13souenzzoIt's not statefull. it access a *dynamic* env var üôÇ#2018-11-2018:43ethancThe use of a dynamic var would likely be considered stateful, as the state of the var would impact the result from the predicate. Clara makes some pretty big assumptions on statelessness, as in it will not reevaluate conditions that it "doesn't have to". Air quoting doesn't have to because clara determines what must be reevaluated by direct or indirect actions(Truth Maintenance) on the session, ie insertion or retraction of facts. That being said, if there is statefulness in a session's rules and for some reason that state changes then all bets are off when it comes to the validity of the outcome of said rules.#2018-11-2018:45mikerodPerhaps you could instead insert facts that represent the same thing that this dynamic var encapsulates#2018-11-2018:45mikerodhowever, evaluating anything at ‚Äúcompile time‚Äù of mk-session seems weird to me. I‚Äôd have to see it reproduced probably to understand what may be happening there#2018-11-2020:23souenzzohttps://gist.github.com/souenzzo/e38e600d486532308084c2bba0a9b3e9 @mikerod#2018-11-2020:25souenzzo#tools-deps is awesme to report bugs ‚ù§Ô∏è#2018-11-2021:36ethanc@souenzzo, I was looking at your example, it seems that the side effect that you mention is due to: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L2050 which is used during the creation of the session as you described: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L264 The left activate in that snippet seems to be aimed at rules that have no LHS, ex: 
(r/defrule insert-sentinel 
  =>
  (r/insert! (->SomeFact)))
the token being passed is empty. This "bootstrapping" operation is likely done because these productions wouldn't have an alpha-root for them to be triggered later. In your scenario: 
(defrule rule1
  [:test (my-pred? :rule1)]
  [Fact (= a ?a)]
  =>
  (prn ["rule1" ?a]))
the first node in the beta-roots would be the test-node, as mentioned before this is not a normal pattern as test nodes are usually dependent on prior facts. When the conditions are reversed the test node would not be evaluated as it would be a child node of a join node.#2018-11-2021:44souenzzoPROPOSAL: If is possible to reach LHS, then run the RHS. If there is no how to reach LHS, then do not run anything in RHS. Is it possible? Is it reasonable? Should I open a issue? I think that I can try a PR.#2018-11-2022:54ethanc@souenzzo I'm not sure i fully understand the intent of your proposal. The determination of RHS evaluation is done currently by percolating facts down the nodes until they ideally enter a ProductionNode, assuming all conditions are met. To do this we would still have to evaluate the truthiness of the LHS.#2018-11-2621:07eraserhdHey, where‚Äôs the source for the Clara Rules site? I don‚Äôt see it on gh-pages or master in the clara-rules repo. #2018-11-2621:25mikerod@eraserhd https://github.com/cerner/clara-site#2018-11-2621:43eraserhdoh, thanks#2018-11-2622:21mikerodno prob, hopefully it has enough info there to see how to work with it#2018-11-2700:51eraserhdwaving Don‚Äôt know what it‚Äôd look like, but I‚Äôm at the Conj and would love to meet any/all people using or contributing to Clara.#2018-11-2700:53jvtriguerosSad I‚Äôm missing Conj this year :( sounded like some really good stuff was gonna be announced#2018-11-2704:36mikerodI won‚Äôt be at conj this year sadly. I know a few Clara contributors here are though. #2018-11-2919:42devnwaving #2018-11-2919:42devnnot a contributor, but was a satisfied user for a few years #2018-12-0516:23eraserhdI'm in the process of documenting :exists, and I see that there is a thing called :condition which also isn't documented.#2018-12-0516:49mikerod@eraserhd what is this :condition that you are referring to?#2018-12-0516:49mikerodwhere do you see it?#2018-12-0516:54eraserhdIn compiler.clj... I just realized that I didn't look at the context. It might be a compiler internal.#2018-12-0516:54ethancthat sounds right#2018-12-0516:55ethanci would think that we surfaced it in the dsl proper#2018-12-0516:57ethanc*wouldn't#2018-12-0516:57ethancsorry about the confusion#2018-12-0517:20mikerodyeah, should just be internal compiler stuff#2018-12-0517:20mikerodthat‚Äôs what I thought :condition was#2018-12-0613:29hjrnunesHello! I'm trying to get some explanations for my rules, but clara.tools.inspect/explain-activations doesn't print anything at all. With clara.tools.inspect/inspect I get a map but :fact->explanations is nil: 
{:rule-matches
 {{:ns-name validator.typing,
   :lhs
            [[:not {:type validator.typing.LowCardinality, :constraints []}]],
   :rhs     (do (c/insert! (->ColType :t))),
   :props   {:salience -100},
   :name    "validator.typing/text",
   :doc     "The column is textual when cardinality is not low"}
  (),
  ...
  :query-matches ...
  :condition-matches
  {{:type validator.typing.ColInfo, :constraints [(= 1 non-num-vals)]}
                                                                   (),
   {:type validator.typing.LowCardinality, :constraints []}        (),
   ...
  :insertions
  {{:ns-name validator.typing,
    :lhs
             [[:not {:type validator.typing.LowCardinality, :constraints []}]],
    :rhs     (do (c/insert! (->ColType :t))),
    :props   {:salience -100},
    :name    "validator.typing/text",
    :doc     "The column is textual when cardinality is not low"}
   (),
   ...},
  :fact->explanations nil}
#2018-12-0613:30hjrnunesIs this a problem with my rules?#2018-12-0613:30hjrnunesAlso, how do I interpret this data?#2018-12-0613:37hjrnunesOK, I re-read the docs, and I can't understand what is meant by 'logical insertions". Isn't this inserting a fact on the RHS of a rule? The one above is inserted in the RHS of a rule, but there's no explanation for it...#2018-12-0615:07mikerod@hjrnunes logical insertion is the default c/insert! in the RHS of the rules#2018-12-0615:08mikerodit is referring to insertions that are managed by the truth maintenance system (TMS) of the engine. If the rule is found to later become unsatisfied in its LHS, the logically inserted fact will be automatically retracted.#2018-12-0615:08mikerodI don‚Äôt think that is your main question though, you are wondering why :fact->explanations is nil above#2018-12-0615:12mikerodWhat you have above, if you look at :insertions, it is saying that the rule :name validator.typing/text had no facts inserted as a result of it.#2018-12-0615:12mikerodAlso, :rule-matches says similar, there were not matches for the rule#2018-12-0615:13mikerodSo the result of this is that you have no facts that were inserted from a rule, so there are no :fact->explanations to show#2018-12-0615:13mikerodPerhaps you can show how you ran this rule.#2018-12-0617:25hjrnunes@mikerod thanks! I'll take a better look at the inspect result and rules tomorrow based on your feedback to see if I get it#2018-12-0617:25hjrnunesif not I'll come back with a fuller example#2018-12-0617:37mikerodsounds good#2018-12-1020:13eraserhdAFAICT, I have a situation where a [:not [:or A B]] is being ignored on a rule. Any thoughts about how to troubleshoot this?#2018-12-1020:32mikerod@eraserhd there are certainly some issues that can happen with negated complex conditions. #2018-12-1020:32mikerodCan find some in the github issues #2018-12-1020:33mikerodOne thing I‚Äôd do is to not combine it all to see that things work#2018-12-1020:35mikerodI believe syntax is [:not [:or [A] [B]]]#2018-12-1020:35mikerodBut perhaps you were simplifying#2018-12-1020:35mikerodOr I‚Äôm wrong hah#2018-12-1020:47eraserhdI'm definitely simplifying. We're working on making a small reproduction. Maybe it'll go away, or we'll figure out we're doing something boneheaded. :D#2018-12-1020:57mikerodCould do 2 not conditions for that one right#2018-12-1020:57mikerodBut in general Clara compiler will try to convert things into disjunctive normal form. #2018-12-1020:58mikerodSometimes there may be issues with doing this when variable bindings are used across clauses that are moving around. #2018-12-1020:58mikerodIt may or may not relate to your issue. I just think there were perhaps still a few edge cases pointed out in some gh issues outstanding#2018-12-1020:59mikerodI often will just advocate for breaking more complex expressions into separate rules that have intermediate facts between them to recreate the logic you are looking for#2018-12-1021:00mikerodGenerally will lead to less confusion and more transparency in introspection since you can look at the intermediate facts. #2018-12-1021:00mikerodOften perf is fine or better that way too, but that can depend. #2018-12-1317:34eraserhdSo, I should follow up. Clara was working correctly. We had an extra rule spelled weirdly enough to defy grep.#2018-12-1317:36mikerodOh good I suppose then. Hah#2019-01-0820:11eraserhdHad some discussions about performance for our use cases, and I made a bunch of assumptions. 1) In terms of inserts/retracts and fire-rules, Clara is single-threaded and does not take advantage of parallelziation. 2) Working set size and memory bandwidth dominate CPU speed.#2019-01-0820:12eraserhdDo those sound accurate?#2019-01-0820:28mikerod@eraserhd (1) seems accurate enough; I think (2) isn‚Äôt clear enough to me to say yes/no#2019-01-0820:30mikerodThe CPU is typically dominated by the number of constraints being evaluated against the working set of facts. So yes to that part I believe. What do you mean by memory bandwidth?#2019-01-0905:44devnI think they are saying what I might assume to be true. Large numbers of facts coupled with large numbers of rules are likely to create memory pressure as they scale in number. But, I‚Äôll go on record as saying I doubt physical limits are a bottleneck when it comes to performance in Clara. Mechanical sympathists in the audience?#2019-01-0915:07wparkerAgreed with (1), with the proviso that one could create multiple sessions and get parallelization that way. Regarding (2), in part I'd have to give the annoying-but-true answer that much depends on the structure and size of your rule/fact set. For many use cases, particularly on clj since it has gotten most of the perf optimization, perf likely is good enough to be a non-issue. CPU can be a concern, especially for rulesets with lots of truth maintenance work. When you say memory bandwidth, do you just mean memory use or the actual speed of retrieval of data from RAM/the CPU cache? It isn't clear to me how you'd optimize the latter effectively running on top of the JVM, but TBH I haven't thought about that level of optimization in the context of Clara. I suspect there's still much lower hanging fruit to work on in term of perf improvements.#2019-01-0915:09eraserhd@mikerod by memory bandwidth, I mean memory bus speed. If the working set is larger than cache, I assume the speed constraint is loading the data to the CPU, not number crunching.#2019-01-0915:10eraserhdAnd the way to optimize it is to choose a different AWS instance type :D#2019-01-0915:25mikerodI see. Thanks for clarifying #2019-01-0915:26mikerodYeah. All of this can contribute. The underlying hardware solution would likely be a last resort time. But if you are seeing a perf issue and can get profiler sampling data that could be useful. #2019-01-0915:30mikerodThere are also some ways to look at tracing output to get a sense of count of times parts of the network were evaluated. Sometimes you can look for outliers there #2019-01-0915:53wparkerKeep in mind that the CPU cache will hold more than just what you think of as the data e.g. routines of the JVM itself, methods from the Clojure runtime, Clara itself, etc. If you were trying to make the cache efficient that might dominate the actual ‚Äúdata‚Äù you‚Äôre working with. I‚Äôm a bit skeptical that that‚Äôs your dominating performance factor though - agreed with Mike that a profiler snapshot showing what‚Äôs taking time in Clara would be helpful.#2019-01-1015:05mauricio.szaboDoes clara supports creation of a session and firing rules in different threads? I'm having an exception trying to do it: 
Exception in thread "async-dispatch-24" java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: find not supported on type: clara.rules.engine.Token$reify__26254
#2019-01-1015:28mikerod@mauricio.szabo I‚Äôd expect it to be ok. Can I see (1) more stack trace and (2) an (perhaps simplified) example of how you are setting up for this?#2019-01-1016:32mauricio.szaboOk, I'll run some code here and then give you the results#2019-01-1017:29wparkerAre you creating more than one session at a time? The compiler uses eval calls internally, and the Clojure compiler itself isn‚Äôt thread-safe.#2019-01-1017:37mikerodyeah, this is why I‚Äôm looking for some example of how it is being tried#2019-01-1018:08mauricio.szabo@U0KRSVDHR I've tried creating more than one, and don't creating it, and they both gave me the same error#2019-01-1018:10mikerod@mauricio.szabo can you give at least an outline of hwo you are doing this#2019-01-1018:10mikerodlike how you create the session, and then how you distribute it to other threads#2019-01-1018:11mikerodI‚Äôm guessing the other threads have the same classloaders too?#2019-01-1018:11mikerodan example would make that easier to track through#2019-01-1018:12mauricio.szaboOkay, just give me some minutes üôÇ#2019-01-1018:13mikerodoh, no problem. not time sensitive (for me at least) hah#2019-01-1018:53mauricio.szabo@U0LK1552A I'm running the code in the following way: 
(let [session (-> (mk-session 'events-reports.reports.deferred
                              'events-reports.reports.normalize-data
                              :fact-type-fn :fact))
      res (jdbc/query db "SELECT * FROM my_table WHERE ...")
      location-ids (map :id res)]

  (doseq [id location-ids]
    (async/go
     (println "Emitting for" id)
     (jdbc/with-db-connection [db @smart/db]
        (let [facts (search-facts db id)
              rows (-> session
                       (insert-all facts)
                       (fire-rules)
                       (query detailed-anual-report)
                       (->> (map make-detailed-anual-row)))]
         (println "Saving for" id)
         (save-rows rows))))))
