Perhaps *e in REPL after you see this or something?#2019-08-0418:10mikerodOh. How is db defined? Is it a field on either a record/type/class named TransactionSettings?#2019-08-0418:12mikerodBased on the form trying to be compiled there it looks like Clara cannot resolve what db is for that class so it is assuming it‚Äôs just a symbol resolving to something in the namespace stacks.laws.db/db #2019-08-0714:04hadilsThanks @mikerod ! I am creating an empty session at this point. That seems to resolve these errors. #2019-08-0714:24mikerodHmm. Interesting. Well feel free to ask if you have more questions. #2019-08-0720:29sparkofreasonIf the only thing that changes in the LHS of a rule is an accumulator value, is it correct that the rule won't fire if the collection of facts matching the accumulator condition change?#2019-08-0720:35ethancI would think that if an accumulator saw a new value, and the previously accumulated objects changed that there would be work that the rhs would have to do. Though I might be misunderstanding your question#2019-08-0720:36sparkofreasonThat's how I want it to behave, but I have a distant recollection that it doesn't actually work that way. Been awhile since I've played with clara.#2019-08-0720:42ProbablyJody@dave.dixon, are you thinking of the retract-fn‚Äôs behavior?#2019-08-0720:42sparkofreasonCould be. Possible I'm just writing my accumulation clause wrong or something, because sometimes it does seem to behave as you described.#2019-08-0720:53ProbablyJodyAh, I think this might help: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/ce65c5071a271905786449db1190687ee40e4624/src/test/common/clara/test_accumulation.cljc#L1121#2019-08-0721:22mikerod@dave.dixon in current version of Clara (and several before) the rule will not continue to propagate if the accumulated value hasn‚Äôt changed according to = See lines like https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/engine.cljc#L1200#2019-08-0721:24mikerodSo specifically if the accumulators result from the :convert-return-fn is = to what it was in the previous round of accumulating fact matches, propagation stops - which would imply no RHS action being triggered/activated#2019-08-0721:25mikerodThe tests near what Jody pointed too could be enlightening on some more semantics though. I agree#2019-08-0721:26mikerodThere are quite detailed github issues out there that also discuss these semantics when we added the related changes. #2019-08-0721:48sparkofreason@mikerod Thanks. Not exactly sure what I was thinking of. My actual problem was that I was hacking at something trying to make it update in place rather than letting truth maintenance do the lifting. Need to get back to "thinking TMS" üòâ#2019-08-0721:52mikerodYes. No mutate in place. That‚Äôll indeed cause issues. #2019-08-0800:26sparkofreasonThink I hit another issue trying to update in place. I thought I could get away with it for unconditional facts, but it appears that when I have multiple LHS bindings on a rule that does a retract! followed by an insert-unconditional!, the RHS fires for all bindings, so the retracts all occur before other rules fire that would potentially invalidate the LHS on the first rule after a subset of firings, based on those retractions.#2019-08-0801:50mikerod@dave.dixon if you get into the business of doing unconditional things, you‚Äôll have to control rule order more. This can be done with salience and possibly ‚Äúblocker‚Äù fact patterns. #2019-08-0815:19sparkofreasonIt seems like avoiding this sort of thing can be a guiding principle for data modeling. For example, the existence of an entity might be unconditional, but the facts describing that entity may have more detailed logical relationships. Trying to group those facts as attributes under a single entity fact map or record leads to the headaches I'm encountering. But maybe if I separate them so that they can be separately inserted/retracted, things will be cleaner. Giving clara-eav a try for this purpose.#2019-08-2813:10griersonShould I run side effectful things (database/email) in the RHS of a rule. Or should I insert a new fact, query the session, and do side effectfs based on the query result?#2019-08-2813:45ethancThe latter is recommended, Clara makes no promises on the number of times that the RHS will be executed before reaching steady state.#2019-08-2813:57griersonThank you @ethanc, I thought that might be the case but just wanted to clara-fy :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing:.#2019-09-1014:12mbraggHi. Im having a play around with Clara and seeing if it‚Äôll fit our use case. One of which is to know which Rule(s) failed. I can see the inspect function gives loads of nice info for all the activations; what could I do if i wanted to know which Rules were not triggered and why?#2019-09-1014:18mikerod@mbragg I think that will be a bit of a challenge with a forward-chaining approach to rules#2019-09-1014:19mikerodif you have more specific questions - you can model that as rules and queries#2019-09-1014:19mikerodbut just to find out something like ‚Äúwhat was missing that you would have needed to reach certain goals/conclusions‚Äù is more of a backwards chaining strength (ie goal-driven) I‚Äôd say#2019-09-1014:19mikerod‚Ä¢ clara is based around the rete algo which is a forward-chaining (ie data-driven) approach Good references for further reading: 1) https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/54af/b81b814acea73450430b4dabd0fc5c13732a.pdf 2) http://iips.icci.edu.iq/images/exam/artificial-intelligence-structures-and-strategies-for--complex-problem-solving.pdf (section 8.2 Rule-Based Expert Systems)#2019-09-1014:20mikerodyou can make some progress of course with inspection - you can see what did happen, and subtract that from all the rules you know exists to find which were left out#2019-09-1014:21mikerodyou can also make more rules in some cases, perhaps even systematically (and programmatically) that try to capture the ‚Äúnegative‚Äù cases#2019-09-1014:21mikerodeg. if I have a rule rule a => insert b, then also make a rule rule not(a) => insert z#2019-09-1014:22mikerodof course it can be more difficult than that with mult-condition joins, negation, and accumulators involved#2019-09-1014:33mbraggMany thanks @mikerod That all makes sense. diffing the activated vs non-activated rules & using inspection does feel a little hacky, It seems like I should either re-think the problem and model it in a forward-chaining manner, or maybe not use clara and implement some sort of backward-chaining model. Thanks again!#2019-09-1018:33devn@mbragg at my previous gig, we found that doing what @mikerod mentioned was sufficient for our observability purposes. (Namely, we generated negative cases for certain types of rules, and created targeted queries to aid in observability.)#2019-09-1018:42mbraggThanks @devn yeah I‚Äôm having a think about that too#2019-10-0420:19jjttjjIs the support for map types documented anywhere? I found this: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/6 but it seems to use some outdated parts of the api (`mk-query` etc)#2019-10-0420:24hiredmanhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Guide#fact-types#2019-10-0420:25jjttjjthere it is, thanks!#2019-10-0421:10mikerod@jjttjj you‚Äôll see it used fairly often in test cases within clara as well, such as https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L1129#2019-10-0422:17Eduardo MataHow can I apply rules to my Records and modified them if needed then return all the Records that either change or did not change to the caller?#2019-10-0422:17Eduardo MataI am using an atom but maybe that is wrong?#2019-10-0500:04mikerod@contact904 Ideally, you‚Äôd make a new type of fact for the ‚Äúmodified‚Äù record and/or ‚Äúprocessed record‚Äù and just query for those types#2019-10-0500:04mikerodthey can still hold the original, real modified record, so you could still access it#2019-10-0615:31jjttjjAre clara sessions intended as throwaway cheap things meant to replace an elaborate cond? I have a long running process that receives events every few seconds, and needs to make decisions based mainly on that new data point, and to a lesser extent some previous, accumulating state, but not previous events in the stream. Which one is the default approach with clara: a new session for each new data point, adding in the needed extra state with insert? Or should I be building up one session over time and retracting the old/unused data points#2019-10-0615:44jjttjjPut slightly differently, the "sensors" example in the clara-examples repo seems similar to what i'm trying to do, but I'm not quite sure how the main function would translate to the "real world": https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/examples/sensors.clj#L87 Should the same session persist throughout the long-running process that provides the sensor data? Or is the run-examples function similar to something that would be called frequently in response to new data?#2019-10-0616:39mikerod@jjttjj you could certainly create one ‚Äúbase session‚Äù and hold a reference to it#2019-10-0616:40mikerodThen do insert+fire on independent ‚Äúbranches‚Äù from there. In isolation#2019-10-0616:40mikerodIf old state doesn‚Äôt need to influence ‚Äúnew‚Äù you don‚Äôt need to try retracting the last cycle of facts etc. just start from scratch again from the base session#2019-10-0616:40mikerodThis will be cheap. #2019-10-0616:43jjttjjgreat, thanks!#2019-10-0816:24Eduardo MataI have a multi-threaded parallel synchronous processor using Clara rules. How can I make sure that for every Rule session is clear out for the following session?#2019-10-0816:30jjttjj@contact904 I'm still really new to Clara, but sessions are immutable, so you should be able to make a session and then use that as the starting session from any number of parallel threads without worrying. Is the work each thread does independent of all others? Or does there need to be some coordination?#2019-10-0816:31Eduardo MataThe threads are independent of each other, but some of them use the same rules.clj module#2019-10-0816:32jjttjjOk then yeah that's perfect, you should be able to bind mk-session somewhere, and then use it from any number of threads and the threads will only see the starting point. (Someone correct me if I'm wrong :)#2019-10-0816:34Eduardo MataSo if I have a set of N threads and the N thread are independent of each other running in parallel. All these N threads are using the same rules.clj module. I should not worry because the threads getting facts from other threads as they are only aware of the session the thread created at the time?#2019-10-0816:35jjttjjYes, that is my understanding#2019-10-0816:36ethancThe rule definitions should be separate from the memory of the sessions that are created.#2019-10-0816:37jjttjjyou can even share a "root" session because they are immutable, in the same way a bunch of threads can operate on the same root vector in clojure and only see their version of it#2019-10-0816:37ethancjjttjj is correct, assuming that all threads were loading the same rules#2019-10-0817:36Eduardo MataCorrect me if I am wrong. So I have multiple rules, I inserted a collection of events into the current session in progress. My main record is called Event. I will insert-all the Records in to the session and fire the rules. A little of back story, I used to have an atom, now I am inserting facts in to a new Record called NewEvents. Back to the current situation, The first rule will create a side effect (modify) on the Record and insert it in to NewEvents. The following rules will be fired with the Record Event, if it fits the rule, I want to look in to the past modified record in NewEvents and apply the changes to the corresponding NewEvent. This contains a couple bugfixes and a new default optimization to reduce memory usage. Details on the changelog: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/CHANGELOG.md#0200#2019-10-2921:50bartukahi people, I am very glad to have found this library#2019-10-2921:50bartukathere is only one thing though that I wish to fix... cider is not identing correctly all my conditions =(#2019-10-2921:50bartukaany suggestions on how to fix it? üôÇ#2019-10-3001:21nopromptSee put-clojure-indent#2019-11-0301:35mikerodYeah it‚Äôd probably be cool if someone could share a cider config that helped indent some of the macros from Clara. #2019-11-0301:35mikerodI believe cursive IDE has some work in this area perhaps before if I recall. #2019-11-0305:38dominicmThe clara macros could add metadata to indicate to cider how to indent.#2019-11-0508:44wparkerIs this the indentation metadata you‚Äôre referring to @dominicm? https://docs.cider.mx/cider/indent_spec.html I‚Äôve generally been satisfied with the default indentation in Cider when writing rules, are there examples of cases where the indentation is strange? My initial instinct if this sort of thing is desired would be to look for/create an extension mechanism for it so various development environments could be supported without everything needing to be in the main codebase (this is orthogonal to whether it would be in the main repo IMO and this could be separately considered).#2019-11-0508:56dominicmCursive looked at implementing the spec, I'm not sure if it happened though. It hasn't seen much adoption in other editors.#2019-11-0519:34sashtonI‚Äôm trying out Clara right now. Is there a way to get all the current facts from a session? I‚Äôve tried various inspection functions, and come up short. - inspect/explain-activations - fact-graph/session->fact-graph - inspect/inspect I can get most facts from the above functions. What I am missing is facts inserted directly into the session, which haven‚Äôt themselves fired any rules. This would be just for debugging the rules, not for production queries. I don‚Äôt want to write a query which includes all Fact types, I‚Äôm looking for a simple way to enumerate all current facts in the system. Any ideas?#2019-11-0520:37mikerod@sashton easiest is a query on Object. #2019-11-0520:37mikerodIt doesn‚Äôt necessary perform well though#2019-11-0520:37mikerodBeyond that, it‚Äôs been done with hooking into the listeners Api#2019-11-0520:38mikerodI don‚Äôt think anything out of the box for it. I may be forgetting#2019-11-0520:38sashton> listeners api I was just exploring that path#2019-11-0520:38mikerodIf you watch the alpha node activations. #2019-11-0520:38mikerodAnd retractions. #2019-11-0520:39sashtonI‚Äôll try out the Object query, thanks for the pointer. This is only for debugging, so I‚Äôm not worried about performance#2019-11-0520:39mikerodBut there are some complexities involved depending how precise you need it#2019-11-0520:41mikerodObject query is straightforward. It‚Äôs slow because it always is activated by all working memory changes#2019-11-0520:41mikerodAnd remember to fire rules always before running query#2019-11-0520:41mikerodThey (can) do some batching/lazy stuff they may delay until fire rules.#2019-11-0520:43sashtonThanks!#2019-11-0522:04wparkerOn the subject of the query performance, something that may be counterintuitive is that the cost comes from the presence of the query in the rules session, not the query call itself. In essence when fire-rules is called the query results are computed. Agreed that a query on Object is the simplest way to get all facts in the session if the perf hit doesn't matter e.g. in testing.#2019-11-0522:05wparkerAssuming we're talking about JVM clojure, not sure offhand what the cljs equivalent would be.#2019-11-1313:51sashtonI‚Äôm trying to figure out if there is a way to accumulate some joined data. I haven‚Äôt been able to come up with a single rule which will fire with my desired output. In the following example, I am trying to answer the question, what is the sum of quantities for each name: 
(defrecord A [id name])
(defrecord B [id quantity])

(defrule merge-things
  ???
  =>
  (println ?name ?total-quanity))

(-> (mk-session)
    (insert (->A 1 "car"))
    (insert (->A 2 "truck"))
    (insert (->A 3 "car"))
    (insert (->B 1 2))
    (insert (->B 2 3))
    (insert (->B 3 5))
    (fire-rules))
I am trying to have that rule print out: 
car 7
truck 3
#2019-11-1313:52sashtonI haven‚Äôt been able to come up with a ??? for that rule which works.#2019-11-1314:00sashtonWell, duckie to the rescue. While typing this up, I found one way I hadn‚Äôt tried. So now my question is, are there any problems with the following rule definition? (memory,performance,other,‚Ä¶) It is different that other rules I‚Äôve used. Not sure if using the accumulator and re-creating the set of ids ‚Äî (set (map :id ?a)) ‚Äî in the rule expression would cause any unexpected problems. 
(defrule merge-things
  [?a <- (acc/all) :from [A (= ?name name)]]
  [?total-quantity <- (acc/sum :quantity) :from [B (get (set (map :id ?a)) id)]]
  =>
  (println ?name ?total-quantity))
#2019-11-1418:36ethanc@sashton, Sorry for the delay. From my experience accumulators are relatively cheap with respect to memory/performance in scenarios where the state of the session that they are accumulating is relatively stable. Performance can degrade in the event that there are massive amounts of logical retractions due to truth maintenance, but it would be directly linked to the data in the session and other rules that may feed into this rule. To the second half, > Not sure if using the accumulator and re-creating the set of ids ‚Äî (set (map :id ?a)) ‚Äî in the rule expression would cause any unexpected problems. I believe that would require each B in the session to generate the set again, perhaps using the distinct accumulator instead might be ‚Äòbetter‚Äô. Any updates to A would also require this work to be redone. Something like: 
(defrule merge-things
  [?ids <- (acc/distinct :id) :from [A (= ?name name)]]
  [?total-quantity <- (acc/sum :quantity) :from [B (contains? ?ids id)]]
  =>
  (println ?name ?total-quantity))
In theory this would only have to recalculate the set when a new A was seen and then only if that return value changed then re evaluation of the B logic would have to occur. Then again all of this needs to be taken with a grain of salt as data scenarios can change the behavior of performance while executing rules.#2019-11-1418:44bartukainsteresting error, I am using a private function inside the namespace of the rules and clara gave me the follow stacktrace 
#error {
 :cause var: #'secland.securities.contract-rules/now-in-inst is not public
 :via
 [{:type clojure.lang.ExceptionInfo
   :message Failed compiling alpha node...
#2019-11-1418:44bartukaI would like to understand more why#2019-11-1418:48ethanc@iagwanderson, Was the function was used inside the LHS of a rule?#2019-11-1418:50ethancnvm, i missed Failed compiling alpha node. So the answer to my question would be yes.#2019-11-1418:58ethancThe reason that this would occur would be due to how clara evaluates LHS/RHS. The LHS is assumed to be namespace agnostic, as nodes that make up the LHS(AlphaNodes, JoinNodes, ect.) could be shared across namespaces and rules in those namespaces, whereas the RHS(ProductionNodes) can‚Äôt be shared and can be seen as Namespace bound. This means that Clara evaluates LHS nodes outside of the original namespace that they are defined within, and production nodes are evaluated within the namespace that they are defined. So, by having a private function within the LHS of a rule clara will cause an exception to be thrown due to illegal access. I‚Äôm not sure if that is documented anywhere, but it probably should be‚Ä¶ I will see if i can find any.#2019-11-1419:30bartuka@ethanc thanks so much for the clear explanation, didn't find any explanation around it when I searched#2019-11-1419:32bartukaI have a more general question about code organization#2019-11-1419:33bartukaI have some rules that need to be run for specific clients and products, there is a recommended approach about how to organize the rules and the sessions for each situation?#2019-11-1419:33bartukaI would like to enable some users to enable/disable a rule, so probably having a reference to it in a database#2019-11-1422:33ethancI guess it would depend on your use-case, i think the way i would handle them would be treating a namespace as a ‚Äúfeature package‚Äù. Then a given client could enable features(sets of rules) by namespace, of course through some abstraction(wouldn‚Äôt want consumers directly loading namespaces). That way when it comes to session creation you would only have to worry about loading a set of namespaces containing rules, ex 
(defn load-session 
  []
  (let [client-namespaces (get-namespaces-by-client)]
    <require namespaces if not already done>
    (com/mk-session client-namespaces)))
per rule filtering would probably be more tricky.#2019-11-2620:23bartukahi, @ethanc thanks for the answer#2019-11-2620:23bartukaI was out of work these days. I just tried your approach, but the problem is to pass a list of symbols to mk-session, I am not able to use apply because this is a macro#2019-11-2620:24bartukahow are you handling this?#2019-11-2620:39mikerod@iagwanderson clara.rules.compiler/mk-session can be used#2019-11-2620:39mikerodit‚Äôs the underlying fn - just have to deal with some boilerplate with quotes etc#2019-11-2620:39mikerodit‚Äôs signature is slightly different#2019-11-2620:40mikerodtakes sequence of sources-and-options#2019-11-2620:40mikerodsources expected to come first#2019-11-2620:40mikerodthen keyword options#2019-11-2620:40mikerodexample ['my.ns.name :my-option :foo]#2019-11-2620:42bartukaoh, cool. let me try out! thanks#2019-11-2620:43bartukaworked just fine o/#2019-11-2620:51mikerodnice#2019-12-1013:05Konstantinos TzanidakisHi everyone, I was hoping to get some help on seriliazing the session in Clara Rules. The second (= ?cd_paciente cd_paciente) is a comparison because the binding is already established right ?#2019-12-1301:20ethancThat is correct#2019-12-1301:21geraldodevIts beautiful . (error prone too) if i remove a char of ?cd_paciente I got two bindings#2019-12-1301:24ethancYeah, i've wondered if the Clara compiler should warn on unused bindings...#2019-12-1311:58bartukathis could be very handy#2019-12-1315:49mikerod@geraldodev yeah, because ?binding-name is just some arbitrary local name you want to give for the context#2019-12-1315:50mikerodthe warning isn‚Äôt a bad idea, @ethanc is a genius#2019-12-1315:51ethancI will log an issue for enhancement, when i get a few free seconds @mikerod#2019-12-1317:28geraldodev@mikerod the warnings from clj-kondo have improved a lot my experience with clojure.#2019-12-1317:36mikerod@geraldodev I‚Äôve started to play around with clj-kondo, but haven‚Äôt done so very seriously yet - it looks promising#2019-12-1317:37mikerodfor a Clara DSL thing though - not thinking it can help you much? like in the case of this variable binding thing?#2019-12-1317:37mikerodI know it does have some pretty good extension points though - so can do some nice things#2019-12-1318:11geraldodev@mikerod I've asked on #clj-kondo if it's possible to lint the unused binding case#2019-12-1318:14geraldodevI think it's a work for a linter. But it's a very especific syntax. for macros that follows defn or def pattern you simply configure :lint-as on a config file like: {:lint-as {com.fulcrologic.fulcro.components/defsc clojure.core/defn }}#2019-12-1318:15mikerod@geraldodev yeah, I‚Äôve seen how to do that pattern following like you have above#2019-12-1318:15mikerodI‚Äôve used that one#2019-12-1318:15mikerodbut the clara DSL is of course more complicated#2019-12-1318:16mikerodof course for unused, it may be just not finding the symbol more than one time in the entire DSL form hah#2019-12-1318:16mikerodEthan did log a Clara issue it looks like now though#2019-12-1318:17mikerodHis proposal targets more on the AST compilation side - which is better since the DSL layer is something that is ‚Äúpluggable‚Äù in Clara (people could use their own and target same AST pre-compilation)#2019-12-1318:19geraldodevYesterday was my 1st day with clara. I'm enjoying.#2019-12-1318:42mikerodoh, nice#2019-12-1320:36geraldodevAbout processing facts that comes from sql databases on long running sessions. Because of mutation, one has to query the session looking for the fact based on the primary key of the table, compare it with the current value and if it's different retract the old fact and insert again. Is that correct ?#2019-12-1323:10Eduardo Matawhat does this even mean" 
Java.lang.IllegalStateException: Attempting to call unbound fn: #'
#2019-12-1323:12Eduardo Mataups wrong place#2019-12-2319:59ethanc@geraldodev, sorry i missed your comment: > About processing facts that comes from sql databases on long running sessions. Because of mutation, one has to query the session looking for the fact based on the primary key of the table, compare it with the current value and if it‚Äôs different retract the old fact and insert again. Is that correct ? I think that makes sense, for changes outside of the session, you would have to manually update the fact inside the session via an external retract followed by insertion of the fact.#2019-12-2723:48futuroIs it possible to compose left hand sides in rules?#2019-12-2723:57ethancCould you elaborate on what you mean by composing?#2019-12-2800:51futuroI have three rules which have the same fact expressions in their LHS, and I‚Äôd like to extract them to aid in reuse. #2019-12-2800:52futuroI‚Äôm not at a computer, but I can write up a little snippet later if that‚Äôd make it clearer. #2019-12-2800:54ethancI would usually use an intermediate fact in that scenario, one rule that inserts the fact constrained by the common lhs and then downstream rules can rely on the presence of the intermediate fact#2019-12-2800:57futuroHmmm, yeah, that could work. I suppose you‚Äôd put any shared fields you needed into this shared fact, which would allow downstream rules to pull them back out, yeah?#2019-12-2801:10ethancYes, they would carry what's needed. In some cases simply wrapping the whole fact might make sense#2019-12-2801:57futuroSwanky, thank you @ethanc !#2020-12-3118:19Matthew PettisDoes anyone know of any examples of clara-rules that solve logic problems? Such as in logic problems found here: https://www.brainzilla.com/logic/logic-grid/apples-to-apples/#2020-12-3118:20Matthew PettisI"m looking to do this in an industrial setting ("machine A can't be on if machine B is on", or "machine B cannot turn on unless machine A is already on", etc.) Logic puzzles seem to be a template for what this concept is...#2020-12-3119:29geraldodevhttps://gist.github.com/geraldodev/076ccb995db907644070f134656fb74b Hi can you comment on this gist. It looks like defsession with :fact-type-fn does not stick with the var#2020-12-3120:05Matthew PettisThank you, I'll check out.#2020-12-3120:09Matthew PettisSorry, thought this was related to my question...#2020-12-3120:54ethanc@U0516053R, I don‚Äôt typically use the defsession macro, but it seems to me that it is building the call to mk-session differently. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L368 
(mk-session [:fact-type-fn :type])
vs 
(mk-session :fact-type-fn :type)
so the session in this case is empty(no productions) due to defsession not appending the current namespace.#2020-12-3120:57ethancTo get this to work, 
(defsession session `app.mv.clara2 :fact-type-fn :type)
the namespace would have to be provided#2020-01-0101:38geraldodev@U3KC48GHW Thank you!. I've started with (def session (mk-session . Later I've switched to defsession. Also I was trying to infer changes on the sql table based on the primary key. The plan was to baby sit the session like an atom. I've stumbled across a issue that shows that clara ignores facts that are not touched by rules and queries. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/48 . I was intending to use it wrong. It looks like reading the table, insert the facts and collect the results and let the session go way is a more correct approach..#2020-01-0619:55Eduardo MataI am applying a basic rule saying 
(defrule missing-information
[?event <- Event (nil? flower-id) (= ?id _id)]
=>
(insert! ->AddError _id  :error "Missing Flower _id"))
#2020-01-0619:56Eduardo Matafor some reason, I have a Record with flower-id and it clara still telling me the flower-id is missing#2020-01-0620:18mikerod@contact904 do you have more than one Event? Are you saying an Event with a non-nil flower-id and a unique _id is being matched with the above rule which insets the AddError fact? Your ->AddError syntax seems incorrect since it isn‚Äôt calling the fn to but guessing that this is maybe pseudo-code#2020-01-0620:21Eduardo MataAddError is a new Record with fields _id, error, value it is close to a pseudo-code#2020-01-0620:22Eduardo MataI am confused because I have been usings this rule for a long time, this is the first time I get this error#2020-01-0620:25Eduardo MataI see what is my problem. I have similar _id;s#2020-01-0620:34mikerod@contact904 (insert! ->AddError _id :error "Missing Flower _id") is missing parens was my comment on syntax (insert! (->AddError _id :error "Missing Flower _id"))#2020-01-0714:32Konstantinos TzanidakisHi all, I want to serialize/deserialize the working-memory separately so I started off by using a simple implementation for IWorkingMemorySerializer that serializes to an atom (as per Clara's docs) and deserializing from the atom by derefing it. That works perfectly fine, in that I am able to run queries and get the same results from both the original and deserialized session. However, if I add the extra step to write to fressian and read fressian to the ser/deserializer of the IWorkingMemorySerializer , all queries in the deserialized version of the session return with nil: eg. ({:?crn nil}) while the same query on the original is returning ({:?crn {:fact-type :client-representative-notification, :name "Alice", :client "Acme", :level :high}}) . I should note that I am fairly new to clara rules. Has anyone come across something like this before?#2020-01-0715:09ethanc@konstantinos562, Do you have a small snippet, it would help me reproduce it locally?#2020-01-0715:12Konstantinos TzanidakisHi @ethanc do you need the rules as well?#2020-01-0715:13Konstantinos Tzanidakis
(defrecord WorkingMemoryAtomSerializer [input output]
  d/IWorkingMemorySerializer
  (serialize-facts [_ facts]
    (reset! state (write-fressian facts)))
  (deserialize-facts [this]
    (-> @state io/input-stream read-fressian)))
#2020-01-0715:14Konstantinos Tzanidakiswith (def state (atom nil)) in the namespace#2020-01-0715:14Konstantinos Tzanidakisand the read and write fressian as follows#2020-01-0715:14Konstantinos Tzanidakis
(defn write-fressian [obj]
  (let [baos (ByteArrayOutputStream.)
        wr   (frz/create-writer baos)]
    (frz/write-object wr obj)
    (.toByteArray baos)))

(defn read-fressian [b]
  (-> b frz/create-reader frz/read-object))
#2020-01-0715:14Konstantinos Tzanidakissorry for the long posting all#2020-01-0715:15Konstantinos TzanidakisNB: I have replaced fressian with nippy/freeze and nippy/thaw and it works perfectly fine now. I am not sure what the issue was (most probably I am doing something wrong there)#2020-01-0715:16mikerod@konstantinos562 not sure what frz ns is referring to#2020-01-0715:16mikerodYou may just not have setup good read/write handlers for your facts#2020-01-0715:16mikerodFressian‚Äôs defaults tend to be insufficient#2020-01-0715:16Konstantinos Tzanidakissorry it's the requirement: [clojure.data.fressian :as frz]#2020-01-0715:16mikerodor they will cause many clj data structures to become Java structures - or not the same as before#2020-01-0715:17mikerodyou can see Clara defines a more robust set of fressian handlers for clj to clj serialization https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/durability/fressian.clj#L231#2020-01-0715:17mikerodhowever, there really is no compelling reason to not just use nippy if you have it set up#2020-01-0715:18mikerodI wouldn‚Äôt have used Fressian to impl Clara‚Äôs session serialization if I were to do it again today. it is difficult to work with in what it provides by default and I don‚Äôt think it is any better than something like nippy or perhaps a few others. It is also not documented super well and at the ‚Äúprimitive‚Äù level makes some unavoidable Java collections that are awkward to convert from (and also wasting perf time)#2020-01-0715:18Konstantinos Tzanidakisfor this example, I have not set up any handlers but the facts are fairly simple 
[{:fact-type :client-representative :name "Alice" :client "Acme"}
 {:fact-type :support-request :client "Acme" :level :high}]
#2020-01-0715:18mikerod(this is all pluggable and could be implemented with something else on Clara‚Äôs side just as well too)#2020-01-0715:18mikerodtry to Fressian write/read that and see that it returns you the facts in the same structure#2020-01-0715:18mikerodleaving Clara session/rules out of the test#2020-01-0715:19mikerodthat may give some insight#2020-01-0715:20Konstantinos Tzanidakis@mikerod simply using the fressian write/read does work correctly in REPL#2020-01-0715:20Konstantinos Tzanidakisyes, I think I will use the nippy as it seems to be something in the fressian side that I cannot track at the moment#2020-01-0715:21mikerod> simply using the fressian write/read does work correctly in REPL You‚Äôve analyzed waht is returned? is it still a clj vector with 2 clj maps etc?#2020-01-0715:21Konstantinos Tzanidakisthank you very much for the prompt responses and help!#2020-01-0715:21Konstantinos Tzanidakis@mikerod yes it returns exactly the same facts that are serialized; i.e. a vector of two clj maps#2020-01-0715:21mikerodI‚Äôd have to experiment some to look close, can‚Äôt right now#2020-01-0715:23mikerodI have some examples in http://www.metasimple.org/2018/02/19/clj-fressian-ext.html#2020-01-0715:23mikerodwhere things don‚Äôt work out-of-the-box with conversions and types#2020-01-0715:23mikerodUnder ‚ÄúDefault handlers‚Äù#2020-01-0715:23mikerodHowever, didn‚Äôt mention anything with vectors/maps there#2020-01-0715:26mikerodI immediately see that types at least aren‚Äôt preserved 
(let [r (serde-obj [{:fact-type :client-representative :name "Alice" :client "Acme"}
                    {:fact-type :support-request :client "Acme" :level :high}])]

  (type r))
;;= java.util.Arrays$ArrayList
#2020-01-0715:27mikerodthis isn‚Äôt immediately meaning Clara wouldn‚Äôt accept it - but it is already on shaky ground#2020-01-0715:27Konstantinos Tzanidakisoh I see#2020-01-0715:27Konstantinos Tzanidakis@mikerod thank you very much on this!#2020-01-0715:27mikerodyou could attempt to just add the handlers from clara.rules.durability.fressian#2020-01-0715:28mikerodonly issue there being you may not want to deal with the ‚Äúidentity preserving‚Äù parts potentially#2020-01-0715:28mikerodyou can see examples https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/test/clojure/clara/test_fressian.clj#L16#2020-01-0715:28mikerodof how you‚Äôd do that#2020-01-0715:29Konstantinos Tzanidakisthat makes sense#2020-01-0715:29mikerodhas 2 dynamically scoped bindings you add for it‚Äôs internal caching#2020-01-0715:29mikerodyou can see it via pform/thread-local-binding#2020-01-0715:29mikerodd/node-id->node-cache doesn‚Äôt matter for working memory - so you can leave that off#2020-01-0715:30mikerodd/clj-struct-holder is required I‚Äôm fairly sure - it is used to preserve object identity during (de)serialization#2020-01-0814:58bartukais it possible to remove a rule from a session before firing it? I say that because I have a namespace with 10 rules and I want to run 9 of them. I would prefer to insert all the namespace and remove the single one#2020-01-0816:17ethanc@iagwanderson, Currently there is no way to add/remove rules from the rulebase after the session has been created#2020-01-0816:37bartukaok, thanks!#2020-01-0816:40mikerod@iagwanderson as I think you already know you can pass a collection of rules to make a session too. #2020-01-0816:40mikerodHowever it‚Äôs more of a ‚Äúwhite list‚Äù. And you seem to want a ‚Äúblack list‚Äù #2020-01-0816:42bartukaexactly, just to avoid typing too much#2020-01-0816:51mikerodYou can list rule names in a vector in a var as well with :production-seq metadata. But still doesn‚Äôt help you. (defrecord Values [id])

  (defrule testing->include
    [?value <- Values [v] (= ?id (:id v))]
    =>
    (println "INCLUDING!!! " ?value))

  (defrule testing->exclude
    [?value <- Values [v] (= ?id (:id v))]
    =>
    (println "EXCLUDING!!! " ?value))

  
  (def session-without (rl/mk-session 'clara.rules.compiler/testing->include
                                      'clara.rules.compiler/testing->exclude
                                      :blacklist ['clara.rules.compiler/testing->exclude]))
#2020-01-1011:38bartukaI already have a working solution to this problem. I am touching only the clara.rules.compiler/mk-session function. There are many tests namespaces in the project. #2020-01-1009:30Konstantinos TzanidakisHi all, I'm back üôÇ . Sorry for the several questions and thank you very much for all your prompt and very helpful responses; it's been very enjoyable working with Clara. I am progressing very well in building up the ruling system in Clara however I am getting some OOMs when I surpass a certain number of facts in my application. My application has around 15 rules, some of which are fired by others, and the facts may well range between 300k - 2m, but when I go closer to the upper end I get OOMs. So, I thought that it may be reasonable to run a few benchmark tests (and maybe start profiling?). I tried the clara-benchmark repository and experimented a bit with the AccumInsert test; in this I've played with the number of Customers, setting it from 250k to 10m. I noticed that on my machine, Clara threw an OOM above 5m facts. I was wondering whether you have a direction to suggest on methods to cut down such costs? In my application the first try was to chop the initial facts only to the absolutely necessary fields required (I am using clojure maps as extracted from a DB) but without luck. Thank you all in advance!#2020-01-1013:49mikerod@konstantinos562 2m facts themself would be quite a memory burden in the jvm I think. If it‚Äôs just memory issues is the heap space you‚Äôre giving enough? #2020-01-1013:50mikerodYou can use a profiler to look more at the memory layout but Clara will certainly take more space than those 2m facts since it has working memory structure it uses on top of what they already take alone. And if you have rules inserting facts based on them. #2020-01-1013:51mikerodThe benchmark stuff would be more aimed at execution time. Which isn‚Äôt too useful if you‚Äôre running out of memory. If it‚Äôs slow it‚Äôs probably due to GC thrashing before OOM#2020-01-1013:52mikerodOr at least that‚Äôd hide any other perf issues. #2020-01-1013:52Konstantinos TzanidakisHi @mikerod, yes that's true, the heap space is set to 4G. I have tried to trim down the facts' fields to the absolute necessary, and now I am considering of using a strategy to reduce the size of facts sent to Clara#2020-01-1013:53mikerod@konstantinos562 it‚Äôd be good to know how much of the 4G you are using before running the rules #2020-01-1013:53mikerodTo gauge how much clara is adding relative to that. #2020-01-1013:54Konstantinos TzanidakisHmmm good question, I haven't noted this down, although I think it's relatively low as I start from a clean repl.#2020-01-1013:55mikerodBut the diagnosing the issue will also come down to what you‚Äôre rules are doing. If they match too many facts in ways where they are producing factors like n^2 or more rule activations and new fact insertions - I think that already is putting you at quite a lot of objects in memory#2020-01-1013:55Konstantinos Tzanidakisbut will note this with VisualVM#2020-01-1013:55mikerodVisualvm can be good to get some info for this. #2020-01-1013:56Konstantinos TzanidakisYes, that is more close to what happening#2020-01-1013:56mikerodAlso you can try to just jump heap to like 6G then 8G to get a sense of how much memory it really needs. Of course this may not be acceptable in your production, but for testing #2020-01-1013:57mikerodAlso Clara shouldn‚Äôt hold references to facts that can never match any rules. #2020-01-1013:57Konstantinos TzanidakisI think I will try another pass on the rules in an effort to downsize the domain#2020-01-1013:58mikerodSo in some situations, if you actually can filter out a bunch of stuff early, you could do some sort of ‚Äústream of facts‚Äù in a sense. But your calling code would also have to not hold references past inserting them to Clara and firing rules. #2020-01-1013:59Konstantinos TzanidakisI see what you mean#2020-01-1014:00Konstantinos TzanidakisI am currently retrieving all facts from the DB, which maybe streaming this in Clara without holding a head would make a difference... thanks for the suggestion#2020-01-1014:01mikerodYeah to not have them all in memory at once I think you‚Äôd have to be a bit careful. #2020-01-1014:02mikerodNot sure something like insert-all would be careful enough within Clara. Would probably have to like near N number at a time, then fire rules. Then repeat the next batch#2020-01-1014:03mikerodBut if they are mostly matching or even ‚Äúpartial matching‚Äù rules they will be held in memory. So it can be brittle #2020-01-1014:03mikerodA fact is held in memory if it can even ‚Äúpotentially‚Äù be used to satisfy a rule later. That‚Äôs the ‚Äúpartial match‚Äù #2020-01-1014:03Konstantinos Tzanidakis(I was just checking insert-all's source, as this is what I am using to insert facts - but will need to check a bit more carefully on the DB side too)#2020-01-1014:04mikerodWhich intuitively makes sense. Since it may be needed later when new facts come. #2020-01-1014:04Konstantinos TzanidakisMakes sense yeah#2020-01-1014:04mikerodBut yeah my first thought would be the original stuff I said. Understand memory use a bit more. #2020-01-1014:07Konstantinos TzanidakisThanks a bunch @mikerod#2020-01-1014:10bartukahi @mikerod, I am trying to run the tests from clara repository and I keep receiving this error:

There is no clear relationship between my implementation and the error messages#2020-01-1022:03mikerod@iagwanderson you need to use def-rules-test for cross platform ‚Äúcommon‚Äù tests #2020-01-1022:03mikerodThat may be your issue#2020-01-1022:03mikerodLook at another test ns in that dir to see it used. #2020-01-1022:03mikerodIt‚Äôs used in all the rule sort of tests there. #2020-01-1022:04bartukaUhmm... Ok. I will make this change.#2020-01-1313:08wparkerFor some background, in Clojure Clara can create sessions on the fly using eval, while in ClojureScript sessions have to be defined at compilation time typically using a call to defsession at the top level. The dynamic session building in Clojure ultimately uses eval, which is why it doesn't work in ClojureScript. Defsession-test essentially makes the static session building in ClojureScript tests look more dynamic without needing to create tons of top-level defs etc.#2020-01-1323:33bartukainteresting!! I noticed during my tests that in these cases I should uses only the names of the rules that I was filtering inside the mk-session I was thinking that is was going to create the name with my current namespace in it#2020-01-1022:04mikerodCan‚Äôt say it‚Äôs certainly the issue. But likely. I can‚Äôt remember without looking a bit more #2020-01-1022:04mikerodThere are differences in how you would set this up in clj vs cljs. #2020-01-1022:05mikerodSo the test helper makes that not an issue#2020-01-1022:05mikerodFor portable test#2020-01-1022:05bartukaI never did cljc before, so I was betting on something related to that#2020-01-1022:06bartukaI will make the test work and open a PR for discussions around the implementation#2020-01-1022:24bartuka@mikerod looks like the Compiling ["resources/public/js/simple.js"] failed. because in the cljs_deps.js does not have definitions for my new file added#2020-01-1022:34bartukafixed, lein do clean, compile üòÉ#2020-01-1022:51mikerodYeah. I have a long standing issue to improve the cljs setup and build stuff. But it is involved. So for now have to work with this stuff as it is. #2020-01-1114:09bartukaThanks for all the help @mikerod I opened a PR https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/pull/445#2020-01-1114:50mikerod@iagwanderson nice. I‚Äôll check it out #2020-01-1311:40bartukahi, you guys have customized cider to understand rules indentation correctly?#2020-01-1313:33wparkerI don‚Äôt, I think some others may have experimented with it as well as an attempt to format/highlight in Cursive. I‚Äôve personally just used newlines for new conditions and Cider indents that well enough that it hasn‚Äôt bothered me.#2020-01-1313:33wparkerIs there something in particular that looks strange to you?#2020-01-1322:21bartukathe default indentation looks like this:#2020-01-1322:21bartuka
(defrule rule->legacy-contract?
  "Add a Legacy fact into the session if the contract was sent with this status."
  [?contract <- Contract [ct] (= ?principal-external-id (:contract/principal-external-id ct))
   (= :legacy (:contract/status ct))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Legacy ?principal-external-id)))
#2020-01-1322:22bartukaand I have to manually change it to: 
(defrule rule->legacy-contract?
  "Add a Legacy fact into the session if the contract was sent with this status."
  [?contract <- Contract [ct] (= ?principal-external-id (:contract/principal-external-id ct))
                              (= :legacy (:contract/status ct))]
  =>
  (insert! (->Legacy ?principal-external-id)))
#2020-01-1323:34bartukasometimes I need to use M-x align-regexp (= to align the conditions#2020-01-1512:23mbraggHi. Im evaluating potentially using Clara for one of our use cases. Can you imagine a sensible way to be able to determine the start-time and end-time of a given rule execution? Say I have a rule that has some expensive operation‚Ä¶ I‚Äôd like to be able to record when it started and ended, ideally without adding the required code to the rule itself and adding the values to the emitted fact (as it would be great if all rules exposed this information implicitly). I‚Äôve started looked into: ‚Ä¢ The inspect + trace tools dont seem to provide it ‚Ä¢ Creating a new Listener, but this may be a bad idea given it would no longer be immutable if its calling out for the current time? ‚Ä¢ Creating a macro and extend the parsing logic to wrap the rule execution somehow Any thoughts / suggestions appreciated. Many thanks#2020-01-1517:10mikerod@mbragg I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs as straightforward as perhaps it seems. Rules aren‚Äôt the same as something like a fn body that you can time#2020-01-1517:10mikerodThe rules are structures that are used to create a rete based data flow tree (forest really)#2020-01-1517:12mikerodSome examples of the complexity: (1) In some cases LHS conditions from separate rules may end up being shared as one common node in this tree. (2) rule conditions are nodes on the tree. They have varying degrees of eager vs lazy behavior. In most cases, the engine tries to batch facts up prior to evaluation of conditions #2020-01-1517:13mikerod(3) before fire-rules happens a certain degree of evaluation takes place. Once fire-rules happens more work is done but always oriented towards batched fact propagation. #2020-01-1517:14mikerodThe inspection/trace stuff can be useful to get a sense of how many times a condition is being evaluated/matched. This tends to just give a relative ‚Äúcount‚Äù to compare and often find the outliers. #2020-01-1517:16mikerodBut overall. The rules are more like ‚Äúsql query structures‚Äù where they are then compiled to a network, like the ‚Äúdb eval plan‚Äù#2020-01-1517:16mikerodSo the concerns tend to be things like how many times is this ‚Äújoin condition‚Äù being evaluated given some facts. #2020-01-1517:19mikerodWith profiling you can find actually hot spot functions which sometimes end up being a fn used in a condition that is being evaluated a large number of times: 
[MyFact (my-fn ...)]
If that condition has a large number of matches you may profile and see my-fn is a hot spot and looking to be a perf issue.#2020-01-1517:46mbraggThanks @mikerod for the explanation, makes sense. I guess I was specifically meaning everything in the RHS do block for a given rule. But I can see it may not be that straight forward... especially if there‚Äôs batching involved. #2020-01-1522:42wparkerIn case a concrete demonstration helps for clarity, the rule RHS calls like insert! add things to a cache that will be processed later (the details of that probably aren‚Äôt super important here), the default implementation of which is in this file: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/master/src/main/clojure/clara/rules/update_cache/core.cljc It‚Äôs certainly possible to have a poorly-performing function called in a rule, for which profiling with something like VisualVM can be useful, but a simple timer isn‚Äôt necessarily much help with diagnosing poorly performing rules networks as Mike has elaborated on.#2020-01-1616:08mbraggThanks @U0KRSVDHR #2020-01-1517:49mikerod@mbragg the RHS is easier to time at least#2020-01-1517:49mikerodI mean you can wrap that fairly easily - but still the time it takes to do the insert! sort of functions is where the batching happens#2020-01-1517:49mikerodso you if you‚Äôre RHS is: 
(insert! (->Something ?x))
timing it won‚Äôt necessarily tell you much#2020-01-1517:50mikerodthat same RHS may end up being activated N times - so it evaluates N times, and you have N insert! calls all batched, so no fact is actually inserted right away until a later cycle#2020-01-1517:51mikerodthe batching is very useful from a perf standpoint too - but does complicate timing things#2020-01-1518:42mbragg@mikerod ok understood. It think I‚Äôm going to suggest that this ‚Äúrule timing‚Äù requirement is something we drop if we go with Clara, as it sounds like it doesn‚Äôt really make sense... in the way they are imagining rules being executed anyway. Thanks for all your help #2020-01-1518:47Matthew PettisIn a defrule RHS, when making a record to insert, is there a way to access the rule name (the symbol associated with the rule that is firing) to store as a field in the inserted fact?#2020-01-1518:52mikerod@matthew.pettis I suppose you want this instead of being repetitive? 
(defrule my-rule
=>
(insert! (->MyFact `my-rule))
#2020-01-1518:55Matthew PettisYeah, right now I'm copying the name as the rule as a string in the creation of MyFact , so if there is a way to resolve the name of the rule in which the insert is operating that's what I'm looking for (so, as you said, I'm not repetitive in the sense of mis-copypasting the rule name into the string...)#2020-01-1518:57Matthew PettisThinking of something like this, so I can use the same insert statement and not have to copy in the rulename somehow...#2020-01-1519:05mikerod@matthew.pettis have to look to think if anything is directly available#2020-01-1519:05mikerodhowever, you can always opt to make your own macro#2020-01-1519:06mikeroddefrule itself is just a macro and rules and queries in Clara are all modeled in a data-oriented data structure underneath that alternative DSL‚Äôs can be written to produce (via macros typically)#2020-01-1519:06Matthew PettisOK. A macro implementation might be in line for me too.#2020-01-1519:06mikerodor you can have a macro that expands to defrule for your case#2020-01-1519:07Matthew PettisI think I may follow the custom macro expansion to defrule, thanks. Was just wondering if it was a common need and something was built in that I was missing...#2020-01-1519:08mikerodan old (and probably no longer able to run examples) post, that did give a good overview of alterantive DSL‚Äôs http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ just for reference if that concept is something you find further interest in - you don‚Äôt really need it for this small case#2020-01-1519:11mikerodI don‚Äôt see anything built-in as of now#2020-01-1519:12mikerodI have came across a similar use-case in the past. I think I just repeated the name basically - I believe I used keywordized version instead though#2020-01-1519:12mikerodbut can be error-prone indeed#2020-01-1519:14mikerodI‚Äôve also done alternative DSLs that compile to underlying rule structures though in some cases where there was more to it#2020-01-1519:16Matthew PettisI like the macro wrapper for the cases where I want to insert a fact tracking what rule was fired. And, yeah, in my use case, I was thinking of using rule firing to track all of the rules that were fired on a given fact. This is like using rules as a way to track all of the ways a fact can violate rules without making a big conditional statement that checks all conditions and logs that observation.#2020-01-1519:24mikerodYeah that makes sense #2020-01-1602:29Matthew PettisI'm having some trouble with understanding the mk-session function documentation (http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.20.0/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-mk-session). In particular, it references rule sources. Are those namespaces that the rules live in (if they aren't in the current namespace)? I'm wondering what the alternative ways there are to giving rules to a session if you don't use defrule in the current namespace. Can you construct a vector of rules (that don't have names) that you'd get from defrule and feed it to a session?#2020-01-1604:33mikerod@matthew.pettis you can pass a collection of rules and queries#2020-01-1604:33mikerodSo a vector yes#2020-01-1604:34mikerodIf you pass an ns name it‚Äôll be automatically expanded to a collection of all rules sources within it#2020-01-1604:34mikerodRule sources are defined by a protocol #2020-01-1604:35mikerodThere are a few more built in impls but those are the main 2#2020-01-1604:36mikerodAnd ‚Äúrule‚Äù is a bit overloaded here unfortunately since it includes queries. Clara typically calls them ‚Äúproductions‚Äù when referring generally to both. #2020-01-2103:09Matthew PettisAre there any examples out there that show how to define a session in the namespace project.a, define facts in namespace project.b , rules in project.c , and how to import b and c into a to fire rules on them? I'm struggling because I"m sure I don't have namespace usage well...#2020-01-2103:11Matthew PettisMy two files which fails (I"m looking only at importing rules for this examples, not yet facts):#2020-01-2103:11Matthew PettisThe session namespace...#2020-01-2103:12Matthew PettisThe rule namespace I want to import from...#2020-01-2103:21Matthew PettisThe error I get:#2020-01-2103:29ethanc@matthew.pettis I believe you would want to import the fact into the namespace where the rule is using it: 
(ns clara-lein.ex06rulesns
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all] 
            [clara-lein.ex06 :as ex06])
  (:import [clara-lein.ex06 Myfact]))
;; Rules namespace for rules for ex06.
;; Define rules
(defrule rule-1
  "Rule-1 in rulesns"
  [Myfact (= ?size size)]
  [:test (> 1 ?size)]
  =>
  (insert! (ex06/->Rulefail "rule-1" ?size)))
Though this might lead to issues with cyclical dependencies, with the session ns and rules ns. It might be practical to pull the fact definitions out into a separate ns so that they can be pulled by both ns without the possibility of a cycle.#2020-01-2103:35Matthew PettisThank you! If I copy and pasted this correctly, when i run (require 'clara-lein.ex06rulesns) in clara-lein.ex06 , I get an error that No namespace: clara-lein.ex06rulesns found. I'll keep poking, but that's my current error...#2020-01-2103:35Matthew Pettis... and that's when I run the final let that creates the session...#2020-01-2103:37Matthew Pettisoops, I take that back. When I run that require statement, I get a ClassNotFound exception for clara-lein.ex06.Myfact.#2020-01-2116:20Matthew PettisSo, I was able to make this work if I included all of the defrecords, rules, queries, and facts in a different namespace, referred that namespace, and then made a session with mk-session 'source.namespace) . However, I am struggling to modularize this, so that I can make a session where facts come from one namespace, rules from another namespace, and queries from yet another namespace. I'm not sure if it is the namespace inclusion-ing that I am messing up, or that I don't know the proper syntax on mk-session or insert to build up a session that has facts, rules, and queries from these sources in it. An pointing to examples of rules that has that would be appreciated. I am doing this as an exercise to show that you can make a modular rules system and that clara-rules can support that modularity. Which is why I'm making a toy example that is doing this... thanks in advance...#2020-01-2116:59mikerod@matthew.pettis there are no special evaluation rules being done by Clara. You have to appropriately require all ns‚Äôs you depend on in the order they depend on each other via standard clj :require #2020-01-2117:00mikerodYou can have things in as many ns‚Äôs as you want. #2020-01-2117:00mikerodIf you show your example I maybe can help. I‚Äôm confused what you are using to get into a situation you are describing at this point. #2020-01-2117:26Matthew Pettis@mikerod Thanks for the help! I pushed a repo here of example code that doesn't quite work, but has the rules, facts, and queries in separate namespaces. The part is at the end of the core.clj file, where I assemble a session out of the facts, rules, and queries, to be able to query the session. https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex#2020-01-2119:42mikerodFirst just style Notes: In clara-ns-ex.core, typically all :require are in one spec, but I guess what you have can work? I haven‚Äôt actually tested in recent clj: 
(ns clara-ns-ex.core
  (:require [clara.rules :refer :all]
            [clara-ns-ex.facts :refer :all]
            [clara-ns-ex.rules :refer :all]
            [clara-ns-ex.queries :refer :all]))
Instead of 
fact-sess (apply insert query-sess facts)
use insert-all 
fact-sess (insert-all query-sess facts)
just since there is API to make you not need to use apply with varargs.#2020-01-2119:43mikerodSecond (most important): You don‚Äôt insert rules and queries. These are needed upfront at mk-session time. Clara actually does not support dynamically adding or removing rules/queries at all right now. It may be a future potential to add, but there are perf benefits to not doing so. Even if it did allow that later though, you wouldn‚Äôt ‚Äúinsert rules‚Äù. insert is meant for facts, not rules.#2020-01-2119:43mikerodwhat you‚Äôd need to do for your example is: 
init-sess (mk-session 'clara-ns-ex.core 'clara-ns-ex.rules 'clara-ns-ex.queries)
if you just wanted to automatically include all rules/queries defined in those namespaces.#2020-01-2121:00Matthew PettisOK, this is super-helpful, thank you so much! I will try these changes as soon as possible.#2020-01-2121:04Matthew PettisI was not aware that rules and queries could not be dynamically added. It is nice to see an example of mk-session with multiple namepaces put in there. I wasn't sure if it was as a varargs or as a vector of namespaces, etc.#2020-01-2121:16mikerod@matthew.pettis there is likely an issue or 2 in the github repo discussing dynamic rules. However, you may not need it as much as immediately it seems.#2020-01-2121:16mikerodOften there are solutions that don‚Äôt need that sort of feature at least.#2020-01-2201:51Matthew PettisI agree; I don't need dynamic rules. I more needed a hint as to the fact that they are supplied and loaded upon mk-session.#2020-01-2201:53Matthew PettisTo that end, I tried your advice, I think I did it faithfully, and wasn't able to make it work yet. My adjustments are at this commit: https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex/tree/0bdb72e98a8ef657de08579af6ee993c9008a738#2020-01-2201:54Matthew PettisWhen I run that, I still get that Myfact class cannot be found. I think I'm probably missing something about using defrecord definitions from other namespaces.#2020-01-2202:04Matthew PettisAlso, for a baseline, this is how I make it work when everything is in the same namespace... https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex/blob/nonamespace/src/clara_ns_ex/core.clj#2020-01-2202:28mikerod@matthew.pettis so you‚Äôre issue isn‚Äôt just referring to record symbols. Have to follow normal clojure symbol resolution rules. #2020-01-2202:29mikerodSo you require the ns that defines the records - to ensure it is compiled. #2020-01-2202:29mikerodThen you typically would use :import in clj (not cljs) to refer to the record class name as the shortened version#2020-01-2202:30mikerodOtherwise you‚Äôd have to fully qualify it each reference clara_ns_ex.facts.Myfact#2020-01-2202:40Matthew PettisThanks. I thought about that a bit more after I posted, I'll think a bit more carefully about resolution rules, and think I may get it... Thanks for the help; learning Clojure as I learn Clara here...#2020-01-2203:20mikerodNo problem. Let me know if more questions#2020-01-2203:21mikerodI‚Äôd give better examples but typing on mobile is hard hah#2020-01-2203:47Matthew PettisI really appreciate the help.#2020-01-2204:19Matthew Pettisfyi, i think i'm closer, but I can't decipher the location of where the error of can't find Class for Myfact, as it won't tell me at what line it is failing. This is the state that I have it: https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex/tree/f3d6f67346eacb61294205f6da0e1f3073e7428a#2020-01-2204:21Matthew PettisI have the import statements, I tested that it worked. I referenced these pages that went with the hint that @mikerod gave me on using import: https://danielcompton.net/2016/05/04/requiring-records-clojure-clojurescript and https://stackoverflow.com/a/23420084/1022967#2020-01-2204:39Matthew PettisOK, I got it to work by playing with what did and did not need namespace qualified names, and where. I don't fully understand the rules of when I should and should not yet, but I have a working example to go off of, so thanks for all of your help! Here is the commit that has a working example: https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex/tree/d077c141d305ef217043bcf44a328c6921311847#2020-01-2209:41wparkerLooks like you've got it figured out mostly. :). You don't need the fact class imports in your core namespace, but rather just in the rule/query namespaces that use them. Clara rule and query defs use the same evaluation semantics as normal Clojure code, that is something used, be it a function, class, etc. needs to be resolvable in the namespace where the rule/query is being defined. Also it's somewhat a matter of personal preference, but I find it more clear where things are coming from when I use :as aliases rather than :refer :all, that might help reduce confusion.#2020-01-2209:43wparkerAdmittedly there's a fair amount of code in Clara dealing with that evaluation, but the end result is to have the same user-facing semantics.#2020-01-2212:54Matthew PettisAwesome! I'll take out the require and import statements in core and use :as aliases in the rest and push a cleaner example. Thanks for the help.#2020-01-2213:48mikerodI also advocate for :as aliases too. It helps to make it clear where symbols are coming from. ClojureScript doesn‚Äôt even have :refer :all support! Hah#2020-01-2214:06Matthew PettisI just discovered 'how to ns' by Sierra, reading that to guide me on that: https://stuartsierra.com/2016/clojure-how-to-ns.html#2020-01-2214:10mikerodI thought it had some good points. I can‚Äôt remember if I fully agreed with it, but analyzing require forms can become a debate of ‚Äútaste‚Äù at a certain point. Hah. He does at least mention its opinionated. üòé#2020-01-2214:32Matthew PettisOK, just for completeness and posterity... For this question, which was how to use namespaced rules, queries, and facts in making a session, I cleaned up the namespace declaration, using Sierra's "how to ns" style recommendations, and removed most :require :refer :all statements to be more precise (except for clara-rules). Here is the commit that is cleaned up per this comment: https://github.com/mpettis/clara-ns-ex/tree/8b78de1442fd8484341cc68d6ac63b7d78cf85e4#2020-01-2214:10mikerodI thought it had some good points. That repo is where I am putting probably all my examples...#2020-02-0109:21bartukagreat! thanks#2020-02-0721:14Matthew PettisBecause it occurs to me that rules like this are just like basic syllogisms (which I'm sure others have observed long before me here) I put together a dead-simple example of making the rules engine do modus ponens from basic propositional logic. https://github.com/mpettis/clara-lien/blob/master/src/clara_lein/ex07.clj#2020-02-0721:36ethancI don‚Äôt believe that the rhs should be wrapped in a vector, https://github.com/mpettis/clara-lien/blob/master/src/clara_lein/ex07.clj#L28#2020-02-0721:43ethancmy reasoning with this nit is, that the clara wraps the rhs inside a fn and executes it when the lhs is satisfied. basically something like: 
(fn [bindings] 
  <original form>)
The inserts! would be considered stateful as the operate on the active session, thus the example still works its just the vector is superfluous. I am just being nit picky though#2020-02-0721:44Matthew Pettisthis is good... i was getting some wierd nested results when I ran (but still had right answers). I'll remove and see if that does what's expected; i didn't notice I had wrapped that...#2020-02-0722:39Matthew Pettis... guess i'm a little surprised it worked in the original, now that I see it...#2020-02-0723:21ethancI should add that clara also wraps the RHS form in a do when you use defrule. 
(fn [bindings] 
  (do 
     <form>))
Since clara doesn‚Äôt use the returned value from this function, it doesn‚Äôt really make a difference, clojure will gladly return a vector with whatever insert! returns. Which is promptly ignored by clara üôÇ#2020-02-0818:26Matthew Pettisfixed and pushed.#2020-02-0721:15Matthew PettisAnd a slightly more complicated example here too. I'm just experimenting, not saying this is the optimal way to do this, but it is just fleshing out some thoughts and analogies that might be useful for others teaching rules-engines concepts. criticisms welcome. https://github.com/mpettis/clara-lien/blob/master/src/clara_lein/ex08.clj#2020-02-1000:18Matthew PettisDocumentation question: from this page (http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/rules/), in the defrule structure flow has an optional props token. I can't find anywhere in the documentation that talks about what that actually is. Can anyone point me to what that is?#2020-02-1016:16wparkerThe primary property used currently is salience, which allows users to control the order in which rules fire. Usually it shouldn‚Äôt be necessary, but sometimes is useful either for performance optimization or when rules opt out of truth maintenance (by using unconditional insertions and/or RHS retractions). The latter tends to make things more complicated in my experience, but sometimes can be useful/necessary#2020-02-1016:41Matthew PettisOK, thank you, this is nice to know.#2020-02-1017:22mikerodThey are undocumented to discourage use perhaps. Hah#2020-02-1017:22mikerodI thought salience may be documented somewhere though. Would have to look#2020-02-1019:34Matthew Pettisyep, salience is documented here: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/conflictsalience/#2020-02-1019:35Matthew PettisI just didn't connect what I read there with what I read in the documentation...#2020-03-1620:27eraserhdHey, remember when I said I wanted a command-line Clara rules-like thing? It exists: https://www.w3.org/2000/10/swap/doc/cwm.html#2020-03-1700:43staypufdCool#2020-04-0111:32Busy escaping the comfort zoneHey Clara team I'm trying to require clara and I'm getting an error 
namespace 'clara.rules.schema' not found
Any idea what I'm missing? (I am able to require 'http://calra.ru#2020-04-0111:45Busy escaping the comfort zoneOk seems like I had a conflicting [prismatic/schema "1.1.6"] version in my classpath all good üôÇ#2020-04-0114:15ethancI wonder if it would make sense to rip that dependency out of clara. I know it adds a bit of clarity to the underlying structure of the Sessions and whatnot, but it is another dependency we are forcing on consumers. @mikerod do you have any thoughts here?#2020-04-0114:33mikerod@ethanc replace with spec or just nothing?#2020-04-0114:33mikerodWe maybe could get the schema ns usage to be optional (and use it in tests too)#2020-04-0114:34ethancSpec would probably be the ideal, but i‚Äôm not sure what all is going to have to change to uplift clojure/clojurescript versios#2020-04-0114:46mikerodspec could probably be added without much difficulty on the versioning front, but actually making the spec would be more time consuming#2020-04-0114:46mikerodPerhaps we can just get the schema to be an option dependency we only check/bring in during the :dev profile?#2020-04-0114:49ethancI‚Äôm not completely sure how we could do that.#2020-04-0115:24mikerodprobably would have to shim some schema fn‚Äôs/macros#2020-04-0115:24mikerodand have them at compile time decide if the dep is there or not - if not fall back#2020-04-0115:25mikerodprobably isn‚Äôt easy if using harder macro features like schema‚Äôs defn or defrecord#2020-04-0115:43ethancwhich clara does, at least for the defrecord.#2020-04-0116:08mikerodyeah, so it‚Äôs likely difficult üòõ#2020-04-0117:05ethancI really wouldn‚Äôt want to be in the business of trying to parse schema‚Äôs forms and convert them back into clojure‚Äôs forms#2020-04-0117:28mikerodNo. I wouldn‚Äôt want that either#2020-04-0211:40Busy escaping the comfort zoneBTW I think that I have a very interesting use case for Clara rules, once done ill share it but I'm very excited about it#2020-04-0214:19Busy escaping the comfort zoneHi Clara team, is there an option to run a query that matches any fact? for example: 
(defquery get-failures [] 
    (?f <- [_ true]))
Assuming that the first value in the vector is not important we only care for the second true value#2020-04-0214:20Busy escaping the comfort zoneOr alternatively: 
(defquery get-failures [] 
    (?f <- _ (= ?failure true)))
#2020-04-0214:22Busy escaping the comfort zone(looks like ancestors-fn might be useful in such a case?)#2020-04-0214:26ethancA rule/query that has a fact type of Object would find all facts#2020-04-0214:36Busy escaping the comfort zoneIn my case I'm using a keyword as the fact type, if I understand this correctly (ancestors :foo) is nil so Object dosent capture this?#2020-04-0214:36Busy escaping the comfort zone
(defquery get-failures [] 
    (?f <- Object (= ?failure true)))
#2020-04-0214:37Busy escaping the comfort zoneSounds like I need to use an actual clojure keys hierarchy?#2020-04-0214:46ethancah when using a custom fact-type-fn i think the only reliable way to achieve this would be to also provide a matching custom ancestors-fn#2020-04-0214:47Busy escaping the comfort zoneMakes sense, ill continue to fiddle with it#2020-04-0214:47Busy escaping the comfort zoneThanks#2020-04-0423:45rainbow_bambooHi :) I've been working on a website to cite data about the pandemic, http://coronavirus-charts.org . Underneath it uses clara rules to generate HTML charts... (A full writeup on the project https://devpost.com/software/coronavirus-charts-org and the source code https://github.com/rainbow-bamboo/coronavirus-charts/ ) any help, advice or feedback is welcome :)#2020-04-0522:39mikerod@ada this looks interesting! Cool to see clara being used some underneath this. #2020-04-1615:42Busy escaping the comfort zoneHi Clara team just wanted to share my use which is using Clara rules for provisioning https://github.com/re-ops/re-core/blob/re-flow/src/re_flow/core.clj, the ability to combine different flows easily while getting the computation graph for free is amazing, trying to implement this with procedural if/else or state machines would have resulted with much less composeable and brittle code. To be able to just query and see why a flow has failed is just the icing on the cake ;) Thank you for the hard work!#2020-04-1616:24ethancThats pretty cool, its great to see people using clara in new inventive ways#2020-04-1617:15nopromptWorkflows are where its at üôÇ#2020-04-1617:17nopromptIts awesome to hear/see this idea catching on.#2020-04-1618:10mikerod@narkisr looks like an interesting use-case. Nice to see.#2020-04-2811:14Busy escaping the comfort zoneHi Clara team this is a cross post from the #announcements channel (I hope its ok) just wanted to share my post on how I used Clara and why I think its cool for process automation http://narkisr.com/posts/27-04-2020-clara-flow/ I hope to see more projects make use of this awesome project#2020-04-2813:07mikerod@narkisr this is cool to see. Thanks for writing the blog explaining and sharing. Exciting to see clara being useful here. #2020-05-0222:11oskarkvI'm new to Clara Rules. I have been trying to write a rule for a board game, but I haven't been able to do it. The rule in English is: During a player's turn, at the stage of the turn called :into-city, the player will move into the city if either there are no other players in the city, or if there is just one player in the city and the total number of players is more than four. I have these fact types: 
(defrecord Player [id name health score energy])
(defrecord Turn [id stage])
(defrecord InCity [id])
InCity just means that a player is in the city. Turn keeps track of whose turn it is and at what stage the player is in his turn. Player just represents a player. I tried this: 
(cr/defrule into-city
  [?turn <- Turn (= ?id id) (= :into-city stage)]
  [?players <- (acc/count) :from [Player]]
  [?in-city <- (acc/count) :from [InCity]]
  ;; (or (zero? ?in-city
  ;;            (and (= 1 ?in-city)
  ;;                 (> ?players 4))))
  =>
  (cr/retract! ?turn)
  (cr/insert! (->Turn ?id (next-stage :into-city)))
  (cr/insert! (->InCity ?id)))
But of course that part of the condition with "if either there are no other players in the city, or if there is just one player in the city and the total number of players is more than 4" is missing. I have commented out an expression that I tried to put in there somehow. But I'm not sure where to put that. As far as I have seen, conditions apply to individual facts, and I'm not sure if I can put in another condition line with just boolean logic. Can I? Also, since, as you can see, I'm retracting the Turn fact that led to the new facts being inserted, because now the stage of the turn is the next stage, and so the inserted facts will be instantly retracted, right? So how should I think about it? I'm finding it harder than I anticipated to write a program with rules.#2020-05-0317:18ethancTo: > As far as I have seen, conditions apply to > individual facts, and I'm not sure if I can put in another > condition line with just boolean logic. Can I? yes, clara represents this as an underlying join of the two facts. You could also do this in a "test" condition: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/expressions/ For: > Also, since, as you can see, I'm retracting the Turn fact > that led to the new facts being inserted, because now the > stage of the turn is the next stage, and so the inserted > facts will be instantly retracted, right? So how should I > think about it? As you alluded to, truth maintenance(http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/) would kick in when retracting the fact, meaning that this rule would likely cause a loop to occur. I've never really thought about modeling game state management in clara, but i would wonder if the retract is necessary.#2020-05-0319:56oskarkvI discovered that there is insert-unconditional too, maybe I can use that#2020-05-0319:56oskarkvThanks#2020-05-0401:17mikerod@oskarkv maybe related http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html#2020-05-0716:38oskarkvThanks!#2020-05-0716:46oskarkv
(cr/defquery my-query
  [:?x :?y]
  [?p <- (acc/all) :from [Player]])

(defn oktest []
  (-> (cr/mk-session)
    (cr/insert (->Player 0 0 0))
    (cr/insert (->Player 1 2 3))
    cr/fire-rules
    (cr/query my-query :?x 0 :?y 0)))
This does not produce any results. But if I use ?x and ?y in the query, e.g. (= ?x x) and same for y then it does produce results. This is kind of surprising since in normal functions one doesn't have to use the args. Is there any particular reason for this? Same if I remove the arguments :?x and :?y from the query but keep them in the call to cr/query, then the query doesn't produce any results. Also a bit confusing.#2020-05-0716:57oskarkvAnd apparently this doesn't work. I'm confused about queries. 
(cr/defquery my-query
  [:?x :?y]
  [?p <- (acc/all) :from [Player (> x ?x) (> y ?y)]])

(defn oktest []
  (-> (cr/mk-session)
    (cr/insert (->Player 1 1 1))
    (cr/insert (->Player 2 2 2))
    cr/fire-rules
    (cr/query my-query :?x 0 :?y 0)))

Only for testing equality? clarax.queriestest> (q1test)
with (= ?x x)
({:?x 1, :?y 1, :?p [{:x 1, :y 1, :z 1}]})
clarax.queriestest> (q2test)
with no ?x or ?y in body
()
clarax.queriestest> (q3test)
with no argsvector
()

argsvector but no args passed in
({:?p [{:x 1, :y 1, :z 1} {:x 2, :y 2, :z 2}]})

no args whatsoever
