As in the prior case, if P is an inserted fact, and I want to see how I got P, I should just see "P" with no rules, as it was inserted a priori...#2020-10-0719:03wparkerAs far as I know the clara-tools project isn‚Äôt really maintained anymore. From what you describe though I think you can probably accomplish what you‚Äôre looking for in a non-GUI environment with session inspection, particularly the :fact->explanations key. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/inspection/#2020-10-0719:04wparkerThe fact-graph functionality might also be of use, though note that this is basically just another view over the information returned by session inspection. https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/main/src/main/clojure/clara/tools/fact_graph.cljc#2020-10-0719:36Matthew PettisThanks! I think session-inspection is exactly what I need at this point of what I think are my simple needs.#2020-10-0711:47dharriganCan clara be used to enforce a type of "state", i.e., something starts with a state, then moves to another state, but cannot move to a previous state?#2020-10-0713:08mikerod@dharrigan I‚Äôd think you can model this via forward-chaining#2020-10-0713:58dharriganOkay, thank you. I'll have a play üôÇ#2020-10-0719:08wparkerLike a state machine basically? It certainly could be done in Clara, although maybe something more specifically aimed at representing state machines would be simpler. Depends on the use case probably and whether it is part of your rules or the whole thing; I haven‚Äôt tried encoding any state machines ‚Äúfor real‚Äù before.#2020-10-0719:13dharriganYes, a very very simple state machine, just a few states.#2020-10-0719:13dharriganPerhaps I may just end up doing a cond üôÇ#2020-10-0800:12sparkofreasonIs there a technical reason why tests are not included in boolean expressions?#2020-10-0800:15sparkofreasonMaybe because the variables have to be bound before executing the test?#2020-10-0800:23ethancAs you mentioned, test conditions allow a fact-binding to be bound before evaluation. My go-to example would be checking the result of an accumulator#2020-10-0803:48Matthew PettisLooking at output of clara.rules.inspect... just wondering, when using inspect on a session, what is the difference in the contents of the :condition-matches vs the :insertions. They seem to have pretty much the same information, but granted, I am just using a single rule and single insertion and trying to inspect the output to figure out what inspect can tell me, and how, at the moment...#2020-10-0813:32ethancI believe that the :condition-matches is meant to capture/explain join nodes, where :insertions should contain what facts were inserted and why they were inserted i believe#2020-10-0815:27Matthew PettisIt looks like :condition-matches will also show the unconditional inserts (like the initial facts loaded to a session)... does that seem right?#2020-10-1614:40PBIs there a way to create rules without the defrule macro? I am currently pulling constraints out of a database and would like to make a bunch of rules based off of those. I noticed that the macro appears to just create a var? 
(def
 do-it
 {:ns-name 'woof,
  :lhs '[{:type woof.Person, :constraints [(= name "me")]}],
  :rhs '(do (prn "99999")),
  :name "woof/do-it"})
However creating that var does not seem to create the rule.#2020-10-1614:43PBMy guess is that this is not adding that var to the clara-session?#2020-10-1614:47mikerod@petr it is supported and you don‚Äôt even need vars#2020-10-1614:47mikerodbut you can use vars if that is convenient for you#2020-10-1614:47mikerodif you do use vars, the question then becomes how is it ‚Äúauto detected‚Äù via Clara‚Äôs default namespace scanning impl#2020-10-1614:47mikerodand that is done via metadata#2020-10-1614:49mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.21.0/src/main/clojure/clara/rules.cljc#L271-L305#2020-10-1614:50PB@mikerod I would use vars or not. It just feels better than using a macro to generate defrules#2020-10-1614:50mikerodthis is what it does to scan built-in#2020-10-1614:50mikerodso specifically for vars#2020-10-1614:50mikerodif you have meta : :rule, :query, or :production-seq#2020-10-1614:50mikerodit is treated as a rule container of some sort#2020-10-1614:50mikerod:rule and :query are a single rule/query#2020-10-1614:50mikerod:production-seq is a collection of rules/queries - aka ‚Äúproductions‚Äù#2020-10-1614:50mikerodyou don‚Äôt need macros#2020-10-1614:50mikerodand you don‚Äôt need vars#2020-10-1614:50mikerodif you have a more data-oriented case#2020-10-1614:51mikerodmk-session takes collections of rule/query (aka production) structures#2020-10-1614:51PBI'm open to really any approach here#2020-10-1614:51mikerodwell, you just have to choose what is best suited#2020-10-1614:51PBOh cool. so I could actually pass those "rule" maps to the mk-session?#2020-10-1614:51mikerodvars are awkward to create if you‚Äôre doing it like at runtime#2020-10-1614:52PBI agree#2020-10-1614:52mikerodif you look at tests#2020-10-1614:53mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/0.21.0/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L144#2020-10-1614:53mikerodas example#2020-10-1614:53mikerodyou see they are almost all just based on passing rule/query maps in a collection to mk-session#2020-10-1614:53mikerodso this is probably all you are really looking for#2020-10-1614:53mikerodvars with metadata are basically just a convenience#2020-10-1614:53mikerodfor automatic rule/query detection in namespaces#2020-10-1614:54mikerodwhich works better for cases where you are more statically writing rules via macros/DSL#2020-10-1614:55PBOhhh that looks useful, thank you for showing me that#2020-10-1615:43mikerodno problem#2020-10-1615:43mikerodI looked briefly on http://clara-rules.org and do not see any actual good documentation around ‚Äúrule sources‚Äù#2020-10-1615:43mikerodwhich I think could be improved#2020-10-1615:43PB@mikerod thank you so much for that. This has made my day a lot easier#2020-10-1615:43mikerodI think it‚Äôs lacking if we don‚Äôt include other major variants of how to load rules#2020-10-1615:43mikerodWe‚Äôve taken special care in a lot of the clara stuff to make it where the DSL is optional#2020-10-1615:44mikerodand to have the API accept other data-oriented options#2020-10-1615:44PBYeah, this is clearly very well thought out#2020-10-1615:44mikerodjust DSL + var/ns scan-loading is built-in for convenience and the typical, most easy examples#2020-10-1814:28schmeeare rule clauses order sensitive?#2020-10-1814:37schmeei.e if I have 
(defrule foo
  [HighCardinality (= foo ?foo)]
  [LowCardinality (= foo ?foo)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Foo ?name)))
does it matter for performance that HighCardinality is before LowCardinality?#2020-10-1817:41ethancI don't believe it would impact performance. The cartesian product would be the same size I believe#2020-10-1819:04schmeeokay, this one has me completely stumped: 
(defrecord Reachable [nodeType name])
(defrecord Node [nodeType area name])

(defrule area-reachability
  [Reachable (= nodeType :area) (= name ?area)]
  [Node (= area ?area) (= nodeType ?nodeType) (= name ?name)]
  ; [:not [Reachable (= nodeType ?nodeType) (= name ?name)]]
  =>
  (insert! (->Reachable ?nodeType ?name)))

(comment
  (-> (mk-session [area-reachability])
      (insert (->Reachable :area "World"))
      (insert (->Node :room "World" "Foo"))
      fire-rules))
#2020-10-1819:04schmeeas written it finishes instantly, if you uncomment the [:not ...] it goes into an infinite loop#2020-10-1819:11schmeethe intent is to not insert the Reachable fact if it‚Äôs already in the session#2020-10-1819:27mikerodIt‚Äôs a commmon issue @schmee and you have to rethink the LHS to be in terms of what‚Äôs true about the entire state of the system#2020-10-1819:27mikerodSo with the :not above you are expressing a logical contradiction. #2020-10-1819:38schmeeI see, could you elaborate a bit?#2020-10-1819:39schmeemy mental model is that since the inserted node is not of nodeType :area, it will fail to match the first clause and hence the rule as a whole will not fire#2020-10-1819:39schmeebut that can‚Äôt be the case?#2020-10-1820:59ethancWhat Mkie is alluding to is clara's truth maintenance: http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ With the not un-commented, the rule itself becomes a logical contradiction of itself. The rule will only execute and be considered true if the fact in question is not within the session. However, if the rule inserts a fact that itself asserts to be absent, then a loop would be formed. A base state would be a session without the fact in question, ergo the rule must insert the Fact. Then clara must assert that all truth has been maintained, and finds that the Fact is now present. Meaning that the Rule is no no longer true, thus a logical retraction occurs removing the Fact from the session. Then clara must asser that all truth has been maintained, again. However we are back to the base state meaning that there is no Fact within the session and the Rule is true again, thus the cycle repeats and continues forever. The wiki mentions ways to circumvent this mechanic using unconditional inserts, however these can lead to non-logical conclusions if assumptions are made.#2020-10-1821:09schmeethanks @ethanc, that clears things up quite a bit! I‚Äôll take some time to ponder that and see if I can write the rule differently#2020-10-1821:11schmeeI‚Äôm coming into Clara with a Datomic mindset, which will surely trip me up a few times before I understand the ‚Äúrule engine way‚Äù#2020-10-1822:33sparkofreasoninsert-uncondtional! is your friend here, if you want to have effects in the LHS of your rules. I find it easier to always use insert!, so that my rules are pure logic statements. When I want an effect, instead I insert a request fact, which is executed by some external component. That effect often invalidates the rule, thus causing the request to then be retracted by truth maintenance.#2020-10-1822:43mikerodYeah. I avoid unconditional in most cases. #2020-10-1822:44mikerodYou typically can phrase the problem in a way that works with TMS. Often intermediate facts and accumulators in an aggregate rule can solve common situations. #2020-10-2013:49schmeewhat a good approach to ensure that a fact is only inserted once, kind of like a primary key in a DB?#2020-10-2013:49schmeeI could have a rule where the RHS literally checks in a DB to see if the key is there, but it seems better to keep as much state as possible in the session?#2020-10-2217:25PBIt seems kind of dangerous have side-effects inside of a rule.#2020-10-2015:29nikolaWhat would be the best practice to implement a decision table like that?#2020-10-2015:31nikolaAt my team a couple of product specialists use Excel for logic like that and I was wondering if I can somehow turn them into Clara rules and use it to make decisions. Has anyone have done something similar in the past?#2020-10-2016:20mikerod@schmee Use an accumulator for the fact you actually want 1 of#2020-10-2016:20mikerodif you have rules that may produce multiples#2020-10-2016:20mikerodmake an intermediate fact type to represent the multiple#2020-10-2016:20mikerodthen a single acumulator to aggregate it ‚Äúdown to 1‚Äù#2020-10-2016:20mikerodthis aggregation rule is you explicitly choosing how you want to represent or handle multiple supporting matches#2020-10-2016:21mikerodit‚Äôs not always obvious actually - if they happen to have different data associated with them them or something#2020-10-2016:21schmeegotcha, thanks for the tip!#2020-10-2016:22mikerod@nikola.kasev I haven‚Äôt attempted anything first-class with tables like that - but you could start by just trying to make rule to represent it and see what patterns may emerge#2020-10-2016:22mikerodI know some traditional rete-based engines - like Drools on the JVM - had some spreadsheet-like decision table functionality built on top to capture the pattern - but underneath was stilll just plain rules#2020-10-2615:17eraserhd@nikola.kasev I use tables a lot, and I'm not sure of a general way to make them into rules (I would definitely be curious about such a thing!), but I have at least one example I can think of: https://gist.github.com/eraserhd/a60250281e9d47743e9021ccd1337bcaa#2020-11-0511:04nikola@U0ECYL0ET, can you check the link?#2020-10-2615:18eraserhdI've also used macros to make different shapes of data into Clara rules.#2020-10-2617:00mikerodhttps://github.com/cerner/clara-site/issues/34 @wparker did log an issue to document better the rules-as-data model#2020-11-0200:13piphi, i get this issue on compiling a rules namespace. could anyone help me understand what‚Äôs wrong with my bindings? 
Malformed variable binding for #{?contract-provider ?claim-provider}. No associated value.
(defrule associated-contracts
  [:contract (= ?contract this)]
  [:contract (= ?contract-provider (:subject ?contract))]
  [:claim (= ?claim this)]
  [:claim (= ?claim-provider (-> ?claim
                                  :billing-provider
                                  :identifier
                                  :value))]
  [:associated? (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
  =>
  (insert! {:resource-type :associated-contract
            :claim ?claim
            :contract ?contract}))
#2020-11-0200:14pipi‚Äôm using fact-type functions instead of clojure records but i‚Äôm having trouble figuring out what are the right patterns#2020-11-0200:14pipin this case i want to bind the entire object to either ?claim or ?contract#2020-11-0200:15pipand i also want to bind nested variables in that map#2020-11-0200:20ethancI don't have repl open currently, but it looks like this might be because of the multiple conditions with similar fact types. rather than 2 conditions to bind contract and claim, i would assume that you might actually want a single condition for each. Something like: 
(defrule associated-contracts
  [:contract 
(= ?contract this)
(= ?contract-provider (:subject this))]
  [:claim 
 (= ?claim this)
(= ?claim-provider (-> this
                                  :billing-provider
                                  :identifier
                                  :value))]
  [:associated? (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
  =>
  (insert! {:resource-type :associated-contract
            :claim ?claim
            :contract ?contract}))
#2020-11-0200:24pipoh i see ‚Äî that‚Äôs definitely a lot cleaner üôÇ it‚Äôs still giving me that error though#2020-11-0200:31ethanchmmm, seems clara is incorrectly moving the joined conditional up in front of the binding itself. Specifially, 
[:associated? (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
#2020-11-0200:31ethanchowever this condition seems odd to me, you are looking to a fact in the session but not asserting anything based on this fact#2020-11-0200:32ethancit almost seems as if that should be a test node: 
[:test (= ?claim-provider ?contract-provider)]
#2020-11-0200:33ethancor potentially rolled up into the :claim condition itself#2020-11-0200:34ethancsomething like: 
(r/defrule associated-contracts
  [:contract
   (= ?contract this)
   (= ?contract-provider (:subject this))]
  [:claim
   (= ?claim this)
   (= (-> this
          :billing-provider
          :identifier
          :value)
      ?contract-provider)]
  =>
  (r/insert! {:resource-type :associated-contract
              :claim ?claim
              :contract ?contract}))
#2020-11-0200:37pipoh that‚Äôs totally it ‚Äî i‚Äôm trying to set it up to have the simple predicate comparing facts and i didn‚Äôt realize that you had to name it :test in order for that to work‚Ä¶#2020-11-0200:37pipwould the above example give you ones that matched or all combinations of facts?#2020-11-0200:38pipalso how does querying for the fact-type-fn work? i tried the following: 
(defquery get-associated-contracts
  []
  [?associated-contract <- :associated-contract])
#2020-11-0200:39ethancin the example above, the RHS should execute and insert a fact for each combination of a Claim and Contract that share the same provider#2020-11-0200:43pipoh i see#2020-11-0200:43pipthat‚Äôs perfect! thank you so much!!#2020-11-0200:44ethancQueries should work the same way while using/not using an overridden fact-type-fn. For example: 
(defn test-session
  []
  (-> (r/mk-session :fact-type-fn :resource-type)
      (r/insert {:resource-type :contract :subject :Thomas})
      (r/insert {:resource-type :claim :billing-provider {:identifier {:value :Thomas}}})
      (r/fire-rules)
      (r/query get-associated-contracts)))
should net: 
({:?associated-contract {:resource-type :associated-contract,
                         :claim {:resource-type :claim, :billing-provider {:identifier {:value :Thomas}}},
                         :contract {:resource-type :contract, :subject :Thomas}}})
#2020-11-0200:46pipooh i see ‚Äî thank you! that makes sense#2020-11-1011:51Busy escaping the comfort zoneHi Clara team, I'm looking for a way to add/remove rules from a LocalSession, I'm not seeing any matching function in http://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.21.0/clojure/index.html any idea if this is possible? Thanks!#2020-11-1012:05Busy escaping the comfort zone(BTW I don't expect to keep any facts within the session prior to manipulating it, I just want to be able to manipulate the rules prior to usage in some tests)#2020-11-1015:17ethanc@narkisr, Clara does not currently support adding or removing productions from a compiled session. I believe that currently the only way to have a session with fewer rules would be to remake the session without providing the rules in question.#2020-11-1113:50Busy escaping the comfort zoneYeap thats the route iv went with (the session is stored in atom which makes it possible) thanks for help#2020-11-1716:36PBI'm looking at the rules-dsl and came across parse-query. The first argument is params . I was wondering what that construct is for?#2020-11-1722:44mikerod@petr I believe the doc for query mentions how params work#2020-11-1722:44mikerodCan‚Äôt look now#2020-12-0119:18PBIs there a way to update a record? I want to specifically use this with rules that deal with total amounts. I.e. A previous rule would consume part of the total#2020-12-0119:25ethancCan you give a small example of the use-case? From my knowledge, clara doesn‚Äôt play nice with stateful manipulations. That being said, it sounds as if you might be able to use an accumulator, but that depends on the use-case#2020-12-0120:21PBI go shopping, and I have $100 to spend. I want to buy 10 items, which total $200. Each item has a priority, which items can I buy?#2020-12-0120:22PBI'm thinking I'm going to have to create a new fact and use an accumulator to sort by priority#2020-12-0120:23jeff.engebretsenI‚Äôve only casually used clara but its seems like having $100 will be a fact and if that fact changes it‚Äôd cause the session to undo it‚Äôs fired rules and re-fire.#2020-12-0120:23PBMy hope was that it if I could update the root fact with the amount of money left and use salience to trigger rules, and when I ran out of money, the rest of the rules wouldn't trigger#2020-12-0120:23PB@jeff.engebretsen that's my understanding as well#2020-12-0120:26jeff.engebretsenI think like @ethanc said, the accumulator would take in that $100 fact and 10 item priority list fact and spit out 0-10 items#2020-12-0120:27PBYep#2020-12-0120:27PBThank you both#2020-12-0121:29PBSo it looks like I'll likely need my own reducer here. I only want to include the items I can buy. But I'm not really sure how to pass in a sentinel amount. 
(defrule find-what-i-can-get
  [:money (= ?amount (:amount this))]
  [?items <- (acc/reduce-to-accum
              (fn [coll item]
                ;; some way to access `?amount` variable?
                ...))])
#2020-12-0121:30PBI have also tried to pass this into the convert and combine fns#2020-12-0121:31PBIs there a way to do this. Or do I need to add the total amount I have available to the items i'm iterating over?#2020-12-0121:46PBIt also strikes me that I'd need to sort by priority before the reduce#2020-12-0121:49PBI am not sure this is possible to do in accumulators#2020-12-0121:54PBI guess I could use the combine-fn to sort, but I still can't find a way to pass the ?amount into that fn to limit which items are put out#2020-12-0121:55ethancAccumulators do not allow access of constraint bound vars. It might require doing some of this logic in RHS of the rule. Something like: 
(defrule find-what-i-can-get
  [:money (= ?amount (:amount this))]
  [?items <- (acc/all) :from [:item (< (:cost this) ?amount)]]
  [:test (seq ?items)]
  =>
  (let [sorted-priority (sort-by ... ?items)
        ... <reduce logic>]
  <insert statement>)
#2020-12-0121:56PBI don't know why I didn't consider that. Too much tunnel vision I think#2020-12-0121:56PBThank you#2020-12-0121:56ethancadded a test node to eliminate execution where all items are unaffordable#2020-12-0121:59PBHmm (< (:cost this) ?amount) would just ensure the cost of 1 item isn't greater than the total amount I have, yes?#2020-12-0121:59ethanccorrect#2020-12-0817:06Pradeep BHello Everyone, I am evaluating different Rule Engine for our Production usecase and want it to have very low latency (think of like a promotions service in e-commerce store) . Did some PoC with GoLang GRule and it was fine however documentation is not that great/helpful, and personally also not able to increase development speed with golang. Now want to explore Clara and wondering if someone already had some documentation done around Benchmarking. GRule has some good details (impressive numbers) on benchmarking page https://github.com/hyperjumptech/grule-rule-engine/blob/master/docs/Benchmarking_en.md#2020-12-0817:06Pradeep B#2020-12-0817:08Pradeep BAnything similar for Clara will be of great help and i can push it through my team to user Clojure in Prod.#2020-12-1409:15wparkerThere are a few benchmarks, although a lot of performance optimisation has been done against non-public data and rulesets. More public benchmarks/performance tests would be useful if someone had anything to add btw. This was done a while back but is a bit out of date in terms of current performance concerns: https://github.com/rbrush/clara-benchmark In terms of the performance of running rules I don‚Äôt think the number of rules or facts is particularly predictive of performance problems - it tends to be more particular bad patterns at this point in terms of how rules interact with each other that cause problems.#2020-12-1409:18wparkerThe time to create a session will be more closely correlated with the number of rules, but this should only need to be done once in your JVM per set of rules since sessions are immutable.#2020-12-0820:18PBIs there any information around performance scaling over the number of rules defined? I am trying to decide between loading several thousand rules for different customer accounts vs loading the rules for the customer account at the time of the request.#2020-12-0822:05mikerodI don‚Äôt think we have ever had any documented benchmark information#2020-12-0822:05mikerodClara has been optimized heavily to support cases with large numbers of rules and facts in a production environment, but those sorts of details were all internal and never generalized#2020-12-0900:36ethancThis might also be going off on a tangent, however I know that I have avoided when possible adding performance metrics like this in the past. As clara's dsl allows arbitrary clojure in both left/right hand sides, creating "real world" metrics could be misleading to consumers, as we most likely wouldn't have modeled anything close to the use case.#2020-12-2312:26mathias_dwHi, i have a question about the dynamic creation of sessions: as I understand from the docs, mk-session doesn‚Äôt work for cljs, because the rule compilation is done at macro compile time. But it‚Äôs not clear to me if the macro compiling is only referring to the defrules and namespaces, or also ‚Äúdeeper‚Äù. Specifically, is it possible to dynamically create a session in clojurescript if the rules are provided already in the output form of the defrule macro, so with the explicit :lhs and :rhs in a map?#2020-12-2312:28mathias_dwMy usecase is the following: I promised my customer to allow for dynamic addition of (simple) rules through a web interface. Those rules would be used together with pre-defined rules in another web app. Of course I can run the rule execution on the backend and communicate between front-and-backend, but running it on the frontend would be more elegant‚Ä¶#2020-12-2312:30mathias_dwIf it‚Äôs not possible, a follow-up: would it work to do the dynamic (re)compilation on the backend, and then serialize the session in fressian, send it to the frontend and unpack and use it there?#2020-12-2320:22mikerod@mathias_dw the session must be compiled in clj space. It is compiled to data structure but also has Forms that need to be compiled by the cljs compiler - such as functions #2020-12-2320:22mikerodSo the cljs compiler must Pre compile all of the session structure resulting in JS #2020-12-2320:22mikerodThat JS would evaluate on client. You can‚Äôt dynamically alter it all in JS#2020-12-2320:23mikerodIt‚Äôd require having the whole cljs compiler available in the JS. Which is possible. But not the usual setup for a web app#2020-12-2320:23mikerodAnd even the. Would require Clara to support self hosting. Which I don‚Äôt think it may fully do yet#2020-12-2320:24mikerodI have been working (slowly) on a big overhaul of the mechanics of how cljs is compiled in Clara. But it doesn‚Äôt change above. #2020-12-2320:24mikerodSerialization as freesian won‚Äôt work though#2020-12-2320:24mikerodIt‚Äôs not a ‚Äúpure data structure‚Äù #2020-12-2320:25mikerodie. Has things like functions. And possibly closures etc. Could try serializing fn‚Äôs but that‚Äôs a whole other problem space and has it's limits #2020-12-2320:31clyfe@mathias_dw maybe the competition helps https://github.com/oakes/odoyle-rules#2020-12-2321:20mathias_dwThanks a lot, guys! I'll just run it on the backend then. I did see odoyle rules, but I definitely want truth maintenance.#2020-12-2322:34mikerodSeems perhaps odoyle is too different to be true ‚Äúcompetition‚Äù #2020-12-2322:35mikerodOr should there be one rules engine to rule them all? üòõ#2021-01-2516:35apbleonardHi there - we're trying to use Clara in the REPL and having problems.... Specifically a REPL-run test that checks the output of a rule doesn't fail when that rule is redefined with errors, as if it is remembering the old rule. Restarting the REPL solves the problem, but wastes time and resources (memory in IntelliJ at least.) This https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/wiki/Using-Clara-from-the-REPL suggests that a defrule can be re-evaluated in the repl and then clara will use the new version. However looking at the code suggests that rules are set statefully in an atom. It looks also as if that atom might be cleared using (clear-ns-productions!) (https://www.clara-rules.org/apidocs/0.18.0/clojure/clara.rules.html#var-clear-ns-productions.21), - perhaps when this form is evaluated in the namespace in which the rule was defined? But in any case that didn't seem to help for us. Are we missing something obvious? What is the expected way? I could post further codes examples to reproduce etc but wanted to open discussion first. We are using Clara 0.20 üôÇ#2021-01-2516:51mikerod@apbleonard are you using Clara in CLJ or CLJS?#2021-01-2516:51apbleonardCLJ - was just noticing that the stom is cljs ...#2021-01-2516:51apbleonardatom#2021-01-2516:52mikerodYeah, in CLJ it‚Äôs simpler evaluation rules#2021-01-2516:52mikerodwhen you use defrule it makes a var#2021-01-2516:52mikerodand if you are using mk-session to automatically scan a namespace to find rule vars#2021-01-2516:52mikerodthey‚Äôll linger if you remove them in a repl session from the source buffer#2021-01-2516:53mikerodyou can do something like typical clj idioms for removal if that‚Äôs the case, like (ns-unmap *ns* 'rule-name)#2021-01-2516:53mikerodif you redefine the rule with the same name - it‚Äôll overwrite it though#2021-01-2516:54mikerodalso, you do not have to use Clara in a stateful/var oriented way#2021-01-2516:54mikerodyou can pass explicit rule/query structures to mk-session instead if that better suits your usage#2021-01-2516:55mikerodyou can see examples of that such as https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/blob/main/src/test/clojure/clara/test_rules.clj#L171#2021-01-2517:10apbleonardThanks so much for your help. We are clearly not misunderstanding how it should work .... It's still a problem for me .... but now I think the problem maybe our stateful test set up.#2021-01-2517:16mikerodok#2021-01-2517:16mikerodno problem#2021-01-2517:35apbleonardD'oh ... we'd reloaded the namespace containing the defrule, but not the namespace which was def-ing up a set of rules for a particular use-case, that was then passed to fire-rules further in. Simple as that picard-facepalm. Thanks a lot for your help though.#2021-01-2616:52mikerodGood you sorted it out#2021-01-2616:52mikerodI‚Äôve seen this sort of thing happen to#2021-02-1113:05bherrmannI've recently been thinking of playing with rules engines (perhaps I need a hobby?) I recently watched and enjoyed (@sekao is a funny character. ) this presentation on O'Doyle - https://youtu.be/XONRaJJAhpA The talk references Clara a lot. I wondered though does O'Dolyle have the ability to explain why a rule was executed... I'm starting to think about using a rules engine, and the idea of being able to trace why a rule fired seems important. Also did O'Dolye not have retraction? He mentioned you can "replace" a fact.#2021-02-1116:33mikerod@bherrmann I still need to watch that talk on O‚ÄôDoyle. It did sound to me like what it wasn‚Äôt planned to have is a truth maintenance system. This is a key part of Clara‚Äôs feature sets/priority. It allows rules to be written in a way that is less coupled to order of evaluation and instead a more ‚Äúdeclarative logic system‚Äù. Also, there is retraction, but typically external to the rules retraction tends to be the more stable given the truth maintenance system mentioned.#2021-02-1116:33mikerodThere is no concept in clara of fact ‚Äúreplacement/modification‚Äù#2021-02-1116:38bherrmannThanks!#2021-02-1116:33mikerodIn terms of ‚Äútracing why‚Äù something happened#2021-02-1116:42mikerodClara has a few built in facilities to give back various granularity detailed traces of what happened within the rules engine - which can include inserts and retract etc. For a higher-level view though, it often is enough to just write rules in a way that track their ‚Äúsupporting facts‚Äù directly 
(defrule do-thing-with-support
  [?a <- A]
  [?b <- B]
  =>
  (r/insert! (map->C {:value :something
                      :support [?a ?b]})))

(defrule do-other-with-support
  [?c <- C]
  [?d <- D]
  =>
  (r/insert! (map->E {:value :other
                      :support [?c ?d]})))

;;; Later

(defn get-supporting-facts [{:keys [support] :as fact}]
  (into support
        (mapcat get-supporting-facts)
        support))
#2021-02-1116:42mikerodget-suporting-facts could remove duplicates etc as needed#2021-02-1116:42mikerodand you can also just build helpers for these sorts of things to not be so repetitive in rules#2021-02-1116:43mikerodWith truth maintenance, a nice part is if facts becomes invalidated because newer insertions cause formerly fired rules to become false, then they are automatically retracted and the rule network re-establishes consistency across the rules - which would fix these supporting facts as well.#2021-02-2106:17devnWhat @mikerod posted above is basically what we did to deal with capturing the provenance of data and the observability of key facts that led to our decisions.#2021-02-2106:19devnWe called them :contributing-factors, but same idea#2021-02-2119:23mikerodNice#2021-03-0121:18Mario C.Hey guys, I'm getting started with Clara and creating a few examples but something is not clicking. I created some types and created two queries, like this. 
(defrecord Account [total-balance owner])
(defrecord Wallet [type balance])
(defrecord Transaction [type cost])

(defquery get-accounts
  "Query to find the owner's account."
  [:?owner]
  [?account <- Account (= ?owner owner)])

(defquery get-all-accounts
  "Query to return all accounts."
  []
  [?account <- Account])
I inserted some facts like so. 
(def temp-sesh (-> (clara/mk-session 'mac)
                     (clara/insert (->Account 10000 "person")
                                   (->Account 1000 "human"))))
But when I try to run the queries I don't get anything back. Just an empty list. (clara/query temp-sesh get-all-accounts) => () and (clara/query temp-sesh get-accounts :?owner "human") => () What am I doing wrong? Also, when I do (inspect temp-sesh) the :insertions key is an empty map. It's almost as if the facts that I am inserting are immediately discarded. Do I need to have rules in order to insert facts?#2021-03-0121:22ennDoes it make any difference if you call fire-rules?#2021-03-0121:23ethancWithout firing rules, nothing will be processed#2021-03-0121:23Mario C.It does, that worked. But why? There aren't any rules...#2021-03-0121:28ethanci believe that is related to performance, clara doesn‚Äôt operate until a user is ready to operate. In certain scenarios, the operation of inserting a fact could trigger a multitude of processing in the sense of truth maintenance. This could be compounded, if the user later adds more facts thus triggering more work. So at some point, it was decided that nothing would occur until fire-rules was called.#2021-03-0121:29ethancAll of the operations would be ‚Äúpending‚Äù until the point that a user determine that they were ready to run.#2021-03-0121:33Mario C.Okay, got it! Thanks, I was confused and couldn't find any docs mentioning that part#2021-03-0200:35ethancI‚Äôm honestly not sure if any documentation on that reasoning exists, the issue that i was talking about was: https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/268#2021-03-0300:25mikerodDelayed evaluation can be advantageous certainly for performance #2021-03-0300:25mikerod‚ÄúFire rules‚Äù is a poor name in some contexts of course. More of a historic wording #2021-03-0301:34ethancYeah, additionally my previous statements also glossed over: > There aren't any rules Clara doesn't make distinctions between rules and queries in the context of fire rules, they are both productions in the session and are treated in very similar ways.#2021-03-0316:42bherrmannI'm still figuring out "what is a rule engine good for"¬† My specific use case is for a complex ordering system, sort of like a restaurant.¬†¬†Where a customer might order a "veggie burger" and I was thinking that the rule system could be used to build out the list of ingredients¬†and compute their final cost and perhaps caloric impact.¬†¬†¬†And allow for variations, like extra mustard etc...¬†¬† So my thought was the menu and its items would be the initial facts, and then the "orders" facts are mixed in - then the output is several detailed views (or queries)...¬†¬†The bill, the ingredient list, the caloric breakdown.¬†¬† Is this an appropriate hammer for this problem? In particular I like the way you can "audit" the outcome by looking at the detail of which rules fired and why. (For example, to see the extra pepers caused the price to change.)#2021-03-0316:57ennI think a useful heuristic is: would this be hard to model without a rules engine?#2021-03-0316:59ennOften these are problems that would involve lots of tangled nested conditional logic, and where the domain rules have sufficient inter-relatedness that they resist easy breakdown into simple components.#2021-03-0317:01enn(For example, imagine modeling a tax code, where taking a certain deduction might result in adjustments to multiple computed figures, and might also mean that you can‚Äôt simultaneously take another deduction that you would otherwise be eligible for.)#2021-03-0317:02ennIf your ordering system has those kinds of rules, a rules engine might be a good fit.#2021-03-0317:05bherrmannYea, I tend to think of a spreadsheet (although I use those rarely) but I think of the data cells as facts, and as some cells having forumula - rules.#2021-03-0317:05bherrmannI would think you could transform a spreadsheet into facts and rules.#2021-03-0317:31mikerodIt‚Äôs a good question to consider and it is often hard to articulate#2021-03-0317:32mikerodI think rules engines were once were pushed heavily as a way to do business logic without needing developers. I think that perhaps had some success, but I think it is missing a lower level target that is valuable - and still can involve developers#2021-03-0317:32mikerodIt‚Äôs really this issue of how conditional logic can build up over time and become quite tangled. Let‚Äôs keep in mind that Clara puts emphasis on the truth maintenance system sort of approach to rules engines as well.#2021-03-0317:32mikerodSo it allows for a level of decoupling of conditional logic and making it potentially much less order sensitive (ie. declarative)#2021-03-0317:33mikerodIt can also ‚Äúrebalance‚Äù efficiently if new facts come in over time.#2021-03-0317:34mikerodAnd since it‚Äôs a structured way to somewhat declaratively represent this logic, you can fairly easily add automatic ‚Äúauditing‚Äù (why facts were derived) structure over it in various ways. We‚Äôve discussed this before a bit here with ‚Äúsupporting facts‚Äù or ‚Äúcontributing factors‚Äù#2021-03-0317:37mikerodI have somewhat contrived example I used for this blog post (and associated clj/conj talk) years ago. http://www.metasimple.org/2017/02/28/clarifying-rules-engines.html I‚Äôll share it since I at least attempted to make some ‚Äúconditional‚Äù logic become tangled in a more traditional functional data-flow approach with no rules. Then showed how to rethink it via rules instead and examine the difference.#2021-03-0320:14wparkerAgreed with the above. In terms of things many people would be familiar with, enn‚Äôs example of a tax code I think is a good one. There comes a point in the complexity of that kind of logic where expressing it with non-declarative approaches becomes quite challenging and IMO exponentially more difficult as new conditions are added. I informally think of a rules engine as being able to reduce such problems to ‚Äúlinear complexity‚Äù relative to the number of requirements.#2021-03-0321:34mikerod‚ÄúLinear complexity‚Äù. Nice. Good way to think of it. #2021-03-0401:07HeatherHi I have a question. I‚Äôm playing with Clara Rules so that I can understand rules engines better. I have 2 queries that look something like this: 
(defquery query-1?
  "Returns what is set on Record 1"
  []
  [Record1 (= ?foo foo) (= ?bar bar)])

(defquery query-2?
  "Returns what is set on Record 2"
  []
  [Record2 (= ?baz baz) (= ?oof oof)])
And I want to make a query that returns the aggregate of both the queries. Something like this: 
(defquery unified-query?
  "Returns what is set on both Record 1 and Record 2"
  []
  ;; [Record1 (= ?hmm hmm) (= ?huh huh)
  ;; [Record2 (= ?ooh ooh) (= ?aah aah)]]
  )
#2021-03-0401:07HeatherI‚Äôm not sure how to set up that unified query to return both Records. Is that possible? Or do I need a third Record that represents the 2 records together?#2021-03-0401:08HeatherI couldn‚Äôt find examples of aggregating queries in any of the tutorials I saw, which made me wonder if it‚Äôs not something that happens often- it seems like it would be.#2021-03-0401:13ethancWould Record1 and Record2 have anything in common?#2021-03-0401:19ethanc
(r/defquery q1
  []
  [:and
   [Rec1 (= ?hmm hmm) (= ?huh huh)]
   [Rec2 (= ?ooh ooh) (= ?ahh ahh)]])
would be the way to query both records, however since the records don‚Äôt share anything in common you would end up with a cross product, ex. 
(defn test
  []
  (-> (r/mk-session)
      (r/insert (->Rec1 :a 1) (->Rec1 :b 2) (->Rec2 :c 3) (->Rec2 :d 4))
      (r/fire-rules)
      (r/query q1)))
ends up producing: 
({:?hmm :a, :?huh 1, :?ooh :c, :?ahh 3}
 {:?hmm :a, :?huh 1, :?ooh :d, :?ahh 4}
 {:?hmm :b, :?huh 2, :?ooh :c, :?ahh 3}
 {:?hmm :b, :?huh 2, :?ooh :d, :?ahh 4})
#2021-03-0401:30ethancor perhaps the less explicit way: 
(r/defquery q1
  []
  [Rec1 (= ?hmm hmm) (= ?huh huh)]
  [Rec2 (= ?ooh ooh) (= ?ahh ahh)])
they both behave the same way#2021-03-0401:35ethancI can‚Äôt speak for other‚Äôs usage of queries, but in our stack it usually ends up boiling down to a single record type that encompasses several pieces of smaller data.#2021-03-0401:49ethancIt should also be noted, to my knowledge, anything that is possible in the lhs of a rule should also be possible in a query#2021-03-0416:36HeatherYeah, they have nothing in common and I just wanted to squish them together without a cross product. I was getting a cross product, but really wanted to just concat them.#2021-03-0416:44ethanchmm, not sure i am following you there, however perhaps an accumulator or two might be what you are looking for: 
(r/defquery q2
  []
  [?rec-1s <- (acc/all) :from [Rec1]]
  [?rec-2s <- (acc/all) :from [Rec2]])
which nets: 
({:?rec-1s [#test_queries.Rec1{:hmm :a, :huh 1} #test_queries.Rec1{:hmm :b, :huh 2}],
  :?rec-2s [#test_queries.Rec2{:ooh :c, :ahh 3} #test_queries.Rec2{:ooh :d, :ahh 4}]})
note that this doesn‚Äôt have the niceties of the field level binding because of accumulator grouping semantics(and me wanting to avoid that), but instead offers the full records#2021-03-0416:45ethancacc in this context is an alias for clara.rules.accumulators#2021-03-0603:10bherrmannFYI: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zoOXCaZ3M2Y#2021-03-0700:43mikerodLooks like Clara received a mention at least#2021-03-2609:34Pieter SlabbertI think I have found a memory leak in clara when calling mk-session. I have been trying to find a memory leak in one of our services. I eventually found that the leak was from mk-session. This service creates lots of rules dynamically so initially I assumed it was that. I saw the :cache option in mk-session and thought that we were probably caching all those dynamically created rules, however turning off the cache did not help. I eventually created this minimal code to reproduce the leak. With cache false this leaks, with cache true it doesn't, but when adding in dynamically created rules the cache true also leaks, even after calling clear-session-cache! 
(ns mem-leak
  (:require [clara.rules :refer [mk-session defquery]]))
(defquery get-status [:?status] [?result <- :status [{status :status}] (= status ?status)])
(defquery get-all-status [] [?result <- :status])

(doseq [i (range 10000)]
    (mk-session 'mem-leak
                :cache false))
#2021-03-2613:06Linus EricssonGood finding! Have you created an issue in the clara-rules github repo? https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues#2021-03-2613:07Pieter SlabbertI haven't yet, I'm still busy digging into it, going to create the issue soon#2021-03-2613:10ethancIs this is the Clojure side or the clojurescript side? My gut says clojure, but i just wanted to make sure#2021-03-2613:11Pieter Slabbertclojure#2021-03-2613:22ethancAt first blush, my mind goes to the nature of mk-session. Its usage of eval generates classes on the fly, and i have to wonder if those classes are unable to be freed for some reason‚Ä¶. I will have to find time to look into this#2021-03-2613:14Pieter SlabbertI didn't end up finding anything else useful, so I have just created the ticket https://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/468#2021-03-3002:40Daniel CraigHow is the story around Clara and out-of-order processing? Like if I were processing real time events that had a chance of coming out of order, this would be a natural fit for a rules engine right?#2021-03-3002:43ethancTruth maintenance in clara should honor any order of execution. if the rules are satisfied it should not matter the order of the facts#2021-03-3002:49ethancIs a rules engine the correct fit for the use case is a little more of a muddy answer.... and it probably comes down to "it depends". It depends on the use-case you are trying to solve with reasoning about the series of events. If its reasonably sized then a rules engine might be considered overkill, but if you are trying to tie a lot of disparate reasoning together in a logical manner, then a rules engine might be correct.#2021-03-3003:53Daniel CraigWe‚Äôre building a graph database with real time events sourced from multiple systems... it‚Äôs not overkill to consider a rules engine in my opinion#2021-03-3003:59Daniel CraigMaybe I should read up on truth maintenance systems... that‚Äôs basically what we‚Äôve been building, without knowing it#2021-03-3003:59Daniel CraigIf I understand correctly#2021-03-3101:56mikerodVarious discussions of Clara specifically with truth maintenance. http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ http://www.metasimple.org/2017/12/23/clara-updating-facts.html (beginning problem statement ) #2021-03-3103:39Daniel CraigThanks!#2021-04-0818:14PBIs there a way to use :keys[a b c] inside of a list of constraints to avoid doing (`?something (:a this))`#2021-04-0818:15ethanci believe so, let me see if we have doc somewhere#2021-04-0818:16PBThank you!#2021-04-0818:17PBThere appears to be afunction called destructure-syms which looks like what I'm looking for. I just don't know how to do this with the sugar#2021-04-0818:22PB@ethanc even if there isn't documentation, if you just happen to know how to do this, it would be greatly appreciated#2021-04-0818:23ethancThe doc is alluding me, but the usage would be like this if i remember correctly: 
(r/defrule a-rule
  [::some-fact [{:keys [a]}] (= a 12)]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->X "hey")))
#2021-04-0818:24PBThank you!#2021-04-0818:41PBI found an oddity and I can't quite figure out what is wrong here: 
(defrule something
    [:bill [{:keys [direction customer-total]}] (clojure.core/= ?direction direction) (clojure.core/= ?customer-total customer-total)]
    [:direction-looup (clojure.core/= ?outcome (?direction this))]
    =>
    (prn "aaaaacccccbbbbba" ?direction ?customer-total ?outcome))
Works, however: 
(defrule something
    [:bill [{:keys [direction customer-total]}] (clojure.core/= ?direction direction) (clojure.core/= ?customer-total customer-total)]
    [:direction-looup (clojure.core/= ?outcome ?direction)]
    =>
    (prn "aaaaacccccbbbbba" ?direction ?customer-total ?outcome))
Throws the error Malformed variable binding for #{?outcome ?direction}. No associated value. I'm not quite sure why this wouldn't work. Can anyone explain it to me?#2021-04-0819:09ethancThe original rule and the latter differ slightly in the behavior of what is being requested. The first is trying use a prior bound key to get the value out of the direction-lookup fact, where as the latter is simply trying to re-bind the prior bound var with the join. The error doesn‚Äôt seem to be describing itself very well, either that or its an edge-case that clara isn‚Äôt checking and its failing later in the parse of the rule. Either way, clara doesn‚Äôt seem to expect to re-bind vars with joins in this manner.#2021-04-0819:12ethancI have also logged an issue to the http://www.clara-rules.org/ site to add documentation on the nature of destructuring in the LHS: https://github.com/cerner/clara-site/issues/39#2021-04-1217:54Drew VerleeGiven Truth Maintenance is turned on by default in Clara, how would I organize different outcomes for entering a state or leaving it? I assume i'll need to track entering & existing that state and have my rule take that information as a precondition.#2021-04-1219:35ethancIm not sure i can properly visualize your use-case, however typically while skirting Truth Maintenance using something like insert-unconditional! can prevent the fact from being ‚Äútracked/managed‚Äù by truth maintenance.#2021-04-1219:40Drew VerleeThanks @ethanc, I don't have a particular use case üôÇ. I was just looking into how clara worked in respect to some other rules engines.#2021-04-1423:34wparkerIn terms of Clara having truth maintenance by default, note that whether truth maintenance is used determined by whether insert! or insertion-unconditional! is used, either of which the user opts into. Since we generally feel that using truth maintenance is a better starting point, that is what examples in docs etc. tend to use. In terms of logic on entering a state or leaving it, do you mean within a rules session fire-rules call or between calls? In the case of the former, note that the guarantees from Clara concern the final state after fire-rules complete, not intermediate states. It tries to avoid creating states during fire-rules that will need to be retracted before returning for performance reasons, but this is expected behaviour in some cases. So something like (defrule yourrule ‚Ä¶. (state-change-when-activated!)) may not behave as you expect. Otherwise perhaps between fire-rules calls you could run a query and store the result?#2021-04-1515:35mikerodYeah, to expand some on @wparker‚Äôs point: truth maintenance (aks tms) is one of the more emphasized practice in Clara. It‚Äôs optional, but when you abandon it you introduce order-of-evaluation-dependencies within the rules. It can be easy to get in inconsistence states when managing it all unconditionally. Typically, ideally, you‚Äôd be able to run the rules with full truth maintenance as somewhat of a ‚Äúpure fn‚Äù. You‚Äôd then use a query on some derived facts to drive external processes and side effects. To ‚Äúupdate‚Äù the rules after, you could call some external extract on the rulebase and re fire-rules, then rerun the query and do it all again.#2021-04-1515:36mikerodIn this way, you could have the rules be fully consistent with respect to truth maintenance within a single fire-rules (final state result) cycle.#2021-04-2600:46Drew VerleeThanks @mikerod, sorry for the late reply, just saw this. I don't understand the relationship between TM and ordered rules. My novice expectation is that TM means a rule triggers, but doesn't untrigger. Put another way, i'll enter the state, but TM means i'll leave it if the condition is no longer met. Ah, i see. If i don't leave the state, we could consider it an ordering problem if i then transition to another State. I feel like TM is a reasonable default, simply thinking about it has been enlightening. Thanks.#2021-04-2600:59mikerodOk. Yes. It sounds like you have figured out how it relates to order dependence now#2021-05-0721:08HeatherHi, I have a question. I‚Äôm doing some basic exploration/learning of clara and rules engines and I‚Äôm making a small app that tells you what to wear, depending on the weather. For example, I have rules like these: 
(defrule precipitation-more-than-20%-chance
  "keep your head dry"
  [Weather (>= precipitation 20)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Hat :bucket-hat)))

(defrule above-70-wear-a-sun-hat
  "If it's warm, the sun might be in your eyes"
  [Weather (>= temperature 70)]
  =>
  (insert! (->Hat :straw-hat)))
I want hats to be determined by temperature, but allow for a waterproof hat to override any temperature-determined hat, if it‚Äôs going to rain. The only way I can do this right now is if my rules are ordered like they are above, with the precipitation rule first and the temperature rule second, but I know for the engine to be robust, the rules should be able to occur in any order. How would I get the waterproof hat to supersede all other hats? Is there there a better way to handle insert! ? I don‚Äôt want the rules to be order-dependent like they are right now.#2021-05-0721:19Mario C.Perhaps instead of having the precipitation-rule insert a hat fact. Have it insert a "it-will-rain" fact. And then have the hat rules test against that fact#2021-05-0721:20Heatherah interesting. I‚Äôll look into that.#2021-05-0721:24Mario C.There are different ways to achieve it, not sure what the "best" way is#2021-05-0721:24Mario C.You can keep it that flow and have another rule that decides what hat to wear and pulls in all the hat facts#2021-05-0721:24phronmophobiclogically, you want to make decisions based on the properties of hats, rather than just being categorized as a "hat" (what is a hat, really?). some hats provide shade, some don't. some hat's provide rain resistance, some don't. etc.#2021-05-0721:26Mario C.A temperature of 70 could still be a cloudy and rainy day#2021-05-0721:27Mario C.That could have just been a simplified example but just something to keep in mind lol#2021-05-0721:30phronmophobicand there's a difference between finding the "optimal" outfit based on the weather and finding all "acceptable" outfits.#2021-05-0801:14mikerodYou can do 2 other possible things: In the lower priority hat rules do something explicit like [:not [Hat (= ?type :bucket-hat)]]#2021-05-0801:14mikerodIn the :straw-hat rule. #2021-05-0801:14mikerodBut I don‚Äôt like it much. #2021-05-0801:15mikerodBetter likely to state your weather situations and then ‚Äúblock‚Äù summer hat rule based on conditions it isn‚Äôt appropriate for - like it raining. Similar to what was suggested above. #2021-05-0801:17mikerodAnd lastly, not always great but you could insert ‚Äúhat options‚Äù instead in each rule. Then do a final accumulator rule that selects from the options the best choice in priority order. #2021-05-1219:53mathias_dwHi, I ran into some unexpected behavior today. I managed to replicate it in a small example (not sure if it's minimal): 
(defrecord A [n])
(defrecord B [m])
(defrecord C [m n])
(defrule loop-rule
  [B (= ?m m)]
  [C (= ?m m) (= ?n n)]
  [:not [A (= ?n n)]]
  =>
  (println (str "A: " ?n))
  (insert! (->A ?n)))

(-> (mk-session :cache false)
    (insert (->B 1))
    (insert (->C 1 2))
    (insert (->C 1 3))
    (fire-rules))
This results in an infinite loop. So I guess the rule is triggering on each insertion of a new A, always finding the other C to make things fire? I expected the A to be inserted just twice. Note that in my real life use case, the A type is also coming from another source, so that's why I'm checking it. Am I simply not understanding the :not?#2021-05-1219:55ethancI think http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/truthmaint/ might be a good start.#2021-05-1219:56ethancThe rule itself is contradicting itself#2021-05-1219:56mathias_dwAh, yes, now I get it#2021-05-1219:56ethancor perhaps it could be thought of as a self fulfilling prophecy#2021-05-1219:56mathias_dwthanks for the fast reply!#2021-05-1219:57mathias_dwand thanks for clara: I'm building a pretty product and it's been a joy to work with üôÇ#2021-05-1219:58mathias_dw*pretty complex product#2021-05-1220:17ethancThe minimal example of the looping behavior would probably be something like: 
(defrecord A [n])
(clara/defrule not-a
  [:not [A]]
  =>
  (clara/insert! (->A 12)))
Typically to prevent this loop i would use something like a ‚Äúreason‚Äù field on the fact if possible to denote default from other facts. Something like: 
(defrecord A [n reason])

(r/defrule not-a
  [:not [A (not= ::default reason)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->A 12 ::default)))
#2021-05-2617:11Linus EricssonWhen I construct rules, I sometimes make circular references (often by a rule inserting a fact which invalidates itself which triggers a rule that inserts a fact again). Is there any way to tell clara-rules to actually cancel when it has ended up in a cycle like this?#2021-05-2617:12ethancI believe @wparker was working on something like this#2021-05-2617:13ethanchttps://github.com/cerner/clara-rules/issues/275#2021-05-2908:31wparkerYes this feature allow you to detect when Clara is likely in a loop and then define behaviour such as logging something, throwing an exception, etc. Do note that it is fundamentally an error handing construct though, not a way to actually stop the loop while still having a valid outcome of firing the rules (obviously throwing an exception etc. will stop the loop but you won‚Äôt have output from the rules session). @UQY3M3F6D#2021-05-2714:59Mario C.RE: looping If a session (rules/facts) can be thought of/represented as a directed graph. Couldn't you just check for a cycle in the graph during "compile" time? I can see how it could be difficult determining what facts are produced by a firing rule but if you can figure that out, shouldn't you have all the information you need to create a graph and check for a cycle?#2021-05-2715:04ethancAs you have said, determining what facts a rule produces is the main blocker here. As the RHS is arbitrary clojure code, we would have to have some way to determine what a given blob of code would do. The tricky bit being that consumers could have arbitrary functions that insert facts and determining that would be practically impossible.#2021-05-2715:07Mario C.Perhaps if you could "fact-hint" a rule. "This rule produces these fact type(s)" Then it could be possible#2021-05-2715:10ethancAdditionally, its not as straight forward as just scanning the RHS as examples like: https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1620850662084600 where its not technically a loop, as the writer has accounted for loop like behavior#2021-05-2715:21Mario C.Hmm a warning like "possible loop detected" would work but I guess this starts getting convoluted when it may be easier/faster to detect loops as its done now#2021-05-2715:23Mario C.On that note: Is it possible to detect why a rule did not fire?#2021-05-2715:23Mario C.It almost feels like it suffers from the same problem above#2021-05-2715:48ethanc> Is it possible to detect why a rule did not fire? > It almost feels like it suffers from the same problem above yes, it does suffer from a similar issue. From the rules engine side of things its pretty easy to say what facts match certain criteria, but the inverse is significantly more tough, as it generally requires an understanding of the constraints of the rules themselves. Typically for use-cases like this, i believe the common practice is to have a ‚Äútiered‚Äù set of rules to explain what caused a fact not to match. ex: 
(r/defrule expected-rule 
  [?a <- A (> x 12)]
  => 
  (r/insert! (->B ?a)))

(r/defrule missing-fact 
  [:not [B]]
  [?a <- A]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->MissingB ?a "A had a value less than or equal to 12")))
#2021-05-2716:04Mario C.Ahh, I didn't even think about doing something like this facepalm#2021-05-2912:39EsakkiSundar VaratharajanHello Clara Gurus, I'm a newbie and just getting started with Clara Rules and planning to use it with Java. I'm getting an error when trying to run the code.¬†`ExceptionInInitializerError: Syntax error compiling at (example/shopping.clj:2:3). clara.rules.accumulators`¬†I'm attaching the project source for your reference. Could you please help. Please install Maven. Go to your project root directory and to compile the project execute¬†`mvn -q compile`¬†To run the code¬†`mvn -q exec:java -Dexec.mainClass=example.ClaraExampleMain`#2021-05-2913:00Linus Ericssonyou have a syntax error in the import clause, there are ))) on the second row. should be )) (ns example.shopping (:import (example Customer Promotion Order)) (:require [clara.rules.accumulators :as acc] [clara.rules :refer :all])) like so#2021-05-2913:06EsakkiSundar VaratharajanThanks a Lot Linus for your help and support. Highly appreciate your time and effort for spotting this out. It works fine now.#2021-05-3007:12EsakkiSundar VaratharajanI wanted to learn ClaraRules and use with Java. There are not enough tutorials out there in youtube or udemy. Could you please let me where to get started and become familiar with this? Please share your experience how did you get started.#2021-06-0107:23wparkerThere is an example of using Clara from Java at https://github.com/cerner/clara-examples/blob/master/src/main/java/clara/examples/java/ExampleMain.java#2021-06-0107:23wparkerAlso see the docs at http://www.clara-rules.org/docs/java/#2021-06-0107:25wparkerNote that the actual process of writing rules etc. is the same as in Clojure, since they will be in Clojure source files. The Java wrapper basically makes invoking Clojure from Java easier - you could also do this yourself in any domain-specific way that makes sense. That said, IMO the subset of Clojure you need to understand to write basic rules is relatively small.#2021-06-0117:43EsakkiSundar VaratharajanThanks wparker. I have few questions and hope you can clarify my doubts. 1) Do I need to get solid understanding on Clojure to write Clara rules? 2) What is your recommendation for people who are not familiar with Clojure. Is there a way to generate Clara rules from a excel based sheet or provide the Excel sheet as input to Clara. As an example, in Drools it has support to define the rules defined in an excel and pass to the engine. 3) Also could you please explain more on "you could also do this yourself in any domain-specific way that makes sense"#2021-06-0403:14mikerod1) I think you‚Äôd need to know some basic clj to write rules typically. Not necessarily too advanced though. 2) no spreadsheet features built in 3) making your own DSL would likely require more clj - but see http://www.toomuchcode.org/blog/2015/11/14/insta-declarative-dsls/ for the concept#2021-06-0518:05paulocuneoHi everyone! Newbie here, I want to use clara with clojure/script in the browser, but I'm having a hard time making it work with figwheel and reagent. I was expecting the following code to run println in the rules, but it doesn't seem to work 
(ns ^:figwheel-hooks fallas1.nurse
  (:require [goog.dom :as gdom]
            [reagent.core :as reagent :refer [atom]]
            [reagent.dom :as rdom]
            [clara.rules
             :refer [insert fire-rules]
             :refer-macros [defsession defrule]]))

(defsession session 'clara.example)

(defrecord SupportRequest [client level])
(defrecord ClientRepresentative [name client])

(defrule is-important
  "Find important support requests."
  [SupportRequest (= :high level)]
  =>
  (println "High support requested!"))

(defrule notify-client-rep
  "Find the client representative and request support."
  [SupportRequest (= ?client client)]
  [ClientRepresentative (= ?client client) (= ?name name)]
  =>
  (println "Notify" ?name "that"
           ?client "has a new support request!"))

(defonce app-state
  (atom {:session (-> session
                      (insert (->ClientRepresentative "Alice" "Acme")
                              (->SupportRequest "Acme" :high))
                      (fire-rules))}))

(defn main []
  [:div
   [:h1 (str (:session @app-state))]])

(defn mount [el]
  (rdom/render [main] el))

(defn get-app-element []
  (gdom/getElement "app"))

(defn mount-app-element []
  (when-let [el (get-app-element)]
    (mount el)))

(mount-app-element)

(defn ^:after-load on-reload []
  (mount-app-element))
#2021-06-0521:54mikerod@paulocuneo it‚Äôs not clear you have println hooked up to js console. So to eliminate that variable try it with js/console.log instead of println first. #2021-06-0521:54mikerodBut it is also happening during the defonce init so may also be an odd time to see the output. I still think you should be able to get it to print in the js console though #2021-06-0522:06paulocuneo@mikerod Thank you very much! üôè I changed it a bit, based on your advise and got it to work. 
(ns ^:figwheel-hooks fallas1.nurse
  (:require [goog.dom :as gdom]
            [reagent.core :as reagent :refer [atom]]
            [reagent.dom :as rdom]
            [clara.rules
             :refer [insert fire-rules]
             :refer-macros [defsession defrule]]))

(defrecord SupportRequest [client level])
(defrecord ClientRepresentative [name client])

(defrule is-important
  "Find important support requests."
  [SupportRequest (= :high level)]
  =>
  (js/console.log "High support requested!"))

(defrule notify-client-rep
  "Find the client representative and request support."
  [SupportRequest (= ?client client)]
  [ClientRepresentative (= ?client client) (= ?name name)]
  =>
  (js/console.log "Notify" ?name "that"
                  ?client "has a new support request!"))

(defsession session 'fallas1.nurse)

(defonce app-state
  (atom 0))

(defn run-rules [_]
  (-> session
      (insert (->ClientRepresentative "Alice" "Acme")
              (->SupportRequest "Acme" :high))
      (fire-rules))
  (swap! app-state  inc))

(defn main []
  [:div
   [:div "Rounds:" @app-state]
   [:button
    {:on-click run-rules}
    "run"]])

(defn mount [el]
  (rdom/render [main] el))

(defn get-app-element []
  (gdom/getElement "app"))

(defn mount-app-element []
  (when-let [el (get-app-element)]
    (mount el)))

(mount-app-element)

(defn ^:after-load on-reload []
  (mount-app-element))
#2021-06-0522:06mikerodNice#2021-06-0522:07mikerodYeah above makes more sense to me now in terms of making sure evaluation happens at a normal sort of time #2021-06-0522:07mikerodBut also you can get println to work to in cljs. But you‚Äôd have to enable console print earlier than the rest of this ns #2021-06-0522:07mikerodhttp://clojurescriptmadeeasy.com/blog/easy-console-printing.html#2021-06-0522:10paulocuneoYeah, I've disabled println by mistake :face_palm: üòÖ#2021-06-0915:24Mario C.If you are not going to use bindings in the LHS and only use them in the RHS; Is it okay to just bind the whole fact and then pluck what you need from that fact binding on the RHS. Or is the better approach to just bind everything that you need in LHS to be used in the RHS? Is it a matter of style only or are there trade offs Im not aware of? I lean on the former since it makes the rule's LHS more "digest-able" instead of seeing 10 lines of bindings that dont really do much in terms constraints/conditions#2021-06-0915:38mikerod@mario.cordova.862 As long as you are only using the binding on the RHS and you are not using an accumulator - I think there isn‚Äôt a lot of functional difference in terms of the engine operation.#2021-06-0915:38mikerodIf you are using an accumulator, you have to be aware of the ‚Äúunusued‚Äù bindings actually forms ‚Äúpartitions‚Äù#2021-06-0915:39mikerod
[?all <- (acc/all) :from [X (= ?x x)]]
#2021-06-0915:39mikerodthat‚Äôd actually ‚Äúpartition‚Äù the accumulations by their x values#2021-06-0915:39mikerodSo it looks ‚Äúunused‚Äù perhaps, but really it semantically matters.#2021-06-0915:40mikerodIf you ignore that - perhaps not related to your particular usage you have in mind: I‚Äôd still favor being more explicit in the LHS because the LHS is in general more structured. It has more ability to be parsed/analyzed by tooling. Everything you do in the RHS is basically just free-form clj forms.#2021-06-0915:41mikerodSo my default preference is to express as much as possible to as much granularity as possible in the LHS and minimize the amount the RHS does#2021-06-0916:06Mario C.Is that assuming that ?x was already binded with some other fact? Or if that was all there was to the LHS?#2021-06-0916:07ethancMight also be worth noting that using bound fields could also be more performant in certain scenarios, ex. 
(defrule some-rule 
  [?x <- X]
  [?y <- Y (= y-field (:x-field ?x))]
  =>
  (<RHS things>))
vs 
(defrule some-rule 
  [X (= ?x-field x-field)]
  [?y <- Y (= y-field ?x-field)]
  =>
  (<RHS things>))
Probably not a super huge deal for small rules networks, but the latter would likely produce a HashJoin node rather than an ExpressionJoinNode. ExpressionJoinNodes, in my experience, have a bit more overhead (minuscule) due to additional function evaluations and invocations.#2021-06-0916:09Mario C.
(defrule my-rule
  [:x/y :from [{:keys [a b c d e f g h i j]}] (= a ?a) . . . (= j ?j)]
  =>
  (insert! {:data {:my-a ?a ... :my-j ?j}}))
#2021-06-0916:10Mario C.This is what I had in mind#2021-06-0916:10Mario C.vs 
(def my-rule 
  [?xy <- :from [:x/y] ...)
#2021-06-0916:11Mario C.(ignore syntax errors)#2021-06-0916:14ethancAs Mike mentioned the top rule will perform a partitioning action, with potentially different behavior. If the number of fields being bound is equivalent to the number of fields of the fact, then simply binding the entire fact probably makes just as much sense.#2021-06-0916:20Mario C.hmm very interesting, I did not know that. Thanks for the input @ethanc @mikerod. Will need to do some exploring then#2021-06-0916:47Mario C.
(defrule binded-rule
  [:foo/bar [{:keys [id first-name last-name]}]
   (= id ?id)
   (= first-name ?first-name)
   (= last-name ?last-name)]
  =>
  (println "fire bind")
  (insert! {:fact/type  :binded/person
           :id         ?id
           :first-name ?first-name
            :last-name  ?last-name}))

(defrule unbinded-rule
  [?person <- :foo/bar]
  =>
  (println "Fired unbind")
  (insert! {:fact/type  :unbinded/person
            :id         (:id ?person)
            :first-name (:first-name ?person)
            :last-name  (:last-name ?person)}))

(defrule binded-acc-rule
  [?persons <- (acc/all) :from [:foo/bar [{:keys [id]}] (= id ?id)]]
  =>
  (println "BINDED ACC:")
  (println ?persons)
  (insert! {:fact/type  :binded/acc
            :some :foo}))

(defrule unbinded-acc-rule
  [?persons <- (acc/all) :from [:foo/bar]]
  =>
  (println "UNBINDED ACC:")
  (println ?persons)
  (insert! {:fact/type  :unbinded/acc
            :some :bar}))
The first two didn't really see any difference aside from the binded rule having constraints. But the last two def had difference. The binded-acc-rule fired 3 times for each 3 facts and the unbinded just fired once, accumulating all 3 facts. I understand now what you meant by partition#2021-06-0917:08mikerod@mario.cordova.862 yes the accumulator cases is waht I was mentioning#2021-06-0917:09mikerodAccumulators (necessarily) have to be ‚Äúpartitioned‚Äù by the binding#2021-06-0917:09mikerodTo understand why, consider this 
[?persons <- (acc/all) :from [:foo/bar [{:keys [id]}] (= id ?id)]]
=>
(println [?id ?persons])
#2021-06-0917:09mikerodNotice how if you were referring to the ?id binding itself - it would need to have a single-stable value for that accumulation of facts?#2021-06-0917:10mikerodSo (acc/all) must only work across ‚Äúequal join binding partitions‚Äù#2021-06-0917:10mikerodThe same goes for any accumulator#2021-06-0917:12mikerodAlso, as Ethan said https://clojurians.slack.com/archives/C08TC9JCS/p1623255042062600 and I just left out since you said ‚Äúunused LHS bindings‚Äù - I‚Äôd certainly favor direct field bindings in join cases due to the rules engine taking advantage of that visibility into the lower-level of granularity#2021-06-0917:12mikerodI can understand how 
(defrule my-rule
  [:x/y :from [{:keys [a b c d e f g h i j]}] (= a ?a) . . . (= j ?j)]
  =>
  (insert! {:data {:my-a ?a ... :my-j ?j}}))
may be a bit tedious though#2021-06-0917:13mikerodYou could consider perhaps wrapping some sort of helper over it#2021-06-0917:13mikerodOr just bind to the whole fact, but know there are these certain caveats and also the thing I said about expressing as much as possible in LHS#2021-06-0917:19Mario C.Yea when I mentioned the problem I wasn't referring to accumulators but learning this bit actually made me "read" the rules differently now. Always had trouble wrapping my head around having a binding in an accumulator. "If its accumulated which id is the ?id tied to??" but now I see that it fires once for each#2021-06-1020:23Joshua SuskaloI'm just trying out clara rules for the first time, and I am trying to express the following idea: I have a bunch of facts. Based on some condition from the facts I want to insert a fact "DataRequest", but only if one doesn't already exist The way I'm testing this right now is like so: 
(defrecord Field [name value])
(defrecord DataRequest [data-partner])

(defrule enrich-fields
  [Field (= ?name name)]
  [:not [DataRequest (= data-partner ?name)]]
  =>
  (r/insert! (->DataRequest ?name)))
The problem is that when I do this, it goes into an infinite loop, which I had thought this [:not section would prevent. Am I missing something obvious?#2021-06-1020:43Joshua SuskaloI see now the problem here is that the rule invalidates itself, causing truth maintenance to trigger, and re-evaluating the rule immediately.#2021-06-1021:43Joshua SuskaloI have an additional question: Is there a way to migrate sessions from an old rulebase to a new one? I understand this causes serious problems if there's substantial change in the rules, but if for example there is only accretion of new rules and old rules are not changed, is there a way to do this while keeping truth support? As I was thinking about this what I'd wanted to do was to query all the facts in the working memory and insert them into a new session, but this loses truth support, seemingly because clara uses identity to track records rather than clojure equality.#2021-06-1110:52wparkerClara doesn‚Äôt support adding rules to an existing session at present. However Clara is meant to use equality to track facts. There are performance optimisations around when things are identical in places, but if this is actually changing behaviour then that would be a bug.#2021-06-1113:36Joshua SuskaloThe reason that I say things are tracked by identity and not equality is that if I insert two facts into a working memory, one which would be equal to a fact generated by a rule that operates on the other, then I get two copies of that fact.#2021-06-1113:37Joshua SuskaloRather than the rule realizing that the action has already occurred because the derived fact is already in the working memory.#2021-06-1620:38wparkerThis happens because Clara allows multiple equal facts to exist in the session, and tracks the number of them inserted. So after something like (-> session (insert a) (insert a) fire-rules (retract a) you‚Äôd still have on ‚Äúa‚Äù in the session.#2021-06-1620:39wparkerThe same applies for facts created as a result of rules firing.#2021-06-1620:40wparkerIf this isn‚Äôt desirable in your use-case the distinct accumulator can be used.#2021-08-2700:48colinkahnI've used Clara rules a bit but am planning on doing something more complicated with it and had a question. It seems like when you start working on defining your rules you have to decide on a sort of scope for your session. I was curious if sessions have any way of composing? Let's say I decide I want to handle some subset of rules in its own session and then apply that to many of some type in a parent session. Is that possible?#2021-08-2700:55ethancI don't think that Clara has anything like that. I would assume that one could fire the sub session, then extract data via queries to populate facts within the parent session. Though I would think that simply having a single session would be less complex#2021-08-2700:57colinkahnIs there any general wisdom about what a session should operate on? Like let's say I had some domain for accounts, should my session be for a single account vs all accounts, which I imagine could get confusing because you're dealing with many things vs one?#2021-08-2701:05ethancIn general, It would come down to the scope of what you are reasoning about. If all of the questions you are trying to answer, if all of them are bounded by a single account, then it would probably make sense to operate on a single rather than multi.#2021-08-2701:07ethancIt would likely reduce the complexity of the rules, as they could implicitly assume that the facts pertain to a single accout#2021-08-2701:07ethanc*account#2021-08-2701:08colinkahnI think in my case it's most likely the scope will be both the single and the many, at least for some parts. Which is why I was worried starting at one level would require lots of rework later to adjust the scope.#2021-08-2701:13ethancGoing from multi to single, in theory, should be passive. Though single to multi would require rework as the implicit assumptions based on a single account would be broken#2021-08-2701:16colinkahnRight, without the ability to compose sessions, starting at many is probably the way to go to avoid rework.#2021-08-2701:17colinkahnThanks for discussing!#2021-08-2701:18ethancGlad to lend an ear, and hear about people using Clara#2021-08-2716:13mikerodYeah, I agree with Ethan overall#2021-08-2716:13mikerodIf your cases now were single account - you could go about it that way and expose queries to data from that session later that you could use for ‚Äúmulti account reasoning‚Äù#2021-08-2716:13mikerodbut it really depends on the case which would be more efficient or make more sense.#2021-08-2718:37colinkahn@mikerod I‚Äôll give that a shot too. I think the way I‚Äôll be analyzing the data it could work, IE multiple passes through different sessions.#2021-08-3105:15ishodgei was trying to evaluate the following query from the query documentation:

  [?promotion <- Promotion (= ?type type)])
